item.title: GCS
item.description:
EYES for the eye test
VOICE for the verbal test
OLD BEN for the motor test


Mild TBI (13-15): Possible concussion, brief loss of consciousness, confusion, or headache.
Moderate TBI (9-12): More significant injury with possible prolonged confusion and neurological deficits.
Severe TBI (≤8): High risk of mortality or long-term disability; often requires intubation and intensive care.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: NIH Stroke Scale
item.description:
0 = No stroke symptoms
1–4 = Minor stroke
5–15 = Moderate stroke
16–20 = Moderate to severe
21–42 = Severe stroke


1a. LOC (Level of Consciousness)
0 = Alert
1 = Not alert, but arousable
2 = Requires repeated stimulation
3 = Unresponsive
1b. LOC Questions (Month & Age)
0 = Both correct
1 = One correct
2 = Neither correct
1c. LOC Commands (Open eyes, grip hand)
0 = Both correct
1 = One correct
2 = Neither correct
2. Best Gaze (Horizontal eye movement)
0 = Normal
1 = Partial gaze palsy
2 = Forced deviation or no movement
3. Visual Fields (Confrontation test)
0 = No loss
1 = Partial hemianopia
2 = Complete hemianopia
3 = Bilateral blindness
4. Facial Palsy
0 = Normal
1 = Minor paralysis
2 = Partial (lower face only)
3 = Complete (one or both sides)
5. Motor Arm (L & R – 10 sec hold)
0 = No drift
1 = Drift, doesn’t hit bed
2 = Some effort, can't hold up
3 = No effort against gravity
4 = No movement
UN = Amputation or joint fusion
6. Motor Leg (L & R – 5 sec hold)
0 = No drift
1 = Drift, doesn't hit bed
2 = Some effort, can't hold up
3 = No effort against gravity
4 = No movement
UN = Amputation or joint fusion
7. Limb Ataxia
0 = Absent
1 = Present in 1 limb
2 = Present in 2 limbs
UN = Paralysis prevents test
8. Sensory
0 = Normal
1 = Mild to moderate loss
2 = Severe or total loss
9. Best Language (Naming, repetition, picture description)
0 = No aphasia
1 = Mild to moderate aphasia
2 = Severe aphasia
3 = Mute or global aphasia
10. Dysarthria
0 = Normal
1 = Mild to moderate slurring
2 = Unintelligible or mute
UN = Intubated or physical barrier
11. Extinction & Inattention (Neglect)
0 = No neglect
1 = Mild neglect
2 = Severe neglect


1a. Level of Consciousness (LOC Responsiveness)

How: Observe patient when you walk in. If needed, call name, tap, or use painful stimulus (sternal rub).
Look For: Spontaneous activity, alertness, arousability.
1b. LOC Questions

Say: “What month is it?” “How old are you?”
Score: 1 point for each incorrect or no answer.
1c. LOC Commands

Say: “Open and close your eyes.” Then “Grip and release my hand.”
Look For: Correct performance of both tasks.

2. Best Gaze

How: Ask them to follow your finger horizontally (not vertical).
Look For: Symmetric movement of both eyes; forced deviation or inability to track.

3. Visual Fields

How: Cover one eye at a time. Wiggle fingers in upper/lower quadrants.
Ask: “How many fingers do you see?” or “Point to the side where you see movement.”
Look For: Field cuts or blindness.

4. Facial Palsy

Say: “Show me your teeth.” “Close your eyes tight.” “Raise your eyebrows.”
Look For: Symmetry, droop, weakness.

5. Motor Arm (Left & Right)

How: Hold arm up 90° (sitting) or 45° (lying).
Say: “Keep your arm up — don’t let it drift.”
Watch: For 10 seconds.
Look For: Drift, falling, or no movement.

6. Motor Leg (Left & Right)

How: Hold leg up 30° while lying down.
Say: “Keep your leg up — don’t let it fall.”
Watch: For 5 seconds.
Look For: Drift, effort, or no movement

7. Limb Ataxia

How: Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin tests (eyes open).
Look For: Overshooting, jerky or uncoordinated movement.
Note: Score only if weakness isn’t the cause.

8. Sensory

How: Lightly touch arms/legs with your fingers or a pin.
Ask: “Does this feel the same on both sides?”
Look For: Numbness, decreased feeling, no response.

9. Best Language

How: Show picture cards, name objects, repeat phrases, describe a scene.
Look For: Word-finding difficulty, gibberish, comprehension issues.

10. Dysarthria

How: Ask patient to say “The sky is blue in Cincinnati” or repeat words.
Look For: Slurred or garbled speech (not aphasia).
Note: Use writing or gestures if intubated.

11. Extinction & Inattention (Neglect)

How: Do double simultaneous touch or ask them to describe picture details.
Ask: “Do you feel me touching both sides?” or “What do you see in this picture?”
Look For: Ignoring one side, inattention, denial of weakness.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Phsyical Ass
item.description:
#physical #assessment #headtotoe #nursing #foundations
#physical #assessment #headtotoe #nursing #foundations

Rinne - placed on ear; normal: AC>BC, "rinne under the pine (pineal)"
Webber - placed on head: BC>AC
Lordosis - lumbar (L for L)
Kyphosis - thoracic

Stereognosis is the ability to identify the shape and form of a three-dimensional object and, therefore, its identity with tactile manipulation of that object in the absence of visual and auditory stimuli.**
Gustation: A chemical sense that responds to molecules in food. 
Proprioception: The sense of body position, weight, and resistance in relation to the body. It's also known as kinesthetic sense. 
Kinesthesia: The sense of movement and speed of the body. It's also known as motion sense.


Grade 1+ (Mild):
Depth: Slight indentation (2 mm or less).
Rebound: Indentation disappears quickly (less than 5 seconds).
Grade 2+ (Moderate):
Depth: Moderate indentation (3-4 mm)
Rebound: Indentation lasts for 10-15 seconds.
Grade 3+ (Severe):
Depth: Deep indentation (5-6 mm).
Rebound: Indentation remains for 1-2 minutes.
Grade 4+ (Very Severe):
Depth: Very deep indentation (greater than 6 mm)
Rebound: Indentation persists for more than 2 minutes.


Olfactory (I): Sensory - Smell.
Optic (II): Sensory - Vision.
Oculomotor (III): Motor - Eye movement, pupil constriction.
Trochlear (IV): Motor - Eye movement (superior oblique).
Trigeminal (V): Both - Facial sensation; mastication.
Abducens (VI): Motor - Lateral eye movement.
Facial (VII): Both - Taste; facial expressions.
Vestibulocochlear (VIII): Sensory - Hearing, balance.
Glossopharyngeal (IX): Both - "ah," and assess swallowing and voice quality
Vagus (X): Both - Visceral sensation; parasympathetic control.
Accessory (XI): Motor - Head, shoulder movement.
Hypoglossal (XII): Motor - Tongue movement.
Stethoscope:

Diaphragm = high pitch sounds; lung sounds and bowel sounds
Bell = low pitched sounds (smaller); heart sounds and murmurs.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Aspiration Risk
item.description:
Assessment: Evaluate swallowing ability using bedside swallow screening, noting coughing, drooling, or difficulty managing secretions.
Diet Modification: Implement NPO status if aspiration risk is high, then progress to appropriate texture-modified diets (e.g., pureed, mechanical soft) and thickened liquids as ordered.
no thin liquids
Positioning: Keep the patient upright at 90° during meals and for 30-60 minutes after eating to reduce aspiration risk.
Swallowing Techniques: Encourage chin tuck, small bites, slow chewing, and alternate solids with liquids to aid swallowing.
Aspiration Precautions: Monitor for coughing, wet voice, increased secretions, or respiratory distress, and implement suctioning if needed.
Oral Care: Provide frequent oral hygiene to reduce bacterial aspiration pneumonia risk.
Collaboration: Work with speech-language pathology (SLP) for swallowing therapy and further evaluation.
Enteral Nutrition Consideration: If oral intake is unsafe, initiate NG or PEG tube feeding per provider order.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Neutropenic Precautions
item.description:
Infection prevention measures for patients with low neutrophil counts (neutropenia)
Neutropenia: Absolute Neutrophil Count (ANC) <1,500 cells/mm³, with severe neutropenia at <500 cells/mm³
Common in chemotherapy patients, bone marrow transplant recipients, and immunocompromised individuals
WBC Reference Ranges: 4,000–11,000 cells/µL


Cancer treatments (chemotherapy, radiation)
Bone marrow suppression (leukemia, lymphoma, aplastic anemia)
Autoimmune disorders (Lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Severe infections (HIV-AIDS, sepsis)
Certain medications (immunosuppressants, corticosteroids)
Congenital neutropenia (rare genetic conditions)


Prolonged hospitalization (increased exposure to infections)
Invasive procedures (IV lines, catheters, surgeries)
Poor nutrition (malnutrition weakens the immune system)
Age (older adults and infants have weaker immune responses)
Chronic illnesses (diabetes, kidney disease)


Hand hygiene: Frequent and proper handwashing for patients, visitors, and staff
Protective isolation: Private room with HEPA filtration if severe neutropenia
No fresh flowers, plants, or standing water (reduce exposure to mold and bacteria)
No raw or undercooked foods (risk of bacterial contamination)
Limit visitors: Avoid sick individuals, ensure visitors follow hygiene protocols
Strict aseptic technique for IV lines, catheters, and dressings
Daily assessment for infection signs (fever, chills, redness, swelling)
Avoid invasive procedures if possible (IM injections, rectal exams, urinary catheters)
Encourage good oral hygiene (soft toothbrush, avoid flossing if thrombocytopenic)


Sepsis (life-threatening infection)
Pneumonia
Opportunistic infections (fungal, viral, bacterial)
Mucositis (oral ulcers, GI inflammation)


Complete Blood Count (CBC) with differential (low neutrophil count)
Blood cultures, urine cultures (to detect infections)
Chest X-ray (to check for pneumonia)


Broad-spectrum antibiotics (immediately for fever)
Colony-stimulating factors (filgrastim, pegfilgrastim) to stimulate neutrophil production
Antifungal or antiviral medications (if infection suspected)
IV fluids and supportive care


Monitor temperature closely (report fever ≥100.4°F (38°C) immediately)
Assess for infection symptoms (may be subtle in neutropenic patients)
Educate patients on infection prevention at home (avoid crowds, wear a mask, maintain hygiene)
Encourage adequate hydration and nutrition
Monitor CBC results to track neutrophil recovery


Risk for infection related to neutropenia
Impaired oral mucous membrane related to chemotherapy-induced mucositis
Risk for imbalanced nutrition due to dietary restrictions and mucosal damage
Fear/anxiety related to risk of infection and isolation

item.title: Fishbones
item.description:
Na | Cl | BUN ---|----|---- K | CO2 | Cr Glu
Nuckle BUNS - COCO crunch!

Na (Sodium): 135-145 mEq/L
Cl (Chloride): 96-106 mEq/L
BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen): 7-20 mg/dL
K (Potassium): 3.5-5.0 mEq/L
CO2 (Bicarbonate): 22-29 mEq/L
Cr (Creatinine): 0.6-1.2 mg/dL
Glu (Glucose): 70-100 mg/dL (fasting)

WBC Hgb | Hct Plt

WBC (White Blood Cells): 4,500-11,000 cells/µL
Hgb (Hemoglobin): 13.5-17.5 g/dL (male), 12-15.5 g/dL (female)
Hct (Hematocrit): 38-50% (male), 34-44% (female)
Plt (Platelets): 150,000-450,000 cells/µL
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: GFR
item.description:
GFR measures how well the kidneys are filtering blood, specifically the volume of blood that passes through the glomeruli (kidney's filtering units) per minute.
Normal GFR for a healthy adult is typically around 90–120 mL/min/1.73m², and it can vary based on age, gender, and body size.
A decrease in GFR indicates impaired kidney function, which is crucial in diagnosing and staging Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD).

Just note that normal GFR is ≥ 90

Guiding Treatment Decisions: Changes in GFR guide adjustments in medication (e.g., dosages of renally cleared drugs) and lifestyle modifications.
Monitoring Complications: Low GFR can lead to complications like fluid retention, electrolyte imbalances, and uremia, all of which require close monitoring and management.
Preventing Progression: Nurses use GFR to track kidney function over time and assess the effectiveness of interventions (e.g., blood pressure control, blood sugar management) in preventing further damage.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Lactate Levels
item.description:
What is it: Byproduct of anaerobic metabolism produced when oxygen delivery to tissues is insufficient; elevated levels indicate hypoxia or impaired cellular respiration.
Normal Range: 0.5 - 2.2 mmol/L (may vary slightly by lab).
Out of Normal:
Mild Elevation (2.2 - 4 mmol/L): Possible early tissue hypoxia, sepsis, or shock.
Severe Elevation (>4 mmol/L): Suggests significant hypoxia, sepsis, organ dysfunction, or metabolic crisis; often linked to poor prognosis.

item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: PCT
item.description:
What is it: A precursor of calcitonin released in response to bacterial infections; useful for detecting systemic inflammation and sepsis.
Normal Range: <0.1 ng/mL (may vary slightly by lab).
Out of Normal:
0.1 - 0.5 ng/mL: Possible mild infection or inflammation.
0.5 - 2 ng/mL: Suggestive of localized infection; increased risk of sepsis.
>2 ng/mL: Strongly indicates systemic bacterial infection or sepsis; higher levels correlate with severe infection and poor prognosis.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: General Nursing
item.description:
#foundations #nursing
#foundations #nursing


Enema: left side, insert 3-4 inches (2-3 for peds), raise 12-18 inches above anus, lubricate 2 inches
Physiotherapy for lower lobe atelectasis: place client in Trendelenburg
IM Injection site:
Eyedrops: administration: administer on conjunctival sac (not directly on eye)
Tracheostomy care at HOME for caregivers
clean technique is okay
Tracheostomy care
hydrogen peroxide for cleaning inner canula, pipe cleaners or brush to remove crusties
do not use on SKIN (must be diluted if used on skin)
no cotton balls
80-120mmHg suction pressure for adults, 50-100mmHg peds
Catheter: Male Indwelling
secure on upper thigh or lower abdomen with tape/securement device
Collecting culture from wounds
irrigate with NS prior to collecting
rotate swab back and forth at base of wound to collect pathogens (NOT EDGES of wound)
Enema Types

Cleansing enema - removes feces stimulates peristalsis treats constipation or pre-procedure bowel prep.
Retention enema - retains solution for prolonged periods for medication absorption or softening stool.
Oil retention enema - softens stool lubricates rectum for easier defecation.
Medicated enema - delivers drugs for local or systemic effects such as antibiotics or steroids.
Carminative enema - relieves gas by stimulating peristalsis and expelling flatus.
Return-flow enema - relieves gas by repeated instillation and removal of fluid to stimulate peristalsis.
Hypertonic enema - draws water into the colon by osmosis for rapid evacuation.
Isotonic enema - saline solution mimics body fluids to soften stool and stimulate evacuation.
Soap suds enema - irritates mucosa and stimulates peristalsis using soapy water.


Braden Scale: parameters are nutrition, sensory perception, moisture, activity, mobility, friction and shear
NG Tube Feeding - flush with 30 mL after feeding
Wound Care
Hydrocolloid - best for wounds with minimal/moderate drainage, stage 2 pressure injury
Alginate - for heavy exudate, nonadherent dressings that conform to the wound’s shape and absorb exudate
TPN (nutrition thru IV) - check blood glucose q4, change tubing q24, D10/D20 if nutrition unavailable, check weight daily
Oxygen At Home: do not wear cotton to limit buildup of static (ATI book says cotton is encouraged)
Vest Restraint: tie with quick release knot, allow TWO fingerbreadths between restraints and body, apply restraints over clothing
Purpose of log rolling: protect the spine

Contact precautions: Think "MRS. WEE" - chatgpt came up with this. just double check if its accurate.
M = Multidrug-resistant organisms (e.g., MRSA, VRE)
R = Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)
S = Skin infections (e.g., scabies, impetigo)
W = Wound infections
E = Enteric infections (e.g., C. difficile)
E = Eye infections (e.g., conjunctivitis)
Droplet precautions: "SPIDERMAN"
S = Streptococcal pharyngitis
P = Pertussis
I = Influenza
D = Diphtheria (pharyngeal)
E = Epiglottitis
R = Rubella
M = Mumps
A = Adenovirus
N = Neisseria meningitidis
Airborne precautions: "MTV" - this is accurate. if you can only remember one thing, its the airborne
M = Measles
T = Tuberculosis
V = Varicella (chickenpox, shingles)


1 mg = 1,000 mcg
1 g = 1,000 mg
1 kg = 1,000 g
1 oz = 30 mL
1 L = 1,000 mL
1 tsp = 5 mL
1 tbsp = 15 mL
1 tbsp = 3 tsp
1 kg = 2.2 lb
1 gr = 60 mg (grain)
Volume for Medications:

1 tablespoon (tbsp) = 3 teaspoons (tsp)
1 ounce (oz) = 30 milliliters (mL)
1 pint (pt) = 16 fluid ounces (fl oz) = 480 mL
1 quart (qt) = 2 pints = 960 mL
1 gallon = 4 quarts = 3.785 liters
1 gallon = 8 pints
Fluid Ounces and Milliliters:
1 fluid ounce (fl oz) = 29.5735 mL
Erikson's Developmental Stages

Trust vs. Mistrust: Infancy (0-1 year) - Developing trust when caregivers provide reliability, care, and affection; lack leads to mistrust.
Autonomy vs. Shame and Doubt: Early Childhood (1-3 years) - Building autonomy by making choices and gaining control; over-criticism can result in shame and doubt.
Initiative vs. Guilt: Preschool (3-6 years) - Encouraging initiative and decision-making; overcontrol can lead to guilt.
Industry vs. Inferiority: School Age (6-12 years) - Developing competence through learning and achievement; failure results in feelings of inferiority.
Identity vs. Role Confusion: Adolescence (12-18 years) - Forming a strong sense of self and personal identity; failure leads to confusion about one’s role in life.
Intimacy vs. Isolation: Young Adulthood (18-40 years) - Establishing meaningful, intimate relationships; failure can lead to isolation and loneliness.
Generativity vs. Stagnation: Middle Adulthood (40-65 years) - Contributing to society and supporting the next generation; lack of this results in stagnation.
Integrity vs. Despair: Late Adulthood (65+ years) - Reflecting on life with a sense of fulfillment and acceptance; failure leads to regret and despair.
1 lb of body = 3500 calories (having calorie excess of 500cal/day would mean 10 lbs gain within 10 weeks)
Iatrogenic HAI - caused from diagnostic or therapeutic procedures
Glaucoma - optic nerve damage caused by pressure (IOP, intraocular pressure). Pressure is caused by obstructed flow of vitreous humor.
Patient Movement

transferring patient from bed to wheel chair: place wheelchair 45 degree angle to bed, stand on client weaker side

item.title: Health Promotion
item.description:
#healthpromotion #nursing #foundations
#healthpromotion #nursing #foundations
Vaccines Schedules for Peds and Adults
Here is the CDC's 2024 vaccine schedule organized by age milestones as columns:

Vaccines for 65 and older:

Influenza (Flu) Vaccine
Description: Protects against seasonal flu.
Dosage: 1 dose (high-dose or adjuvanted versions for those 65+).
Frequency: Annually.
Pneumococcal Vaccines
Description: Protects against pneumococcal disease (pneumonia, meningitis).
Dosage: PCV20 or PCV21 (if not previously vaccinated). PPSV23 may be required for those previously vaccinated with other pneumococcal vaccines.
Frequency: One dose of PCV20/PCV21, plus PPSV23 if indicated, based on previous vaccinations.
Shingles Vaccine (Shingrix)
Description: Prevents shingles and related complications.
Dosage: 2 doses of Shingrix, spaced 2 to 6 months apart.
Frequency: Once, starting at age 50, including adults aged 65+.
**Tdap/Td (Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis)
Description: Protects against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.
Dosage: 1 dose of Tdap (if not previously received), then Td every 10 years.
Frequency: Every 10 years.
COVID-19 Vaccine
Description: Protects against COVID-19.
Dosage: 1 or more doses depending on prior vaccination history (e.g., booster doses as needed).
Frequency: According to current CDC guidelines (boosters may be recommended annually or as new variants emerge).
Health Promotion: Screenings and Tests for Adults:
Middle Adults (35-65)

Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) screening for osteoporosis
Eye examination for glaucoma and other disorders every 2 to 3 years or annually depending on provider
Mental health screening for anxiety and depression
Pap Test: every 3 years
Mammogram: 45 and older (every 2 years for 55 and older)
Older Adults (65+)

Annual screenings
Hearing
Fecal occult blood test
Digital rectal and prostate-specific antigen (males)
Dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scanning for osteoporosis
Eye examination for glaucoma and other disorders
Periodic screenings
Mental health screening for depression
Cholesterol screening annually
Diabetes screening every 3 years, or every 1 to 2 years if blood glucose levels were elevated on initial screening
Colonoscopy: q10 years

item.title: Lab Values & Electrolytes
item.description:
#labvalues #abg #electrolytes #nursing #foundations
#labvalues #abg #electrolytes #nursing #foundations

pH:

Normal Range: 7.35 - 7.45
pH below 7.35 indicates acidosis, and above 7.45 indicates alkalosis.
Carbon Dioxide (PaCO₂):

Normal Range: 35 - 45 mmHg
Levels above 45 mmHg suggest respiratory acidosis, while values below 35 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis.
Bicarbonate (HCO₃):

Normal Range: 22 - 26 mEq/L (people experiment with being "bi" when they are 22-26 years old)
Low HCO₃ levels suggest metabolic acidosis, and high levels suggest metabolic alkalosis.
Partial Pressure of Oxygen (PaO₂):

Normal Range: 80 - 100 mmHg
below 60 mmHg indicate hypoxemia and may require oxygen supplementation.
Electrolyte Values

Sodium: 136 to 145 mEq/L (when your systolic is 136-145, you need to lower your sodium!)
Calcium: 9 to 10.5 mg/dL (call 9-11 if break your bones: calcium 911)
Potassium: 3.5 to 5 mEq/L (when you're old as fuck 35-50, you need more potassium)
Magnesium: 1.3 to 2.1 mEq/L (magnums are between 1-2 inches long)
Chloride: 98 to 106 mEq/L (a heated swimming pool is 98-106, pool = chlorine)
Phosphorus: 3 to 4.5 mg/dL (we eat PHO between 3-4:30 PM)

BUN: 7-20 (the buns will finish baking by dinner 7:20 PM)

Note: Chvostek's Sign: indicates hypOcalcemia, twitching of facial muscles

Fluid Electrolyte Cheat Sheets
Potassium

Hypokalemia - weakness, fatigue, muscle cramps, weak & irregular pulse, constipation, ileus, shallow respirations
Hyperkalemia - weakness, paresthesia, paralysis, arrhythmias, tall T waves, increased motility, hyperactive BS
Sodium

Hyponatremia - confusion, fatigue, seizures, nausea, vomiting, hypotension, weak extremities, increased GI motility, increased UOP
Hypernatremia - thirst, dry mucous membranes, agitation, edema, hypertension, PULMONARY EDEMA. none or diminished DTR
Calcium

Hypocalcemia - tetany, Chvostek's (facial twitching), Trousseau's (involuntary contraction of the muscles in the hand and wrist), paresthesia, seizures, hyperreflexia (hyperactive DTR)
Hypercalcemia - weakness, lethargy, kidney stones, constipation, bradycardia, decreased DTR, bone pain, n/v
Magnesium

Hypomagnesemia - tremors, hyperreflexia, tetany, seizures, tachycardia, hypertension.
Hypermagnesemia - hypotension, bradycardia, respiratory depression, drowsiness. . wide QRS
Phosphate

Hypophosphatemia - weakness, bone pain, confusion, respiratory failure.
Hyperphosphatemia - tetany, soft tissue calcifications, paresthesia.
Chlorine

Hypochloremia - metabolic alkalosis, tetany, muscle cramps, twitching.
Hyperchloremia - metabolic acidosis, Kussmaul respirations, lethargy, weakness.

item.title: Endocarditis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #endocarditis


Inflammation of the endocardium, typically affecting the heart valves, caused by infection (infective endocarditis) or, rarely, non-infectious processes.
endo = inner, itis = inflammation. endocarditis = inflammation of the inner heart

Infectious: Bacteria (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus viridans, Enterococcus), fungi (Candida, Aspergillus), less commonly viruses.

most common type
mold or bacterial vegetation on the valves
more common on L side (aortic and mitral/bi valve)
Non-Infectious: Autoimmune conditions (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus – Libman-Sacks endocarditis), malignancies.


Prosthetic heart valves
Congenital heart defects
Rheumatic heart disease
History of endocarditis
IV drug use
Poor dental hygiene or invasive dental procedures => strep throat (how creator of muppets died)
Indwelling catheters or central lines
Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV, chemotherapy).

CLOT mnemonic
Clots in heart and body
Lung fluids - crackles & spleen enlarged d/t heart failure & infection
Ovearheated - fever
Too little oxygen = signs of heart failure

General Symptoms: Fever, fatigue, night sweats, malaise, weight loss.
Cardiac Symptoms: New or changing heart murmur, signs of heart failure (demand>output)
Peripheral Signs:
Petechiae (small red spots on skin or mucosa)
Splinter hemorrhages (linear streaks under nails)
Janeway lesions (painless, flat red spots on palms/soles)
Osler nodes (painful nodules on fingers/toes)
Roth spots (retinal hemorrhages with pale centers).
Complications: Embolic events (e.g., stroke, pulmonary embolism), abscess formation, septicemia.


IV antibiotics for 4-6 weeks (based on blood culture results).
Antifungals if fungal endocarditis is confirmed.
Surgical Intervention: Valve repair or replacement if extensive damage, persistent infection, or complications (e.g., heart failure, abscess).


Monitor for signs of embolic events (neurological changes, limb ischemia).
Assess for heart failure (dyspnea, edema, fatigue).
Administer antibiotics on schedule and monitor for side effects.
Educate on completing full antibiotic course.
Encourage proper dental hygiene to prevent recurrence.
Monitor for fever and new murmurs, indicating treatment failure.


Blood Cultures: Positive in most cases, with at least two sets needed before antibiotics.
Echocardiography: Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) or transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) to detect vegetations, valve damage, or abscess.
Labs: Elevated inflammatory markers (CRP, ESR), leukocytosis, anemia.
ECG: May show conduction abnormalities or arrhythmias.
Other Tests: Imaging to detect embolic complications (e.g., CT for stroke, pulmonary embolism).
#nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #endocarditis
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pericarditis
item.description:
Inflammation of the pericardium, the sac surrounding the heart
Can be acute, chronic, or recurrent
Often self-limiting but may lead to serious complications like cardiac tamponade


Viral infections (most common – e.g., coxsackievirus)
Bacterial infections, TB
Post-MI (Dressler's syndrome)
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus, RA)
Uremia, trauma, cancer, radiation
Certain medications (e.g., hydralazine, isoniazid)


Recent viral illness
MI or cardiac surgery
Autoimmune conditions
Chronic kidney disease
Cancer or radiation therapy


Sharp, pleuritic chest pain, worse when lying down, better when sitting up and leaning forward => pericardial layers interact with gravity, when lying down, heart rests against irritated pericardium
Pericardial friction rub (high-pitched scratchy sound)
Dyspnea with Hiccups => common ATI question
Fever, fatigue
Dyspnea, especially with exertion
Nonproductive cough


Pericardial effusion
Cardiac tamponade (life-threatening)
Constrictive pericarditis (chronic thickening)
Recurrence of symptoms


ECG: widespread ST elevation and PR depression
Echocardiogram: detects effusion or tamponade
Chest X-ray: enlarged cardiac silhouette if effusion
Labs: elevated WBC, CRP, ESR; troponin may be mildly elevated


NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) for pain and inflammation
Colchicine to prevent recurrence
Corticosteroids (if autoimmune or unresponsive to NSAIDs)
Antibiotics if bacterial cause
Pericardiocentesis if tamponade develops


Monitor for signs of tamponade: hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds (Beck’s triad)
Position patient sitting up and leaning forward for comfort
Administer anti-inflammatories as prescribed
Educate on activity restriction during recovery
Monitor vital signs, ECG, and for worsening symptoms
Supportive care: oxygen if dyspneic, emotional reassurance
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pericarditis - ati
item.description:
Inflammation of the pericardium, the sac surrounding the heart
Can be acute (sudden onset) or chronic (lasting more than three months)
Leads to chest pain, pericardial effusion, and possible cardiac tamponade if untreated



Infections (viral, bacterial, fungal, tuberculosis)
Post-myocardial infarction (Dressler’s syndrome)
Autoimmune diseases (lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Uremia (kidney failure-related pericarditis)
Cancer (metastatic spread to pericardium)
Chest trauma or post-cardiac surgery
Radiation therapy to the chest
Medications (hydralazine, procainamide, isoniazid)


Recent viral infection (e.g., influenza, HIV, Coxsackievirus)
History of heart attack or cardiac surgery
Chronic kidney disease or dialysis
Autoimmune conditions
Malignancy with metastasis to the heart
Tuberculosis exposure


Sharp, pleuritic chest pain (worse with deep breathing, relieved by sitting up and leaning forward)
Pericardial friction rub (high-pitched, scratchy sound over the left sternal border)
Fever and chills if infection is present
Dyspnea due to pain and pericardial effusion
Tachycardia from cardiac stress
Beck’s Triad (if cardiac tamponade develops): hypotension, muffled heart sounds, jugular venous distension (JVD)


Pericardial effusion (fluid buildup in the pericardial sac)
Cardiac tamponade (life-threatening compression of the heart)
Constrictive pericarditis (chronic scarring and thickening of the pericardium, restricting heart movement)


Electrocardiogram (ECG) – ST-segment elevation in multiple leads, PR depression
Echocardiogram – Detects pericardial effusion and heart compression
Chest X-ray – Enlarged cardiac silhouette (if effusion is large)
Cardiac biomarkers (troponins, CK-MB) – Normal or mildly elevated (rules out myocardial infarction)
Inflammatory markers – Elevated ESR, CRP, leukocytosis
Pericardiocentesis (if effusion is suspected) – Fluid analysis for infection or malignancy


NSAIDs (ibuprofen, aspirin, indomethacin) for inflammation and pain
Colchicine to prevent recurrence
Corticosteroids (prednisone) for autoimmune or refractory cases
Antibiotics or antifungals if infectious cause suspected
Dialysis if uremic pericarditis is present
Pericardiocentesis for large pericardial effusions or tamponade
Pericardiectomy (surgical removal of the pericardium) for chronic constrictive pericarditis


Monitor for signs of cardiac tamponade (hypotension, muffled heart sounds, JVD, pulsus paradoxus)
Position patient upright and leaning forward to relieve pain
Administer prescribed anti-inflammatory medications and monitor for side effects
Assess for worsening dyspnea, tachycardia, or hypotension (signs of pericardial effusion)
Monitor ECG for ST-segment changes and dysrhythmias
Educate patient on medication adherence and recurrence prevention


Recognize and manage acute pericarditis early to prevent complications
Monitor for and intervene in cardiac tamponade
Ensure adequate pain management to promote comfort
Educate on lifestyle modifications and follow-up care
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: PAD vs PVD
item.description:
Umbrella term for diseases affecting blood vessels outside the heart and brain
Includes arterial and venous disorders
Most common: Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD) and Chronic Venous Insufficiency



Subset of PVD
Caused by atherosclerosis in peripheral arteries
Results in reduced blood flow to limbs (typically legs)






PAD: Antiplatelets, statins, smoking cessation, walking programs, revascularization
PVD (venous): Compression stockings, leg elevation, avoid standing long, diuretics (if edema), wound care
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Raynaud’s Disease
item.description:
A vasospastic disorder that causes intermittent constriction of small arteries, usually in fingers and toes.
Triggered by cold exposure or stress, leading to reduced blood flow and color changes.


Primary Raynaud’s: Idiopathic with no underlying disease.
Secondary Raynaud’s: Associated with autoimmune conditions (e.g., Scleroderma, Lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis).


Female sex (more common in women ages 15–40).
Cold environments.
Family history of Raynaud’s or autoimmune disease.
Occupational triggers (e.g., vibration tools).
Smoking (vasoconstriction).


Triphasic color changes in digits:
White (pallor) from vasoconstriction.
Blue (cyanosis) from poor oxygenation.
Red (rubor) from reperfusion.
Numbness, tingling, burning pain during or after attacks.
Cold, pale, or blue fingers/toes, often symmetrical.


Ulcers or sores on fingers in severe cases.
Tissue necrosis if blood flow is severely compromised.
Functional impairment with frequent attacks.


Clinical history and symptoms during cold/stress exposure.
Nailfold capillaroscopy to examine capillary structure (esp. in secondary).
Antibody testing (ANA, anti-centromere) for autoimmune association.


Lifestyle modifications:
Avoid cold, wear gloves, keep core warm.
Manage stress.
Stop smoking.
Medications:
Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) – relax vessels.
Vasodilators (e.g., topical nitroglycerin).
In secondary cases, treat underlying condition.
Severe cases:
Sympathectomy (nerve surgery to reduce spasms).


Teach cold avoidance strategies and layering clothing.
Encourage smoking cessation.
Educate on early symptom recognition and attack prevention.
Monitor for skin breakdown or signs of ulceration/ischemia.
In secondary Raynaud’s, coordinate care for underlying autoimmune disease.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Raynaud's vs Buerger's Disease
item.description:
Raynaud’s = Red, White, Blue (triphasic response)
Buerger’s = Bad smoker’s fingers
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing


dilation of the aorta greater than 30mm
if greater than 55mm => large, requires urgent treatment
very deadly if it ruptures
infrarenal aorta = most common location of AAA
Patho: aortic wall weakens; thinning of the media & adventitia with the loss of vascular muscle


ATHEROSCLEROSIS - buildup of plaque
high BP
infection
trauma


smoking => biggest risk factor
other major risks: male, history
renal insufficiency
Cardiac: HTN, CAD, PAD, Heart Failure
COPD
recommended screening: abd US, 65-75 yo, smoking hx
Geriatric Considerations: polypharmacy, comorbidities,
NOTE: DIABETES DECREASES RISK


early signs: N/V, satiety, pain: lower back, flank, & groin, audible bruit, pulsating mass (nontender), abdominal pain
late signs: intense pain with distention, abdominal distension, Cullen's sign (umbilical), turner sign (flank)


90% mortality related to blood loss


abdominal US
CT => surgery
PET scan - determines size


manage BP: maintain SYS 90-120
check VS: as much as possible
assess pedal pulses, bruits
monitor for mottling => turns into ecchymosis
sudden pain


Education: stop smoking, low fat, low NA diet, exercise, manage BP, routines of ICU
Assess regularly: mass, bruits, abdomen
Trending of VS, labs, UOP
Insertion of: arterial lines, central lines, foley
CBC: shows rupturing - hematocrit is decreased if it ruptured
DraW: CMP, coags, blood type


2 large bore IV
crentral pressure devices
fluids, PRBCs, meds (pressors, inotropes)
consent, ADs
vitals
type & screen for blood


turn q2
IS
deep breathing
clear liquid diet, advance as tolerated
ambulation
education: follow-up prn, advance activity as tolerated
monitor: graft complications
Cardiac meds: BP, statin
abx
Glucose control
antiplatelet
Lifestyle: exercise, balanced diet
repeat CT: 1month, 6 month,12 month


EVAR: endovascular aneurysm repair - stent placement; less invasive
Open Repair
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: CAD & MI
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #mi


Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) - broad term involving arteries in heart leading to: either Chronic Stable Angina or ACS
CAD = CSA or ACS
Chronic Stable Angina - predictable chest pain during exertion, resolves with rest or nitroglycerin, can progress to unstable

ECG: Normal at rest; ST depression or T wave inversion during stress
Cardiac Biomarkers: normal
Treatment: Lifestyle changes, nitrates, beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, statins
Acute Coronary Syndromes (ACS)

sudden, life-threatening condition caused by a sudden reduction in blood flow to the heart
Umbrella term for UA (unstable angina), NSTEMI, and STEMI
ACS = STEMI / NSTEMI / UA
STEMI - ischemia causing full-thickness myocardial infarction

cardiac biomarkers: elevated troponin, CK-MB
Treatment: Emergency PCI or thrombolysis, MONA (morphine, oxygen, nitrates, aspirin).
NSTEMI - ischemia with myocardial infarction but without full-thickness injury

caused by- spasm of artery, stable plaque, a cardiac embolism, or arteritis and injury to the heart
similar to UA but more severe and prolonged, unrelieved by rest or nitroglycerin
Cardiac Biomarkers: Elevated (troponin, CK-MB).
Treatment: Same as UA with emphasis on revascularization (PCI).
Unstable Angina (UA)- ischemia without myocardial infarction, cardiac markers are NOT elevated.

Occurs at rest, increasing frequency/severity, lasts >20 minutes, unrelieved by nitroglycerin.
Treatment: Antiplatelets (aspirin), anticoagulants, beta-blockers, nitrates, PCI if high risk.
Terms to note:
Infarction - tissue death or necrosis caused by prolonged lack of blood supply
Ischemia - reduced cardiac tissue perfusion, can progress to infarction if unresolved
Miscellaneous Things to note:
Prinzmetal angina (vasospastic angina or variant angina) - chest discomfort or pain at rest with transient ECG changes in the ST segment, and with a prompt response to nitroglycerin


Atherosclerosis - plaques that narrow or occlude blood flow to coronary arteries, decreasing perfusion
oxygen and nutrient demand outpace supply then causes pain
hypertension, having a sedentary lifestyle, using tobacco or smoking, and by having insulin resistance or diabetes
Non modifiable Risk Factors: Age (45 men, 55 women), Sex, Family history/genetics, race/ethnicity (higher w non-Hispanic white individuals)
Modifiable risk factors: inactivity, poor sleep, vaping/tobacco, obesity, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, stress
Comorbidities: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, thyroid disease, dm, depression, obesity, gout, cancer


Chest discomfort or angina (only when demand is greater than supply)
pain can radiate to the left arm, the neck, jaw, or back
diaphoresis, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, SOB, lightheadedness, and weakness
females may not experience chest pain (may present with extreme fatigue, dizziness, abdominal pain, nausea, and pressure in the chest)

Cardiac Biomarkers - detect heart muscle damage

Troponin - peaks in 24-48 hours, protein found in heart muscle, detects myocardial injury, elevated in NSTEMI, STEMI
Creatine Kinase-MB - elevated; enzyme found in the heart muscle, indicates MI
B-type Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) - Primarily used to r/o HF and assess the severity of volume overload or cardiac stress.
C-Reactive Protein (CRP)- Measures inflammation levels; Non-specific, but often elevated in CAD & ACS
Lipoprotein - LDL, HDL (see Lipid Panel)
Stress Test

evaluate how well the heart functions with activity, diagnose CAD and arrhythmias, evaluate treatment, and determine the risk of having an MI
Exercise Stress Test - exercises on a treadmill or bicycle, with increasing intensity. HR, BP, and EKG are monitored during the test.
stop stress test once chest pain is present
Stress Test Echocardiogram - same as exercise but with echo (U/S)
Nuclear Stress Test - radioactive dye is used during stress test

Initial management: MONA (morphine, aspirin, nitro, O2)
STEMI
Cardiac Catherization / Coronary Angiogram - diagnostic and/or therapeutic procedure; insertion of catheter into a blood vessel
visualize the coronary arteries using contrast dye and X-ray imaging to identify blockages, narrowing, or other abnormalities
used to plan angioplasty, stent placement, or other revascularization procedures.
PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) - non-surgical procedure to treat coronary artery blockages and restore blood flow to the heart
aka Angioplasty
within 90 minutes, if not: fibrinolysis within 120 minutes
catheter through the skin (usually via the groin or wrist) and threading it to the coronary arteries to open up blockages
balloon angioplasty, stent placement, atherectomy
CABG - coronary artery bypass graft
dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel)
not first line therapy, must be given 6-9 hours
NSTEMI / UA
more conservative treatment, depends on severity
DAPT/anticoags, betablockers
heparin does not dissolve clots, only prevents it
post catherization: absent pedal pulses may be present 4-12 hours

chest pain = EKG, lab draw
ST is LOW = O2 is low
ST is HIGH = muscles have died
elevated troponin = 150-300 mg aspirin, IV heparin
antiplatelet therapy with either ticagrelor or clopidogrel taken by mouth
#nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #mi
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cardiac Arrest
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

cessation of heart and respiratory function which results in death
death occurs in minutes


Ventricular fibrillation => most common cause
asystole, PEA
CAD & MI that includes unstable lesions, ruptured plaques of atherosclerosis and/or thrombosis.


loss of consciousness and loss of pulse and respiration
prior to the arrest: heavy chest pain with possible radiation to other areas such as the jaw, abdomen, or back, tachypnea and diaphoresis
Post-Cardiac Arrest Syndrome

cascade of events including neurologic injury, cardiac, and microcirculatory dysfunctions following ROSC
e.g. ARDs, DIC, adrenal dysfunction, hepatitis, AKI
neuro: seizures, coma, or brain death


elevated Troponin levels (elevated as soon as 2-3 hr following incident)
Reference Cardiac Troponin T: < 0.1 ng/mL
Reference Cardiac Troponin I: < 0.03 ng/mL
Elevated CK - indicates muscle injury (CK-MB is specific to cardiac muscle) => ref,: CK (total): 20-200 U/L, ​​​​​​​CK-MB: 5–25 IU/L
BNP - elevated indicates Heart Failure, BNP: < 100 ng/L
D-Dimer - elevated indicative of clotting; ref: < 500 ng/mL
ESR - elevated indicates infarction, infection, inflammation; ref Male: up to 15 mm/hr

CAB algorithm
Goals:
PaCO2 range of 35 to 45 mm Hg
SPO2 92-98%
maintain >90 mm Hg systolic and > 65 mm Hg diastolic
First Responder Tasks:

Call for help
CPR – Initiate compressions to the client
Crash cart – Instruct an assistive personnel or other team members to obtain the crash cart
“ati_engage_ams_2022_L24_adult_ca_400.svg” could not be found.
Cardioversion - performed on clients who have a pulse but are not stable hemodynamically; a low energy, synchronous shock that is delivered at the exact point of the QRS complex
Defibrillation - asynchronous shock that is delivered without delay
implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) - treats VT and VT, for patients with high risk
Emergency meds: LEAN (Lidocaine, epi, atropine, narcan)
Epinephrine - vasopressor, maintain HR & BP, 1 mg q3-5min
Amiodarone - Antiarrhythmic (VFIB, PVT), IV 150mg over 10 min
Lidocaine - Antiarrhythmic (ventricular rhythms)
Atropine - Antiarrhythmic, increase HR, decrease resp & GI secretions, IV 0.5-1 mg q3-5 (max 2mg)
Treatment post-ROSC

monitor everything including EEG (for comatose patients)
TTM 24 hrs: 32° and 36° C (89.6° and 96.7° F) => minimize brain injury and neuro impairment if comatose
Vent support with ETCO monitor
EEG
blood glucose monitoring

Critical Findings (increased risk of arrest)

An increase in normal chest pain or unrelenting chest pain, chest pain at rest or chest pain not relieved by nitroglycerine
BP 60 mm Hg or less systolic
BP greater than 180 mm Hg systolic and/or mm Hg diastolic
BP change from lying to standing of greater than 20 mm Hg systolic or 10 mm Hg diastolic
Pulse rate greater than 100 bpm or less than 60 bpm
Pulse deficit
Presence of crackles in lungs bilaterally
Diminished or absent peripheral pulses


Chest pain - 12 lead, check cardiac enzymes, prepare for catherization
BP<60 sys - central line monitor, 12-lead ecg, portable x-ray, CMP, chem, vasopressors
Pulse deficit/arrhythmias - 12 lead, e-, thyroid function blood test, cardiovert
Lung Crackles - 12 lead, BNP, e-, chem
Pulse > 100 bpm or < 60 bpm - e-, assess confusion or restlessness
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cardiac Surgeries
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing


A surgical intervention that uses a graft vessel to bypass obstructed vessels in the coronary arteries
obstruction usually caused by constricted or clogged due to plaque
donor vein from leg (saphenous vein or artery in chest (internal mamary), radial artery
cardiobypass machine used while heart is stopped
Off-pump CABg - option to keep heart beating rather than using bypass machine during surgery
usually required by patients with CAD & MI

Mitral Valve Regurgitation - MR

blood flow is reversed from LV to LA, usually during systolic
aka mitral valve insufficiency
causes: Endocarditis
Aortic Regurgitation - AR

inadequate closure of aorrtic valve during diastole
leads to back flow of blood through aortic valve
causes: calcified aortic valve disease, tear or laceration, Endocarditis
Aortic Stenosis - AS

common valve disorder that causes LV obstruction through valve stenosis and calcification
increases valve LV systolic pressure, leading to increase in LV ejection time, ultimate leading to decreased aortic pressure
leads to LV hypertrophy, dysfunction, and failure
causes: congenital or d/t rheumatic valve disease, Lupus, METS, ESRD
Common manifestations:

fluid retention => rapid weight gain
edema of abdomen, ankles, feet
palpitations
SOB, chest pain
dizziness
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cardiac Tamponade
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing


A life-threatening condition caused by excess fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart and impairing its ability to pump blood.
Leads to decreased cardiac output, hypotension, and potential cardiovascular collapse.
Considered a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention
Normal Fluid: 15-50 mL, CT = 200-300 mL


MOST COMMON: percutaneous cardiac interventions, MI complications, aortic dissection, pericarditis
Trauma: Blunt or penetrating chest injury
Pericarditis: Inflammation leading to fluid accumulation.
Malignancy: Metastatic cancer invading the pericardium.
Myocardial infarction (MI) complications: Ventricular wall rupture.
Aortic dissection: tearing of aorta, Blood leaks into the pericardium.
Cardiac surgery or invasive procedures: Postoperative bleeding, central line placements, pCI
Uremia: Kidney failure leading to pericardial effusion.


History of pericarditis or pericardial effusion
Recent cardiac surgery or trauma
Connective tissue disorders (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Advanced malignancy (lung, breast, lymphoma)
ESRD (leading to uremic pericarditis)
Anticoagulation therapy (increased risk of pericardial bleeding)
HIV+


Beck's Triad => Classic sign: hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds
Pulsus paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP >10 mmHg during inspiration.
Ewart's sign: dullness with bronchial breath sounds auscultated just below the scapula area
Tachycardia & hypotension: Compensatory response to reduced cardiac output.
Dyspnea & tachypnea: Due to poor oxygenation and pulmonary congestion.
Weak peripheral pulses: Reduced perfusion.
Cool, clammy skin: Signs of circulatory collapse.


Cardiogenic Shock leading to multi-organ failure (MODS)
Med-Surg/Cardiovascular/Cardiac Arrest due to severe heart compression
PEA
Pulmonary edema from fluid backup
Death if untreated


echocardiogram => gold standard, shows extent of effusion and compression
ECG
CXR - "watter bottle" appearance
Hemodynamic monitoring
cardiac catherization


pericardiocentesis - needle drainage of pericardial fluid
pericardial window - surgical drainage
supportive: IVF, vasopressors
Treat the cause: abx, chemo, dialysis for uremic pericarditis
Vasopressors


elevate legs to increase venous return
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cardiomyopathy
item.description:
A group of diseases that affect the heart muscle, impairing its ability to pump blood effectively.
Can lead to heart failure, arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death.
Classification:
Dilated (DCM) - most common

enlargement of the ventricles with reduced systolic function and decreased EF
Causes: Idiopathic, ischemic heart disease, alcohol abuse, viral infections, toxins, genetic mutations
symptoms: chest discomfort, peripheral edema, exponentially increasing levels of fatigue as the condition progresses, and exertional dyspnea.
Hypertrophic (HCM)
thickened ventricular walls, most commonly affecting the interventricular septum, leading to diastolic dysfunction.
causes: Genetic mutations
symptoms: fatigue, syncopal episodes, chest discomfort or palpitations, exhaustion, and dyspnea
Restrictive (RCM)
Stiffened ventricular walls due to fibrosis or infiltration, leading to impaired diastolic filling while systolic function is preserved
poor prognosis; least common
causes: Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis, radiation therapy, idiopathic.
symptoms: similar to HF with DCM/HCM
Arrhythmogenic (ACM)
Fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricular myocardium, leading to arrhythmias and structural changes
Causes: Genetic mutations (autosomal dominant), familial
symptoms: ascites, increased JVD, and lethal dysrhythmias, VFib, VTach, including manifestations of other CMs


Fluid overload: Diuretics and vasodilators
Heart Failure meds: ACEi, ARBs, BB, CCB, Diuretic
DCM or RCM: heart transplant, LVAD (left ventricular assist device): can be permanent or temporary fix until transplant
Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD): Prevents sudden cardiac death.
Pacemaker: Helps regulate heart rhythm.
septal myectomy - remove portions of hypertrophied ventricular septum
alcohol septal ablation
Lifestyle


fluid restriction: 2L/day
sodium restriction
Lifestyle


Echocardiogram
BNP/NT-proBNP levels (heart failure markers)
Troponin (I and T)- indicates myocardial injury
genetic testing (for familial cases)
MRI - detailed imaging
CXR - cardiomegaly, pulmonary congestion
ECG
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: EKG
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #ekg
#nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #ekg


P Wave: Represents atrial depolarization; should be upright and precede each QRS.
PR Interval: Time from atrial depolarization to ventricular depolarization (normal: 0.12–0.20 seconds).
QRS Complex: Represents ventricular depolarization; normal duration <0.12 seconds.
T Wave: Represents ventricular repolarization; upright in most leads.
ST Segment: Should be isoelectric; elevation or depression indicates ischemia or injury.
QT Interval: Represents total ventricular activity (depolarization + repolarization); prolonged QT may indicate risk for arrhythmias.
Strip Timing

small square - .04 second
large square (5 smalls) = .20 seconds
1 strip = 6 seconds (that means multiply QRS's by 10 = heart rate per minute)


ECG Description: Regular rhythm, rate <60 bpm, normal P wave before each QRS.
Causes: Athletes, medications (beta-blockers, digoxin), hypothyroidism, vagal stimulation.
Clinical Presentation: Dizziness, fatigue, syncope, or asymptomatic.
Treatment: None if asymptomatic, atropine or pacing if symptomatic.


ECG Description: Regular rhythm, rate >100 bpm, normal P wave before each QRS.
Causes: Fever, anxiety, pain, dehydration, anemia, hyperthyroidism.
Clinical Presentation: Palpitations, dyspnea, dizziness, or asymptomatic.
Treatment: Treat underlying cause (e.g., fluids for dehydration, antipyretics for fever).


Mnemonic/Description: A heartbeat that starts in the wrong part of the heart, causing a random extra thud.
Rate: Depends on underlying rhythm.
Rhythm: Irregular.
P Wave: present with every QRS except it is absent with PVC.
PR Interval: Not measurable for PVC.
QRS Complex: >0.12 seconds (wide).
Causes: Electrolyte imbalance, ischemia, stimulants.
Clinical Presentation: Palpitations or asymptomatic.
Treatment: Treat cause, beta-blockers if frequent.


Mnemonic/Description: Early P wave, normal QRS, An early, out-of-sync beat from the top chambers of the heart
Rate: Depends on underlying rhythm.
Rhythm: Irregular due to premature beat.
P Wave: Abnormal shape, early.
PR Interval: Normal or shortened.
QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds.
Causes: Stress, caffeine, electrolyte imbalance.
Clinical Presentation: Palpitations or asymptomatic.
Treatment: Avoid triggers, rarely needed.


Mnemonic/Description: Prolonged PR interval.
Rate: Usually normal.
Rhythm: Regular.
P Wave: Normal, one per QRS.
PR Interval: >0.20 seconds (prolonged).
QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds.
Causes: Aging, medications (beta-blockers, digoxin).
Clinical Presentation: Asymptomatic.
Treatment: None unless symptomatic.


Mnemonic/Description: Irregularly irregular, no P waves. atria quiver instead of contracting effectively, causing irregular heartbeats and impaired blood flow
Rate: Variable (ventricular rate).
Rhythm: Irregularly irregular.
P Wave: Absent, fibrillatory waves.
PR Interval: Not measurable.
QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds.
Causes: Hypertension, coronary artery disease, valvular heart disease, heart failure, hyperthyroidism, alcohol use, obesity, sleep apnea, post-surgery, or idiopathic
Clinical Presentation:
Cardiac: Irregular pulse, palpitations, pulse deficit (apical vs peripheral pulse are different), chest pain
General: fatigue, dizziness, shortness of breath
Can be asymptomatic.
Risk of thromboembolism (e.g., stroke) due to blood stasis in atria.
Treatment:
Rate Control - beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin
Rhythm Control - antiarrhythmic drugs, cardioversion
Anticoagulation - warfarin, DOACS (apixaban, etc)
Interventional - ablation, pacemaker

“AdobeStock_385717687-1.webp” could not be found.

Mnemonic/Description: Sawtooth flutter waves.
Rate: Atrial 250-350 bpm; ventricular varies.
Rhythm: Regular or irregular.
P Wave: Sawtooth appearance.
PR Interval: Not measurable.
QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds.
Causes: Similar to AFib (hypertension, CAD).
Clinical Presentation: Palpitations, fatigue.
Treatment: Rate control, cardioversion, anticoagulation.


Mnemonic/Description: Narrow, rapid QRS, hidden P waves.
Rate: >150 bpm.
Rhythm: Regular.
P Wave: Often hidden in QRS.
PR Interval: Not measurable.
QRS Complex: <0.12 seconds.
Causes: Re-entry circuits, stress, stimulants.
Clinical Presentation: Palpitations, dizziness, chest discomfort.
Treatment: Vagal maneuvers, adenosine, beta-blockers, cardioversion if unstable.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: EKG - Critical Care
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
Note only shockable rhythms: VFib, pulseless VT


see EKG for basics


Overview: A rapid, abnormal heart rhythm originating in the ventricles, often life-threatening and requiring immediate intervention.
Rate: 100-250 bpm
Rhythm: Regular
P-Waves: Not typically visible or unrelated to QRS complex
QRS Complex: Wide (greater than 0.12 seconds), bizarre shape
PR Interval: Not measurable or absent
Stable VTACH Treatment: minimal symptoms: administer amiodarone or lidocaine (antiarrhythmic drugs), consider cardioversion if drug therapy is ineffective.
unstable VTACH: immediate synchronized cardioversion or defibrillation if no pulse is present. Consider an ICD (Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator) for recurrent episodes.
Symptoms: palpitations, syncope, chest pain, shortness of breath, cardiac arrest, or even sudden cardiac death.
Synchronized Cardioversion

typically less than what is required for defib
set to synchronize => track R waves
typically 50-100 joules, max 200
Remember: pulseless VT => defib, CPR, intubate, epi, ami/lido
note: VTACH is from ventricles, SVT is from atrium
note: VTACH has wide QRS, SVT has narrow QRS
Cardioversion - performed on clients who have a pulse but are not stable hemodynamically; a low energy, synchronous shock that is delivered at the exact point of the QRS complex - R to be exact
Note: follow CAB priority framework during CPR
Causes: underlying ischemic heart disease, acute MI, dilated cardiomyppathy, e-, structural heart disaese, illicit drug use (meth, coke)



Overview: A rapid, erratic electrical activity in the ventricles, causing ineffective quivering instead of a coordinated contraction, leading to no pulse and requiring immediate intervention.
Rate: Indeterminate (chaotic electrical activity), 150-500 bpm
Rhythm: Irregular, erratic
P-Waves: None
QRS Complex: None, appears as a chaotic, irregular baseline
PR Interval: None
Treatment: Immediate defibrillation is the primary treatment. Perform CPR until defibrillator is available, followed by epinephrine or amiodarone if necessary. Advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) protocols should be followed.
Causes: MI, structural heart disease, e- imbalance: hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, hyperkalemia, hypoxia, acidosis, etc
Manifestations: sudden collapse due to cardiac arrest, no pulse, unresponsive




Overview: A condition where there is organized electrical activity on the EKG but no mechanical heart activity or pulse, often associated with cardiac arrest, requiring immediate intervention.
Rate: Varies depending on underlying rhythm
Rhythm: Can be regular or irregular depending on underlying electrical activity
P-Waves: Present or absent, depending on the underlying rhythm
QRS Complex: Present or absent, depending on the underlying rhythm
PR Interval: Present or absent, depending on the underlying rhythm
Treatment: Immediate CPR, administer epinephrine, and correct the underlying cause (e.g., hypoxia, electrolyte imbalances, trauma). Follow ACLS protocols for resuscitation.
Primary Causes: cardiac
Secondary Causes: Hypoxia or resp failure (50% of cases), H's & T's
H: hypovolemia, hypoxia, htdrogen ion, hypo/per-kalemia, hypothermia
T: Tension pneumo, trauma, tamponade, thrombosis-pulm, thrombosis-coronary
NOTE: for CPR, follow CAB priority framework

Epinephrine 1 mg q3-5 min
amiodarone 300mg or lidocaine 1-1.5 mg/kg


flatline
result of the failure of the intrinsic electrical system of the heart
often result of VFib, pulseless VTach, PEA
also be the result of attempted defibrillation for another dysrhythmia
terminal rhythm
Presentation: no pulse, unresponsive, flatline EKG
Treatment:

Asystole is a non-shockable rhythm!
intubation of the airway
CPR (with minimal interruption of < 5 seconds)
IV epinephrine (ideally within 5 minutes of the start of cardiac arrest) followed by 1 mg every 3 to 5 minutes.


A conduction delay at the AV node resulting in prolonged PR interval without dropped beats; generally asymptomatic and often benign.
Rate: Usually normal
Rhythm: Regular
P-Waves: Present, one for each QRS complex
PR Interval: Prolonged (>0.20 seconds) but consistent
QRS Complex: Normal (0.06-0.10 seconds)
Treatment: Typically no treatment required unless symptomatic. Monitor for progression to higher-degree blocks. Address underlying causes such as medication effects, electrolyte imbalances, or ischemia.


Longer, longer, longer, drop! Then you have a WENCKEBACH

Overview: A progressive delay in AV node conduction until a QRS complex is dropped; often transient and may not require treatment.
Rate: Usually normal or slightly slow
Rhythm: Irregular due to dropped beats
P-Waves: Present, with more P-waves than QRS complexes
QRS Complex: Normal (0.06-0.10 seconds)
PR Interval: Progressively lengthens until a QRS complex is dropped
Treatment: Typically no intervention if asymptomatic. If symptomatic (e.g., dizziness, syncope), consider atropine (for brady) or temporary pacing. Monitor closely for progression to a higher-degree block.
Causes: medications sch as CCBs, beta-blockers, digitalis, amiodarone, adenosine, increase in vagal tone, post cardiac surgery, e- imbalance, cardiomyopathies, hyperkalemia, MI, myocarditis
Presentation: no physical manifestations, and minimal hemodynamic alterations

If some P’s don’t get through, then you have MOBITZ II

Overview: A more serious block where some P-waves are not conducted to the ventricles without a progressive PR interval change; higher risk of progressing to third-degree block.
Location: bundle of His, bundle branches, or fascicles (basically the ventricles)
Rate: Usually slow, depending on the number of dropped beats
Rhythm: Regular or irregular (based on conduction pattern)
P-Waves: Present, with more P-waves than QRS complexes
QRS Complex: Often widened (>0.12 seconds) if block occurs below the AV node
PR Interval: Constant in conducted beats (no progressive lengthening)
Treatment: Permanent pacemaker placement is often indicated due to risk of progression to complete heart block. Temporary pacing is done while waiting.
Other info:

Causes: MI, necrosis in heart, e-, CCBs, betablockers, amiodarone, digoxin, adenosine, post cardiac surgery
Patho: block in conduction system (usually bundle of HIS or bundle branches)
Presentation: bradycardia, fatigue, syncope, dyspnea, dizziness, palpitations, shortness of breath, and nausea
Things to note

if caused by meds, stop those meds
there is increased risk for falls d/t fatigue, dizziness, SOB

If P’s and Q’s don’t agree, then you have a THIRD DEGREE

Overview: A complete heartblock! Total disruption of electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles, causing them to beat independently; a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention.
Rate: Atrial rate typically normal, ventricular rate slow (usually < 40 bpm)
Rhythm: Regular, but atrial and ventricular rhythms are independent
P-Waves: Present, unrelated to QRS complexes (no consistent PR interval)
QRS Complex: May be narrow or wide depending on the location of the block
PR Interval: Variable with no consistent relationship between P-waves and QRS complexes
Treatment: Immediate intervention required; temporary transcutaneous pacing followed by permanent pacemaker placement is the primary treatment. Administer atropine or epinephrine if symptomatic while awaiting pacing
manifestations: varies: bradycardia, chest pain, shortness of breath, generalized fatigue, or syncope, altered LOC, JVD
bradycardic manifestations: decompensated heart failure, decreased capillary refill, cool skin, diaphoresis, altered mental status, tachypnea, cool skin, retraction, and respiratory distress
Things to note:

increased risk for falls
increased risk for nausea and aspiration
Atropine is for bradycardia since 3rd Degree blocks feature a ventricular escape rhythm (which is slower)
Amiodarone is for tachyarrhythmias (AFIB, VT, VF)


post-op: avoid strenuous activity, keep arm immobilized
do not drive for 2-3 weeks
use arm sling during night time (and during day if possible)
do not move arm above shoulder level
wear medical alert bracelet
beware of magnets, large motors, radars, MRIs
no contact sports
keep cellphones at least 6 inches
regular monitoring of function, battery life, identified abnormal rhythms
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Heart Failure
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #heartfailure #bnp
#nursing #medsurg #cardiovascular #heartfailure


heart is not able to meet the needs of the systemic circulatory system
leads to inadequate tissue perfusion and fluid overload.


CAD, MI, diabetes
Uncontrolled arrythmias, hypertension, myocarditis, congenital heart disease
non structural causes: thyrotoxicosis, anemia, thiamine deficiencies, pregnancy


family hx COPD, CAD, HTN
chronic infection
DM
obesity, alcohol abuse

Depends on which side is affected
Left Side

Pulmonary congestion: crackles/rales, cough w/ frothy or blood tinged sputum
fatigue, weakness, dyspnea on exertion
orthopnea (SOB when supine)
cyanosis, S3 present
paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND = party next door)
Right Side

systemic congestion: ascites, peripheral edema, generalized swelling, enlarged liver/spleen
sudden weight gain (3 lbs in 1 day or 5 lbs in 7 days = VERY BAD)
chest pain, murmurs, palpitations
JVD
Biventricular - both ventricles

combination of both symptoms of L and R side HF (systemic and pulmonary congestion)
point of maximum impulse (PMI) displaced to one side

Pharmacologic (see Pharmacology/CardioVascular/Heart Failure)
ABCDD - Aldosterone (ACE, ARB), betablockers, CCB, digoxin, diuretics
Surgical
Catherization and PCI if with MI
Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) with pacemaker
Implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) - when EF<35%, high risk for arrhythmia
Lifestyle
Diet - low sodium (2g or less), low fluid (2L), no OTC meds, no packaged food
Nursing
elevate legs or use stockings
falls precautions
daily weights
sex - abstain unless able to climb 2 flights of stairs with no SOB


B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP): measures protein in blood, indicates heart failure #bnp
Echocardiogram - calculate EF, reveal structural defects
CXR - r/o pulmonary congestion, cardiomegaly
ECG
MRI
stress test
Right Heart Catherization - assess pressures
Farmingham Diagnostic Criteria for HF: acute pulmonary edema, JVD, PND/orthopnea, S3, rales, diuretic response, imaging
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hemodynamic Monitoring
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing


insertion of catheter in peripheral art (usually radial, femoral, brachial), see trends or abrupt changes in BP, frequent lab draws
transducer must be positioned at the level of the midaxillary line at the level of the right atrium when lying in bed
too low: high pressure, too high - low pressure => all wrong
manual blood pressures can be unsafe due to sudden hemodynamic changes


catheter is inserted through the brachial, antecubital, jugular, or femoral vein to connect with the right side of the heart and then proceed to the pulmonary artery
for patients who have cardiogenic shock, pulmonary hypertension, and unexplained dyspnea
Pulmonary Capillary Wedge Pressure (PCWP) - measure of the pressure in the small blood vessels (capillaries) that lie between the lungs and the left atrium. Reflects left atrial pressure and left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP); indicates left heart function and fluid status. Normal Range: 6-12 mmHg.
Normal Range: 6-12 mmHg


pressure in the superior vena cava or right atrium; reflects right ventricular preload and fluid status.
Normal Range: 8 and 12 mm Hg.
central venous access device (CVAP), generally inserted in the internal jugular or subclavian vein and advanced into the superior vena cava at the entrance to the right atrium.
Decreases in CVP can be an indication of hypovolemia, blood loss greater than 10%, dilation of the vena cava, or a decrease in intrathoracic pressure
Elevations in CVP can indicate decreased cardiac contractility, dysrhythmias, or abnormal functioning of the cardiac valves, all of which may indicate heart failure
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Shock
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

Shock

life-threatening condition that occurs as a result of circulatory failure
causes decreased SVR and perfusion
leads to tissue hypoxia, cellular death, and organ dysfunction
4 Main Types:

Distributive (septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic, toxic) => vasodilation
Cardiogenic
Hypovolemic
Obstructive
Common Manifestations: tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, abnormal mental status, mottled skin, cold and clammy extremities, oliguria, hyperlactatemia, and metabolic acidosis


Systemic vasodilation
results in decreased perfusion the heart, brain, and kidneys => eventually organ damage
Capillary fluid leaks into the surrounding tissue causing further clinical deterioration with decreased systemic vascular resistance and abnormal oxygen utilization.
decreased CO, hypotension
Subtypes: septic, anaphylactic, neurogenic, toxic
risk factors: CKD, lots of lines, immunosuppression, recent surgery, old, cancer


release of inflammatory cytokines in the presence of sepsis
cytokines damage blood vessel walls, triggering clotting and forming tiny clots
fluid leaks!
Causes: pancreatitis, burns, HAI
Treatment: abx within 1 hour, IVF (crystalloid - Salt solutions used for fluid replacement that can easily move around the body), norepi to manage BP
Resus: 3-mL/kg first 3 hours of resus


severe hypersensitivity reaction that is mediated by IgE
results in the release of chemical mediators such as histamines, prostaglandins, leukotrienes
increases vascular permeability and subsequent decreased SVR, vasodilation, decreased perfusion to vital organs, and bronchoconstriction
Causes: exposure to an allergen (foods, latex, medications, animal venom, insect stings)
signature cue: exposure to an allergen such as medication, food, or insect sting
Manifestations: flushing, edema of the face and mouth, urticaria, hypotension, hoarseness, facial and oral edema, tachypnea, wheezing or stridor
FIRST LINE TX: IM EPI (give first before anything else), keep repeating until symptoms resolve => hold epi in muscle for 10 sec
remove cause of allergic rxn, IVF (crystalloids), corticosteroids, antihistamines, albuterol
Scenario: if giving abx & patient complains of itchiness and difficulty breathing, do the ff: 1. stop meds, 2. auscultate lungs, 3. epi


due to autonomic dysregulation caused by a primary and secondary spinal cord injury above the level of T6,
often associated with trauma to the cervical or thoracic vertebrae.
Primary injury: damage to axons, grey mater, and the anterior root
Secondary injury: causes electrolyte shifts, edema, and a vascular insult that leads to necrosis of the grey matter.
Causes: trauma, Guillain-Barre Syndrome, spinal anesthesia
Manifestations: brady cardia = unique symptom, flushed and warm skin, autonomic dysreflexia, temperature dysregulation, orthostatic hypotension, and bradyarrhythmias
Tx: IV NS ASAP


involves infection from Staphylococcus aureus and endotoxins from group A streptococcus
often resulting from the use of nasal or vaginal tampons
Other causes: burns, soft tissue or post-surgical infections, and dialysis catheters
manifestations: hypotension, rash resembling a sunburn, fever, and ultimately organ-failure related to vascular permeability.


intravascular volume is decreased, resulting in poor CO
result of blood loss or extracellular fluid loss
25-30% loss of volume
Hemorrhagic shock - insufficient perfusion of blood
inadequate O2 demands => anaerobic metabolism, by-product: lactic acid (leads to lactic acidosis => decreased cardiac contractility)
Coagulopathy: impaired coagulation as a result of blood loss
Signature cue: flattened neck veins and orthostatic hypotension
low central venous pressure (normal is 2-6 mmHg)
risk factors: trauma, Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm, PUD, maternal clients with bleeding risk
Nursing intervention: lower HOB (more perfusion to brain and core)
Note: infuse NS first before vasopressors (do not infuse vasopressors first!)
Put SPO2 on forehead instead of extremities for more accurate
Volume Loss Manifestations by %
<20% loss - anxiety, restlessness
20-40% loss - tachycardia, tachypnea, oliguria (dec. UOP), and orthostatic hypotension
40%+ loss: hypotension, severe tachycardia, and deteriorating mental status
Other manifestations: muscle cramps, thirst, abdominal or chest pain, lethargy, agitation, or confusion, decreased skin turgor, dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, cyanosis
Internal bleeding symptoms: hematemesis, bloody stool, and abdominal distention
Hemorrhagic Causes: trauma, rupture of esophageal varices GI bleed, aneurysm rupture, anticoags
Non-Hemorrhagic causes: excessive diuresis, burns, GI fluid loss, third spacing (ascites, edema, pleural effusion, interstitial shift)
Treatment: determine if hemorrhagic or not ASAP
Hemorrhagic: stop the bleed, administer blood products (PRBCs), FFP, plasma, large bor IV
Non-hemo: rapid infusion of warm isotonic crystalloids for a total of 30 mL/kg
do not give vasopressors in hypovolemic shock => it can worsen tissue perfusion (if given, infuse NS first)


Cardiac dysfunction causes myocardial ischemia => less CO => hypoperfusion
Compensatory mechanisms: peripheral vasoconstriction, tachycardia
Signature cues: chest pain and cardiac arrhythmias, narrowed pulse pressure, rhonchi, and distended jugular veins with elevated pulsations.
Causes: PE, metabolic acidosis, e- imbalance, cardiac nature
risk factors: 75 older, asian, pacific islander, female, DM, CVD, sepsis, obese
Signature manifestations: chest pain, arrhythmias, narrowed pulse pressure, ronchi, distented JV with pulsations
tx: goal is to restore optimal CO; vasopressors (norepi), inotropes (dobutamine, milrinone), IVF, treat cause or mechanical support
Positive Inotropic = more forceful beats, Double D's = Digoxin & Dopamine
Note: Dopamine can cause Tachycardia and Arrythmias (lower dose if this happens)
MCS: mechanical circulatory support. Examples: LVAD, balloon pump (IABP), ECMO, cardiac transplant


blood flow is blocked and circulation to the major organs is disrupted
examples: pulmonary embolism, tension pneumo, mechanical ventilation with high levels of PEEP
other examples: aortic dissection, pericardiac tamponade, pericardiac effusion, mass within heart
other Causes: tension pneumo, ventilation high VEEP, PE
Risk factors: atherosclerotic disease, uncontrolled HTN, coagulopathies resulting in increased clotting, cancer, AIDS, pulmonary HTN, respiratory diseases or surgeries requiring the use of mechanical ventilation, and thoracic trauma.
Sx for Tension pneumo: diminished or absent breath sounds, tracheal deviation, or neck vein distention
sx for Cardiac Tamponade: Beck’s triad (muffled heart sounds, hypotension, increase jugular venous pressure) in addition to experiencing dyspnea.
sx for Pulmonary Embolism: pulsus paradoxus, hemoptysis
sx for Pericarditis, p. effusion: pulsus paradoxus
sx Aortic Dissection: pulse deficit
tx - remove obstruction, vasopressors
Pulmonary Embolism: signature sign: hymoptysis, pulsus paradoxus


Initial Stage
Patho: Cellular hypoxia leads to anaerobic metabolism and lactic acid buildup
S/S: Often subtle; possible mild tachycardia and cool extremities
Compensatory Stage
Patho: Body activates compensatory mechanisms (SNS activation, RAAS system) to maintain perfusion, "FIGHT OR FLIGHT", peripheral vasoconstriction
S/S: Tachycardia, increased respiratory rate, cool/clammy skin, decreased urine output, altered mental status.
Progressive Stage
Patho: Compensatory mechanisms fail, resulting in worsening hypoxia and cellular dysfunction
S/S: Hypotension, weak pulses, severe confusion, anuria, metabolic acidosis, cold and clammy skin is priority in this stage
Refractory Stage - irreversible
Patho: Widespread organ failure with severe hypoxia and cellular death,
S/S: Profound hypotension, unresponsive state, multiple organ dysfunction, death imminent

Modified Early Warning Score (MEWS) - employed to identify risk of mortality and clinical deterioration based on SBP, RR, HR, mental status, and temperature.
Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy (CRRT)

A dialysis method used in critically ill patients who are unable to tolerate traditional intermittent hemodialysis.
provides continuous, slow filtration of waste products and fluids from the blood.
may cause pneumothorax
Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump (IABP)

ballon inflates during diastole with aortic valve closure causing blood from aorta to flow into circulation better
treatment for cardiogenic shock
requires informed consent
inserted into femoral artery
Lactate Levels: elevated indicates hypoxia (normal is 0.5 to 2.0 mmol/L)


Monitor BP: must be at least 90 sys, 65 MAP, oliguria (dec. UOP), anuria (no UOP)
insert central lines, art lines, etc
IVF, PRBC, blood
trend HD
Manage IV drips: pressors (norepi), inotropes (dobutamine, milrinone)
nutrition or TPN
abx
indwelling urinary catheter
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Valvular Dysfunctions
item.description:
abnormal function or structure of heart valve leading to impaired heart blood flow
leads the Heart Failure, cardiac arrest, death
can either be inability to fully open or close:
stenosis - narrowing, valves do not completely open; caused by calcification of the valves
regurgitation - backflow; valves do not close completely


congenital => born with it
rheumatic disease - infection from strep throat that was not treated promptly with antibiotics, leading to scarring of the heart valve
Endocarditis - infection of the inner layer of the heart, is caused by septicemia or intravenous drug use
Heart diseases: MI, hypertension, atherosclerosis of aorta, HF
Autoimmune: lupus, marfan syndrome (connective tissue disorder), high dose radiation, aging process


age (over 75)
inactivity
high fat/sodium/sugar diet
obesity
family hx
defibrillators/pacemakers
IV Drug use => risk for Endocarditis
Comorbidities: HTN, HLD, AFib, DM
Medical Procedures: dilation of L ventricle, radiation treatment
previous heart surgeries


Cardiac: chest pain, arrhythmia, heart murmur
Respiratory: dyspnea, PND (paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea)
Constitutional: fatigue, weakness
Neuro: dizziness
heart failure symptoms: lower extremity edema
FLASH PUMONARY EDEMA
abdominal pain from large liver; ascites
note: symptoms present when disease has progressed


Heart Failure
AFIB
Thromboembolism
Endocarditis
Sudden Death


echocardiogram - gold standard, measures pressure on each valve, EF
note: patients lie on LEFT side
normal EF: 50-70%
Transthoracic Echocardiogram (TTE)
Transesophageal Echocardiogram (TEE) - small transducer is introduced into the throat and passed down the esophagus into the stomach
CXR, MRI,
ECG - detects enlarged chambers (abrnomal)
Cardiac Catherization - aka angiogram, catheter is inserted into either an artery, dye used, then x-ray
Stress Test - exercise to determine capacity

Drug Therapy:

Beta blockers: lower BP/HR
CCB - C = calms the heart (low BP, low HR)
Digoxin - Increase contractility, decrease HR, cardiac remodeling!
Diuretics
Vasodilators
Surgical

Valve repair
balloon valvuloplasty
minimally invasive procedure that expands the openings of stenosed valves
small catheter is threaded into a vessel in the groin and advanced into the heart
At the end of the catheter is a balloon, which is guided into the narrowed heart valve
balloon is inflated to dilate the valve, and the leaflets of the valve are separated
valve replacement - from cow, pig, human, mechanical/artificial
Mechanical valves: must be younger than 65; must take Warfarin forever
Biological valves: older than 65, kidney disease, warfarin, pregnant, increased risk for bleeding
Lifestyle mods


Heart Failure Care: daily weights, fluid balance


infection prevention - dental hygiene; brush and floss regularly
report signs of infection
monitor for bleeding: PTT, INR => Coags
Maintain consistent intake of vitamin K
monitor for DVT
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Addison vs Cushing
item.description:
Inverse of each other!

Cushing's Disease (Excess Cortisol)
Everything is elevated except potassium
“CUSH” - Cortisol Up, Sugar High
• ↑ Cortisol
• ↑ Sodium (hypernatremia)
• ↑ Glucose (hyperglycemia)
• ↑ BP (hypertension)
• ↓ Potassium (hypokalemia)
• Skin fragile, truncal obesity, moon face, buffalo hump

Addison's Disease (Adrenal Insufficiency)
“ADD” - All Down in Deficiency
Everything is decreased except potassium
• ↓ Cortisol
• ↓ Sodium (hyponatremia)
• ↓ Glucose (hypoglycemia)
• ↓ BP (hypotension)
• ↑ Potassium (hyperkalemia)
• Skin pigmentation (bronze tone)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Addison's Disease
item.description:
ADD => add the steroids!, added stress will kill!
chronic condition caused by insufficient production of cortisol and aldosterone by the adrenal cortex
aka primary adrenal insufficiency
