Possible signs of sepsis (altered mental status, respiratory distress)
cloudy dialysis fluid (if on peritoneal dialysis)


Septicemia - spread of bacteria and toxins in blood stream
Sepsis - body's systemic response to an infection; leading cause of death from peritonitis


Clinical assessment (rigid abdomen, rebound tenderness)
CMP - elevated CK, BUN (d/t )
CBC (leukocytosis)
Blood cultures
Abdominal X-ray (check for free air from perforation)
CT scan (source of infection)
Peritoneal fluid analysis (bacteria, WBCs) => abdominal tap or paracentesis


IV antibiotics
Fluid resuscitation
NG tube for decompression PRN
Pain management
Surgery for perforation or abscess drainage
Peritoneal lavage if severe infection


NPO, progress accordingly
Avoid gas producing foods: carbonated
Avoid Irritating foods: spicy, high-fat
Once recovered: high protein/high calorie diet to support recovery, high fiber meals


Monitor vital signs for sepsis (fever, tachycardia, hypotension)
Assess for worsening pain or rigidity
Maintain NPO status
Administer IV fluids and antibiotics
Manage NG tube if present
Provide pain relief
Prepare for possible surgical intervention
Educate on infection prevention and post-op care
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: BPH
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


non-cancerous enlargement of prostate gland; Benign Prostate Hyperplasia
common in aging males
Leads to various urinary disorders: Retention, bladder outflow obstruction, urethra constriction


hormonal changes (DHT or dihydrotestosterone, estrogen imbalance)
aging


men over 50
family history
obesity, Metabolic Syndrome, HTN, DM


increased urinary frequency and urgency
weak urine stream
hesitancy
straining
dysuria
nocturia - frequent night time urination
decreased QOL/sef-esteem


urinary retention
UTI, urisepsis
bladder stones
hydronephrosis - kidney damage from backlflow


PSA - prostate specific antigen test
screen for prostate cancer


Alpha blockers: Cardura
Tamsulosin (flomax) - relax smooth muscles in prostate and bladder neck
5-Alpha Reductase Inhibitors
Surgery: prostatectomy for super large prostates over 100g
Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP) = gold standard
TURP - a surgeon inserts a thin tube called a resectoscope through the urethra and into the prostate. The resectoscope has a camera and an electrical loop that cuts away excess prostate tissue. The tissue is removed in small pieces, which are flushed out of the bladder

indwelling cather needed postop to monitor UOP and bleeding
cloudy urine = infection
expected: temporary dribbling and leakage postop (ALL NORMAL)
expected: urge to urinate following procedure (ATI), poor sphincter control
expected: blood tinged urine postop (a few days)
expected: burning & pain


Monitor for urinary retention, bladder distention
Educate on medication side effects (dizziness, hypotension)
Encourage timed voiding, fluid management (avoid evening fluids)
Post-TURP: monitor for bleeding, continuous bladder irrigation (CBI)
Teach patients to avoid bladder irritants (caffeine, alcohol)
Reinforce importance of follow-ups for PSA and symptom monitoring


sterile saline fluids to flush clots from the bladder after surgery
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Incontinence
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


involuntary loss of urine
Types:

Stress - caused by weakness of the urethral sphincter or the pelvic floor muscles, involuntarily urine leakage with sneezing, coughing, or physical exertion.
Urge - detrusor muscle overactivity that causes bladder contraction, or; loss of neurologic control or by irritation of the bladder.
Overflow - urine leakage of an overdistended bladder, which is caused by a bladder obstruction that blocks urine excretion or impaired contractility of the detrusor muscle. Bladder obstruction causes of the distended bladder include pelvic organ prolapse, abdominal or pelvic masses, or BPH.
Iatrogenic - caused by medical treatments or interventions like Diuretics, sedatives, surgeries that affect bladder function
Mixed - combination of urge and stress


usually temporary; usually d/t food irritants: alcohol, spicy, sugary, caffeine, carbonated.
Meds: diuretics, BP meds, Doxazosin (cardura), antidepressantsm CCB, ACEi


coughing - stress incontinence
Heart Failure - fluid overload
Neurologic conditions: MS
MSK disorders, mobility issues


stress test: cough
Check for UTI: UA
bladder scan to check post-void residual volume (result of greater than 200mL = overflow incontinence)


Urinary antispasmodics, such as oxybutynin (Ditropan XL)
bladder relaxants, such as Mirabegron (myrbetriq)
Bladder Training - urinating at set time intervals
Pelvic Floor Muscle Training - kegels
Catheters - use judiciously to minimize UTI, can help avoid skin breakdown
Alternative urine collection: condom cath, purewick


falls precautions
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Retention
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


unable to empty bladder


Obstruction: prostate enlargement, urethral structure, renal stone, pelvic mass, stenosis of bladder neck
Underactive Bladder - weak bladder muscles from aging or neuro problems (MS, Parkinsons, stroke, DM, meds)
Medications: anticholinergics, opioids, anesthesia, antihistamines
Postop: anesthesia, prolonged catherization


BPH
cervical cancer
old age - underactive bladder
pregnant - underactive bladder
pelvic organ prolapse
recent surgery
Diabetes
history of pelvic injury


slow urine stream
feeling of full bladder
urge to void
bladder discomfort
distended bladder
200 mL post void residual (PVR) = inadequate emptying
400 mL = urinary retention
Normal PVR: <20mL, 50-100mL for elderly


UTI from urine stasis
Bladder overdistention - loss of bladder tone
Hydronephrosis: kidney damage from backflow
Renal Failure


UA
culture for UTI
Bladder scan: check post void residual scan (PVR)
PSA for BPH
Check for infection: CBC
Check for renal dysfunction/electrolyte imbalance: CMP


treat cause: BPH => 5-Alpha Reductase Inhibitors, Tamsulosin, TURP
urinary strictures: endoscopy urethral dilation
catheterization


Monitor urinary output and bladder distention
Teach catheter care if self-catheterization is required
Educate on medication effects and side effects
Encourage scheduled voiding to prevent overdistention
Assess for UTI symptoms and complications
Provide post-op care if surgical intervention is done
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: UTI
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


broad term indicating infection in bladder, kidneys, ureters/urethra
females more at risk d/t anatomy
Based on Severity

Uncomplicated UTI - or cystitis occurs when the bladder becomes infected with bacteria but there are no comorbidities present.
Complicated UTI - clients who have comorbidities, such as diabetes, who are pregnant, or immunocompromised
Based on Location

Lower UTI: Cystitis - inflammation of the bladder
Lower UTI: Urethritis - inflammation of the urethra
Upper UTI: Pylonephritis - infection of the renal pelvis and kidney
Upper UTI: Ureteritis - less
Based on Source of Infection

Community-Acquired UTI → Occurs in individuals outside healthcare settings
Nosocomial (Hospital-Acquired) UTI → Acquired in a healthcare setting, often associated with urinary catheters (Catheter-Associated UTI or CAUTI)


e.coli - #1 cause; bacteria travels up urethra into the bladder
indwelling catheters
sexual intercourse
pregnancy
poor hygiene


female
frequent pelvic exams
diaphragms
condoms with spermicidal foam
Comorbidities: Diabetes T1, Diabetes T2, immunocompromised


Old fucks: CONFUSION, agitation
Lower UTI: dysuria, urinary frequency/urgency, suprapubic pain, cloudy, foul urine, hematuria
Upper UTI: fever, chills, flank pain (kidney pain), N/V, fatigue, malaise (see Pylonephritis)


Urosepsis - systemic infection that starts in urogenital tract
CKD
Retention


Clean Catch Urinalysis - clean labia three times with sterile wipes, front to back, catch midstream
dipstick urine testing
Urine culture - also midstream
BUN - CMP


antibiotics (Bactrim) - based on culture results
Analgesia
cranberry juice
hydration


encourage hydration
educate proper hygiene
void before/after intercourse
Avoid bladder irritants: caffeine, alcohol, spicy
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: AKI
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


interchangeable term: Acute Kidney Failure (ARF)
sudden onset and usually reversible decrease in kidney function
can progress to CKD and ESRD if not treated
3 Categories
Prerenal - most common, reduced blood flow to kidneys

caused by hypotension, hypovolemia, Heart Failure, Liver failure, renal artery stenosis
Vasodilation: sepsis, anaphylaxis
common cause: Cirrhosis
meds: NSAIDs, ARBs, ACEi, cyclosporine
ATI Tip: aka "Pre-renal Azotemia: - caused by a decrease in blood flow to the kidneys, known as renal hypoperfusion
Intrarenal - direct Kidney Damage (renal cortex and renal medulla)

caused by nephrotoxic agents: contrast dyes, NSAID, aminoglycosides, vancomycin
Acute Tubular Necrosis: deadly, renal tubules become damaged and die, GFT decreases
Glomerulonephritis, lupus nephritis
Rhabdomyolysis
Hemolysis
Postrenal - obstruction of urine flow

Renal Calculi, BPH
tumors, strictures, neurogenic bladder
other ureteral obstructions


sepsis, shock
Nephrotoxic drugs: NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, contrast dyes, ACEi)
kidney disease, diabetes, HTN
major surgery, trauma, burns (fluid loss, rhabdo risk
elderly


Oliguria (<400 mL/day) or Anuria (<100 mL/day) in severe cases
Azotemia (↑ BUN & creatinine) → Causes nausea, confusion, fatigue
Fluid overload → Edema, hypertension, pulmonary congestion
Hyperkalemia → ECG changes (peaked T waves, arrhythmias) => kidneys unable to excrete potassium, it builds up
Metabolic acidosis → Kussmaul respirations
Uremic symptoms (pruritus, anorexia, altered mental status)**


e- imbalance
pulmonary edema, Heart Failure
Metabolic acidosis (kussmaul breathing
infection, sepsis
CKD, ESRD


Serum creatinine & BUN → Increased (hallmark of AKI)
GFR → Decreased
Urinalysis → Casts, protein, hematuria (intrarenal causes)
Electrolytes → Hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia
Renal ultrasound → Identifies obstruction (postrenal causes)
Fractional Excretion of Sodium (FeNa) → Low in prerenal, high in intrarenal AKI


Prerenal AKI → IV fluids (if hypovolemic), vasopressors if shock
Intrarenal AKI → Avoid nephrotoxins, manage underlying disease
Postrenal AKI → Relieve obstruction (catheter, surgery)
correct e- imbalance or acidosis
Diuretics for fluid overload
Dialysis if severe


#1 priority: e- imbalance, fluid overload, hyperkalemia, cardiac output
adjust nephrotoxic drugs
hydr8


Vancomycin
Tetracycline
Pantoprazole
Omeprazole
Methotrexate
Lithium
Cortisone
Cimetidine
Aspirin 
Allopurinol
Acetaminophen
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: CKD
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


gradual loss of kidney function over time
will lead to ESRD
Differences between AKI:

AKI is usually reversible, CKD is not
CKD is progressive, AKI is sudden (hence the term "acute")

Just note that normal GFR is ≥ 90


Diabetes T2 => most common cause (Diabetes T1 can also be cause but less rare)
Hypertension
Glomerulonephritis
Polycystic Kidney Disease
Obstructions like Renal Calculi, BPH, tumors
Chronic use of NSAIDs


Metabolic Syndrome
smoking
higher risk: Asian, Hispanic, and Black
male 65 and older


Early stage (mild to moderate): no symptoms in earlier stages; can be vague symptoms like fatigue, edema, changes in urination
Fluid overload: edema, jugular vein distention, crackles in lungs, uncontrolled hypertension
anemia (causes fatigue) => because of low EPO (produced by the kidneys), EPO produces RBC
e- imbalance
metabolic acidosis
Neuro: lethargy, confusion, hand tremors, sleep disturbances, unusual behavior, and decreased mental sharpness
pruritus (itchy skin)
urine changes: dark, foamy, bloody urine
metallic taste in mouth
poor appetite & unintentional weight loss
Uremic Pericarditis: S3 gallop or pericardial friction rub may be present
uremic frost crystals - crystals form on the skin because your kidneys are so shot that waste builds up in your blood, causing it to sweat out and leave nasty, gritty white crystals all over you


ESRD
Anemia: decreased erythropoietin production leads to lower red blood cell count
Cardiovascular Disease: Increased risk of heart attack, stroke, or heart failure due to CKD's effect on blood vessels constant fluid overload
Metabolic Acidosis
Electrolyte Imbalances: Such as hyperkalemia (high potassium) or hyperphosphatemia
Bone Mineral Disorder: Alterations in calcium and phosphate balance, leading to weakened bones.


GFR
CMP: BUN, Creatinine, e-
UA: + for protein or blood
Urine Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio: A marker for kidney damage.
Ultrasound or CT Scan: To evaluate kidney size, cysts, or obstructions.
Kidney Biopsy: In some cases, to determine the exact cause of CKD.


fluid restrictions
Diuretics
Manage BP: Hypertension meds: ACEi, ARBS
Diet: low protein (to reduce kidney workload = avoid uremia), Na + K restrictions
Manage anemia: ESA and iron supplements
Dialysis: hemo or peritoneal for ESRD
Kidney transplant for ESRD


strict I/O
monitor daily weight
control blood glucose
avoid nephrotoxins: NSAID, smoking, alcohol


limit: phosphate, potassium, sodium => hard to excrete
protein restriction


Monitor vital signs (BP, HR, temp) before, during, and after dialysis.
Weigh the patient before and after dialysis to assess fluid removal.
Care for the dialysis access site, checking for infection, clotting, or poor flow.
Monitor for electrolyte imbalances and adjust dialysis as needed.
Hold medications like antihypertensives before dialysis.
Educate the patient on treatment, diet, fluid restrictions, and adherence.
Watch for complications like dialysis disequilibrium syndrome, air embolism, or bleeding.
Provide emotional and psychosocial support to manage chronic illness.
Ensure proper anticoagulation and monitor post-dialysis for side effects (hypotension, cramps).
Practice infection control and aseptic technique when accessing the dialysis port.


Excess Fluid Volume - Related to decreased kidney filtration, fluid retention.
Risk for Electrolyte Imbalance - Related to impaired renal function, decreased excretion of electrolytes.
Imbalanced Nutrition: Less Than Body Requirements - Related to decreased appetite, nausea, and vomiting.
Fatigue - Related to anemia, uremia, altered metabolism, decreased kidney function.
Risk for Infection - Related to impaired immune system, dialysis access sites.
Risk for Impaired Skin Integrity - Related to edema, frequent dialysis, uremic pruritus.
Disturbed Body Image - Related to physical changes (e.g., edema, dialysis access devices).
Activity Intolerance - Related to decreased oxygenation, fatigue, and weakness.
Risk for Impaired Gas Exchange - Related to pulmonary edema, fluid overload, respiratory distress.
Chronic Pain - Related to renal disease, uremic pruritus, musculoskeletal pain.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Dialysis
item.description:
A medical procedure that replaces the function of the kidneys when they are no longer able to filter waste, toxins, and excess fluids from the blood.
Function of Dialysis:

remove excess fluid + electrolytes
acid-base balance
remove waste products
restore homeostasis thru osmosis, diffusion, ultra-filtration
Types of Dialysis:
Hemodialysis: Blood is filtered through a machine outside the body to remove waste and excess fluids.
Peritoneal Dialysis: Uses the lining of the abdomen (peritoneum) to filter blood inside the body by infusing a dialysis solution into the abdomen.
Dialysis Access Sites
Hemodialysis: Fistulas, grafts, or central venous catheters (CVC)
Peritoneal Dialysis: Catheter inserted into the abdominal cavity
Dialysis Procedure
Hemodialysis: Blood is removed, cleaned, and returned to the body via a machine over a 3-5 hour period, typically 3 times a week.
Peritoneal Dialysis: Dialysate fluid is infused into the abdomen, where it absorbs waste and excess fluid, and is then drained out, typically performed daily.
Considerations for Fistula

assess patency: presence of bruit, palpable thrill, distal pulses, circulation
Avoid the fistula sight! do not: measure BP, inject, venipuncture.
Elevate site after fistula creation
Have protamine sulfate ready to reverse heparin.


Renal insufficiency: CKD, AKI, ESRD
Medication or illicit drug toxicity
Persistent hyperkalemia
Pulmonary edema
severe Hypertension
hypervolemia that does not respond to diuretics


Hemodialysis: Infection at the access site, hypotension, muscle cramps, blood clots, anemia
Peritoneal Dialysis: Peritonitis 1, catheter infection, fluid imbalance, inadequate dialysis
DDS: Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome

patients new to dialysis can develop d/t rapid removal of solutes and changes in blood ph
look for: BUN above 175
manifestations: headaches, N/V, decreased LOC, seizures, restlessness
severe: confusion, seizures, coma, death


Priority: monitor for K! (RBCs are not affected by Dialysis)
monitor kidney function values: BUN, creatinine
Assess for signs of complications (e.g., infection, fluid overload)
Provide education on dietary restrictions, fluid intake, and medication adherence
Encourage psychological support due to the chronic nature of dialysis treatment


Risk for Infection related to dialysis access site (e.g., fistula, catheter) and immune suppression.
Imbalanced Nutrition: Less than Body Requirements related to dietary restrictions and altered metabolism due to kidney dysfunction.
Fluid Volume Excess related to impaired renal function and fluid retention.
Fatigue related to dialysis procedure and chronic kidney disease.
Risk for Electrolyte Imbalance related to dialysis treatment, particularly changes in potassium, calcium, and sodium levels.


Fluid restriction
Limit Na
Limit K (bananas, beans, potatoes, oranges, tomatoes, spinach, avocados)
High protein to prevent muscle loss (dialysis removes protein in blood but for CKD patients that are not undergoing dialysis, limiting protein may be indicate to prevent Uremia)
Uremia - buildup of waste products in the blood due to kidney failure
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: ESRD
item.description:
End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD)


Final stage of CKD where kidneys can no longer maintain fluid, electrolyte, and waste balance
GFR < 15 mL/min, requiring dialysis or kidney transplant for survival
Leads to multisystem complications due to accumulation of toxins, fluid overload, and hormonal imbalances
RIFLE Criteria for AKI (from mild to very bad)

Risk: Increased creatinine x1.5 or GFR decrease >25% with urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hr for 6 hrs
Injury: Increased creatinine x2 or GFR decrease >50% with urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hr for 12 hrs
Failure: Increased creatinine x3 or GFR decrease >75% or creatinine ≥4 mg/dL with urine output <0.3 mL/kg/hr for 24 hrs or anuria for 12 hrs
Loss: Persistent AKI requiring dialysis for >4 weeks
End-stage kidney disease: Dialysis dependence for >3 months


Diabetes mellitus (Diabetic nephropathy) → Leading cause
Hypertension → Chronic high BP damages glomeruli
Polycystic Kidney Disease
Glomerulonephritis (chronic inflammation damaging nephrons)
Autoimmune diseases (Lupus, IgA nephropathy)
Obstructive uropathy (chronic kidney stones, BPH, reflux nephropathy)


Uncontrolled diabetes & hypertension
Family history of kidney disease
Obesity, smoking, high-sodium diet
Nephrotoxic medications (NSAIDs, aminoglycosides)
African American, Hispanic, Native American ethnicity (higher prevalence of diabetes & HTN)


Fluid overload → Edema, pulmonary congestion, hypertension
Uremia (toxin buildup) → Fatigue, confusion, pruritus, nausea, metallic taste
Electrolyte imbalances → Hyperkalemia (dysrhythmias), metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia
Anemia → Pallor, weakness (decreased erythropoietin production)
Bone disease (renal osteodystrophy) → Bone pain, fractures (due to calcium/phosphorus imbalance)
Cardiovascular complications → Heart failure, pericarditis, arrhythmias


Cardiovascular disease (leading cause of death in ESRD patients)
Hyperkalemia-induced cardiac arrest
Pulmonary edema from fluid overload
Infections (weakened immune system, dialysis access site infections)
Uremic encephalopathy (neurological dysfunction from toxin buildup)
Malnutrition (protein-energy wasting common in dialysis patients)


Serum creatinine & BUN → Significantly elevated, see CMP
GFR < 15 mL/min → Diagnostic of ESRD
Electrolytes (↑K+, ↓Ca2+, ↑Phosphate, metabolic acidosis)
Hemoglobin & hematocrit (↓ due to erythropoietin deficiency)
Renal ultrasound → Small, atrophied kidneys (except in PKD)


Dialysis (Hemodialysis or Peritoneal Dialysis)
Kidney transplant (preferred long-term solution)
Fluid & dietary restrictions (low sodium, potassium, phosphorus, and protein moderation)
Erythropoietin-stimulating agents (epoetin alfa) for anemia
Phosphate binders (calcium acetate, sevelamer) to prevent bone disease
Vitamin D & calcium supplements to manage hypocalcemia
Blood pressure & glucose control to slow progression in early CKD


Monitor fluid status (daily weights, edema, lung sounds, BP)
Assess for dialysis complications (hypotension, infection, disequilibrium syndrome)
Monitor potassium levels & cardiac rhythm (risk of hyperkalemia-induced arrhythmias)
Educate on dietary restrictions (low sodium, potassium, phosphorus, and controlled protein intake)
Administer medications safely (adjust dosages for renal impairment, avoid nephrotoxic drugs)
Assess for uremic symptoms (pruritus, confusion, nausea)
Encourage adherence to treatment plan (dialysis schedule, medications, diet)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Glomerulonephritis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


inflammation of the glomeruli, impairs kidney function => more waste in blood steam, e- imbalance, loss of blood RBC and protein
can be acute or chronic
results in proteinuria, azotemia, hematuria
proteinuria => elevated cholesterol, HTN, edema
severity is classified based on proteinuria of greater than 3.5g/day and edema
Azotemia - elevated N2 waste products such as urea and creatinine
Acute - primary renal cause or by an illness that impairs renal function
Chronic - progressive, leads to ESRD


streptococcal infection - most common; usually after a strep throat (Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus)
Endocarditis - also linked to gn (watch out for cardiac valve replacement)
Autoimmune diseases (Lupus, IgA nephropathy, Goodpasture’s syndrome)
Vasculitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis, polyarteritis nodosa)
Diabetes mellitus (Diabetic nephropathy leading to glomerular damage)
Bacterial endocarditis, viral infections (Hepatitis B, C, HIV)


see causes
family history of kidney disease
Drug toxicity: NSAID, abx, illegal drugs


periorbital edema: hallmark symptom
decreased eGFR (normal is greater than 60/ml/min)
dark and frothy urine
decreased UOP
elevated BP - from fluid overload and RAAS activation
infection: fever, malaise, weakness
abdominal discomfort


CKD that can lead to ESRD
Acute Kidney Injury
Nephrotic Syndrome - severe protein loss, high cholesterol, edema
Pulmonary edema, Heart Failure, due to fluid overload
Hypertensive crisis from uncontrolled BP


CMP - check e-, elevated K, BUN, creatinine
GFR: down
UA: RBC, WBC, protein, casts => indicates glomerular damage
Kidney Biopsy
CXR: pulmonary edema
US


goal: manage cause, avoid CKD and ESRD
Corticosteroids: prednisone for anti-inflammation and immune suppression
Abx if caused by stre[
Diuretics: manage edema
ACEi/ARBs - control BP, reduce proteinuria
Dialysis: for AKI or ESRD
Diet restriction: low Na, K, protein, fluid restriction


#1 Priority: manage BP as this can lead to further kidney damage
Second level priority: decreased UOP
salt restriction
more severe: Na, K, protein restriction to slow progression
Lifestyle: smoking, DM, HTN
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Nephrotic Syndrome
item.description:
Kidney disorder with massive proteinuria (> 3 g/24 h) leading to hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.
Results from injury to the glomerular filtration barrier (podocyte / basement‑membrane damage).


Primary glomerular: minimal‑change disease (children), FSGS, membranous nephropathy
Secondary: diabetes, systemic lupus erythematosus, infections (HIV, hepatitis B/C), malignancies, drugs (NSAIDs, lithium).


Diabetes or long‑standing hypertension.
Autoimmune disease (e.g., SLE).
Chronic infections, Hepatitis, HIV-AIDS.
Nephrotoxic medications (NSAIDs).
Genetic podocyte defects; family history of renal disease.


Generalized pitting edema (periorbital → dependent).
Frothy or foamy urine.
Weight gain, ascites, anasarca in severe cases.
Possible hypertension.
Fatigue, loss of appetite.


Thromboembolism (loss of antithrombin III).
Infections (loss of IgG, edema‑related skin breakdown).
AKI / progressive CKD
Hyperlipidemia → atherosclerosis.
Hypocalcemia, vitamin D deficiency, malnutrition.


Urinalysis: 3+ – 4+ protein, oval fat bodies, lipiduria.
24‑h urine protein or random protein/creatinine ratio.
Serum: ↓ albumin / total protein, ↑ cholesterol & triglycerides, possible ↓ Ca²⁺.
Kidney biopsy to identify underlying lesion (in adults).
Ultrasound to assess kidney size/rule out obstruction.


Edema management: sodium (< 2 g/day) & fluid restriction, loop diuretics, IV albumin + furosemide in refractory edema.
RAAS blockade: ACE I or ARB to cut proteinuria and protect kidney.
Statins for hyperlipidemia.
Anticoagulation if high thrombotic risk (e.g., serum albumin < 2 g/dL).
Immunosuppressants (steroids, calcineurin inhibitors, cyclophosphamide) for immune‑mediated causes.
Tight glycemic and BP control in diabetic or hypertensive patients.


Daily weights, strict I&O, edema map.
Monitor vital signs, especially BP; watch for orthostatic changes.
Assess skin integrity, provide pressure‑relief mattress, elevate edematous limbs.
Monitor labs (albumin, electrolytes, lipids, creatinine).
Administer diuretics in AM; monitor for hypovolemia/ototoxicity.
Implement infection precautions; obtain cultures if fever.


Adhere to low‑sodium diet; limit processed foods.
Take medications exactly as prescribed; do not stop steroids abruptly.
Weigh yourself daily; report sudden gain > 2 lb (1 kg) in 24 h.
Recognize signs of infection (fever) and clots (leg pain, chest pain).
Avoid NSAIDs and nephrotoxic agents unless approved.
Schedule regular follow‑ups and lab checks; keep vaccinations current (pneumococcal, flu).
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pylonephritis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


kidney infection
Ascending infection: develops from lower UTI where bacteria travels from urethra=>bladder=>ureters=>kidney
2 Types:

Acute - abrupt swelling
Chronic - aka reflux nephropathy, is much rarer than the acute condition and is diagnosed when repeated bouts of acute pyelonephritis occur usually in clients with urinary obstructions


e.coli
other bacteria (klebsiella, etc)
obstruction: BPH, stones, strictures (narrowing of urinary tract)
Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) (backward urine flow from bladder to kidneys)
prolonged catheterization


females
renal stones
kidney or bladder disorders
immunosuppression
enlarged prostate
urinary catheters
Diabetes => can lead to emphysematous pyelonephritis, which is a necrotizing infection that destroys the kidney tissues


fever over 102F
pain in side, back, or groin
dysuria
cloudy or bloody urine
fishy odor urine
General infection sx: chills, N/V, fatigue
mental confusion


Emphysematous Pyelonephritis
Renal Abscesses => pus in kidney
Thrombosis in Renal Vein
Acute Renal Failure
Hypertension d/t kidney damage


UA with culture
CBC
Renal US
DMSA - dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) test would show any scarring in the urinary tract due to pyelonephritis using a radioactive material injected into the arm then images are taken during the material’s passage through the kidneys.


abx, levofloxacin, ampicillin


educate: wipe from front to back
Assess CVA tenderness
monitor BUN, creatinine, UOP
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Renal Calculi
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary
#nursing #medsurg #genitourinary


kidney stones, nephrolithiasis, or urolithiasis
caused by accumulation of minerals and salts that lodge in the kidney or urinary tract = pain, hematuria


Dehydration: most common
Calcium Oxalate (most common) in urine => too much vitamin C!
Calcium Phosphate
uric acid (look out for gout)
struvite
cystine stones: genetic
Hyperparathyroidism


diet: high sodium, high oxalate( spinach, nuts, chocolate), high purine (red meat, alcohol, shellfishh)
environmental: extreme heat and sun exposure = e- imbalance
lifestyle
genetic: family hx
gout (uric aid stone)
age: 43 and older
male: twice as likely
obesity
frequent UTI
Diabetes T2
CKD
HTN


severe flank pain with acute oset
N/V
infection: fever, malaise, etc
If presents with Pylonephritis, surgery may be required


Urinary Obstruction => hydronephrosis (kidney swelling) => HIGH PRIORITY
Pylonephritis, sepsis
AKI


UA: check RBC, WBC, crystals
Non-contrast CT = gold standard
Renal US: useful for pregnant patients, children
KUB X-ray (Kidney, Ureter, Bladder)


observation: if stones are small (<5mm)
Tamsulosin (alpha blockers): relax ureter muscles for easier stone passage
CCB: for vasodilation (do not use if hypotensive)
Analgesia
Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) → Breaks stones using sound waves
Ureteroscopy with stone removal → For larger or impacted stones
Percutaneous nephrolithotomy → For large or complex stones


risk for obstruction( dec UOP, pain, hematuria)
risk for infection
strain urine to collect stone
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Renal Transplant
item.description:
indications: ESRD, dependence on Dialysis
must have donor recipient tissue match
best donor: living donors, alternatives: non-heart-beating, cadaver
Other indications:

anuria
proteinuria
Marked azotemia (elevated blood urea nitrogen [BUN] and blood creatinine)
Severe electrolyte imbalance (hyperkalemia, hypernatremia)
Fluid volume excess conditions (heart failure, pulmonary edema)
Uremic lung


age younger than 2
older than 70 => age group has more comorbidities and risk factors
Advanced, untreatable cardiac disease
Active or recent cancer
Chemical dependency
Chronic infections or systemic diseases (HIV, hepatitis B or C)
Coagulopathies and certain immune disorders
Obesity (BMI > 35 kg/m2)Diabetes mellitus
Chronic pulmonary disease
Untreated gastrointestinal diseases, such as peptic ulcer disease


schedule assessments: labs, bleeding times, blood type, cross match
initiate: abx
Immunosuppressants: corticosteroids, anti-rejection meds, cyclosporine
Cyclosporine - immunosuppressive agent used to treat organ rejection post-transplant


vitals q15, advance to q1hr
monitor UOP => expected: 30ml/hr
daily weight
monitor infection, e-, organ rejection


turn, cough, deep breathe, ambulate

Low-fat to decrease cholesterol High-fiber to avoid constipation Increased protein to promote healing, and rebuild and maintain muscle mass Adequate intake of potassium, calcium, and phosphorus Restricted sodium intake to prevent fluid retention and hypertension especially when taking prednisone Avoidance of concentrated sugars or carbohydrates to control glycemic factors when on prednisone Magnesium supplements because cyclosporine can reduce magnesium levels​​​​​​​
Note: avoid grapefruit => causes increased cyclosporine blood levels, when taking cyclosporine.


classified based on timing
Hyperacute

within 48 hours after surgery
small blood clots to form in the transplanted kidney
irreversible
fever, hypertension, pain
treatment: removal of kidney
Acute

1 week to 2 years after surgery
body destroys the donor kidney => vasculitis, cellular destruction starts with inflammation
Oliguria, anuria, low-grade fever, hypertension, tenderness over the transplanted kidney, lethargy, azotemia, and fluid retention
Treatment: Involves increased doses of immunosuppressive medications
Chronic

gradually over months to years
Blood vessel injury from overgrowth of the smooth muscles of the blood vessels causing fibrotic tissue to replace normal tissue, resulting in a nonfunctioning donor kidney
gradual return of azotemia, fluid retention, electrolyte imbalance, and fatigue
Treatment: Conservative (monitor kidney status, continue immunosuppressive therapy) until dialysis is required


Renal artery stenosis is due to scarring of surgical anastomosis.
findings: hypertension, bruit, decreased kidney function: oliguria, elevated BUN & Cr
task: kidney scan to verify renal blood flow
treatment: angioplasty or surgery
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: SIADH
item.description:
SI = "soaked inside", same amount of koolaid but diluted with too much water => hyponatremia (no flavor), low osmolality
condition characterized by excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) => aka too much VASOPRESSIN
causes water retention, dilutional hyponatremia, and low serum osmolality.
Commonly associated with malignancies, neurological disorders, and certain medications.
Note: Diabetes Insipidus is the direct opposite of SIADH
Note: ADH is also called Vasopressin, so in order to treat SIADH, Vasopressin ANTAGONISTS are used (Tolvaptan, Conivaptan) => only in severe cases


Cancer: Small cell lung cancer (common test question), pancreatic cancer, leukemia.
CNS disorders: Stroke, TBI, Meningitis, brain tumors.
Pulmonary conditions: Pneumonia, tuberculosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
Medications: SSRIs, opioids, antipsychotics, chemotherapy agents.
Postoperative stress: Surgical procedures, especially brain or thoracic surgeries.
mnemonic: SSS
S - small cell lung cancer
S - severe brain trauma
S - sepsis infections of brain (meningitis)


Elderly individuals: More prone to impaired water balance.
Cancer patients: Particularly with small cell lung cancer.
Neurological disorders: Brain trauma, infections, and strokes increase risk.
Certain medications: Drugs that enhance ADH secretion or action.


Neurological symptoms: Headache, confusion, irritability, seizures, coma (due to hyponatremia).
Gastrointestinal symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, anorexia.
Fluid retention: Weight gain, without edema (since fluid is retained intracellularly).
Cardiovascular effects: Hypertension, bounding pulses, jugular vein distension.
Urinary changes: Decreased UOP, concentrated urine with high specific gravity.


Severe hyponatremia (<120 mEq/L): Can lead to seizures, coma, and death.
Cerebral edema: Due to water shifting into brain cells, leading to increased intracranial pressure (ICP).
Pulmonary edema: Fluid overload can impair respiratory function.


ADH elevated (normal 1-5 ng/L)
Low serum sodium (<135 mEq/L).
Low serum osmolality (<280 mOsm/kg) => normal is 275-290 mOsm/kg
Normal or high urine sodium.
High urine osmolality (>100 mOsm/kg).
High urine specific gravity (>1.030). => normal range is between 1.005 and 1.030.
ADH levels: Increased despite normal or expanded intravascular volume.


Fluid restriction: First-line treatment (500–1000 mL/day) to prevent further dilutional hyponatremia.
Hypertonic saline (3%): For severe hyponatremia, given cautiously to prevent rapid sodium shifts.
Diuretics (loop diuretics like furosemide): To promote free water excretion if sodium is >125 mEq/L.
Demeclocycline: A tetracycline that blocks ADH action in kidneys.
Vasopressin receptor antagonists (Tolvaptan, Conivaptan): Block ADH effect in severe cases.


Monitor sodium levels closely to prevent complications of rapid correction (e.g., central pontine myelinolysis).
Assess for neurological changes: Confusion, restlessness, seizures, and coma.
Strict fluid intake and output (I&O) monitoring to prevent fluid overload.
Daily weights to detect fluid retention.
Implement seizure precautions for patients with severe hyponatremia.
Educate patients on fluid restrictions and symptoms of worsening SIADH.


Excess fluid volume related to water retention.
Risk for electrolyte imbalance related to hyponatremia.
Risk for injury related to confusion, seizures, or altered mental status.
Ineffective cerebral perfusion related to cerebral edema from hyponatremia.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Uremia
item.description:
A condition resulting from severe kidney dysfunction, leading to the accumulation of waste products (urea, creatinine) in the blood.
Associated with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and acute kidney injury (AKI).
Causes multi-system complications due to toxin buildup and electrolyte imbalances.


Chronic kidney disease (CKD) or ESRD
Acute kidney injury (AKI)
Severe dehydration leading to kidney failure
Glomerulonephritis
Polycystic kidney disease
Obstructive uropathy (e.g., kidney stones, tumors)
Uncontrolled diabetes or hypertension (leading to nephropathy)
Autoimmune diseases affecting the kidneys


Long-term diabetes or hypertension
Family history of kidney disease
Chronic NSAID or nephrotoxic drug use
Recurrent urinary tract infections or kidney infections
Age-related kidney decline
Severe infections or sepsis affecting kidney function


Fatigue, weakness, and confusion (due to toxin buildup)
Nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite
Metallic taste in mouth and uremic breath odor
Pruritus (severe itching) due to toxin accumulation in the skin
Peripheral Neuropathy (tingling, burning sensation in limbs)
Fluid overload leading to hypertension and pulmonary edema
Muscle cramps, restless legs, and bone pain (due to electrolyte imbalances)
Decreased urine output or anuria
Pericarditis - ati (chest pain, friction rub)


Cardiovascular disease (major cause of death in uremia)
Metabolic acidosis due to impaired bicarbonate regulation
Hyperkalemia leading to life-threatening arrhythmias
Uremic encephalopathy (confusion, seizures, coma)
Pericarditis and pericardial effusion
Increased risk of bleeding due to platelet dysfunction
Bone demineralization and fractures (renal osteodystrophy)


Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine
Electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, metabolic acidosis)
Decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
Urinalysis (proteinuria, hematuria)
Echocardiogram/ECG (to assess for pericarditis, arrhythmias)


Dialysis (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis) to remove toxins
Diet: low protein to reduce urea buildup, adequate to prevent muscle wasting, low K, low phosphate, low Na
Fluid restriction - prevent edema
Correction of electrolyte imbalances (calcium supplements, phosphate binders)
Blood pressure control (antihypertensives)
Erythropoietin therapy for anemia
Renal transplant (definitive treatment for ESRD)


Monitor fluid balance, weight, and signs of fluid overload
Assess for uremic encephalopathy (confusion, lethargy, asterixis)
Manage itching with skin care and antihistamines
Administer medications cautiously due to impaired drug excretion
Monitor and educate on dialysis access care (AV fistula, peritoneal catheter)
Encourage adherence to dietary and fluid restrictions
Provide emotional support, especially for patients considering dialysis or transplant


Prevent life-threatening complications (hyperkalemia, fluid overload, pericarditis)
Ensure adherence to dialysis and medication regimens
Educate on dietary restrictions and symptom management
Support mental health and quality of life in chronic kidney disease patients
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Anemia
item.description:
#cbc

abnormally low RBC, Hgb concentration, or HCT
indicator of underlying disease or disorder
results in diminished o2 carrying capacity and delivery to tissues and organs


Little to no manifestations in mild cases
Pallor
Fatigue, somnolence, and headache
Irritability
Numbness and tingling of extremities (paresthesia)
Dyspnea on exertion
Sensitivity to cold
Pain and hypoxia with sickle-cell crisis
SOB, tachy, dizziness
nail deformities when chronic


goal of treatment is to restore and maintain adequate tissue oxygenation
Iron Supplements: oral, IV for severe cases
Iron Oral Supplements => must take on EMPTY stomach to increase absorption
do not take with calcium supplements
Vitamin C increases iron absorption
Erythropoietin: epoetin alfa - ematopoietic growth factor used to increase production of RBCs
monitor for increased BP, monitor CBC, monitor for cardiac event
B12 supplements - to convert folic acid
administer parenterally if lack of intrinsic factors/stomach malabsorption
Folic Acid Supplements
Blood Transfusions - for severe only due to risk of infections


Prevention:
pregnant/menstruating = ensure more iron foods, iron supplements
iron-deficient and have elevated cholesterol levels => eat more iron-rich foods that are not red or organ meats into their diets
eat more folate (spinach, lentils, bananas) and folic acid fortified grains and juices
Iron supplements causes constipation = increase FIBER intake
CALCIUM (milk) disrupts iron absorption


CBC #cbc
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): Size of red blood cells
Normocytic: Normal size
Microcytic: Small cells
Macrocytic: Large cells
Mean corpuscular Hgb (MCH): Determines the amount of Hgb per RBC
Mean corpuscular Hgb concentration (MCHC): Indicates percentage of Hgb present relative to the size of the cell
Iron Studies
Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) - an indirect measurement of all proteins that bind with iron and transports it for storage
Sickle cell
Schilling Test - measure B12 absorption for G6PD


blood loss
Inadequate RBC production (hypoproliferative)
Increased RBC destruction (hemolytic)
Deficiency of necessary components (folic acid, iron, erythropoietin, vitamin B12)


acute or chronic blood loss (trauma, menorrhagia, GI, chemical or radiation exposure)
rapid metabolic activity: pregnancy, adolescence, infection
Increased hemolysis: Sickle Cell, Impaired Glycolysis: G6PD deficiency anemia, Immune Disorders,
Trauma to RBCs: mechanical heart valve, cardiopulmonary bypass
Diet or malabsorption: iron, folic acid
Pernicious Anemia - deficiency of intrinsic factor produced by gastric mucosa, which is necessary for absorption of vitamin B12
Pica - persistent eating of substances not normally considered food (nonnutritive substances), such as soil or chalk
Bone Marrow Suppression - exposure to radiation or chemicals
Aplastic anemia - results in fewer RBCs as well as decreased platelets and WBC
Age - Older adult clients are at risk for nutrition-deficient anemias; can be misdiagnosed as depression
Complications

heart failure due to increased heart demand
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Aplastic Anemia
item.description:
A rare condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells
Leads to pancytopenia: decreased RBCs, WBCs, and platelets
Can be acquired or inherited


Idiopathic (most common)
Autoimmune destruction of hematopoietic stem cells
Exposure to toxins (e.g., benzene), radiation, or chemotherapy
Certain medications (e.g., chloramphenicol, NSAIDs)
Viral infections (e.g., hepatitis, EBV, HIV, parvovirus B19)
Inherited disorders (e.g., Fanconi anemia)


History of toxic chemical exposure
Autoimmune disorders
Use of specific medications
Previous cancer treatment
Viral infections


Fatigue, pallor, weakness (due to anemia)
Frequent infections, fever (due to neutropenia)
Easy bruising, petechiae, bleeding gums, epistaxis (due to thrombocytopenia)
Tachycardia, dyspnea


Life-threatening infections
Severe bleeding
Heart failure from chronic anemia
Death if untreated


CBC: pancytopenia
Bone marrow biopsy: hypocellular marrow with fatty infiltration
Rule out other causes of pancytopenia (e.g., leukemia, myelodysplastic syndrome)


Identify and remove causative agent if possible
Blood transfusions (RBCs, platelets)
Immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., ATG, cyclosporine)
Bone marrow or stem cell transplant (curative for severe cases)
Antibiotics for infections


Monitor for signs of infection and bleeding
Use neutropenic and bleeding precautions
Educate on avoiding crowds and injury
Administer transfusions and medications as ordered
Provide emotional support for long treatment course and potential isolation
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Blood Transfusion
item.description:
FACH => Transfusion Reactions Pnemonic

Febrile
Anaphylactic
Circulatory Overload
Hemolytic

mild allergic reaction

flushing or redness
itchy


wheezing
hives
hypotension



a person's immune system destroys red blood cells during a blood transfusion
destroyed RBCs release free hemoglobin in blood stream
kidneys filter hgb, damaging renal tubules, causing pain and inflammation
Manifestations:

low back pain
hyPOTENSION
fever
tachycardia
mental: apprehension
urinalysis: hemolyzed RBP


Iron Toxicity - client who has received several blood transfusions is at risk for development of hemosiderosis, which is excess storage of iron in the body. The excessive iron can come from overuse of supplements or from receiving frequent blood transfusions, as in sickle cell anemia
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: DIC
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

A life-threatening hematologic disorder characterized by simultaneous clotting and bleeding due to widespread activation of the coagulation cascade
Leads to microvascular thrombosis, ischemia, and organ failure, followed by excessive bleeding due to depletion of clotting factors and platelets
usually found in patients who are already in critical condition => DIC worsens their outcomes
Can be acute (life-threatening) or chronic (low-grade, seen in cancer patients)
DIC = Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation


Sepsis (most common cause, especially Gram-negative infections)
Severe trauma or burns
Obstetric complications (placental abruption, amniotic fluid embolism, preeclampsia)
Malignancies (leukemia, metastatic cancer)
Major surgery or massive blood transfusion
Severe liver disease (liver produces clotting factors)
Snake venom poisoning


Cyanosis or gangrene (due to microthrombi in extremities)
Altered mental status (cerebral ischemia)
Acute kidney injury (renal ischemia)
Respiratory distress (pulmonary embolism, ARDS)


Petechiae, ecchymosis, and purpura
bleeding from existing wounds: IV sites, surgical wounds, mucous membranes
Hematuria, hematemesis, melena
Epistaxis (nosebleeds), gingival bleeding
Intracranial hemorrhage (severe cases)


MODS
hypovolemic Shock
ishcemic limb loss d/t clotting
intracranial bleeding => coma, death


D-Dimer: elevated, indicates clot
Prolonged PT, aPTT, INR
Thrombocytopenia - low platelet count
Low Fibrinogen - converted into clots
Schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) on blood smear


Treat cause: abx for sepsis, deliver baby
Blood product replacement (if severe): platelets, FFP, cryoprecupitate for fibrinogen replacement
Heparin for chronic DIC => if clotting predominant
supportive care: o2, IVF, vasopressors


monitor for bleeding and thrombosis
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: DVT
item.description:
type of blood clot that forms in large veins of extremities or pelvis
usually occurs in lower extremities
3rd most common cause of death among cardiovascular disorders
DVT will go unnoticed but can dislodge and result in a pulmonary embolus, a life-threatening event
Types:
provoked: from an acquired cause (obesity, cancer, immobility)
unprovoked: from an endogenous cause such as recurrence
Proximal: above the knee, and this type is more likely to cause complications leading to PE
Distal: below the knee (most common)


pain, redness, swelling, warmth at affected extremity**
edema


no longer recommended: DVT filters on inferior vena cava
Prophylaxis: SCD, Xa inhibitors (Eliquis, newer class)


ambulate early
anticoags
administer Lovenox - low molecular weight heparin injection
conduct "wells criteria test" - establish DVT risk


venous doppler - detects bloow flow
venography - invasive procedure involving contrast dye and xray
d-dimer
MRI


caused by damage to the wall of a blood vessel
turbulence to blood flow, such as with atrial fibrillation, a heart arrhythmia
hypercoagulability, meaning the blood is increasingly coagulating or clotting
decreased blood flow due to immobility, surgery, catheter
dehydration due to increased blood viscosity
genetics - factor V Leiden (FVL) mutation
CHF, COPD
hospital stay


immobility: bedrest, airplane right, anesthesia
hormonal: pregnant, contraceptive therapy or hormone replacement therapy with estrogen
smoking
family hx, previous hx
old age
tumors
sepsis
chronic health conditions: HTN, DM
Usual comorbidities: cellulitis, thrombophlebitis, eczema, vasculitis, cancer, CHF, IBS
obesity: pressure on the lower extremities
SSC


DVT can dislodge and travel = becomes a PE


Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) - profoundly serious health condition
clotting and anticlotting mechanisms occur at the same time.
hypovolemic shock
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hematological everything else
item.description:
#hematologic #anemia #nursing #medsurg #bloodclot #anticoagulant #stroke
#hematologic #anemia #nursing #medsurg

#bloodclot
What is it

Blood clots are made up of platelets and fibrin and are a gel-like consistency
thrombus - when blocks vein or artery
arterial thrombosis - occurs in artery
venous
Embolus/embolism - if it moves throughout the body; can cause serious harm
Subtypes

Pulmonary Embolism
Myocardial Infarction (MI)
Ischemic Stroke - occurs in artery to the brain caused by plaque (fatty deposits)
Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)
Clinical Presentation

chest pain that worsens with deep breathing
tachycardia, SOB, lightheadedness, hemoptysis
MI: chest pain radiating left arm, SOB, diaphoresis
Stroke: facial weakness, difficulty speaking, visual deficit, L/R sided weakness, seizures Treatment
Thrombolytics - class of meds that dissolve clots
Tissue Plasminogen Activator - give within 3 hours for stroke, do not use with hemorrhagic stroke, verify with CT
Thrombectomy - specialized instruments to surgically remove a blood clot
Prevention:
Coumadin/Warfarin - avoid diet changes, monitor INR, high K diet contradicts this medication
Factor Xa Inhibitors - Eliquis, monitoring not required, oral
Lovenox/Enoxaparin
Heparin - Hold heparin if the platelet count is less than 100,000/mm, monitor aPTT
Plavix/Clopidogrel
Antiplatelets - ensures platelets do not stick together
most common: aspirin, clopidogrel (Plavix), usually prescribed with ACS Nursing Interventions
ambulate
diet
note aging adults challenges
be on alert with anticoagulants #anticoagulant
higher risk for bleeding
Warfarin - needs INR, diet restrictions
Causes/Risk Factors

injury or damage to vein
surgery exacerbated by bed rest
hormonal: oral contraceptives, pregnancy, hormone replacement, estrogen (menopause, prostate cancer)
child birth after first 3 months
smoking
cancers: lungs, brain, pancreas, uterus, ovaries, blood cancers, chemotherapy
family history
Atrial Fibrillation
Infection
mechanical heart valves
SSC - systemic sclerosis, aka "scleroderma": also provides increased risk for clots
Diagnosis

D-dimer test: blood test, high = clot. can also be present during pregnancy or postop
small fragment of protein is detected from blood clot
not definitive, more testing needed if positive
CT, US, MRA (magnetic resonance angiography)
MRA = more specific to blood vessels
V/Q scan - ventilation/perfusion test aided by radioactive and imaging techniques
Systemic Effects

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) - profoundly serious health condition
clotting and anticlotting mechanisms occur at the same time

What is it

Hemorrhage: Loss of blood from damaged vessels, inside or outside the body.
Severity impacts treatment and prognosis.
Blood loss classess:
Class I - 0-15%
Class II - 15-30% (shock symptoms apparent)
Class III - 30-40% (delayed cap refill, SBP<90, tachy)
Class IV - 40% or more, no UOP, peripheral pulses absent, shock
Types of Hemorrhages:

Intracranial - brain bleeds
Pulmonary - hemothorax; caused by trauma, cancer, or clotting
Stroke - hemorrhagic; vessels rupture and blood leaks into brain
Clinical Presentation

Symptoms vary: nausea, dizziness, cool skin, shortness of breath, weakness, tachycardia, confusion.
Internal bleeding signs: hemoptysis, hematemesis, clammy skin, abdominal rigidity, altered consciousness.
intracranial hemorrhage: #stroke
headaches, slurred speech or difficulty speaking, facial numbness, upper and lower extremity weakness or numbness, decreased level of consciousness, seizures, or difficulty with ambulating
Treatment

IV fluids, blood transfusion, oxygen therapy, warming blankets, emotional support.
Type and cross-match for blood products.
Physical and occupational therapy for rehabilitation.
Nursing Interventions

Goal: stop the bleed
Assess and identify bleeding source, apply pressure, ensure IV access, administer fluids.
Monitor vital signs, oxygen saturation, and mental status.
Educate on gradual activity increase and rest.
MAP > 65 mm Hg indicates adequate cardiac perfusion.
MAP = (DBP×2) + SBP /3
Diagnostic Tools

CBC, platelet count, PT, PTT.
CT scans, x-rays, ultrasounds
endoscopy for suspected GI bleeds.
Causes

Traumatic injuries, cancer, clotting disorders, elevated BP leading to ruptured aneurysm.
Risk Factors

Trauma, accidents, cancer
blood clotting disorders: hemophillia (genetic mutation)
poor people = higher risk
postpartum hemorrhage = atony (flaccid fetus due to significant blood loss during childbirth or postpartum period)
Systemic Effects

Hypovolemic shock: decreased cardiac output, circulatory insufficiency, hypoxemia.
Cognitive impairments, fatigue, depression, anxiety, PTSD.
Orthostatic hypotension increases fall risk.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Polycythemia
item.description:
Blood disorder with increased red blood cell (RBC) mass
Can be primary (Polycythemia Vera) or secondary to chronic hypoxia or tumors
Increases blood viscosity, causing sluggish blood flow


Primary: Myeloproliferative disorder (Polycythemia Vera – JAK2 mutation)
Secondary: Chronic hypoxia (COPD, high altitude), tumors producing erythropoietin (renal cell carcinoma)
Relative: Dehydration (hemoconcentration without true RBC increase)


Smoking
Living at high altitudes
Chronic lung disease
Genetic mutations (JAK2)
Renal tumors or cysts


Ruddy complexion, facial plethora
Headache, dizziness, blurred vision
Pruritus (especially after hot shower)
Splenomegaly
Hypertension
Thrombosis or bleeding episodes


CBC: Elevated RBC, hemoglobin, hematocrit
Erythropoietin level (↓ in PV, ↑ in secondary)
JAK2 mutation testing
Bone marrow biopsy
Oxygen saturation, ABG (in secondary causes)


Phlebotomy (mainstay for PV to reduce Hct <45%)
Hydroxyurea (myelosuppression) for high-risk PV
Low-dose aspirin to prevent thrombosis
Treat underlying cause in secondary polycythemia
Oxygen therapy for hypoxic patients


Monitor for signs of thrombosis or bleeding => elevate legs when sitting down to prevent blood pooling
Educate on hydration and avoiding iron supplements
Assist with phlebotomy procedures
Manage pruritus and skin integrity
Monitor CBC, clotting profile
Ensure safety during dizziness or vision changes

Cardiovascular strain from hyperviscosity
Increased risk of stroke, MI, DVT
Possible progression to myelofibrosis or acute leukemia (in PV)

Thromboembolic events (DVT, PE, stroke)
Hemorrhagic complications
Splenomegaly or splenic rupture
Gout (due to increased cell turnover)
Progression to malignancy (myelofibrosis, leukemia)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Sickle Cell Anemia
item.description:
affects the shape of the red blood cells in the body by causing hemoglobin to be sticky
cause tissues in the body to become hypoxic, leading to many complications
sickle-shaped RBCs flowing through the blood vessels of the client’s abdomen, chest, and joints cause severe pain, which can last for hours or days
Vaso-Occlusive Crisis (VOC) - a painful complication of sickle cell anemia that occurs when blood vessels are blocked by sickle-shaped red blood cells
Symptoms: severe pain, acute chest syndrome (reduced lung perfusion = DEADLY), dactilytis (inflammation of finger, toes), priapism


both parents must be carriers of the sickle cell trait for the child to be affected
if only one parent is carrier, child will be carrier only


genetics


severe pain - affects ADLs, damage to joints
can cause anxiety, depression, stress, sleep disorder, poor coping
fatigue caused by anemia (sickle cells die within 10-20 days, normal life span is 120 days)
swelling of hands and feet
visual deficits (sickle cells block vessels in eyes)
anemia symptoms
Acute Chest Syndrome - emergency


stroke
blindness
blood clots during pregnancy and hypertension
acute chest syndrome - most serious
blood flow can be blocked to the lungs, causing breathing difficulty, fever, and severe chest pain
emergency!
Damage to organs, pulmonary hypertension, leg ulcerations due to poor circulation, blindness, priapism, DVT, and gallstones are all diseases or disorders that can occur in clients who have sickle cell anemia.


newborn screening - serum test
Hemoglobin electrophoresis to identify the type of hemoglobin.
Complete blood count (CBC) showing anemia and high reticulocyte count.
Peripheral blood smear showing sickled cells.


pain management
IV fluids for hydration
blood transfusion
Hydroxyurea - reactivates production of fetal hemoglobin
prevention:
drink 8 glasses water daily to prevent dehydration (dehydration = crisis)
avoid extreme temp changes
avoid high altitudes affecting O2 intake


lookout for iron overload arising from frequent blood transfusions
iron deposits in organs = organ damage
needs iron chelation therapy
encourage support group


Drink 3-4L per day
Avoid traveling to high altitudes and airplanes => reduced oxygen, can lead to vaso-occlusive crisis
Avoid activities that require persistent exposure to cold weather
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Thrombocytopenia
item.description:
Low platelet count (<150,000 platelets/mm³) leading to increased bleeding risk
Mild (100,000–150,000/mm³): Usually asymptomatic
Moderate (50,000–100,000/mm³): Risk of prolonged bleeding
Severe (<50,000/mm³): High risk for spontaneous bleeding
Critical (<20,000/mm³): Risk of life-threatening hemorrhage


Decreased platelet production
Bone marrow disorders (leukemia, aplastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndrome)
Chemotherapy, radiation therapy
Viral infections (HIV, hepatitis, Epstein-Barr virus)
Nutritional deficiencies (vitamin B12, folate)
DMARDs
Increased platelet destruction
Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT)
Autoimmune diseases (lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
Increased platelet sequestration - Splenomegaly (due to liver disease, lymphoma)


Cancer treatments (chemotherapy, radiation)
Autoimmune disorders
Chronic infections (HIV, H. pylori)
Liver disease (cirrhosis, portal hypertension)
Use of blood-thinning medications (heparin, warfarin)
Genetic disorders (Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome, Fanconi anemia)


Easy bruising (ecchymosis)
Petechiae (tiny red or purple spots on skin)
Prolonged bleeding from minor cuts
Gum or nosebleeds (epistaxis)
Heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia)
Blood in urine (hematuria) or stool (melena)
Severe cases: Intracranial hemorrhage, GI bleeding


Uncontrolled bleeding (internal or external)
Intracranial hemorrhage (life-threatening)
Severe anemia due to blood loss
Shock if bleeding is extensive


Complete Blood Count (CBC): Low platelet count
Peripheral blood smear (assess platelet shape and function)
Bone marrow biopsy (if bone marrow failure suspected)
Coags (PT, PTT, INR) (to rule out clotting disorders)
HIT antibody test (if heparin-induced thrombocytopenia suspected)


Treat underlying cause (infection, bone marrow suppression, autoimmune disease)
Platelet transfusions (for severe thrombocytopenia or active bleeding)
Corticosteroids or IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) (for immune-related thrombocytopenia)
Discontinuation of causative drugs (e.g., heparin in HIT)
Plasmapheresis (for TTP)
Splenectomy (if refractory ITP)
Avoid NSAIDs, aspirin, and anticoagulants


Monitor platelet count trends and bleeding symptoms
Implement bleeding precautions:
Use soft toothbrush, avoid flossing
Avoid IM injections and invasive procedures
Use electric razor instead of a blade
Prevent falls and injuries
Apply prolonged pressure to any bleeding sites
Monitor for signs of internal bleeding (hypotension, tachycardia, pallor, dizziness)
Educate patient on bleeding risk and safety measures


Risk for bleeding related to low platelet count
Impaired oral mucous membrane related to gum bleeding
Risk for injury related to fall risk and potential bleeding
Deficient knowledge related to thrombocytopenia management
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Vitamin Deficiency Anemia (pernicious)
item.description:
Results from fewer healthy RBCs due to the body’s low vitamin B12 and folate levels
B12 is essential for DNA synthesis in the production of RBCs, leading to immature, large cells
Absorption problem (lack of intrinsic factor) or diet issue


Autoimmune: Pernicious Anemia (terminal ileum cannot absorb B12)
Malabsorption: lack of intrinsic factor
Disease: celiac or Crohn’s
Nutritional deficits: vegan diet


Antiseizure meds: reduces B12 absorption
Gastric surgery
Alcohol consumption
DM meds
PPI
Contraceptives
Old age
Celiac/Crohn’s
Sjogren’s Syndrome: dry mucous membranes, including dry mouth and eyes


Little to no manifestations in mild cases
Signature symptom: BEEFY, smooth, sore TONGUE
Pallor
Fatigue, somnolence, and headache
Irritability
Numbness and tingling of extremities (paresthesia)
Dyspnea on exertion
Sensitivity to cold
Pain and hypoxia with sickle-cell crisis
SOB, tachy, dizziness
nail deformities when chronic


Newborns: developmental delay, spine/brain defects
Dementia
Mood changes, psych issues
Neuropathy, ataxia


B12: injection, nasal spray, oral
Diet changes: include red meat, chicken, fish, milk
Vegetables do not naturally contain vitamin B12


Note safety issues due to peripheral neuropathy; ADLs may be impaired
Visual problems increase the risk of falls


CBC with peripheral smear
B12 and folate serum
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Gout
item.description:
A type of inflammatory arthritis caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals
Uric acid crystals form and deposit in the joints, causing inflammation and pain
Often affects the big toe (podagra), but can involve other joints such as the knees, wrists, and elbows.
Acute episodes of gout may last a few days to weeks and can be triggered by dietary factors, alcohol, dehydration, or trauma.


Hyperuricemia (high levels of uric acid in the blood) due to: excessive production OR reduced excretion
Genetic predisposition (family history of gout)
High purine foods (red meats, shellfish, organ meats)
Alcohol consumption (beer and liquor)
Sugary drinks (high fructose corn syrup)
Excessive intake of processed foods
Obesity, diabetes, hypertension, and kidney disease increase risk.
Medications (e.g., diuretics, low-dose aspirin) can elevate uric acid levels.


Male gender (more common in men, especially age 30-50)
Obesity (increased uric acid production)
Chronic kidney disease (decreased excretion of uric acid)
Family history of gout
Medications (diuretics, immunosuppressive drugs)
Hypertension and metabolic syndrome


Severe, sudden pain in a joint, most commonly the big toe (podagra)
Swelling, redness, warmth in the affected joint
Pain may be excruciating to touch, with symptoms often occurring at night
Tophi (hard nodules) may form in chronic gout, typically around the joints or ears
Fever in severe cases
Long-term: Tophi formation in joints, tendons, or skin, joint deformities


Joint damage and deformities due to long-term uric acid crystal deposition
Kidney stones (due to uric acid buildup in kidneys)
Chronic pain and decreased mobility
Cardiovascular issues (increased risk of hypertension and heart disease)
Tophi formation in soft tissues


Joint aspiration (synovial fluid analysis): Identifies uric acid crystals under a microscope.
Blood tests: Elevated serum uric acid levels (although may not be elevated during acute attack).
X-rays: May show joint damage in chronic gout cases or presence of tophi.
Ultrasound: Detects urate crystals in joints and soft tissues.

Acute attack management:

NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) to reduce pain and inflammation
Colchicine (reduces inflammation and pain, especially within the first 24 hours)
Corticosteroids (oral or injected into the joint) for severe cases
Uric acid-lowering drugs:

Allopurinol (reduces uric acid production)
Febuxostat (alternative to allopurinol)
Probenecid (increases uric acid excretion by kidneys)
Lifestyle modifications:

Low-purine diet: Avoid red meats, shellfish, and organ meats
Limit alcohol (especially beer and liquor)
Weight loss (reduces uric acid levels)
Adequate hydration (helps prevent uric acid crystals from forming)


Pain management: Administer NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids as prescribed.
Encourage proper hydration: Fluids help in reducing uric acid concentration in the blood.
Monitor serum uric acid levels during treatment.
Education on lifestyle changes
Prevent future attacks: Ensure patient adheres to long-term medications (e.g., allopurinol) and dietary modifications.
Monitor for signs of kidney stones (severe pain, hematuria).


Acute pain related to inflammation from uric acid crystals
Impaired physical mobility related to joint pain and swelling
Ineffective health maintenance related to poor dietary habits or medication adherence
Risk for injury related to decreased mobility from joint inflammation
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
item.description:
Acute autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the peripheral nervous system
Leads to demyelination of peripheral nerves, causing ascending weakness and paralysis
Often follows infection or vaccination


Often triggered by infections: Campylobacter jejuni (most common), cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, influenza
Occasionally follows vaccination or surgery
Immune system mistakenly targets peripheral myelin


Recent viral or bacterial infection
Recent immunization or surgery
Male sex
Age over 50


Symmetrical, ascending muscle weakness starting in legs
Paresthesia (tingling, numbness)
Loss of reflexes (areflexia)
Facial weakness, difficulty speaking or swallowing
Respiratory muscle weakness or failure
Autonomic dysfunction: fluctuating BP, arrhythmias


Respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation
Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) from immobility
Autonomic instability
Aspiration pneumonia
Permanent neurologic deficits (rare)


Clinical presentation and history of recent illness
Lumbar puncture: elevated protein in CSF with normal WBC
Nerve conduction studies and EMG: slowed conduction
MRI to rule out other causes


Hospitalization and supportive care
Plasmapheresis or IV immunoglobulin (IVIG) to reduce immune attack
Mechanical ventilation if respiratory muscles involved
Pain control and DVT prophylaxis
Physical therapy during recovery


Monitor respiratory status and prepare for intubation if needed
Assess motor strength, cranial nerves, and reflexes regularly
Prevent complications from immobility (pressure ulcers, DVT)
Support nutrition, communication, and emotional needs
Educate on slow recovery process and provide rehab support
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: HIV-AIDS
item.description:
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) => a retrovirus that is transmitted through blood and body fluids (semen, vaginal secretions)
also found in feces, urine, tears, saliva, cerebrospinal fluid, cervical cells, lymph nodes, corneal tissue, and brain tissue
attacks CD4+ T cells, weakening the immune system
CD4

protein found on the surface of certain immune cells, known as helper T cells
crucial in recognizing and responding to infections
CD4 range: 500-1,500 cells/mm3 (average adult, lower for younger or elderly)

Stage 1 - Acute HIV Infection

Occurs 2-4 weeks after exposure
Rapid viral replication and spread
Symptoms: Flu-like symptoms (fever, sore throat, rash, swollen lymph nodes, headache)
Highly infectious phase
CD4+ T-Lymphocyte Count: 500 cells/mm3 or more
Stage 2 - Chronic HIV, latent

Virus continues to replicate at low levels
Can last for several years (longer with ART)
Symptoms: Few or no symptoms
Gradual decline in CD4+ T-cell count
CD4+ T-Lymphocyte Count: 200 to 499 cells/mm3
Stage 3 - AIDS

Final stage, severe immune system damage
Vulnerable to opportunistic infections and cancers
Symptoms: Severe immunosuppression, opportunistic infections (e.g., tuberculosis, pneumonia, candidiasis), cancers (Kaposi’s sarcoma, lymphoma)
CD4+ count below 200 cells/mm³ (less than 14% of lymphocytes)


Unprotected seggs (vaginal, anal, oral)
Multiple seggs partners
Occupational exposure (health care workers)
Perinatal exposure
Blood transfusions (not a significant source of infection in the U.S.)
IV drug use with a contaminated needle


asymptomatic initially
Chills, fever
Rash
swollen lymph nodes
Anorexia, nausea, weight loss
Weakness and fatigue
Headache and sore throat
Night sweats
Kaposi Sarcoma (cancer) - manifests as hyperpigmented multicentric lesions that can be firm, flat, raised, or nodular. Following a biopsy, the lesions are treated with radiation and/or chemotherapy


Opportunistic infections
cancers (Kaposi’s sarcoma, lymphoma)
neurological issues (HIV-associated dementia)
wasting syndrome - significant unintentional weight loss, muscle wasting, and fatigue
organ failure.


CD4+ T-cell count: Normal: 500-1,500 cells/mm³; AIDS diagnosis: <200 cells/mm³
Viral Load: below 40 to 75 copies/mL of blood
CBC and differential: Abnormal (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia)
Platelet count: Decreased less than 150,000/mm3
HIV antibody screening test (ELISA, Western blot, IFA, home test kit)
Test viral load before beginning treatment
HIV Drug resistant testing - guides medication therapy
Brain or lung MRI/CT


antiretroviral therapy (ART) - suppress viral replication and restore immune function; lowers viral load
postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) medication - for accidental exposure, must be taken within 72 hours, daily for 28 days


All women who are pregnant should be screened for HIV
DO NOT administer live virus vaccines (especially for CD4+ count below 200 cells/mm³ due to the risk of uncontrolled viral replication)
positive Western blot or IFA test => client has been exposed to and has the AIDS virus in their body BUT does not mean the client has clinical AIDS.
Promote medication adherence
monitor for side effects of ART
educate on transmission prevention
provide emotional support
encourage routine screening
encourage high protein diet - at least six small feedings with high protein value
manage symptoms of opportunistic infections: TB, Pneumonia, septicemia, kaposis sarcoma, lymphoma
report indications of infection immediately to the provider
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Lupus
item.description:
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease where the immune system attacks its own tissues, leading to inflammation and damage.
Affects multiple organs, including skin, joints, kidneys, and the heart.
More common in women (especially those of childbearing age) and can be triggered by genetic, environmental, and hormonal factors.


unknown
genetic, hormonal (PREGNANT), and environmental factors
Genetic predisposition: Family history of lupus or other autoimmune diseases increases risk.
Environmental triggers: Infections, medications, UV light exposure, and smoking.
Hormonal influence: Estrogen plays a role, making lupus more common in women.


Gender: More common in women, particularly those of childbearing age.
Ethnicity: More prevalent in African American, Hispanic, and Asian populations.
Family history of lupus or other autoimmune diseases.
Environmental triggers: UV light, infections, and certain medications.


Systemic: Fatigue, fever, weight loss, malaise.
Skin: Butterfly-shaped rash across the cheeks and nose, photosensitivity, discoid lupus.
Joint: Pain, stiffness, and swelling, commonly affecting small joints.
Kidneys: Lupus nephritis (inflammation of the kidneys) can cause edema, proteinuria, and kidney failure.
Neuro: Headaches, seizures, and memory loss.
Cardiovascular: Increased risk of pericarditis and stroke.
Respiratory: Pleuritis, pleural effusion, and interstitial lung disease.


Lupus nephritis: Kidney failure due to glomerulonephritis.
Cardiovascular disease: Increased risk of heart attacks, strokes, and pericarditis.
Infections: Due to immunosuppressive treatments and the disease itself.
Osteoporosis: Long-term use of corticosteroids can lead to bone thinning.
Psychosocial impact: Chronic pain, fatigue, and cosmetic issues (skin rashes) can affect quality of life.


Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test: Positive in most patients with lupus.
Anti-dsDNA: Specific to lupus, high titers correlate with kidney involvement.
Anti-Smith antibodies: Specific but less common.
Complete blood count (CBC): May show anemia, leukopenia, or thrombocytopenia.
Complement levels (C3, C4): Low levels suggest active disease.
Urinalysis: Detects proteinuria, hematuria, and casts indicating kidney involvement.
Skin biopsy: To confirm lupus-induced skin lesions.
Kidney biopsy: In suspected lupus nephritis.


Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain and inflammation.
Antimalarial drugs (e.g., hydroxychloroquine) for skin and joint symptoms.
Corticosteroids for acute flare-ups and inflammation.
Immunosuppressive drugs (e.g., azathioprine, methotrexate) for severe disease or organ involvement.
Biologic agents (e.g., belimumab) for refractory cases.


Monitor for flare-ups: Assess for signs of active disease, such as fever, joint swelling, and rash.
Patient education: Importance of sun protection, medication adherence, and avoiding triggers.
Kidney function monitoring: Regular urinalysis and serum creatinine levels.
Psychosocial support: Address the emotional and psychological impact of chronic disease.
Bone health: Monitor for osteoporosis, especially in patients on long-term corticosteroid therapy.
Infection control: Educate patients about the increased risk of infections due to immunosuppressive treatment.


pain management
prevent flare-ups
maintain skin integrity
decrease joint stiffness, increase ROM
educate
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: MODS
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing


A progressive, life-threatening condition where two or more organ systems fail due to an uncontrolled systemic inflammatory response
reversible but deadly => higher # of organs affected = higher chance of death
leads to longer ICU stay, higher mortality
Often results from sepsis, trauma, burns, or severe illness, leading to widespread tissue hypoxia and organ failure.
Can be primary (direct organ injury) or secondary (resulting from systemic inflammation and shock).


Sepsis & septic shock: Most common cause due to overwhelming infection.
Severe trauma: Major burns, crush injuries, or hemorrhagic shock.
Pancreatitis: Triggers systemic inflammation.
Major surgery: Postoperative complications and ischemia-reperfusion injury.
Respiratory failure (ARDS): Leads to oxygen deprivation affecting multiple organs.
Toxic drug reactions: Overdose or chemotherapy-induced toxicity.


Advanced age: Poor physiologic reserve.
Chronic illnesses: Diabetes, chronic kidney disease, heart failure.
Immunosuppression: Cancer, chemotherapy, organ transplantation.
Prolonged ICU stay: Mechanical ventilation, multiple invasive devices.
Severe hypotension: Prolonged shock states leading to ischemia.


Respiratory failure: ARDS, hypoxia, need for mechanical ventilation.
Cardiovascular dysfunction: Hypotension, tachycardia, poor perfusion.
Renal failure: Oliguria, increased creatinine, electrolyte imbalances.
Hepatic dysfunction: Jaundice, elevated liver enzymes, coagulopathy.
Neurological changes: Confusion, agitation, decreased LOC, coma.
Metabolic derangements: Lactic acidosis, hyperglycemia, electrolyte disturbances.
Coagulopathy: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), increased bleeding risk


Severe hypotension & shock: Progresses to cardiovascular collapse.
Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC): Widespread clotting and bleeding.
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): Worsening hypoxia and ventilatory failure.
Acute kidney injury (AKI): Requires dialysis in severe cases.
Liver failure: Increased ammonia, encephalopathy, coagulopathy.
Death: MODS has a high mortality rate, especially if more than three organs are involved


SOFA Scoring (sequential organ failure assessment) = assess risk morality related to MODS
Elevated lactate levels (tissue hypoxia).
Coagulation tests (DIC screening).
Renal function tests (BUN, creatinine).
Liver enzymes (AST, ALT, bilirubin).
Arterial blood gases (ABGs) (hypoxia, acidosis)
CTI, MRI, US


Supportive care & organ support
Mechanical vent
Vasopressors (Norepinephrine, dopamine)
Dialysis for AKI
Sepsis Management: abx, IVF, blood products
Nutritional Support: enteral or parenteral nutrition


Monitor for early signs of organ failure (urine output, oxygenation, mental status).
Maintain hemodynamic stability: Monitor BP, HR, CVP, and fluid balance.
Assess for infection: Frequent cultures, temperature monitoring.
Manage mechanical ventilation: Prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
Prevent complications: DVT prophylaxis, repositioning to prevent pressure ulcers.
Provide emotional support: For patient and family regarding prognosis and treatment decisions


Early recognition of MODS to prevent progression.
Maintain adequate oxygenation and perfusion.
Prevent & treat infections aggressively.
Support failing organ systems with appropriate interventions.
Coordinate multidisciplinary care for comprehensive treatment.
Educate family members on prognosis and treatment options.
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Osteoarthritis
item.description:
Degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and underlying bone
Most common form of arthritis, affecting weight-bearing joints (knees, hips, spine, hands)
Progressive (irreversible) and non-inflammatory, leading to pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility
osteo = bone
Bone Spurs - occurs because of changes in bone; small pieces of bone that form at joints with arthritis leading to further breakdown of joints and cartilage
Comparison vs Rheumatoid Arthritis
Osteoarthritis - caused by joint mechanical stress, affects big joints, more common
Rheumatoid - autoimmune, inflammatory, affects all joints, less common


Cartilage deterioration due to mechanical stress and aging
Chronic joint overuse (e.g., repetitive movements, high-impact activities)
Joint misalignment or instability
Obesity-related increased joint load
Previous joint injuries or surgeries


Aging (most common in adults over 50)
Obesity (increased stress on weight-bearing joints)
Joint injuries or trauma
Repetitive stress from occupation or sports
Genetic predisposition
Muscle weakness and poor joint support


joint pain (worsens with activity, relieved by rest)
Morning stiffness (lasting <30 minutes)
Crepitus (grating sound) with movement
Decreased range of motion and flexibility
Joint swelling (mild, non-inflammatory)
Bony enlargements (Heberden’s nodes on distal fingers, Bouchard’s nodes on proximal fingers)
