HEBERDEN's NODES - hard lumps over the joints of the fingers


Chronic pain and disability
Joint deformity and stiffness
Decreased mobility leading to muscle atrophy
Increased risk of falls due to instability
Depression and reduced quality of life


clinical assessment
XR, MRI
erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) to show inflammation (ref: 0-15 for male 0-20, female => higher if older)
synovial fluid analysis - to rule out inflammatory arthritis


no permanent treatment; supportive unless severe
Non-pharmacologic: weight loss (reduce joint stress), PT & exercise (improve strength), assistive device & better shoes (comfort), hot/cold therapy (pain relief)
Pharmacologic: acetaminophen, NSAIDs, capsaicin, lidocaine, hyaluronic acid injection (lubricates joints), steroid shots
Surgical (severe): joint replacement (aka arthroplasty)


Encourage regular exercise (low-impact like swimming, walking)
Teach joint protection techniques (assistive devices, ergonomic adjustments)
Promote weight management (reduces joint strain)
Administer and monitor pain medications (watch for NSAID-related GI side effects)
Encourage warm showers or heat therapy to relieve stiffness
Monitor for complications like decreased mobility and fall risk
For recent knee replacements: do not put pillow under joint (impairs circulation, risk of flexion contracture)


Chronic pain related to joint degeneration
Impaired physical mobility due to joint stiffness and pain
Self-care deficit related to limited joint function
Activity intolerance related to fatigue and discomfort
Risk for falls due to joint instability and muscle weakness
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Rheumatoid Arthritis
item.description:
Chronic autoimmune disease causing systemic inflammation and progressive joint destruction
Patho: synovium is inflamed, immune system attacks tissue surrounding joint, causing damage (including eyes, mouth, heart, lungs)
Symmetrical polyarthritis, primarily affecting small joints (hands, wrists, feet)
Leads to pain, swelling, stiffness, and deformities
Can also affect organs (heart, lungs, eyes, skin)


Autoimmune response triggering synovial inflammation
Genetic predisposition (HLA-DR4 and HLA-DR1 genes)
Environmental triggers (e.g., smoking, infections)


Female sex (3:1 female-to-male ratio)
Ages 30-50 (peak onset)
Family history of RA
Smoking (strongest modifiable risk factor)
Obesity (linked to disease severity)
Infections (may trigger immune response)


Symmetric joint pain and stiffness (lasting >1 hour in the morning)
Swollen, warm, and tender joints
Most commonly affects: fingers, wrists, elbows, knees, ankles
Joint deformities over time (swan neck, boutonnière, ulnar deviation)
Fatigue, low-grade fever, weight loss
AFFECTS THE WHOLE BODY

Mouth - gum disease, dry, tooth decay
Limbs - deformities, swelling, locking, weakening, ruptured tendons, bunions
Skin: rash, ulcers, Rheumatoid nodules (subcutaneous lumps), neuropathy
Lungs: COPD, (interstitial fibrosis, pleuritis)
Kidneys: impaired function d/t buildup of proteins (amyloidosis)
Eye inflammation (scleritis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca)


Joint deformities and disability
Osteoporosis (due to chronic inflammation and steroid use)
Cardiovascular disease (increased risk of heart attack/stroke)
Lung disease (fibrosis, pleural effusions)
Anemia of chronic disease
Infections (due to immunosuppressive therapy)


clinical assessment
Rheumatoid factor (RF) (positive in 70-80% of cases)
Anti-CCP antibodies (more specific for RA)
Elevated ESR & CRP (indicate inflammation)
XR: shows joint erosion, osteopenia, narrowing of joint space
MRI/US: early synovitis detection
Culture from Synovial Fluid - r/o bacteria (yes, it can be aspirated)

no cure; only management of symptoms
Pharmacologic:

DMARDs (disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs) – first-line, Methotrexate (MTX) (gold standard)
Biologic DMARDs (if unresponsive to traditional DMARDs) - TNF inhibitors
NSAIDs and corticosteroids (for symptom relief, but not disease progression)
CELECOXIB - cox-2 inhibitor, pain relief for RA, NSAID
Non-Pharmacologic:

PT - joint mobility, increase muscle strength
assistive devices (splints, braces)
Immobility will further hinder joint movement and should be avoided
Gentle exercise of the affected extremities should be performed, even when joints are painful and inflamed


Monitor for side effects of DMARDs (e.g., liver toxicity, bone marrow suppression, Thrombocytopenia - platelet under 100k)
Educate on medication adherence (early treatment prevents joint damage)
Encourage joint protection techniques (avoid prolonged gripping, use adaptive tools)
Promote balanced rest and exercise
Apply warm/cold therapy (warm packs for stiffness, cold packs for inflammation)
Monitor for extra-articular complications (lung, heart, skin issues)
Encourage smoking cessation (reduces disease progression)
Regularly test for TB (DMARDs)
DMARDs - MTX: causes immunosuppression, not for pregnant, bleeding risk, photosensitivity, sun exposure sensitivity


Chronic pain related to joint inflammation
Impaired physical mobility due to joint stiffness and deformities
Self-care deficit related to decreased hand function
Risk for falls due to joint instability
Fatigue related to systemic inflammation
Risk for infection due to immunosuppressive therapy
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Scleroderma
item.description:
Chronic autoimmune connective tissue disorder causing hardening and tightening of the skin and internal organs
the body produces and deposits too much collagen, causing thickening and hardening
Divided into two types:

Localized Scleroderma – Limited to skin and underlying tissues.
Systemic Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis) – Involves skin, blood vessels, and internal organs.


Exact cause unknown; involves immune system dysfunction, genetic factors, and environmental triggers.


Female sex (most common in women aged 30-50).
Family history of autoimmune diseases.
Exposure to silica dust, solvents, or industrial chemicals.
Viral infections may play a role.


Skin thickening and hardening (fingers, face, and extremities).
contractures - tissues around joints become stiff and tight, limiting the range of motion and potentially causing the joint to become fixed in a bent position (fingers - most common, wrists, elbows, shoulders, knees, ankles) - all extremities basically
Raynaud’s Disease (cold-induced color changes in extremities).
Tight, shiny skin over affected areas.
Joint pain and stiffness.
Esophageal dysmotility (difficulty swallowing, acid reflux).
Telangiectasia (visible blood vessels on the skin).
Organ involvement may lead to lung fibrosis, heart issues, or kidney dysfunction.


Pulmonary hypertension.
Heart failure from myocardial fibrosis.
Scleroderma renal crisis (acute kidney failure and severe hypertension).
Digital ulcers and gangrene from poor circulation.
Malnutrition from GI involvement.


Antinuclear antibody (ANA) test – Often positive.
Anti-Scl-70 antibody – Specific for systemic scleroderma.
Anti-centromere antibody – Common in limited scleroderma.
Skin biopsy confirms fibrosis.
Imaging (e.g., CT scan, echocardiogram) assesses organ damage.


Immunosuppressants (e.g., methotrexate, cyclophosphamide).
Calcium channel blockers for Raynaud’s.
Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for acid reflux.
ACE inhibitors for renal crisis prevention.
Vasodilators for pulmonary hypertension.


Promote skin care with moisturizers to reduce dryness and irritation.
Encourage warm clothing and lifestyle adjustments to manage Raynaud’s.
Monitor for hypertension, renal function, and respiratory changes.
Provide small, frequent meals to reduce GI discomfort.
Educate about the chronic nature of the disease and coping strategies.


Impaired Skin Integrity related to fibrosis and tight skin.
Ineffective Airway Clearance related to pulmonary fibrosis.
Chronic Pain related to joint stiffness and inflammation.
Risk for Impaired Tissue Perfusion related to vascular involvement.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: SIRS
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing


A widespread inflammatory response triggered by infection, trauma, or other severe stressors.
Often a precursor to sepsis, Shock, or multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
Diagnosed when two or more criteria are met
cytokine storm - a life-threatening condition characterized by an excessive and uncontrolled release of inflammatory proteins (cytokines) from immune cells
SIRS + infection = SEPSIS
#1 organ affected: LIVER
Liver Failure results in: cerebral edema, blood clotting issues, renal failure
Toxic Shock syndrome - biggest source is TAMPONS (if they are in the hospital)
SIRS Criteria: must meet two or more

Temperature: > 38°C (100.4°F) or < 36°C (96.8°F)
Heart rate: > 90 beats per minute
Respiratory rate: > 20 breaths per minute (and PaCO2 less than 32 mm Hg)
White blood cell count: > 12,000/mL or < 4,000/mL or > 10% bands
Terms:
Severe Sepsis - one or more organ failures
Septic Shock - hemodynamic instability despite volume replenishment


acute stress from infections and noninfectious stimuli
infections: bacterial, viral, fungal (esp with abx use)
trauma/burns
Pancreatitis => huge one
major surgery
ischemia or tissue injury
autoimmune disorders, cancers
illicit drugs
heart valve abnormalities
artificial joints


Elderly or immunocompromised individuals
Severe injury, burns, or surgery
pregnant
cirrhosis
ABX or corticosteroid use
artificial organs: heart valves, joints
Prolonged hospitalization or invasive procedures; long ICU stays
Malignancy or chronic illness
IV Drug use
Diabetes - do not notice wounds, do not feel pain with UTI or other infections
Comorbidities: dm, MI, HF, cancer, lung disease, CKD, dialysis


Liver Dysfunction => can cause cerebral edema, blood clotting issues, renal failure
Altered mental status
Hypotension
Decreased urine output


Sepsis (if caused by infection)
Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
MODS
DIC
Shock (septic, hypovolemic, or cardiogenic)


see SIRS criteria
blood cultures => draw before ABX treatment
Coags => because of impaired liver function => impaired Vitamin K synthesis => bleeding issues
LFT
UA and culture
Sputum culture => basically anything that can indicate microorganism growth
ABG/VBG
imaging: CXR, CT, MRI, US, ECG
lactate levels: assess for tissue hypoxia (ref <2.0 mmol/L)
procalcitonin or PCT (elevated in bacterial infections) (ref. below 0.1 ng/mL)


treat underlying cause: abx, antiviral, trauma, corrective surgery (incision/drainage)
supportive measures (see below)
IVF resus (isotonic) => bolus of 30 mL/kg
Pressors: norepinephrine => maintain at least 90 mmHg systolic
Corticosteroids
O2 => maintain 92% or greater SPO2
Control glucose 80-110 mg/dL (or follow facility protocol)
antipyretics for fever


main goal: disrupt progression into MODS
SIRS patients will require ICU level of treatment
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Alzheimers
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting memory, thinking, behavior
most common cause of Dementia
amyloid plaque buildup and neurofibrillary tangles in brain
leads to gradual loss of cognitive and functional abilities


Age (most cases occur after age 65)
Family history and genetics
Cardiovascular disease (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia)
Head trauma and traumatic brain injury (TBI)
Chronic stress and depression
Sedentary lifestyle and poor diet


same as Dementia
depends on the stage:
Early stage: Mild Alzheimer's

Short-term memory loss (misplacing items, forgetting names)
Difficulty finding words and making decisions
Mild confusion and disorientation
Middle/Moderate stage:

Increased memory loss and difficulty recognizing loved ones
Behavioral changes (agitation, aggression, mood swings)
Wandering and getting lost
Difficulty with complex tasks (managing finances, cooking)
Late/Severe stage:

Severe cognitive decline and loss of communication
body begins to completely shut down
Inability to perform self-care (feeding, dressing, toileting)
Loss of mobility, swallowing difficulties, and incontinence



Mini-Mental State Exam (MMSE) shorter, longer: Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) - first-line neuro exam, administer several times across time
amyloid beta protein precursor (soluble) - identifies gene mutations causing early-onset
MRI/CT - rule out other conditions
PET scan - detect amyloid plaque buildup



maintain quiet environment
Ensure a safe environment (fall prevention, door alarms for wandering)**
Use simple communication (speak slowly, use short sentences)
Provide structured routines (minimizes confusion and anxiety)
Assist with activities of daily living (ADLs) as disease progresses
Encourage social interaction and cognitive activities
Monitor for signs of infection, dehydration, and malnutrition
Support and educate caregivers on disease progression
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Delirium
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

Acute, reversible cognitive disturbance characterized by confusion, disorientation, and impaired attention
Develops suddenly over hours to days
Fluctuating course with periods of lucidity and confusion
Often secondary to an underlying medical condition
Compared to Dementia:
Dementia: gradual onset, worsens over time
Delirium: sudden, sporadic manifestations (on and off)


Hypoxia (e.g., respiratory failure, cardiac conditions)
Infections (e.g., UTI, Pneumonia, sepsis)
Metabolic imbalances (e.g., Fluid & Electrolyte ATI, electrolyte disturbances, Hypoglycemia)
Medications (e.g., opioids, benzodiazepines, anticholinergics)
Substance withdrawal (e.g., alcohol, benzodiazepines)
Head trauma or surgery (especially in older adults)
Sleep deprivation and sensory deprivation
prolonged heat or sun exposure


Older adults (especially those with dementia)
Hospitalization, ICU stays
Polypharmacy
History of substance use
Severe illness or chronic conditions
Visual or hearing impairment


Acute onset of confusion and disorientation
Fluctuating levels of consciousness (periods of alertness alternating with drowsiness)
Impaired attention and concentration
Disorganized thinking and incoherent speech
Hallucinations or delusions (often visual)
Agitation, restlessness, or lethargy
Sleep-wake cycle disturbances (e.g., nighttime confusion, daytime drowsiness)


Increased fall risk (due to confusion and agitation)
Aspiration pneumonia (from decreased swallowing ability)
Longer hospital stays and functional decline
Progression to dementia in vulnerable individuals


Clinical assessment (based on sudden onset and fluctuating symptoms)
Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) (screens for delirium)
Blood glucose: rule out Hyperglycemia/Hypoglycemia
Drug screen
Urinalysis: rule out UTI
Rue out e-/fluid imbalance: CMP

Neuroimaging (MRI, CT scan) (if head trauma or stroke is suspected)


Identify and treat underlying cause (e.g., antibiotics for infection, fluids for dehydration)
Medications (only if severe agitation; e.g., low-dose haloperidol or atypical antipsychotics)
Environmental modifications (quiet, well-lit room, familiar objects, reorientation cues)
Adequate hydration, nutrition, and oxygenation
Promote regular sleep-wake cycle


Monitor for sudden changes in mental status
Reorient frequently (provide clocks, calendars, family photos)
Ensure safety (fall precautions, avoid restraints)
Encourage family presence (reduces anxiety and confusion)
Minimize use of sedatives and anticholinergic medications
Promote mobility and engagement (helps prevent worsening symptoms)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Dementia
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

Progressive decline in cognitive function, affecting memory, reasoning, language, and problem-solving
Types:

Vascular Dementia - reduced oxygen to brain from altered vasculature
Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) - protein deposits in brain block neuron connections
Fronto-Temporal dementia (FTD) - affects frontal lobe causing changes in behavior
Mixed Dementia - self-explanatory


Alzheimers - most common cause


advanced age
brain injury
Alzheimers
cardiovascular disease
neurodegenerative diseases: Huntington's, Wernicke-Korsakoff
poor diet, lack of physical activity
smoking, alcohol


memory loss
changes in judgement, problem solving
confusion
wandering
getting lost
changes in speaking & language
inability to express or understand thots & words
difficulty performing daily tasks
hallucinations or delusions


Malnutrition and dehydration (due to forgetting to eat or drink)
Increased fall risk (due to impaired coordination and judgment)
Infections (e.g., pneumonia, urinary tract infections)
Wandering and getting lost
Loss of ability to perform self-care (requiring full-time assistance)
Aspiration pneumonia (due to swallowing difficulties)
depression, anxiety, social isolation


Clinical assessment and history-taking (evaluating cognitive decline)
Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) or Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA)
Neuroimaging (MRI, CT scan to rule out other causes)
Blood tests (to check for reversible causes like vitamin deficiencies, infections, or thyroid disorders)
CSF analysis (for suspected neurodegenerative conditions)


goal: maintain independence (work with ST=swallowing, OT = ADL, PT=mobility, Psych=feels)
no cure but meds can slow progression or manage symptoms
Cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil, rivastigmine, galantamine) for mild-to-moderate dementia
NMDA receptor antagonists (e.g., memantine) for moderate-to-severe cases
Antipsychotics, antidepressants, and mood stabilizers (for behavioral symptoms if necessary)
Cognitive therapy and memory training
Lifestyle modifications (healthy diet, exercise, social engagement)


provide calm and positive environment
remove hazards, use alarms for wandering prevention
maintain structured routines (avoid confusion and anxiety
speak slowly
monitor: depression, agitation, aggression
ensure nutrition and hydration
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: ALS
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro








#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Autonomic Dysreflexia
item.description:
a life-threatening condition that occurs in individuals with spinal cord injury
typically at or above the T6 level => Spinal Cord Injury - SCI
characterized by sudden, severe hypertension and sympathetic nervous system overactivity in response to a noxious stimulus below the level of injury


Bladder distention (most common)
Bowel impaction
Skin irritation (tight clothing, pressure ulcers)
Painful stimuli (e.g., ingrown toenail, burns)
Urinary tract infections
Labor in pregnant women with SCI


Spinal cord injury at T6 level or higher
History of previous autonomic dysreflexia episodes
Poor bladder or bowel management
Skin breakdown or wounds


Sudden, severe hypertension
Bradycardia (sometimes tachycardia)
Severe pounding headache
Flushing and sweating above the level of injury
Pale, cool skin below the level of injury
Nasal congestion
Blurred vision
Anxiety or feeling of impending doom


Stroke
Seizures
Retinal hemorrhage
Cardiac arrest
Death if untreated


Primarily clinical diagnosis based on symptoms in at-risk individuals
Blood pressure monitoring
Identification of trigger (bladder scan, bowel assessment, skin inspection)


Sit the patient upright immediately to lower blood pressure
Loosen tight clothing and remove restrictive devices
Quickly assess for and treat the cause (empty bladder, disimpact bowel, treat wounds)
Administer antihypertensives (e.g., nifedipine) if blood pressure remains high
Monitor blood pressure frequently until episode resolves


Monitor and manage bladder and bowel schedules to prevent triggers
Perform regular skin inspections to prevent pressure injuries
Educate patient and caregivers on early signs and emergency actions
Keep emergency medications at bedside for high-risk patients
Document and report all episodes of AD to the healthcare provider


Recognize early signs and symptoms of AD
Adhere to bowel and bladder regimens
Avoid triggers such as tight clothing and prolonged pressure
Carry emergency card/medical ID indicating risk for autonomic dysreflexia
Seek immediate medical help if symptoms occur
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cerebral Aneurysms
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro


weakening or bulging area in the wall of a cerebral artery
typically asymptomatic but can rupture causing life-threatening subarachnoid hemorrhage
commonly located at arterial bifurcations in the Circle of Willis
most aneurysms do not rupture


hypertension => increased vessel wall stress
Atherosclerosis (weakens vessel walls)
Congenital arterial defects (e.g. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD))
Head trauma
Infections (mycotic aneurysms)
Connective tissue disorders (Ehlers-Danlos, Marfan syndrome)


family hx
smoking - damaged blood vessels
alcohol or drug abuse
age >40


sudden severe headache
Stroke presentation
N/V
visual disturbances
stiff neck
confusion
seizure
LOC
Cardiac Arrest
Death
Unruptured CA: sometimes none, double vision, pain behind eye, dilated pupil, numbness on one side of face


Cerebral Angiogram - gold standard; small catheter is inserted in vessel in leg all the way to brain, guided by x-ray
MRI, CT, CTA
Lumbar Puncture - presence of blood in CSF (+)


ruptured: need surgical intervention ASAP, life-threatening
unruptured or no manifestations: no treatment required, monitor
unruptured but large and symptomatic: surgical intervention or endovascular therapy
surgical clipping - metal clip punches the aneurysm
Endovascular therapy: stent or mesh barrier is inserted to induce a clot, diverting blood from aneurysm


Monitor neurological status (LOC, pupils, motor function)
Maintain BP within target range (avoid hypotension/hypertension)
Keep HOB elevated 30 degrees to reduce ICP
Minimize stimulation (quiet environment, limit visitors)
Implement seizure precautions
Educate on lifestyle modifications (BP control, smoking cessation, avoiding stimulants)
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cerebral Edema
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

swelling of brain
can be fatal
results in herniation = swelling exerts pressure on brain (ICP), blood restriction induces hypoxia


TBI / concussion
Stroke
Brain Tumors or abscesses
Interstitial Shift: CSF increased, hydrocephalus, Meningitis, encephalitis
Osmotic Shift/Edema: DKA, hyponatremia
High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE)
Carbon Monoxide poisoning
Reye's syndrome
lead poisoning
Hepatitis (Ammonia buildup in bloodstream causes brain swelling)


uncontrolled BP
smoking
Diabetes => DKA
activities that result in high risk for falls


headache (most common)
neck rigidity/pain
Cushing's Triad => 1. hypertension, 2. brady, 3. irregular respirations
N/V
dizziness
respiratory pattern changes
vision changes
ataxia - lack of muscle coordination, balance
aphasia - inability to speak or understand speecj
seizure
LOC
pupil changes
CN deficit


increased ICP, leads to herniation
coma, brains stem compression
respiratory failure


CT/MRI - determine midline shift, herniation
ICP monitoring - invasive procedure
CBC - e-
LP


goal: decrease hypertension, control edema, decrease ICP
Surgical: removal of tumors/lesions, shunt insertion, damaged vessel repair
hyperbaric oxygen therapy
hypertonic IVF to decrease CE
Induced hypothermia to redice swelling
Ventriculostomy - drain CSF
Diuretics - reduce swelling (i.e. osmotic diuretics such as mannitol, hypertonic saline)
glucocorticoids - reduce swelling
induced coma
anticonvulsants


monitor GCS & pupil response - detect deterioration
maintain HOB @ 30 deg
avoid excessive stimulation: loud noises, bright lights, frequent repositioning
Avoid HTN
Prevent fever: increases metabolic demand and ICP
Avoid dehydration and HYPOnatermia: worsens CE
Prepare for intubation if brainstem compression worsens
Prepare for seizures
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Eye Disorders
item.description:
Macular degeneration, often called age-related macular degeneration (AMD), is the central loss of vision that affects the macula of the eye.

There is no cure for macular degeneration.
AMD is a common cause of vision loss in older adults. G

Dry macular degeneration is the most common and is caused by a gradual blockage in retinal capillary arteries, which results in the macula becoming ischemic and necrotic due to the lack of retinal cells.
Wet macular degeneration is a less common form and is caused by the new growth of blood vessels that have thin walls that leak blood and fluid.

A cataract is an opacity in the lens of an eye that impairs vision.
Postoperative care should focus on the following.

Preventing an increase in intraocular pressure (straining, bending over the waist, sneezing, blowing nose, coughing, etc)
Preventing infection.
Administering ophthalmic medications.
Providing pain relief.
Teaching the client about self-care at home and fall prevention
NO READING POSTOP to repair DETACHED RETINA
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Head Injuries
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

broad term that refers to any damage to the head due to trauma
can cause TBI => alteration in neuro function
Types (for other types, go to Critical Care section: TBI)

Concussion - mild head injury that may or may not cause a temporary loss of consciousness
Subdural Hematoma - collection of blood between the brain and dura
Monro-Kellie Doctrine - cranial vault is composed blood, brain tissue, CSF (if one of these swells, the other must decrease, otherwise, will result in increased ICP)

Total Score: 3 (lowest) to 15 (highest)

13-15 = Mild brain injury
9-12 = Moderate brain injury
≤8 = Severe brain injury (coma)


MVA
Falls: d/t old age, visual acuity, weakness, chronic hypertension, meds
physical assault
Type of trauma: blunt, penetrating, blast

Concussion Manifestations - may appear abruptly or within days

headache
confusion
difficulty concentrating
N/V
dizziness
blurred vision
fatigue
amnesia of the event that caused injury
Acute Subdural Hematoma (SDH) Manifestations

change in consciousness; memory loss, disorientation
altered pupil response
hemiparesis
severe: HTN, bradycardia, bradypnea, comatose
Chronic SDH

can manifest weeks to months after initial injury
PCS - Post Concussive Syndrome

when manifestations persists for more than 3 months
such as headache, photosensitivity, dizziness, and fatigue


increased ICP
brain herniation
seizures
Hydrocephalus - CSF accumulation
permanent disability
death


full neuro exam: check reflexes, sensation, strength, visual acuity
Affective/emotional: changes in mood, irritability
Cognitive: difficulty concentrating, amnesia, confusion, brain fog
Physical/Somatic: visual disturbances, headaches, dizziness
Sleep: trouble, drowsiness, sleep alteration
Imaging: CT (most common), MRI, XR
CMP, Coags (check PT/INR, PTT)


Mild Head Injury: supportive care only, discontinue activities, analgesia, observation if at risk (e.g. bleeding disorder, anticoagulants)
Small SDH: few or no neuro concerns: rest and observation, clot will be absorbed in months, no long-term complications
Large SDH: surgical to remove hematoma, ICP monitoring
Rehab


fall precautions
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Headaches
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro


pain from stretching, constriction, dilation, or nociceptor stimulation of muscle fibers, meninges, facial structures, blood vessels, or cranial or spinal nerves
varies in location, intensity (sharp, throbbing, or a dull ache)
Primary Headaches - not caused by other conditions; examples: migraines, cluster headaches, tension-type headaches (TTH)
Secondary - caused by other conditions such as trauma, infections, ICP, vascular disorders, etc
Migraines - recurrent headaches that last for four to 72 hr; from change in cerebral perfusion; not fully understood
Status Migrainosis - lasts for more than 72 hours


Head trauma
Caffeine
Foods containing nitrates or tyramine
Artificial sweeteners
Hormonal changes
Bright lights
Strong odors
Changes in weather
Stress
Skipping meals


Carbon monoxide poisoning
Cerebrovascular Accident
Intracranial hemorrhage (see Subarachnoid Hemorrhage - blood in space under the arachnoid membrane, most commonly from trauma/rupture of an aneurysm)
Hypertension emergencies
Meningitis
Encephalitis
Acute angle-closure glaucoma
Brain tumor



mild/moderate pain on both sides of head
dull/band-like pressure
Muscle tightness in the shoulder, neck, or back
associated with sleep disturbances
lasts 30 min to 7 days


Severe unilateral head pain, often behind the eye
Lacrimation, nasal congestion, eyelid/facial swelling, ptosis may occur (ptosis - drooping eyelid)
Excruciating, nonfluctuating pain; clients may pace or rock
Duration: 15 min to hours, may occur multiple times daily

Prodormal Phase (Hours to Days Before Headache)

Sensitivity to light, sound, odor
Fatigue, yawning
Food cravings, excessive thirst
Mood swings
Constipation or diarrhea
Aura Phase (Lasts ~60 min, Precedes Headache, Reversible Symptoms, Affects ~25%)

Visual, sensory, motor disturbances
Tunnel vision, blindness, visual field loss
Heaviness in limbs
Speech/language disturbances
Scintillating scotoma
Tingling in face/limbs
Headache Phase (Unilateral, Throbbing, Lasts Hours to Days, >72 hr = Status Migrainosus)

Nausea/vomiting
Photophobia, phonophobia => sensitivity to light and sound
Rhinorrhea, lachrymation
Loss of appetite, fatigue
Postdromal Phase ("Migraine Hangover," Lasts 1–2 Days)

Pain with movement in migraine location
Exhaustion, dizziness
Difficulty concentrating
Euphoria




none; usually
MRI/CT - for older than 50 with no hx, if present with hypertension or AMS
Lumbar Puncture - analyze CSF for Meningitis


Analgesia - usually OTC: aspirin, aceta, NSAID
Caffeine with analgesics
Opioids NOT recommended
Pharmacological treatments - only for headaches 3-15 times/month
Triptans - constrict intracranial vessels (e.g.: Sumatriptans, razatiptan) see Migraines pharm section
Anticonvulscants - valpiruc acid, topiramate
beta blockers
tricyclic antidepressants
botulinum toxins
IV fluids
steroids
non pharm: biofeedback, CBT, chiropractor, assage, craniosacal therapy, yoga, accupuntcture


ensure dark, quiet room
NOTE: if patient complains that it is their WORST HEADACHE, assess for secondary headache to rule out life-threats

avoid: cheese, meats with nitrites, aspartame, pickled foods, MSG
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: ICP
item.description:
Increased pressure within the skull due to brain swelling, excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), or bleeding
Can lead to brain herniation and death if untreated
Normal ICP: 5-10 mmHg; Critical ICP: >20 mmHg
Note: MAP (Mean Arterial Pressure) => good indicator of cerebral perfusion; minimum: 60 mm Hg; too high MAP leads to decreased blood flow to brain


Increase in Brain volume: Cerebral Edema, hemorrhage, tumor, abscess, infarction
Increase in CSF: hydrocephalus, Meningitis, choroid plexus tumor, just plain old increase CSF
Increased Blood Volume: venous stasis, elevated CVP
Other Causes - idiopathic intracranial hypertension, skull deformities, tetracycline use
Individual Causes:

TBI
Stroke
Cerebral Edema - head trauma, hypoxia, liver failure (ammonia buildup)
Intracranial Hemorrhage
Severe Hypertension


Head trauma (falls, car accidents, assaults)
Aneurysm rupture (subarachnoid hemorrhage)
Severe infections (meningitis, encephalitis)
Brain tumors or metastases
Congenital conditions (hydrocephalus, Arnold-Chiari malformation)
Liver failure (risk of cerebral edema from ammonia buildup)

Early Signs:

altered LOC: confusion, restlessness, drowsiness
Headache (worsens with movement, coughing, or straining)
Blurred vision, diplopia (double vision)
Photophobia
N/V
Late Signs (Cushing’s Triad - Brainstem Compression):

Hypertension with widening pulse pressure
Bradycardia (slow heart rate)
Irregular respirations (Cheyne-Stokes or Biot’s breathing)
Other late signs:

Papilledema (swelling of optic disc)
Pupil changes (unequal, sluggish, or fixed/dilated)
Posturing: decorticate (flexion), decerebrate (extension)
seizures
coma


Brain herniation (fatal displacement of brain tissue)
Permanent neurological deficits (motor, sensory, cognitive impairments)
Seizures
Coma and death


CT scan/MRI (detect swelling, bleeding, tumors, hydrocephalus)
ICP monitoring (ventriculostomy, intraparenchymal device)
Lumbar puncture contraindicated => increases ICP (d/t decreasing pressure gradient in spine further pushes brain downward)
Fundoscopic exam (papilledema)
Ventriculostomy - insertion of a catheter into one of the brain's ventricles to drain cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) or to monitor intracranial pressure.
Ventriculostomy Transducer => maintain at the level of the tragus


Reduce ICP and prevent complications
Elevate HOB 30 degrees (promotes venous drainage)
Oxygen therapy (maintain cerebral oxygenation)
Mechanical ventilation (if necessary) – PaCO₂ 30-35 mmHg to reduce cerebral blood flow
Surgery: craniotomy, external ventricular drain (EVD) to drain excess CSF, decompressive craniectomy (remove park of skull)
Decrease metabolic demand: barbiturates, sedation, pain control
Medications:

Osmotic diuretics (mannitol) – reduces cerebral edema => initial target of serum osmolality is often set at 300–320 mOsmol/kg.
Hypertonic saline (3%) – pulls fluid out of brain cells
Corticosteroids (dexamethasone) – for tumors, inflammation
Sedatives (propofol, benzodiazepines) – decrease metabolic demand
Antiepileptics – prevent seizures: benzo, phenytoin, valproic acid
Neuromuscular blockers (for severe cases requiring intubation)


No Lumbar Punctures allowed! => increases ICP (d/t decreasing pressure gradient in spine further pushes brain downward)
Monitor LOC and Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) (↓ GCS = worsening ICP)
maintaining the ventriculostomy transducer at the level of the tragus
Assess pupil reaction (PERRLA) and vital signs frequently
Maintain head and neck alignment (avoid flexion or turning head)
Minimize stimulation (low lights, quiet room)
Avoid straining (stool softeners, prevent coughing/sneezing)
Cluster nursing care to minimize ICP spikes
Seizure precautions (padded rails, oxygen, suction at bedside)
Monitor for signs of herniation (fixed dilated pupils, loss of reflexes, coma)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Meningitis
item.description:
inflammation of the meninges (protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord)
viral or bacterial (sometimes parasitic => rare)
causes disruption in neuro functions d/t inflammation
Bacterial - medical emergency due to rapid progression & high mortality
Viral - resolves on its own, less serious


Viral: HSV, enteroviruses (common in warm places/tropical), HIV, measles, mumps, West Nile virus
Bacterial: Hib, Listeria monocytogenes (common in elderly/newborns), Strep pneumoniae, Enteroviruses (common among 5 below)
Funga (rare)
Parasitic (rare)


Immunocompromised - HIV, very old, very young
living in group setting
travel
Direct Bacterial entry - head trauma, skull fractures, neurosurgery
unvaccinated
Recent Surgery: spine, lack of spleen, CSF leak


Classic Triad: Fever, Stiff Neck (nuchal rigidity), altered mental status
Severe headache
Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
Nausea and vomiting
Seizures (in severe cases)
Confusion, lethargy, irritability
Petechial rash (meningococcal meningitis)
Positive Brudzinski’s sign (neck flexion causes knee flexion)
Positive Kernig’s sign (pain with knee extension when hip is flexed)


Sepsis (meningococcemia, life-threatening)
Seizures and epilepsy
Hearing loss (common long-term effect)
Hydrocephalus (CSF buildup in brain)
Cognitive impairments, learning disabilities
Brain damage, coma, or death (if untreated or severe cases)


lumbar puncture (LP): Bacterial => cloudy CSF, ↑ protein, ↓ glucose (bacteria is eating the glucose)
Blood cultures** (to identify bacterial source)
CT/MRI scan (rule out brain abscess, increased ICP before LP)
Nasal/throat swabs (detect viral or bacterial organisms)


Viral; supportive care, Acyclovir (if HSV)
Bacterial: ABX (Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime + vancomycin,)
Reduce brain swell: dexamethasone
Seizure Precautions
ICP management => manage BP, avoid straining, elevate HOB
Prevention: vaccination


Monitor neurological status (LOC, pupil response, vital signs)
Implement droplet precautions for bacterial meningitis (until 24 hrs after antibiotics)
Elevate HOB 30 degrees (reduce ICP)
Reduce environmental stimuli (quiet, dim lights for photophobia)
Monitor for signs of increased ICP (worsening headache, vomiting, bradycardia, hypertension)
Administer pain relievers, fever reducers (acetaminophen)
Encourage vaccination (Hib, pneumococcal, meningococcal vaccines prevent bacterial forms)
Contraindications for LP: increased ICP, Thrombocytopenia, suspected spinal epidural abscess


maintain or normalize BP
manage fever & pain
prevent seizures
maintain or improve neuro status
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Multiple Sclerosis
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro








#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: NIHSS Stroke Scale
item.description:
Overview: Standardized tool for assessing stroke severity evaluates neurological impairment based on specific criteria commonly used in acute stroke care and research
Scoring:
0 = No stroke symptoms
1-4 = Minor stroke
5-15 = Moderate stroke
16-20 = Moderate to severe stroke
21-42 = Severe stroke
Assessment Components:

Level of Consciousness (LOC): Alertness response to questions/commands
Best Gaze: Horizontal eye movement
Visual Fields: Visual field deficits
Facial Palsy: Facial muscle weakness
Motor Arm (L/R): Arm strength and drift
Motor Leg (L/R): Leg strength and drift
Limb Ataxia: Coordination assessment
Sensory: Sensation loss Best
Language: Ability to name objects follow commands
Dysarthria: Clarity of speech
Extinction/Inattention (Neglect): Awareness of stimuli on both sides
Scoring Tips: Each item scored individually then totaled higher scores indicate greater impairment used to guide treatment decisions like thrombolytic therapy and predict outcomes
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Parkinson's
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

degenerative, progressive condition primarily caused by dopamine depletion in substantia nigra
leads to motor and non-motor symptoms
mainly affects movement but can also impact cognition and autonomic functions
Low on Dope: dopamine
High on Acetylcholine => lots of secretions and drooling (rest and digest)
Low on Norepinephrine
Hallmark finding: Lewy bodies => abnormal structures inside brain cells


Idiopathic (most common)
Genetic mutations (e.g., PARK genes)
Environmental toxins (e.g., pesticides, heavy metals)
Brain injury or repeated head trauma
Certain medications (drug-induced parkinsonism)


male
family history
Age >60 years
exposure to environmental toxins (heavy metals, pesticides, and chemical toxins)
history of TBI
Diabetes T2


Low dopamine effects: tremors, slow movement, stiffness, and problems with balance (fall risk)
Low norepinephrine effects: fatigue, irregularities in blood pressure, and slowed movement of the gastrointestinal tract.
HIGH Acetylcholine Effects: secretions, drooling
Motor Symptoms:

Resting tremor (pill-rolling, worsens at rest) = decreased when diverted by activity
Gait: propulsive shuffling, decreased arm swing
Bradykinesia (slowed movements, difficulty initiating)
Muscle rigidity (cogwheel or lead-pipe rigidity)
Postural instability (frequent falls, shuffling gait)
Non-Motor Symptoms:

Autonomic dysfunction (orthostatic hypotension, constipation, urinary retention)
drooling
Cognitive impairment (dementia in later stages)
Depression, anxiety
Sleep disturbances (REM behavior disorder, insomnia)
Anosmia (loss of smell)



Increased fall risk leading to fractures
Aspiration pneumonia (due to dysphagia and excessive drooling) => suction at bedside available!
Dementia (Parkinson’s disease dementia)
Depression, social isolation
Medication side effects (dyskinesia, hallucinations)


no definitive test
mainly clinical diagnosis (based on motor symptoms, response to levodopa)
MRI/CT (rule out other conditions)
DaTscan (dopamine transporter imaging to support diagnosis)


Levodopa-carbidopa (most effective for motor symptoms)
Dopamine agonists (pramipexole, ropinirole)
MAO-B inhibitors (selegiline, rasagiline)
Anticholinergics (for tremors in younger patients)
Amantadine (for dyskinesia)
Deep brain stimulation (DBS) for medication-resistant cases
Rehab:

expiratory muscle strength training
PT
OT
speech


High-protein diet timing (to avoid interfering with levodopa absorption) =>Leave the PROTEIN with LEVOdopa
wandering precautions => use signs on doors, place locks
Falls Risk
Dysphagia => Aspiration
encourage physical activity
expiratory muscle strength training (EMST)
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Peripheral Neuropathy
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro

Damage to the peripheral nerves, leading to sensory, motor, and autonomic dysfunction
generally described as a symptom of something else
Types:

Sensory - numbness, tingling, and decreased ability to sense hot, cold, or pain
Motor - weakness, loss of balance, and difficulty breathing or swallowing
Autonomic - constipation, diarrhea, changes with urination, dizziness, issues with sexual function, or sweating problems


Diabetes T1, Diabetes T2 (most common cause)
Chemotherapy-induced neuropathy (common in Cancer treatment)
Autoimmune diseases (Guillain-Barré syndrome, lupus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Chronic alcoholism (nutritional deficiencies)
Vitamin deficiencies (B12, B6, E, niacin)
Infections (HIV-AIDS, Lyme disease, leprosy)
Toxins (heavy metals, pesticides)
Kidney disease (uremic neuropathy)
Hypothyroidism
Nerve compression (carpal tunnel syndrome, herniated discs)
Hereditary conditions (Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease)


Uncontrolled diabetes
Excessive alcohol use
Poor nutrition
Autoimmune disorders
Chronic kidney or liver disease
Exposure to toxins or certain medications
Genetic predisposition

Sensory Symptoms:

Numbness, tingling, or burning sensation (often in hands and feet)
Increased or decreased pain sensitivity (hyperesthesia or hypoesthesia)
Loss of ability to feel temperature changes or pain
"Stocking-glove" distribution (symptoms begin in feet and hands)
Motor Symptoms:

Muscle weakness or atrophy
Difficulty walking, coordination issues, foot drop
Muscle cramps or twitching
Autonomic Symptoms:

Orthostatic hypotension (dizziness upon standing)
Bowel and bladder dysfunction
Excessive sweating or inability to sweat
Sexual dysfunction


Falls and injuries (due to impaired sensation and muscle weakness)
Chronic pain
Infections, ulcers, and poor wound healing (especially in diabetic patients)
Loss of limb (in severe diabetic neuropathy cases)
Autonomic dysfunction complications (hypotension, cardiac issues)


Clinical assessment (history, symptom pattern)
Nerve conduction studies (NCS) & electromyography (EMG) (assess nerve damage)
Blood tests (check for diabetes, vitamin deficiencies, infections, kidney/liver function)
Skin or nerve biopsy (for small fiber neuropathy)
MRI or CT scan (to rule out nerve compression)


Treat underlying cause (e.g., blood sugar control in diabetes, correcting deficiencies)
Medications for neuropathic pain:
Anticonvulsants (gabapentin, pregabalin)
Tricyclic antidepressants (amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
SNRIs (duloxetine, venlafaxine)
Topical treatments (capsaicin cream, lidocaine patches)
Opioids rarely used (except for severe cases)
Physical therapy (to improve strength, balance, and mobility)
Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) (pain relief)
Plasma exchange or IVIG (for autoimmune neuropathies)


Monitor for worsening symptoms (progressive weakness, autonomic dysfunction)
Educate on foot care (especially for diabetic patients):
Inspect feet daily for ulcers or injuries
Wear properly fitted shoes
Avoid extreme temperatures (due to decreased sensation)
Encourage safety precautions:
Fall prevention (assistive devices, adequate lighting)
Avoid burns (use gloves for hot surfaces, check water temp before bathing)
Promote medication adherence
Encourage lifestyle modifications:
Smoking cessation (improves circulation)
Regular exercise (enhances nerve function)
Well-balanced diet (rich in B vitamins, healthy fats)


Chronic pain related to nerve damage
Impaired physical mobility related to muscle weakness and sensory deficits
Risk for injury related to decreased sensation and balance issues
Self-care deficit related to loss of fine motor skills
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Seizures
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro


abnormal and unregulated electrical impulses in the brain’s gray matter
caused by acute medical issue or recurring (epilepsy)
varied presentation
Types: generalized (both hemispheres), focal (one hemisphere), unknown
Category: motor, nonmotor
Status Epilepticus

seizure lasting more than 5 minutes
recurring seizures without regaining consciousness between episodes
emergency!
leads to permanent brain damage, hypoxia, death
Priority: maintain airway, benzo, antiepileptics
if continuous: intubate and sedate


Structural abnormalities (tumors, stroke, trauma)
Metabolic imbalances (Hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, hypoxia)
Infections (Meningitis, encephalitis, fever in children) - most common
Toxic exposure (alcohol withdrawal, drug overdose)
Genetic disorders (epilepsy syndromes)
Unknown


Stress
Sleep Deprivation or Fatigue
Strobe Lights
Stimulants
Sugar and Low Sodium

4 Stages of Seizures:

Prodormal - hours or days before seizure, anxiety, mood changes, difficulty sleeping
Early Ictal or Aura - warning stage: strange smells, taste or feelings, deja vu, excitement
Ictal - main seizure
Postictal - seizure ends; confusion, drowsiness, headache, muscle soreness, memory loss, weakness
Generalized Seizures - affects both hemispheres of the brain

Tonic-Clonic (Grand Mal) - LOC, muscle rigidity (tonic), rhythmic jerking (clonic), postictal confusion
Absence (Petit Mal) - brief loss of awareness, blank stare, eye blinking or lip smacking, common in children
Myoclonic - (myo=muscle), sudden, brief muscle jerks, no LOC
Tonic - toned muscles (muscle contractions/stiffening, causing falls)
Clonic - (repetitive = clone) repetitive jerking movements, usually symmetrical, contraction then relaxation
Atonic (Drop Attacks) - sudden loss of muscle tone, leads to falls
Focal / Partial Seizures - only one brain hemisphere

Focal Aware / Simple Partial - no LOC, localized symptoms (twitching, sensory changes
Focal Impaired Awareness / Complex Partial - altered consciousness, automatism (lip smacking, picking at clothes), postictal confusion
Status Epilicticus

medical emergency!
seizure lasting >5 minutes ore repeated seizures without recovery
may occur with ant type of seizure


injury from falls, aspiration, or trauma
hypoxia or metabolic disturbances
cognitive impairment with recurring seizures


EEG (detects abnormal brain activity) - usually after a seizure
MRI/CT scan (identifies structural causes)
Blood tests (checks for metabolic or toxic triggers)
Lumbar puncture (if infection suspected)


supportive care: maintain ABC, keep free from injury
First line - benzodiazapines (IV, IM, rectal)
Recurrent issues: anticonvulsants (12 categories, too many to mention, common=>phenytoin AED)
vagal nerve stimulation
neurostimulation
lesionectomy or lobectomy


seizure precautions: call for help, padded side rails, lower bed, O2 & suction at bedside
do not restrain client
do not put tongue blade in mouth during seizure
do not put airway or open jaw during seizure
clear area for any hard objects
Loosen clothes from around the head, neck, or chest
place client in lateral position (left side if possible) - to prevent aspiration
Maintain the airways and suction if needed
record time of seizure, note duration
after seizure, assess ABC: including presence of gag reflex
after seizure: provide supplement O2 , check ABC, VS, neuro check, reorient


anything that could be dangerous with unexpected seizure
climbing tall structures
working from heights
cooking over fire
operating power tools
taking baths/swimming WITHOUT supervision
driving
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Spinal Cord Injury - SCI
item.description:
CNS => brain & spinal cord
Meninges - continuous connective tissue layers covering the spine and brain
Layers of meninges: pia mater, arachnoid, dura
CSF = located in subarachnoid space
Spinal Cord roles:

send stimuli from body to brain
send motor instructions from brain to body
direct reflexes
Spinal Cord Reflexes - do not rely on brain to transmit reflex
Vertebrae Count- In Order: Breakfast at 7, Lunch at 12, Dinner at 5

Cervical - 7 (but has 8 cervical nerve roots)
Thoracic - 12
Lumbar - 5
Sacral - 5
Coccyx - 1

Classification based on Mechanism of Injury:

Compression of Spinal Cord - most common, caused by vertebral fractures with bone fragments or dislocation
Intermittent Compression - often seen in hyperextension injuries
Distraction Injury - two adjoining vertebrae have been pulled apart, causing the spine to stretch and tear.
Transection and Laceration - a projectile object or bone fragments from significant dislocations can tear or sever the spinal cord.
Classification based on Location => see vertebrae count
Classification based on Severity => loss of all sensation and control below the damage (complete, vs incomplete)

A - complete SCI, no sensory function, no motor function
B - some sensory function, no motor function
C - some sensory function, some motor function (less than half can lift against gravity)
D - same as C, but more than half have motor
Secondary Injury - result after the initial injury d/t impaired blood flow (e.g. inflammation, hematoma formation, blood loss, and hypovolemic shock)


Impaired Mobility
Sexual Dysfunction - depends on level of injury
Mental health: dealing with changes and limitations, body image, suicide risk
Aging => patients with SCIs age faster => more likely to have bone loss, chronic pain, kidney stones, and pressure injuries


prevention: motor vehicle safety, seat belts, airbags, car seats, no texting, no DUIs
Falls risk for elderly
responsible gun ownership
sports protective gear
water safety
Trampolines are well lit and ground level to prevent falls, avoid crowing, netting in place, supervise

**Tetraplegia

injuries from C1 to T1
unable to move all extremities (can be all the way from head, neck, to legs)
Paraplegia

loss of fnuction of lower portion of body from chest to lower extremities
T2 to S5
5 Plexuses:
C1 to C4: ventilator dependence
C1 to C8: limited proprioception
T1 to T8: affects trunk movement, lack of abdominal control
T9 to T12: limited abdominal control
L1 to S5: loss of bowel and bladder functioning, affects sexual function

GI: spastic bladder => leakage of stool and urine, bladder flaccidity, inability to expel stool or urine


a complication wherein severe SCI causes loss of muscle tone and reflexes
spinal cord may appear functionless
transient and can have some recovery
manifestations: loss of anal sphincter tone, and the absence of bowel and bladder control


Atelectasis & Pneumonia => decreased cough strength, higher risk of pulmonary complications
Heterotopic Ossification - abnormal bone growth into non-skeletal areas, such as soft tissues, muscles, or tendons
develops 3-12 weeks after injury, but can occur years later
usually occurs in the shoulders, elbows, and knees
more common in females
Autonomic Dysreflexia - exaggerated reflexive response which increases blood pressure due to a noxious stimulus below the level of injury
BP over 150 mm Hg sys, or over 40 diastolic over baseline
caused by certain triggers: pain pressure ulcers, fractures, urinary tract infections, sexual intercourse, constipation, and surgery. Any noxious stimulus can trigger AD.
increased risk of clots and skin breakdown d/t decreased movement
treatment: ROM exercises, meds, therapy
can be life threatening for above the T6 level SCI
Skin Issues => logroll using c-collar, remove backboards ASAP, use dynamic mattresses


patient sit upright with legs dangling
remove tight clothing
vitals Q5
remove triggering stimulis: drain bladder, fecal impaction
Lower BP: nifedipine 10 mg via bite and swallow technique, repeat q20-30 min, or nitroglycerine
preventL self-catherization 5-6 times per day, digital rectal stimulation laxatives


Imaging: XR, CT, MRI
GCS


Halo Fixation Device - rigid external immobilization device for the upper cervical spine
consent needed
nurse: ensure wrenches and tools are attached to the vest in case of an emergent need to remove or tighten the device
Pin Care: daily or per provider orders, clean with hydrogen peroxide, betadine, or other antiseptic. crusts are removed with cottown swabs
separate supplies for each pin site
Surgical - removal of vertebrae, herniated discs, or bone fragments pressing on spine
Surgical - spinal decompression => relives pressures
Rehabilitation - PT, OT => begins on day one


NGT Decompression => if paralytic ileus is present
foley for retention (expected)
TENS - transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation


Diet: fluid and fiber intake to increase their stool's water content to encourage gastric transit
Injury Prevention: decrease the frequency of propulsive strokes during wheelchair mobility and to decrease the number of transfers in a day
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Stroke
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro


sudden loss of brain function due to interrupted blood flow causing neuro dysfunction
brain cells experience hypoxia (unlike TIA where it is temporary)
can cause lifelong disability or death


Ischemic - sudden loss of circulation; embolism or plaques block brain arteries (carioembolic = embolism from heart)
Hemorrhagic - blood vessel in brain ruptures (Cerebral Aneurysms) causing increased pressure, increased ICP = decreased brain blood flow => cerebral ischemia


HTN - most common; increased pressure can cause vessels to rupture leading to hemorrhagic stroke
diabetes - most common
severe OSA
heart valve disease
MI
Aneurysm
smoking, vaping
sedentary
oral contraceptives, coagulopathies, migraines, trauma, drug use


Right Hemisphere Stroke - left side paralysis and sensory loss, right visual field loss, aphasia (look straight, but move opposite)
Left Hemisphere Stroke - r side paralysis and sensory loss, L visual field loss
BE FAST
B - loss of balance, dizziness
E - vision loss in one or both eyes
F - facial drooping, uneven symmetry (Hemiplegia)
A - arms weak, numbness
S - slurred speech
T - call 911 immediately
Hemorrhagic stroke: headache (classic tell-tale sign of hemorrhagic vs ischemic), N/V, seizures
Other Effects:

Aphasia {Expressive = you say words you don't intend to say, Receptive = cannot understand words}
Hemiplegia - paralysis or weakness on one side of body
Hemiparesis - paralysis of one side of body
Hemianopsia - loss of vision in half of visual field
Ataxia - poor muscle control causing clumsy movements
Dysarthria - difficulty speaking
Dysphagia - difficulty swallowing
Increased ICP


falls
depression
UTI
pneumonia


r/o glucose or e- imbalance! (similar manifestations with stroke/TIA)
CBC, Coags => r/o hypercoagulability



Fibrinolysis & aspirin - if embolic (alteplase) => monitor for bleeding, angioedema
Respiratory - supplemental O2; intubation d/t to increased ICP and compression of brainstem
Antiepileptics
Physical Therapy - mobility, strength
Occupational Therapy - ADLs, regain independence
Speech Therapy - swallowing


thrombectomy - blood clot (thrombus) is removed from a blood vessel.
decompressive hemicraniectomy (partial removal of skull to relieve ICP)
reversal agent for anticoagulants (if applicable)
Osmotic Diuretics d/t increased ICP
Respiratory - supplemental O2; intubation d/t to increased ICP and compression of brainstem
Antiepileptics
Physical Therapy - mobility, strength
Occupational Therapy - ADLs, regain independence
Speech Therapy - swallowing


evaluate swallowing ability for choking or aspiration risk
falls risk
bleeding precautions in patients receiving thrombolytics or Anticoagulants, Antiplatelets
#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
item.description:
blood enters space between arachnoid membrane and the pia membrane
common cause: ruptured cerebral aneurism
neurological emergency that leads to Increased ICP, brain ischemia, death
high mortality rate: 10-15% die prior to ED arrival, 25% within 24 hr, 40% within 1 month


Aneurysm Rupture
TBI
Hypertensive crisis
bleeding disorders


hypertension
smoking
alcohol use disorder
cocaine use
Ehler-Danlos Syndrome Type IV
Marfan's Syndrome
Ruptured Aneurysm Risk Factors: 40-50+ years old, female

EARLY SIGNS

Severe “thunderclap” headache – sudden onset
“worst headache of my life”
Double vision
Neck pain
Stiffness
Altered consciousness
Cranial nerve palsy (CN III & VI) => hearing/balance & neck muscles
Nausea and vomiting
LATE SIGNS:

vasospasm
cerebral ischemia
coma
seizures
rebleeding
hydrocephalus


rebleeding - highest risk within 24-48 hours => biggest cause of death
vasospasm
hydrocephalus
seizures
increased ICP
death


Non-contrast CT scan – first-line; highly sensitive within 72 hours
Lumbar Puncture - if CT negative but SAH still suspected => cannot be done on patients with increased ICP; lie on LEFT SIDE; FETAL POSITION
CT angiograph or cerebral angiogram - to identify source of bleeding
MRI/MRA - follow-up or unclear cases


manage blood pressure: keep MAP above 70 mm Hg, 90 mm Hg if vasospasms are present
Antihypertensives: Nicardipine (CCB)
Anti-hypotensive: Levophed - vasoconstrictor
Antifibrinolytics: TXA; prevents rebleeding
Antiseizures: Levetiracetam (Keppra)
Meds for vasospasm => CCBs: Nimodipine
SURGICAL: clipping the aneurysm, coiling the aneurysm
Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) - increased amounts of atmospheric pressure and breathing of increased oxygen amounts to treat conditions such as mild TBIs and, more commonly, acute or chronic wounds


seizure precautions
strict BP monitoring
manage ICP => HOB 30
monitor neuro
avoid stimulation, provide calm environment


avoid activities that increase ICP => straining, coughing
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: TBI
item.description:
Types of mechanical forces:

Direct - direct blow to the head resulting in bruising of the brain.
Rotational - abrupt, rotating impact to the head i.e., an acceleration-deceleration injury.
Shear - Happen when the brain shifts and rotates inside the bony skull causing shearing of the axons in the brain i.e., diffuse axonal injury.
TBI Classification

Primary Injury - skull fracture, contusion, concussion (can be focal, diffuse, or both)
Secondary - ischemia, hypoxia, increased ICP, Cerebral Edema
Coup - A brain injury site on the same side of the striking force.
Contre-Coup - injury site on the opposite side of the striking force caused by the brain impacting the skull.
Mild TBI - concussion


Closed Head Injuries - blunt impact, MVC, fall
Penetrating Head Injuries - exposed to infection
Explosive Blast


neuropathological brain disease associated with multiple mild to severe TBIs
caused by sustained repetitive concussions (contact sports, boxing, wrestling)
can only be diagnosed after death => limited understanding of the disease
changes related to cognitive function, impaired memory and thinking patterns, behavior with increased aggression and impulsivity, moods with depression and anxiety


Loss of consciousness for seconds to minutes
Headache
Confusion
Dizziness
Blurred vision
Ringing in the ears
Tiredness
Changes in behavior or mood
Sensitivity to light or sound
Nausea or vomiting
Changes to sleep patterns


Loss of consciousness for minutes to hours
Persistent headache
Seizures
Loss of vision, dilated pupils
Difficulty understanding, communicating, or concentrating
Extremity weakness
Coordination and balance challenges
Sensory perception changes
Aggression
Depression


CSF Leakage => may lead to meningitis, damage to brain spinal cord
Hyperoxia => too much oxygen, leads to arterial vasoconstriction and injury to the brain, lungs, and heart.


standard labs: CBC, CMP, urine toxicology screen, blood alcohol level
non-contrast head CT, MRI, angiography to identify vascular injuries


maintain cerebral perfusion pressure greater than 60 mm Hg
maintain ABC
Decrease ICP: Mannitol, hypertonic saline, and barbiturates
Surgical: decompressive craniectomy or placement of external ventricular drains or cisternostomy to monitor and maintain intracranial pressures
Therapeutic hypothermia (TH) - lowering of a client’s body temperature from 32° C (89.6° F) to 35° C (95° F) to protect brain function
IVF, pressors PRN
HOB 30-45
Maintain alignment of the head, keep transducer at correct levels
Sedation & Analgesia
Seizure prophylaxis
Insulin Sliding Scale
Nursing: adequate nutrition, skin integrity, infection prevention, seizure precautions, trend vital signs, GCS, I/Os
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: TIA
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #neuro


aka ministroke
blood flow to brain is temporarily blocked
resolves complete and does not cause residual neuro manifestations (unlike a stroke)
can last for a few minutes or up to 24 hours
major warning sign to seek medical attention ASAP


stenosis - reduced blood flow
embolic occlusion - clot of blood vessel, can vary in size, disintegrate and block a smaller vessel in brain
Carotid Artery Stenosis
emboli from heart (e.g. A.Fib, valve disease)
Atherosclerosis
Clotting Disorders - too much clotting


hypertension - major one
Diabetes
cardiovascular disease
hyperlipidemia
smoking
obesity
alcohol
poor
previous TIA


slurred speech
dizziness
headache
blurred vision or double vision
one-sided weakness
aphasia
FAST - stroke



may resremble hypoglycemia or e- imbalance: test glucose and CBC
Coags => PT/INR to determine hypercoagulability
toxicology
Cardiac Enzymes
Lipid Profile
CT/MRI
ECG & CXR - determine a-fib or cardiac abnormaility
Holter Monitor - detect A.Fib
Carotid Ultrasound - assess stenosis


Antiplatelets: CAD (clopidogrel, aspirin, dipyridamole) if embolic
Anticoagulants if with A.Fib: apixaban, warfarin
Surgical: stent or carotid endarectomy (remove buildup of plaque)

#nursing #medsurg #neuro
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: ARDS
item.description:
Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome => occurs after 7 days of a triggering event
results in pulmonary artery vasoconstriction => pulmonary hypertension
life threatening and requires ventilation!
Key Differences Between regular pneumonia:
ARDS:

can be infections or non infectious (PNA is caused by infection)
rapid onset
widespread alveolar damage (PNA is localized)
treated with supportive care only (PNA is antibiotics + supportive)
higher mortality of 30-40%


Injury Trigger: Direct (e.g. pneumonia, aspiration) or indirect (e.g. sepsis, trauma) lung injury causes inflammation
Alveolar-Capillary Damage: Inflammatory mediators damage alveolar-capillary membrane → increased permeability
Fluid Leak: Protein-rich fluid leaks into alveoli → pulmonary edema
Impaired Gas Exchange: Edema + collapsed alveoli (atelectasis) → ↓ surfactant, ↓ compliance, severe hypoxemia
Ventilation-Perfusion Mismatch: Poor oxygenation despite oxygen therapy (refractory hypoxemia)
Progression: Can lead to fibrotic lung changes and multi-organ failure if not reversed
BERLIN DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA (all 4 must be met):

Timing - Within 1 week of clinical insult or new/worsening respiratory symptoms
Chest Imaging - Bilateral opacities not fully explained by effusions, lobar/lung collapse, or nodules
Origin of Edema:
Respiratory failure not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload
Objective assessment (e.g., echo) needed if no clear risk factor
Oxygenation (on PEEP ≥5 cm H₂O)
Mild ARDS: PaO₂/FiO₂ 200–300 mmHg
Moderate ARDS: PaO₂/FiO₂ 100–200 mmHg
Severe ARDS: PaO₂/FiO₂ ≤100 mmHg


Sepsis => MOST COMMON CAUSE
Pneumonia - also common
Aspiration - also common
Community Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)


female
60+
trauma
drowning
drug OD
TBI
recent cardiac surgery
smoking
alcohol abuse
HIV or any Immunosuppressive state
COPD
Heart Failure - chronic
Liver Cirrhosis
Blood Malignancies: cancers
Immunosuppression


dyspnea => progressively worsens within 6 to 72 hours after the event
respiratory distress
tachypnea
diffuse crackles
tachycardia
Severe cases: somnolent, cyanosis, diaphoresis
NOTE SIGNATURE MANIFESTATION: DOES NOT RESPOND TO OXYGENATION!
Somnolent - reduced level of consciousness that is described as lethargic or drowsy



muscle wasting - due to inactivity, patients are too SOB to do anything
weight loss
Functional Impairment - due to decreased mobility, atrophy, weakness
Cognitive loss - caused by brain hypoxia
Dependency on: g-tube for nutrition, new tracheostomy
Prolonged symptoms: exertional dyspnea, exercise intolerance
greater impact for geriatric

Berlin Criteria for ARDS:

onset occurring within 7 days of an event
non-cardiac origin
imaging indicating bilateral lung infiltrates
specific abnormal oxygenation measurements (PaO/FiO ratio of less than 300 mm Hg to confirm the diagnosis)
Other Diagnostic Tools:

ABG
PaO2/Fio2 - less than 300 mm Hg (normal range is over 400 => note that this is a ratio!)
FiO2 & PaO2 => determines severity of ARDS (mild, moderate, severe)
Impaired Kidney Function - elevated, CMP
Cardiac Enzymes - rule out cardiac origin

Goals:

increase O2 delivery
avoid injury to lungs
decrease shunting
decrease O2 consumption
Strategies:

Lung Protective Ventilation (avoid ventilator induced trauma, not too in-depth in exam)
judicious suctioning only PRN
Pain Management & Sedation
V/Q match
Avoid infection/VAPs: HOB 30, oral care, hand hygiene
Turning: passive ROMs, avoiding DVT/PE (thru SCDs, anticoagulants)
Ventilator Weaning ias tolerated
Treatment Interventions:

Pre-intubation: high-flow O2 NC or FM
Intubation meds: Sedative (etomidate), neuromuscular Blockers (succinylcholine)
note: sedate before you paralyze, BVM at bedside (1 breath q.1sec)
Very tube placement: CXR
Verify collar pressure: between 20 and 30 cm of water
Positioning: prone to relieve pressure in lungs
Diuretic
Nutrition: OG, NGT, PEG
Peptic Ulcer Disease prophylaxis => prevent GI bleeds or stress ulcers (usually thru PPI, see PPI and H2 Blockers)
DVT Prophylaxis


Trend Labs: monitor for impending sepsis or renal failure
Skin Integrity
Monitor for Oxygen Toxicity, Pulmonary Edema (early on), Left Ventricular dysfunction
MODS is a huge possibility
Delirium - sign of hypoxia, difficulty in administering treatments


max intubation is 14 days
Intubated patient: vitals signs q5min
Sedation scales - do not go too in-depth but familiarize yourself


Assess, prevent, and manage pain
Both spontaneous awakening trials (SAT) and spontaneous breathing trials (SBT) = > wean off vent, reduce o2 support, sedation vacation
Choice of analgesia and sedation
Delirium: assess, prevent, and manage
Early mobility and exercise
Family engagement and empowerment
Focused Assessments: ABC:

A - attend, intubated => tube placement, line tracing, vent settings, patient response (ABGs reassuring), b/l lung sounds, infection (oral care), capnography
B - dyspnea, tachypnea, low SPO2, crackles, rales,
C - tachycardia, cyanosis, hypotensive,
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Asthma
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #respiratory #asthma #asthma
#nursing #medsurg #respiratory #asthma

-airway inflammation that leads to airway obstruction (mucosal edema)
-exacerbated by mucus production, clogging airway (more pronounced during expiration)
-Hyperventilation: rapid breathing that causes reduced carbon dioxide in arterial blood (hypocapnic)
#asthma
Remodelling

caused by chronic airway inflammation, permanent changes in tissue and structure of the airway wall
changes include airway wall thickness and smooth muscle hypertrophy and hyperplasia
no return
Signs and Symptoms:

wheezing
coughing (usually at night), can be dry or productive
chest tightness
dyspnea
Lab and Diagnostic Testing:

Physical Exam: adventitious length sounds = > complications, wheezing => bronchospasm or impending respiratory failure, RR
PFT
Labs: Urea, Electrolytes, Acid Base Balance
ECG - check for sinus tachy
Pulse Oxymetry - if severe, late finding
Peak Flow Meter - percentage of expected peak flow, compare to baseline
Spirometry - reveals obstructive pattern that response to salbutamol
Treatment:

O2
SABA: albuterol, levalbuterol, terbulatine (relax airway muscles) (see Respiratory Meds)
Corticosteroids: budesonide, fluticasone, beclomethasone (to reduce inflamation and improve airflow)
Asthma Medications see (Respiratory Meds)
Categorized into quick relief, rescue, and long-acting control medications.
Adjusted based on asthma severity.
Common groups: SABAs, LABAs, glucocorticoids, muscarinic antagonists.
Beta-Agonists: Facilitate bronchodilation, relax smooth muscle.
Glucocorticoids: Decrease lung inflammation, aid short- and long-term breathing.
Muscarinic Antagonists: Block inflammatory effects, added to beta-agonists or glucocorticoids.
Aim: Prevent and control asthma symptoms.
Quick-Relief Medications
SABAs (e.g., albuterol, levalbuterol): Immediate relief, prevent exercise-induced asthma.
Adverse reactions: tremors, tachycardia, CNS stimulation.
Anti-Cholinergic (e.g., ipratropium): Prevent respiratory muscle tightening.
Takes effect in 30 min, lasts 3-6 hours.
Long-Term Control Medications
Inhaled Corticosteroids (e.g., beclomethasone, budesonide): Decrease airway inflammation.
Common adverse reactions: oral thrush, dysphonia, respiratory infections.
Use spacer and rinse mouth post-inhalation.
LABAs (e.g., formoterol, salmeterol): Control nighttime symptoms, prevent exercise-induced asthma.
Start within 2-30 min, last 12+ hours.
Long-Acting Anti-Cholinergic Agents (e.g., ipratropium/albuterol, tiotropium): Relieve symptoms, reduce inflammation.
Adverse reactions: urinary retention, dry mouth, headache, dizziness, respiratory issues.
Systemic Effects

perfusion - can lead to hypoxemia
neurological - damaged brain cells d/t hypoxemia, leads to death
memory loss, poor judgement, inattentiveness, decreased muscle coordination
Renal - hypoxemia leads to decreased renal tissue perfusion => fluid, electrolyte imbalance
Mobility - impaired QOL, worse health outcomes
Risk Factors:

genetics
tobacco exposure
environmental particulates, allergens, infections, pollution
chemicals, perfume, candles, changing weather
allergic sensitization - repeated exposure to allergen increases risk
obesity
more common in males prior to puberty, but opposite after
Phenotypes or Subcategories of Asthma:

Allergic Asthma
most common
begins in childhood
usually accompanied by family hx of allergic disorders/exczema
Nonallergic Asthma
less common
common in adults, rare in children
poor response to treatment other than corticosteroids
Aspirin-sensitive Asthma
flare-up when taking aspirin or NSAIDs
accompanied by chronic rhinitis or nasal inflammation
Exercise-Induced Asthma
if client exercises to a certain capacity, they will flare up
managed by pre and post meds
Comorbidities:

obesity can exacerbate SOB
rhinitis
vocal cord dysfunction (voice box does not open correctly)
GERD
OSA


rapid onset asthma attack
severe asthma
Emergency! Very life-threatening
potential acute ventilatory failure or death (d/t hypoxia or hypercapnia)
requires ventiation
10% mortality rate in ICU
Important: give bronchodilator first before oxygen
Risk Factors:

poor recognition of dyspnea
usually have other comorbidities
previous episode of S.A., prior intubation
CAD as a result of adverse reactions from meds
Impact:

airways close prematurely when the client exhales leading to an increase in the volume that remains in the lung (functional residual capacity) and air trapping
leads to hypoxemia that then causes lactic acidosis
stress of having asthma coupled with comorbidities that are associated with it can lead to increases in asthmatic episodes
respiratory system of the aging adult undergoes physiological changes and can mimic the presence of airway obstruction
Signs/Symptoms:

SOB, unable to speak full sentences
chest tightness
accessory muscle use
late signs: drowsiness, confusion, cyanosis
sx do not develop at the same time
mucus plug can lead to asphyxia
resp acidosis
wheezing may not be present on auscultation
absent wheezes = indicate retained secretions and deteriorating respiratory function
Alkalosis if hyperventilating
Diagnostic:

breath sounds
SPO2
ABG
BP - monitor for pulsus paradoxus (When blood pressure drops by more than 10 mm Hg during inspiration.)
LOC & fatigue
PEFR - peak expiratory flow rate; if less than 50% of best = status asthmaticus
PEV
CBC - check for WBC elevation
Systemic Effects:

Perfusion - decreased left ventricular filling and outflow (look for pulsus paradoxus)
MSK - rhabdo from excessive accessory muscle use, hypercapnia, steroids, neuromuscular blocking agents
Treatment:

SABA - relief from bronchospasm
oral or IV corticosteroids - decrease inflammation of airway
O2 for cyanosis, dyspnea
IV fluids for hydration
Magnesium sulfate for smooth muscle relaxation
critical care until symptoms resolve or after 24 hours, then focus on education re: meds and irritants
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: ATI Comp - Resp
item.description:
Bronchoscopy - endoscopic technique of visualizing the inside of the airways for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes
consent for needed: involve sedation
remove dentures, glasses
tissue sample may be obtained
positioning: patient will be hyperextended to allow alignment of trachea and pharynx to easily insert scope
Transillumination - allows passage of light through body tissues
occluded sinuses prevent passage of light rays thru sinus air sacs
clear sinus = allow light
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Chest Tube Care
item.description:
2 Types:

WET SUCTION - CLOSED SYSTEM
DRY SUCTION - connected to wall suction


Drainage Collection Chamber => connected to patient, monitor every 15min first 2 hours (normal: serous, clear, red, ABNORMAL: purulent or yellow, bright red blood (abnormal)
Water Seal Chamber => allows removal of volume from pleural space without allowing air in, sterile water only, add if needed (normal: tidaling => rise and fall during ventilation, continuous bubbling: air leak, no bubbling: kink or occluded, lung re-expanded (need re-eval)
Suction Control Chamber => can be wet or dry.

Dry = Dial on the system (mechanical suction control)

Two or three chambers: drainage, water seal, mechanical suction control (no water)
Suction set with dial or regulator, often quieter
Quieter, portable, easier for ambulation
No water evaporation issues
Easier setup in emergency or transport


Needs sterile water for suction chamber
May be noisy due to bubbling
Water level must be checked/refilled if evaporated
Suction Control Chamber => Continuous bubbling is normal (if bubble too violent = suction too high!)


keep drainage below chest level
must have two rubber-tipped hemostats in the room (in case of dislodgement)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: COPD
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #respiratory


persistent respiratory manifestations and airflow limitation
airway restriction caused by noxious gas and/or particle exposure
can be caused by chronic bronchitis or emphysema
COPD is a broad term that includes bronchitis and emphysema
Emphysema

permanent enlargement of airspaces and destruction of airspace walls
affects respiratory bronchioles, alveolar sacs, ducts, alveoli
Chronic Bronchitis - inflammation of bronchial tubes, leading to increased mucus production and coughing


common: cigarette smoke => more mucus production => cilliary function decreases => inflammation
thickened and fibrosed alveoli => damaged macrophages => more infection


smoking
exposure to noxious gases
occupational exposure to dust, fumes
environmental pollutants, biomass fuel
female
allergen sensitivities
asthma
chronic lung disease


dyspnea, chronic cough, sputum production
exertional dyspnea = most common early manifestation
wheezing, chest tightness
barrel chest - severe and late sign
late sign and poor prognosis: weight loss
decreased breath sounds, crackles at lung bases
sit leaning forward slightly = use of accessory muscles of neck
Pursed lip expiration
Hoover's sign = drawing in of the lower ribs while inhaling
Neck vein distention due to intrathoracic pressure during


thromboembolic disease
lung cancer
resp failure


increased mortality rate
weight loss - too busy coughing to eat
skeletal muscle dysfunction - decreased mobility, decreased nutrition, inactivity, hypoxia, inflammation
more pronounced on elderly


goal: control symptoms, not die, improve QOL
SABA , LABA, inhaled corticosteroids, anticholinergics, methylxanthines, LAMA (antimuscarinic agents)
methylxanthines - relax smooth muscles in airway (Theophylline)
Vaccines: influenza, pneumococcal (PVC13), RSV (>60yo)


CAPTURE questionnaire (0 or 1 => no risk, 5-6 => severe)
weak expiratory flow
PFT especially spirometry => gold standard of diagnosing COPD
spirometry before and after bronchodilator to determine airflow limitation is reversible
Forced Expiratory Volume (FEV1)
forced Vital Capacity (FVC)
SPO2
CXR - to rule out dyspnea/sputum
CT - determine severity of disease


increased mortality rate from respiratory failure
weight loss, skeletal muscle dysfunction, poor nutrition
loss of muscle cells
decreased physical activity
Cardiac: CHF


thromboembolic disease
lung cancer
respiratory failure


female
smoking = MOST IMPORTANT
responsiveness to allergens
exposure to dust/fumes
asthma
chronic lung disease


O2
promote rest
breathing exercises
do not give anti-anxiety medications with BIPAP => ?
encourage vaccination to all diseases
hand
elevate HOB


smoking cessation
avoid exposures
encourage rehab
pursed lip breathing => moves air out of lungs
influenza vaccine
Pneumococcal - 65 and older, once a year
Corticosteroids side effects: trembling, headaches, dry mouth, weight gain, diabetes, osteoporosis
#nursing #medsurg #respiratory
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Flail Chest
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hemothorax
item.description:
What is it?

collection of blood in pleural space: between visceral and parietal pleura
often associated with traumatic thoracic injuries from blunt or penetrating injury
life-threatening due to hemodynamic and respiratory compromise
blood limits airway functioning, increases vascular resistance = leads to cardiac arrest, death
Clinical Presentation

similar to pneumothorax
respiratory distress, tachycardia, tachypnea, decreased or absent breath sounds, dull percussion
asymmetrical chest movement, hypoxia, hypotension
JVD - late sign, but maybe absent in hemothorax
subcutaneous emphysema
Treatment

tube thoracostomy (aka "chest tube")
semi-fowler
analgesia and O2
splinting
Nursing Considerations & Interventions

educate on seat belt, driving impairment, road safety
note that SPO2 of aging adult is usually 93-94%
encourage early mobility
prevent anxiety
Complications & Other Systemic Effects

usually accompanied by chest wall injury, rib fx, flail chest, cardiovascular injury
hypoxia and hypecapnia
Causes

motor vehicle collision - most common cause
blunt chest trauma
less common: iatrogenic, vascular, infectious diseases, spontaneous
iatrogenic: anticoagulation treatment for pulmonary emboli with warfarin, thoracentesis, CVC
most common: chest tube insertion
all involve: major arteries: intercostal arteries and aorta
