Risk Factors

comorbidities: congenital diseases (hemophilia, thrombocytopenia)
Diagnosis

CXR - 1st line tool
ultrasound or FAST
ECG
ABG
CBC - HGB
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: OSA
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #respiratory #osa
#nursing #medsurg #respiratory

episodes of partial or complete collapse of the airway, with decreased SPO2 #osa
defined by apneic episodes caused by repetitive upper airway obstructions, then arousal causing individual to reopen airway and resume breathing
leads to poor sleep, loud snoring, excessive daytime sleepiness
secondary effect: memory, learning, decision making
Detailed pathophysiology:

tongue - huge factor, most common structure associated with
decreased muscle tone of nasopharynx decreases during sleep
Signs and Symptoms:

loud snoring with breathing cessation for 10 seconds or longer, following by loud snore (arousal)
may have 1-500 episodes per night
incidence increases as weight increases
daytime:
chronic fatigue, irritability, moodiness, headache, sleepiness, decreased libido
nighttime:
snoring, gasping, fragmented sleep, nocturia, insomnia, night sweats
Diagnostic Studies:

history and physical exam
PSG - polysomnographic test: records brain waves/EEG, blood oxygen, HR, RR, EMG, ECG
gold standard for dx of OSA
airflow is also measured, with breathing patterns
calculated apnea-hypoapnea index (AHI) = # of apneas per hour
Treatment:

mandibular advancement device: prevents tongue and soft tissue from blocking airway
CPAP: one pressure setting continuously, decreases work of breathing, prevents airway collapse
BiPAP: different pressures on exhale/inhale, for removing CO2, more complex settings
Surgical:
tonsillectomy
resection of pharyngeal soft tissue
partial removal of soft palate and uvula
nasal septoplasty
maxillofacial surgeries
Medications:
Modafinil (Provigil) reduces daytime sleepiness
inhibits dopamine reuptake
adverse: anxiety, HA, nausea
Protriptyline (Triptil) - increases respiratory drive, improves airway muscle tone
taken at bedtime
also an antidepressant (tricyclic antidepressant)
adverse: anxiety, confusion, headache
taken with CPAP/BiPAP
Nursing responsibilities:

facilitate effective sleep environment: dim lights, draw curtains, door slightly closed
provide humidified O2, reposition to one side, encourage deep breathing exercises
elevate head of bed
encourage lifestyle changes: smoking cessation, weight
Risk Factors

obesity
larger neck circumference
high fat around pharynx
nasal congestion
thickened pharyngeal walls
facial malformations
most common in overweight to obese
Effects on Health (other diseases it can lead to):

systemic HTN, cardiac arythmia, heart failure, stroke, MI
contributes to cognitive deficits: irritability, errors, accidents, moodiness, depression
nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
daytime drowsiness, loss of independence
Aging adult considerations:

more contributing factors:
loss of teeth, muscle dysfunction, other comorbidities (stroke, dementia, HF, edema)
sleepiness may be attributed to old age vs OSA symptom
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pleural Effusion
item.description:
abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space between the visceral and parietal pleura surrounding the lungs
can impair lung expansion and gas exchange.


Heart failure (most common transudative cause)
Pneumonia (common exudative cause)
Malignancy
Pulmonary embolism
Liver cirrhosis (hepatic hydrothorax)
Nephrotic syndrome
Tuberculosis
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)


Chronic heart or liver disease
Recent thoracic surgery or trauma
Malignancies
Infections like pneumonia or TB
Autoimmune conditions
Long-term mechanical ventilation


dyspnea
diminished breath sounds
pleuritic chest pain
coughing
tachypnea
Underlying cause (infection): fever, chills, fatigue
intercostal fullness, dullness upon percussion
reduced tactile fremitus
pleural friction rub



CXR
thoracentesis - Removal of fluid or air from around the lung.
US


Thoracentesis - can be at the bedside, w/ or w/o ultrasound guidance
Bloody fluid = trauma
milky fluid - effusion has been sitting there a long time
purulent - infection
Fluid Analysis => determine if a transudate or exudative effusion is present.
Thoracoscopy - insertion of a thin tube with a camera into the pleural space to evaluate the pleural space and take samples of the lung tissue and lymph nodes. ​​​​​​​
Treat Cause: abx for infection, if HF => diuretics, nitroglycerin, PE => anticoagluants
Pleurodesis - procedure that aims to eliminate the pleural space, the area between the lungs and chest wall, by making the two layers of the pleura (the membrane lining the lungs and chest wall) stick together. This is done to prevent the accumulation of fluid or air in the pleural space,
Surgical Pleurectomy or Pleuroperitoneal Shunt Insertion - small catheter attached to a drainage bottle is inserted into the effusion. The client’s treatment can be managed on an outpatient basis.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pneumonia
item.description:
#respiratory #nursing #medsurg #pneumonia
#respiratory #nursing #medsurg
Acid Base Balance => for ABG Values

What is it?

umbrella term used to refer infection of lung parenchyma caused by bacteria, fungi, and viruses #pneumonia
inflammation => exudate/secretions= > occlusion of bronchi => airway compromise
consolidation = air in small airways is replaced by fluid in lungs
Clinical Presentation

fever, chills, malaise, loss of appetite, myalgia
cough (w/ or w/out sputum), tachypnea, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain
SOB, adventitious breath sounds (crackles and rhonchi)
dull percussion, tactile fremitus
Hypoxemia = impaired alveolar gas exchange
CXR: opacity
tachy
Labs: WBC, ESR, CRP, procalcitonin =>all elevated
severe: sepsis, hypotension, altered mental status, organ dysfunction
Treatment

bronchodilators & analgesia
treat cause: antibiotics (depends on culture)
MRSA = vancomycin
encourage early mobility but need rest and avoid overexertion
semi fowler
remove secretions: coughing exercises, increased fluid intake
O2 with humidifier to minimize dry secretions
incentive spirometer -
RT, PT, nutrition consult
CURB-65 Scale (Confusion Urea, RR, BP, 65 or older)

Score of 0-5: 0=outpatient, 4 or greater=ICU
modalities: confusion, BUN, RR, SBP, age
Nursing Considerations & Interventions

infection control
encourage conserving of energy, less stress, educate
smoking cessation
Complications & Other Systemic Effects

poor nutrition
sepsis
atelectasis = inability of lungs to inflate properly
MI, stroke, arrythmia, pulmonary embolism
impaired mobility
Causes
Subtypes:

Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)
s. pneumonia, s. aureus, mycoplasma pneumoniae
s. pneumoniae = most common
influenza
Hospital Acquired Pneumonia (HAP)
s. aureus, MRSA. pseudomonas aeruginosa
Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP)
s. aureus, MRSA. pseudomonas aeruginosa
Risk Factors

over 65
COPD, cystic fibrosis
heart disease, lung cancer
previous viral respiratory infection or pneumonia
bronchiectasis
asthma
Co-morbidities: stroke, DM, malnutrition
immunocompromised: HIV
Diagnosis

CXR, CT
blood culture, sputum, CBC/WBC
CRP, ESR, procalcitonin
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pneumothorax
item.description:
air that collects within pleural cavity d/t leak from lung into parietal and visceral pleura
creates pressure causing lung to collapse
a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention.
Types:
Traumatic Pneumothorax

blunt or penetrating trauma creates one-way valve into pleural space
air goes in but does not go out
common causes: rib fracture, bult trauma, flying or diving, changes in pressure
subtypes:
Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (PSP) - without underlying lung disease but in the presence of asymptomatic bullae or blebs that rupture
Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (SSP) - lung disease is present, most commonly, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Open Pneumo - air entering through an open wound in the chest (sucking sound occurs as air rushes through the chest walls)
Iatrogenic - type of traumatic; caused by a medical treatment or procedure (thoracentesis or biopsy)
Tension Pneumo - severe form, air enters the chest cavity, becomes trapped, and cannot be expelled (common causes: barotrauma, ventilation tracheostomy injury, occlusive dressing ineffective)


subpleural bleb - a small air-filled cyst located on the surface of the lung, close to the pleural lining. They are typically asymptomatic but can rupture, leading to a pneumothorax
smoking cigarettes or MJ
tall & thin
pregnancy
Marfan Syndrome - genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissues
Atmospheric drops - diving, mountain climbing, or any activity with no time to acclimatize


COPD
Tuberculosis
apical blebs or bullae
Cystic Fibrosis
Lung Cancer
ASthma
HIV with pneumonia
any lung condition


chest pain, SOB
hypotension
distended neck veins or hypotension from an increased central venous pressure
tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, hypoxia
pleuritic chest pain radiating to shoulder => common in PSP
asymmetric lung expansion
Decreased tactile fremitus
Hyper resonant percussion notes
Decreased breath sounds or absent breath sounds


hypoxia, hypercapnia
mobility: weakness, physical activity intolerance


CXR - definitive
CT
E-FAST


evacuate air in pleural space: needle decompression (14-16g angiocatheter) 2nd ICS
after: thoracostomy tube or catheter in 5th ICS MCL
ensure drainage system is below catheter
chest tube insertion => 5th ICS MCL
Chest Tube Suction amount: 10 to -20 cm H2O of water
O2
analgesia
pleurodesis - for air leaks longer than 7 days, AIDS patients => surgery that occludes lung


EARLY MOBILITY IS KEY! => encourages airway clearance
educate on chest tube and drainage management
semi fowlers (HOB-35-45)
O2 and analgesia
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pulmonary Edema
item.description:
#pulmonaryedema
What is it?

abnormal build-up of fluid in lungs, specifically in interstitial spaces and alveoli #pulmonaryedema
backup of blood into the pulmonary vasculature is a result of inadequate left ventricular function
life-threatening condition associated with CHF (left ventricle)
can also occur as a exacerbation of CHF or after an MI
Flash Pulmonary Edema - sudden rise in left sided heart filling pressure.
Clinical Presentation

similar with cardiogenic and non-cardiogenic
pink frothy sputum, chest pain
SOB, tachypneic, hypoxic, distress
confusion, agitation, sweating, cyanosis, cold extremities
hypertension with JVD (hypotension can be a late sign from cardiogenic shock)
tachycardia
pedal edema
weight gain
Treatment

O2 titration (goal: >90% usually to preserve vasoconstriction or cardiac output)
proper positioning (semi-fowler): for lung expansion and venous return
control anxiety
diuretics - furosemide
vasodilators PRN - nitro
monitor I/O
Nursing Considerations & Interventions

proper positioning to promote reduction of venous return
encourage mobility for faster recovery, airway clearance
lifestyle changes
commode at bedside for diuresis
Complications & Other Systemic Effects

respiratory failure (often requiring vent)
ARDS
acidosis
Causes

Cardiogenic P.E
CHF, MI, cardiomyopathy, valvular disease, cardiac arrythmia
Non-Cardiogenic P.E. - other causes
kidney injury
chronic hypertension d/t renal artery stenosis (vascular disease)
Risk Factors

one year survival rate of 50%
more common in males
elderly
HF or acute decompensated heart failure (worsening manifestations of HF)
CHF, MI, cardiomyopathy, valvular disease, cardiac arrythmia
Diagnosis

rule out anemia and sepsis - CBC
BNP
Electrolytes to determine diuresis
ABG, SPO2 - oxygenation
ECG
CXR
U/S
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pulmonary Embolism
item.description:
A life-threatening condition where a thrombus or emboli blocks blood flow in the pulmonary arteries, reducing oxygen exchange and straining the heart.
Medical Emergency!
Terms to note:
Thrombus - A blood clot that forms within a blood vessel
Embolus - moving clot or particle that travels through the bloodstream until it lodges in a smaller vessel; made up of fat, air, or tumor
Hence, a thrombus can become an emboli
REMEMBER:

Thrombus = Stays Put
Embolus = Moves and Block


DVT (most common cause)
Fat embolism (from fractures)
Air embolism (from IV lines or trauma)
Amniotic fluid embolism (during labor)
Tumor embolism (from metastatic cancer)

Virchow’s triad - increased coagulability, venous stasis, and endothelial tissue injury
Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) - when patient presents with both PE and DVT
Risk Factors:

females (early and middle adult age groups)
males (elderly)
age: 40+
Black Americans
Family History/Genetics: thrombophilia, protein C or S deficiency, hyperhomocysteinemia
Venous Statis: Immobility or prolonged bed rest
travel greater than 4 hr by air
bedrest greater than three days
Surgery (especially orthopedic or abdominal)
Hospitalization for HF, A.Fib, A.Flutter, central venous catherization
Obesity
Pregnancy and postpartum period
Smoking
Oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy (ESTROGEN BASED)
Cancer - tumors may dislodge, more immobile
Previous DVT or PE
Fractures (especially long bones)
Poor - increased air pollution exposure


sudden onset dyspnea - most common
chest pain
tachypnea
tachycardia
hypoxia
anxiety & restlessness
cough
HEMOPTYSIS - not a common presenting manifestation (ATI)
blood or blood-tinged sputum from the mouth or trachea that originated in the lungs or the lower respiratory tract.
Severe: syncope, hypotension, cyanosis, shock symptoms
Less common: arrythmias (AFIB), JVD

Low Risk - asymptomatic, hemodynamically stable
Intermediate-Risk (or submassive) - right ventricular dysfunction, low BP (corrected with IVF)
High-Risk - hemodynamically unstable


Pulmonary hypertension
Right-sided heart failure (cor pulmonale)
Shock
Death (if untreated)


CTPA - computed tomographic pulmonary angiogram => Gold Standard, uses contrast dye thru arteries, then x-ray. visualizes arteries, locates obstruction
ABG => reveals respiratory alkalosis, hypocapnia
Troponin => may be elevated in moderate to large PEs
D-Dimer - elevated d/t presence of clot
Chest X-Ray => may not show PE but can rule out atelectasis, effusion, or other causes for dyspnea
Assessment Findings:

abnormal lung sounds on auscultation: rales or diminished
abnormal heart sounds: gallop

Treatment Goals:

Maintain Oxygenation, at least 90% SPO2
Maintain Mental Status
Prevent Further Emoblism
Avoid Complications
Interventions
Supplemental O2

Mechanical Ventilation if unstable
ECMO - extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
Thrombolysis (Alteplase) - clot-busting meds
Thrombectomy - surgical removal of clot using endovascular device
Anticoagulants (e.g., heparin, warfarin, enoxaparin) - does not dissolve clots but prevents new ones from forming
Anticoagulation therapy for a minimum of three months


Evaluate Risk Factors for a VTE: examine lower extremities; note swelling, warmth, tender or hard veins in calves
Prevention is Easier Than Treatment! - ensure VTE prophylaxis (pharmacological or mechanical-SCDs), encourage ambulation, hydration
Note bleeding risk R/T anticoagulant therapy
Educate: anticoagulation medications, increased chance of recurrence, medical tag/bracelet, bleeding precautions, avoid risky activities, mobility, lifestyle, nutrition
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Respiratory Failure
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Status Asthmaticus
item.description:
rapid onset of a severe Asthma episode and has the potential for acute ventilatory failure or death
extreme form of asthma exacerbation characterized by hypoxemia, hypercarbia, and secondary respiratory failure.
requires ventilatory support and ICU care
airways close prematurely when the client exhales leading to an increase in the volume that remains in the lung (functional residual capacity) and air trapping.
leads to respiratory acidosis (first resp alkalosis then acidosis)


Low socio-economic status
Low comprehension => poor understanding
Coronary Artery Disease => CAD & MI (d/t adverse effects of meds)
previous episodes
history of intubation


Poor access to care
Financial issues r/t missing work
Kicked out of school r/t missing school


increased risk of obstructive shock
hits harder
increased sensitivity to meds


SOB
unable to speak
chest tightness
accessory muscle use
drowsy, decreased LOC
cyanotic
Diminished or absent lung sounds (possibly no wheezing)
patients tend to sit leaning forward to open airway
asphyxia (resulting from mucus plug) => life-threatening
chest asymmetry
Pulsus Paradoxus => systolic blood pressure falls at the height of inspiration
Early => Respiratory Alkalosis (because of hyperventilation); eventually turns to acidosis
Late => R. Acidosis
Note:

Hypercarbia - too much CO2
Hypoxemia - too little O2
2nd Respiratory Failure


respiratory acidosis
rare: rhabdomyolysis => can lead to permanent disability, fatal; caused by excessive use of respiratory muscles


Pulmonary Function Test =< when PEFR (peak expiratory flow rate) and FEV are reduced by 50% of the patient's best
increased PaCO2, increased pH => respiratory acidosis (see Acid Base Balance)
rule out infection: CBC
rule out Hypokalemia


prepare to intubate if r. acidosis (late stage)
Nebulized Bronchodilator: Albuterol q.20 => SABA
oral or IV Steroids => decrease inflammation (i.e. methylprednisolone or Medrol)
IV fluids - facilitate secretion and expectoration
supplemental I2
Magensium Sulfate - relaxes muscles


Monitor: tripod positioning
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Meniere’s Disease
item.description:
Chronic inner ear disorder affecting balance and hearing
Characterized by episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, fluctuating hearing loss, and aural fullness
Caused by excess endolymphatic fluid in the inner ear


Exact cause unknown
Theories include abnormal fluid drainage, immune response, viral infections, genetic predisposition


Age 40–60 years
Family history
Head injury
Viral infections affecting the inner ear
Allergies or autoimmune diseases


Recurrent episodes of vertigo (lasting 20 min to several hours)
Tinnitus (ringing or roaring in the ears)
Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, especially low-frequency
Aural fullness (pressure or fullness in the ear)
Nausea, vomiting, imbalance during attacks


Progressive, permanent hearing loss
Risk of falls or accidents due to vertigo
Anxiety, depression due to chronic symptoms
Difficulty driving or working


Based on history and clinical presentation
Audiometric tests: sensorineural hearing loss
Electronystagmography (ENG) for balance assessment
MRI to rule out other causes (e.g., tumors)


No cure, focus on symptom management
Low-sodium diet, fluid restriction to reduce inner ear fluid
Diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide)
Antivertigo medications (e.g., meclizine, diazepam) during acute attacks
Antiemetics for nausea (e.g., promethazine)
Hearing aids for hearing loss
Severe cases: intratympanic injections (e.g., gentamicin), vestibular nerve section, labyrinthectomy


Teach fall precautions during vertigo episodes
Encourage low-sodium diet and fluid management
Instruct on taking meds at onset of symptoms
Reduce environmental stimuli during attacks (dim lights, quiet)
Provide emotional support for chronic symptoms
Educate on avoiding alcohol, caffeine, and smoking
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Acid Base Balance
item.description:
#acidosis #alkalosis #medsurg #nursing #nurseinthemaking
Lab Values & Electrolytes => values from Foundations
Fluid & Electrolyte ATI => ATI notes for Acid-Base
#acidosis #alkalosis #medsurg #nursing #nurseinthemaking
From nurseinthemaking:
2 Main organs affecting balance:
Lungs: respiration expel CO2
Kidneys: urine - excrete/retain H2 and/or HCO3 in urine

Metabolic Alkalosis

NGT suctioning/Vomiting - expels H2 from stomach
Metabolic Acidosis

Renal Failure: kidneys fail, acid prevails
Diarrhea - intestines are basic environment, expelling too much would tip balance towards acid
DKA; note: Kussmaul respirations: compensatory

Respiratory Acidosis - low and slow RR

Sleep Apnea
Head Trauma - low respiratory drive
Post-Op - sedation lowers RR
CNS Depressants: Benzo, morphine, alcohol
Impaired Gas Exchange: Pneumonia, COPD, Asthma Attacks
Respiratory Alkalosis
Hyperventilation - panic attack, too much CO2 expelled
pH 7.35 ------- 7.45
PaCO2 35 ------- 45 LUNGS
HCO3 22 ------- 26 KIDNEYS
item.guid: Med-Surg/X - Other Systems/Fluids & Acid-Base/Acid Base Balance.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Fluid & Electrolyte ATI
item.description:
#fluids #electrolytes #nursing #medsurg #hypernatremia #hyponatremia #hypokalemia #hyperkalemia #acidosis #alkalosis
#fluids #electrolytes #nursing #medsurg
Lab Values & Electrolytes => see Foundations Notes for lab values overview
Fluid Electrolyte Cheat Sheets
Outline per syllabus:

Nursing Management of the Client with Fluid and Electrolyte Imbalance, Infusion Therapy, and Acid-Base Imbalance
Sodium (hypernatremia/hyponatremia)
Potassium (hyperkalemia/hypokalemia)
Calcium (hypercalcemia/hypocalcemia)
Magnesium (hypermagnesemia/hypomagnesemia)
Phosphate (Hyperphosphatemia/hypophosphatemia)
Acid base imbalance
Infusion therapy
Diagnostic tests
Treatments


What is it

A state where fluid output exceeds fluid intake
loss of sodium and water leads to a decrease in circulating volume.
Clinical Presentation

tachy, dry mucosa, hypotension, thirst, decreased skin turgor, flat neck veins
decreased UOP, muscle cramps, lightheadedness, orthostatic hypotension
when in hypovolemic shock: clammy, cold, cyanotic, confusion
Lab values:
Hct - increased (blood is more concentrated)
Na - increased
Serum Osmolality - increased
BUN - increased
UA-gravity: increased
Treatment

fluid replacement; orally preferred
IVF if oral
Isotonic Crystalloids - NS
balanced isotonic crystalloids - LR
Hypotonic - 0.45% NaCl, 0.33% NaCl
Hypertonic: D20, 3% NaCl, D50
Nursing Considerations

encourage drinking of 2-3 liters per day
note falls risk d/t orthostatic hypotension
strict I/O
Diagnostic

CBC, hematocrit, electrolytes
BUN, CK
urine specific gravity
Causes:

output > input (e.g. running marathons)
inability to ingest fluids
diuretic use, vomiting, diarrhea, GI bleed, excessive sweating, third space losses
burns
Risk Factors

CKD
central diabetes insipidus - rare condition that causes excessive thirst and urination
65 and older
dementia (forgets to drink)
Complications

cerebral hypoperfusion
organ failure
cardiac damage

What is it

excess of TBW and sodium (total body water)
increase of fluid volume in the extracellular space
intake > needs
Clinical Manifestations

edema, hypervolemia, or both
hypertension, pulmonary congestion, and edema of the extremities
Pulmonary E - tachypnea, worsening dyspnea, pink frothy sputum, hypoxia, and jugular vein distention.
pitting edema, dyspnea, and crackles in lung fields
ascites in liver cirrhosis
increased weight
Labs:
BNP - may be elevated (hormone that indicates cardiac pressure and volume overload); brain natriuretic peptide
normal: <100 pg/mL, above 400 is critical (mostly likely HF)
Treatment

treat underlying cause
low sodium diet, fluid restriction, increase protein
diuretics for edema and fluid
Nursing Considerations

restrict to 2g of sodium per day
restrict to 1.5-2L of fluid per day
weigh daily, assess for edema, heart sounds, lung sounds, VS
Diagnostic

BNP
ECG to rule out cardiac dysfunction
CBC, electrolytes, LFT, Urea, CK
Causes

HF
decreased tissue perfusion => water retention
Liver Disease = > reduced renal perfusion, results in edema and ascites
ascites - Fluid collects within the peritoneal cavity as a result of liver disease or dysfunction.
Kidney Disease, AKI
Electrolyte or acid-base imbalance
iatrogenic: excessive IV fluids
Polydipsia - excessive ingestion of fluid
inappropriate ADJ, diabetes insipidus, psychogenic
Risk Factors

ESLD, HF, kidney disease
pregnancy, pre-eclampsia

normal range: 136-145 mEq/L

What is it #hypernatremia

greater than 145 mEq/L
excessive fluid is lost through body systems (GI, GU, renal, respiratory)
usually in conjunction with hypovolemia
Clinical Manifestations

usually presented with neuro symptoms (brain is sensitive to sodium imbalance)
confused or exhibit altered sensorium
restlessness, irritability, and twitching of muscles
fatigue, extreme thirst, headache
sleeping issues, tachypnea, and restlessness
hypotension, dry mucous membranes, and decreased skin turgor
Compilations:
cerebral edema => may lead to brain damage, death
acute kidney failure
Treatment

oral rehydration
treat underlying cause
IVF with NS or balanced crystalloid
correct slowly (reduce by no more 12 mEq/L in 24 hour)
Nursing Considerations

encourage oral fluids
do not administer IVF rapidly - may result in cerebral edema (seizures)
Causes

vomiting, burns, and profuse diaphoresis.
decreased water intake
diuresis caused by: meds, hyperglycemia, or diabetes insipidus
diet: seawater or salt poisoning, or administration of hypertonic intravenous fluids
Risk Factors

gastroenteritis, diabetes, and kidney disease
impaired thirst response, excessive sweating, and medications
65 and older

What is it #hyponatremia

excess of total body water in relation to total body sodium content
relative to total body fluid:
Euvolemic hyponatremia - increase of TBW without an alteration in body sodium or ECF
Hypervolemic hyponatremia - greater increase in TBW relative to body sodium
can be chronic or acute
Clinical Manifestations

brain is at the highest risk for injury as a consequence of cellular edema
confusion, lethargy or fatigue, seizures, and possibly resulting in death
hyperactive reflexes
decreased attebtuib
often asymptomatic, but if Na < 115 mEq/dL, more severe neurological manifestations are evident
severe = emergency!
Treatment

treat cause
meds = discontinue if possible; if not, restrict fluids
hypovolemia = administer IVF NS
SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) = vasopressin
HF = loop diuretics with sodium restriction
Nursing Considerations

fluid restrictions, high protein diet
educate: athletes drink fluids with electrolytes
constant neuro checks
monitor for edema, p.edema, UOP, I/O
Causes

fluid loss is replaced by sodium-deficient fluids
administration of hypotonic intravenous fluids
Diuretics, NSAIDs, antidepressants => decrease Na
Physiological:
renal: diuretic
extrarenal: bleeding, burns, diarrhea, vomiting, third spacing of fluids
third spacing -excessive fluid moves from the intravascular space into the interstitial space
Acute Hyponatremia: within 24 hours, e.g. runner drank water only
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) - body produces too much ADH
Thiazide Diuretics - increases risk

Risk Factors

alcoholism
65 and older
diuretics, antidepressants, NSAIDs
see causes
Systemic Effects

increases risk of osteoporosis = + risk of fractures

K - 3.5-5 mEq/L

What is it #hypokalemia

normal range for an adult is 3.5 to 5.0 mEq/L
K is regulated by kidneys
Clinical Manifestations

dysrhythmias
muscle weakness, nausea, abdominal distention, vomiting, muscle cramps, impaired renal function
cardiac: U waves and flattening of the T wave
symptoms appear when less than 3 mEq/L
Treatment

oral potassium unless the client cannot tolerate
if severe, IV infusion with 10-20 mEq/hr
if caused by meds, change the meds
Nursing Considerations

oral K can cause Gi discomfort
monitor: mental confusion, hypotension, and cardiac dysrhythmias
Dextrose - increases incidence of hypokalemia due to insulin secretion
IV site - monitor for irritation during infusion
Diagnostic

BMP
spot urine or 24hr urine test to determine kidney K excretion
determine if renal or non-renal (aldosteronism or diuretic administration)
ABG - determine acidosis/alkalosis
ECG
Causes

Renal
diuresis
aldosteronism
GI
decreased intake
vomiting, laxative use, diarrhea
Endocrine:
Cushing's Syndrome - body has too much cortisol
Insulin - moves K from blood into cells
Risk Factors

cardiac and renal disorders
65 and older (more likely to use diuretics, less muscle mass, poor)
Complications

Respiratory failure can result from muscle weakness if severe hypokalemia
fatal dysrhythmias

What is it #hyperkalemia

greater than 5.0 mEq/L
no manifestations, or:
life-threatening: cardiac dysrhythmias or paralysis
Clinical Manifestations

muscle weakness, flaccid paralysis, depressed DTR, fatigue
palpitations, dysrhythmias, syncope
peripheral neuropathy, renal tubular acidosis
Treatment
Nursing Considerations
Diagnostic
Causes
Risk Factors

renal insufficiency, CKD
diabetes
malignancies
burns and trauma
Meds: ACE inhibitors
HF
blood transfusions due to hemolysis
smoking
Systemic Effects
Complications



Lab Values & Electrolytes
ABG

pH:
Normal Range: 7.35 - 7.45
pH below 7.35 indicates acidosis, and above 7.45 indicates alkalosis.
Carbon Dioxide (PaCO₂):
Normal Range: 35 - 45 mmHg
Levels above 45 mmHg suggest respiratory acidosis, while values below 35 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis.
Bicarbonate (HCO₃):
Normal Range: 22 - 26 mEq/L (people experiment with being "bi" when they are 22-26 years old)
Low HCO₃ levels suggest metabolic acidosis, and high levels suggest metabolic alkalosis.

What is it #acidosis
Causes

hypoventilation: more CO2 is produced than expelled
body compensates: more ventilation
Drugs affecting respiratory muscles:
myasthenia gravis, guillain-barre syndrome, asthma, stroke
Chronic respiratory acidosis; caused by:
COPD, obesity, HF, skeletal defects
Risk Factors: surgery, vented, postop from sedation
Clinical Manifestations

difficulty sleeping, anxiety, SOB, dyspnea
cyanosis
COPD-accompanied symptoms:
barrel chest, accessory muscle use, tripod position, coughing, SOB
Prolonged or severe:
neurological, altered MS, myoclonus (sudden jerking muscles), seizures
Complications

memory loss, less coordination, confusion, drowsiness
heart failure from weakened cardiac muscles from acidity
Polycythemia - bone marrow makes too many RBC, thickened blood
Pulmonary Hypertension - type of high BP affecting arteries in lungs and heart
Mental illness, anxiety, depression
Treatment

treat cause:
sedation: naloxone
respiratory difficulty: bronchodilators
supplemental O2
CPAP, BIPAP, vent

#alkalosis
Causes

hyperventilation resulting decreased CO2 => alkalosis
stimulation of central nervous system causing hypervent:
fever, pain, psychosis, brain tumor, anxiety
usually accompanied by some disorders:
pneomonia, p. embolism, COPD, pneumothorax
meds: salicylates
progesterone in pregnancy
intubation
excessive heat
Clinical Manifestations

peripheral edema, orthopnea (supine), fever, weakness, chills, confusion, anxiety, wheezing, dizziness, numbness, paresthesia
sometimes: no manifestations
Treatment

supplemental O2
treat the cause:
- decrease anxiety => anxiolytic, relaxation techniques
- anticoags for embolus
- antibiotics
- adjust vent settings
Nursing Consideration
Diagnostic
Risk Factors

pneumonia, sepsis, COPD, liver disease
**Complications

Lab Values & Electrolytes
ABG

pH:
Normal Range: 7.35 - 7.45
pH below 7.35 indicates acidosis, and above 7.45 indicates alkalosis.
Carbon Dioxide (PaCO₂):
Normal Range: 35 - 45 mmHg
Levels above 45 mmHg suggest respiratory acidosis, while values below 35 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis.
Bicarbonate (HCO₃):
Normal Range: 22 - 26 mEq/L (people experiment with being "bi" when they are 22-26 years old)
Low HCO₃ levels suggest metabolic acidosis, and high levels suggest metabolic alkalosis.

What is it

ph <7.35, HCO3 <22 mEq/L
Causes

salicylates - NSAIDs like aspirin
DKA
uremia, kidney disease, iron, metformin
CO poisoning
vomiting
Clinical Manifestations

DKA:
dry mucous membranes
neuro: confused, lethargic
Cardiac: hypotension, dysrhythmias
Respiratory:
Kussmaul respirations - respirations are initially fast and shallow, and they progressively become deeper
Hyperventilation
Life Threatening Complications:
dysrhythmias, hypotension
Treatment

treat cause: DKA (insulin, IVF)
mild to moderate: IVF, O2
severe (ph < 7.1): raise PH
alkalinization therapy
sodium bicarb - IV or oral, drug of choice

What is it

ph > 7,45, bicarb > 26
Causes

renal dysfunction = > excessive renal hydrogen loss
retention or addition of bicarb
GI loss of H ions or acidity
NG suctioning or vomiting
ingestion of bicarb (antacids)
diuretic
Hyperaldosteronism - adrenal glands produce too much aldosterone
Clinical Manifestations

Neuro: seizures, delirium, confusion
Cardio/Resp: hypoxia, hypoventilation (to increase CO2)
muscle weakness, paresthesia
Life Threatening:
- kidney failure
- ventricular atrial tachyarrhythmias
Treatment
isotonic saline for fluid vol deficit
hypokalemia or hypocalcemia = > IVF to correct
Diuretics => discontinue or reduce dosage
Hyperaldosteronism => low sodium diet
Restrict alkaline substances
item.guid: Med-Surg/X - Other Systems/Fluids & Acid-Base/Fluid & Electrolyte ATI.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Potassium
item.description:
#nursing #medsurg #electrolytes
#nursing #medsurg #electrolytes

Functions:

regulate fluid balance
muscle contractions:
Skeletal muscle:
too much = hyperexcited, spasmic, paralyzed (late sign)
too low = limp and weak
Cardiac Muscle - imbalance causes arrhythmias
Smooth Muscle - low K results in hypOactive bowels
nerve signals


Heart - tight and contracted
ST elevation, peaked T waves
severe: VFib, arrest
hypotension, brady
GI - tight and contracted
diarrhea
hyperactive bowel sounds
Neuromuscular - tight and contracted
paralysis in extremities
increased DTR
profound muscle weakness (causes resp failure)
profound = severe, assess these first!
Common findings in Hypo and Hyper: confusion, respiratory failure


Heart - low & slow
flat T waves
ST depression
prominent U wave
Muscular - low n slow
decreased DTR
muscle cramping (like during prolonged use)
flaccid paralysis
GI - low n slow
decreased motility
hypoactive bowel sounds
constipation
abdominal distention
paralytic ileus (priority = can lead to SBO)
Common findings in Hypo and Hyper: confusion, respiratory failure

functions:

blood pressure
blood volume
pH balance where sodium goes, water goes


skin
flushed - "red and rosy"
edema
low grade fever: dehydration reduces the body's ability to dissipate heat
polydipsia - excessive thirst
late serious signs:
swollen dry tongue
GI: nausea and vomiting
increased muscle tone
common in hypo & hyper: restlessness, fatigue, abdominal cramping


Neuro: seizures & coma
Cardiac: tachy, weak pulses
Respiratory Arrest
common in hypo & hyper: restlessness, fatigue, abdominal cramping


same function as sodium, maintains:
blood volume
BP
pH

same as sodium:

late serious signs:
swollen dry tongue
GI: nausea and vomiting
increased muscle tone

same as low sodium

excessive diarrhea, vomiting, sweating
only difference: FEVER


maintains law & order in the muscles; calming them down
heart
uterus
DTR
required for calcium and vitamin D absorption
bestfriend: calcium


cardiac - calm and quiet
heart block
prolonged PR interval (heart is calm and quiet)
vitals: brady, hypotension
DTR - calm and quiet; decreased
Lungs: depressed shallow respirations
GI: hypoactive bowel sounds
common: confused, irritable, shallow respirations


cardiac: torsades de points, T wave inversion, ST inversion
severe: VFIB
tachy
DTR - increased
Eyes: nystagmus
GI: diarrhea
common: confused, irritable, shallow respirations

functions: keep 4 B's strong

Bones
Blood (clotting factors)
Beats (heart beats)
Bitch Face - muscle contraction & nerve signaling


constipation (moans) - too much calcium in your shit
bone pain (groans)
stone: renal calculi
decreased DTR
severe muscle weakness


Trousseaus sign: facial twitch
Chvostek's sign: arm twerk with BP cuff
diarrhea (food poisoning in mexico)
Weak 4 B's:
Bones: risk for fractures
Blood: risk for bleeding
Beats: risk for dysrythmias
Bitch face: trosseau & chvostek

Function: opposite of calcium

bone and teeth formation
helps regulate calcium
work inversely with calcium


Trousseaus sign: facial twitch
Chvostek's sign: arm twerk with BP cuff
diarrhea (food poisoning in mexico)
Weak 3 B's:
Bones: risk for fractures
Blood: risk for bleeding
Beats: risk for dysrhythmias


constipation (moans)
bone pain (groans)
stone: renal calculi
decreased DTR
severe muscle weakness

item.title: Herpes Zoster or Shingles
item.description:
a painful rash caused by the varicella-zoster virus
same virus that causes chicken pox
Caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which causes chickenpox
Virus stays dormant in nerve ganglia and reactivates later, typically due to immune suppression
Results in painful, blistering skin rash along a dermatomal pattern
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/Med-Surg/X - Other Systems/Infectious Diseases/Herpes Zoster or Shingles.html
item.guid: Med-Surg/X - Other Systems/Infectious Diseases/Herpes Zoster or Shingles.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Lyme's Disease
item.description:
A tick-borne bacterial infection caused by Borrelia burgdorferi
Transmitted through the bite of infected black-legged (deer) ticks
Most common vector-borne illness in the U.S.
Can affect skin, joints, heart, and nervous system


Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, a spirochete bacterium
Transmitted through the bite of infected Ixodes ticks (must be attached for 36–48 hrs)


Outdoor activities in grassy, wooded areas
Living in or visiting endemic regions (e.g., Northeast, Midwest U.S.)
Having pets that bring ticks indoors
Warmer months (late spring to early fall)


Early localized (3–30 days):
Erythema migrans ("bull’s-eye rash")
Fever, chills, headache, muscle and joint aches
Early disseminated (weeks to months):
Multiple rashes, facial palsy, meningitis
Carditis (AV block)
Late disseminated (months to years):
Arthritis, especially in large joints
Neurological symptoms (memory issues, neuropathy)
per ATI:
Early Lyme disease is characterized by:

fever
influenza-like manifestations
- erythema migrans - a distinct, progressive, circular or bullseye rash that often develops at the bite site but can also develop at other sites such as the thighs and knees.


Chronic arthritis
Cardiac complications (e.g., heart block)
Neurologic deficits
Post-treatment Lyme disease syndrome (PTLDS)


Clinical signs (esp. bull’s-eye rash)
Serologic testing: ELISA, followed by Western blot
May take weeks for antibodies to appear


Early disease: oral antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline, amoxicillin)
Neurologic or cardiac involvement: IV antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone)
Pain management for arthritis
No current vaccine (as of now)


Teach tick prevention: use repellents, wear long sleeves/pants, check skin/pets
Instruct to remove ticks properly (tweezers, steady upward pull)
Monitor for signs of systemic involvement
Stress importance of completing antibiotic regimen
Supportive care for joint pain or neurologic symptoms
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Mononucleosis
item.description:
“Mono” or “Kissing Disease”
Viral infection caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)
Common in teens and young adults
Transmitted via saliva (kissing, sharing drinks, utensils)


Primarily EBV (Herpesvirus family)
Occasionally caused by Cytomegalovirus (CMV)


Adolescents and young adults
Close contact (kissing, shared items)
Immunocompromised individuals


Fatigue (can last weeks/months)
Sore throat (resembles strep)
Fever
Swollen lymph nodes (especially cervical)
Enlarged spleen (splenomegaly)
Enlarged liver (sometimes)
Headache, body aches
Mild rash (especially if given amoxicillin or ampicillin)


Splenic rupture (rare but serious)
Hepatitis
Airway obstruction (severe tonsillar enlargement)
Chronic fatigue syndrome
Secondary infections (e.g., strep throat)


Monospot test (detects heterophile antibodies)
EBV antibody panel
CBC: shows atypical lymphocytes, possible leukocytosis
Rule out strep throat with rapid antigen or culture


Supportive care only (since it’s viral)
Rest, fluids, antipyretics (acetaminophen, ibuprofen)
Avoid contact sports for at least 3–4 weeks if splenomegaly
Corticosteroids only if airway obstruction or severe swelling


Monitor for airway obstruction and splenic rupture signs (sudden LUQ pain, hypotension)
Encourage rest and hydration
Educate on avoiding contact sports and overexertion
Promote good hygiene to avoid spreading
No antibiotics unless secondary bacterial infection present
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pseudamonas Aerginosa
item.description:
Gram-negative, aerobic rod
Opportunistic nosocomial (hospital-acquired) pathogen
Known for its resistance to many antibiotics
Commonly produces a blue-green pigment (pyocyanin) and grape-like odor


Infection from **contaminated water, equipment, or hands
Affects immunocompromised or critically ill patients
Can colonize skin, respiratory tract, and indwelling devices


Burns, wounds, surgical sites
Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
Indwelling catheters (urinary, central lines)
Cystic fibrosis
Neutropenia
Prolonged antibiotic use


Skin: greenish-blue pus, wound infections, burn infections
Lungs: pneumonia with thick secretions, dyspnea, fever
Urinary tract: dysuria, frequency, foul odor
Ear: swimmer’s ear (otitis externa)
Sepsis: fever, hypotension, organ dysfunction


Sepsis/septic shock
Multi-drug resistant (MDR) infections*
Endocarditis, osteomyelitis
Chronic lung infection (especially in CF patients)
High mortality in bloodstream infections


Culture and sensitivity from wound, sputum, urine, blood
Blue-green colonies on agar
PCR testing (in some cases)


Requires specific antibiotics due to resistance
Common choices:
Piperacillin-tazobactam (Zosyn)
Cefepime
Meropenem or Imipenem
Aminoglycosides (e.g., tobramycin)
Fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin)
Combination therapy may be used
Infection control measures essential


Implement strict infection control/hand hygiene
Monitor for signs of systemic infection
Administer antibiotics as ordered and monitor for toxicity
Encourage respiratory hygiene (esp. in ventilated patients)
Educate about prevention, especially for high-risk groups
Isolation precautions as needed
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Burns
item.description:
results in release of histamine and prostaglandins => vasodilation, capillary permeability => increased edema


decreased immunity => no skin, exposed tissue, decreased senses
increased metabolic demand => high risk for malnutrition; higher caloric needs
severe dehydration => organ failure, kidney injury
edema
deep burns => release myoglobin => rhabdomyolysis (Release of protein and electrolytes with damage to muscle)
body image issues
decreased mobility d/t edema, dressings => advocate to ambulate

In Terms of Thickness:

Superficial - Damage to epidermis only. Appearance similar to a sunburn
Superficial Partial Thickness - damage to epidermis and superficial portion of dermis and is usually pink or red and blistering and wet.
Deep Partial Thickness - damage to deep in the dermis and wound is usually white or yellow, dry, and nonblanchable.
Full Thickness - Damage to epidermis and dermis and subcutaneous tissue and is usually white or black/brown, dry and leathery, and nonblanchable.
In Terms of Degrees:

First Degree: Damage to the epidermis, such as sunburn
Second degree: Damage to epidermis and dermis
Third degree: Damage to epidermis and dermis that will require skin grafting
Fourth degree: Same as third degree but extending into fat layer
Fifth degree: Same as third degree but extending into muscle layer
Sixth degree: Same as third degree but extending to the bone


Bleeding => Coags
Anemia => CBC
WBC
Electrolytes => CMP
Albumin - low levels => edema; also indicates nutrition status
BUN, Urea, Cr => kidney function
ABG - respiratory acidosis
Liver Enzymes


Rule of 9s TBSA:

One arm: 9%
One leg: 18%
Head: 9%
Torso Front: 18%
Torso Back: 18%
Groin: 1%
Emergency treatment

cool the burn with cool water => do not use ice
ABCs
500 mL/hr of Lactated Ringer, then infuse via Parkland formula => 2-4 mL x kg x TBSA %
insert foley (goal OUP of 0.5 mL/kg/hr)
OG/NG decompression PRN
HOB 30
Minor burns => 4c's: cool with tap or saline water, clean with mild soap, cover with ointment or dressing, comfort with OTC pain meds
Major burns: debride or excision of nonviable tissue
Debride within 24 hours
Escharotomy - removes stiff dead skin to allow tissues to expand (important for torso or extremity as burns here can cause compartment syndrome)
Parkland Formula => 2-4 mL x kg x TBSA %
Rehabilitative Treatment

Range of Motion exercises
skin grafts (autograft = own skin, allograft = cadaver or donor, xenograft = animal)
Monitor for infection
record daily weights
Pharmacological:

Pain: opitates, sedation
Benzo for anxiety
Abx
Topical abx with wound dressings
Silver Sulfadiazine
Silver Nitrate
Apiary Honey
Fluid Replacement

goal:
0.5 mL/kg/hr of UOP or 30/mL/hr
sys 90 mmHg
no AMS
HR < 120
see parkland formula
delivery half in first 8 hours, then the remainder over 16 hours
example:: 4 mL x 70kg x 40% = 11,200 mL
Half in first 8 hours = 5,600 mL or 700 mL/hr
the rest in 16 hours = 5,600 mL or 350 mL/hr
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Frostbite & Burns Stages
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Wounds
item.description:
Incision – Clean, straight cut (e.g., surgical wound).
Laceration – Irregular, torn wound (e.g., from trauma).
Abrasion – Superficial wound caused by friction (e.g., scraped nee).
Puncture – Deep, narrow wound caused by a sharp object (e.g., needle stick).
Avulsion – Tissue torn away from its normal location (e.g., degloving injury).
Ulcer – Open sore due to prolonged pressure or circulation issues (e.g., pressure ulcer).
Burn – Tissue damage from heat, chemicals, electricity, or radiation.


Primary Intention
Edges are approximated (closed) with sutures, staples, or glue.
Minimal scarring and healing occurs quickly.
Example: Surgical incision.
Secondary Intention
Wound heals from the inside out; left open to heal naturally.
Granulation tissue forms, followed by epithelialization.
Higher risk of infection and more scarring.
Example: Pressure ulcers, burns, large wounds with tissue loss.
Tertiary Intention (Delayed Primary Closure)
Wound left open initially, then later closed surgically.
Used when there is a high risk of infection or contamination.
Example: Infected surgical wound, abdominal wound with dehiscence.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cast Care
item.description:
Assess neurovascular status regularly: check circulation, movement, sensation (CMS), color, temperature, pulses, cap refill.
Elevate the casted limb above heart level for the first 24–48 hours to reduce swelling.
Turn the patient every 2 hours if in a body cast to prevent skin breakdown.
Keep the cast dry if it’s not waterproof — cover with plastic when bathing.
Use the palm of your hands (not fingers) to handle a wet plaster cast to prevent indentations.
Report signs of complications: numbness, tingling, severe pain, swelling, foul odor, drainage, or cool/pale skin.
Encourage movement of fingers/toes distal to the cast to maintain circulation.
Apply ice packs to the cast over a towel for the first 24–48 hrs to reduce swelling (if approved).



Don’t insert objects (like pens or coat hangers) into the cast to relieve itching — risk of injury and infection.
Don't insert cotton wipe to dry inside cast - use blow dryer on COOL setting instead
Don’t get the cast wet, unless it's made of water-resistant material.
Don’t cover a wet cast with plastic — it traps heat and moisture and may cause skin damage.
Don’t ignore foul smells or drainage — these could be signs of infection or pressure ulcers under the cast.
Don’t bear weight on the cast unless it’s a walking cast and the doctor says it’s okay.
Don’t trim or pull apart edges of the cast — always consult a provider if the cast is uncomfortable or damaged.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Osteoporosis
item.description:
chronic metabolic bone disorder resulting low bone density
the rate of bone resorption (osteoclast cells) exceeds the rate of bone formation (osteoblast cells)
results in fragile bone tissue and can lead to fractures
progressive deterioration of bone tissue
Often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs (common fracture site: wrist, hips, spine)
Osteopenia - precursor to osteoporosis; low bone mineral density relative to the client’s age and sex; bone density peaks at 18-30, decreases gradually, significant decrease in postmenopausal women


Aging (natural loss of bone mass over time)
Hormonal changes (especially estrogen deficiency in postmenopausal women)
Males: loss of testosterone => decreased bone mass
Nutritional deficiencies (calcium, vitamin D)

Non-Modifiable:

Female sex (higher risk than males)
Aging (risk increases after 50)
Family history of osteoporosis or fractures
Caucasian or Asian ethnicity
History of malabsorption disorders (celiac disease, anorexia, bariatric surgery)
male with decreased T levels
Modifiable:

Low calcium and vitamin D intake
Sedentary lifestyle (lack of weight-bearing exercise)
Excess alcohol (decreased bone formation and increased bone absorption)
Excess Caffeine consumption => increased excretion of calcium in the urine.
Smoking (reduces bone mass)
Long-term corticosteroid use (e.g., prednisone)
Low body weight or eating disorders
High protein or low protein diet
frequent sodas or carbonated drinks - High phosphorus intake increases the rate of calcium loss


Often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs
Loss of height over time (due to vertebral compression fractures)
Kyphosis (hunched back, "dowager’s hump")
Back pain from vertebral fractures
Fragility fractures (hip, wrist, vertebrae) from minimal trauma


Fractures (hip, spine, and wrist most common)
Chronic pain and disability from fractures
Loss of independence (due to mobility issues)
Increased mortality (hip fractures linked to higher mortality rates)


Bone Mineral Density (BMD) Testing (via DEXA scan); T-score ≤ -2.5 confirms osteoporosis
Serum calcium, vitamin D levels (to assess deficiencies)
X-rays (for fractures)
24 hr urine = check

Lifestyle Modifications:

Increase calcium intake (1200 mg/day postmenopausal women)
Vitamin D supplements (800-1000 IU/day) => increases calcium absorption
Weight-bearing exercises (walking, resistance training)
Smoking cessation & limiting alcohol intake
limit caffeine
Medications:

Bisphosphonates (first-line):
Alendronate, risedronate, zoledronic acid (inhibit bone resorption) => take before breakfast with 8oz water, remain upright for 30 min
Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulators (SERMs) (e.g., raloxifene) => replace estrogen due to menopause (note: high risk of breast, endo cancer, DVT)
Denosumab (monoclonal antibody) for high-risk patients
Calcitonin (less commonly used)
Parathyroid hormone analogs (teriparatide) (stimulates bone formation)
Orthotic Devices - immobilization of the spine immediately after a compression fracture of the spine
Surgery: joint repair, vertebroplasty, kyphoplasty


Educate on fall prevention (home safety modifications, proper footwear, clear walkways, adequate lighting, etc)
Encourage weight-bearing and resistance exercises
Monitor for signs of fractures (sudden pain, loss of function)
Ensure adequate calcium and vitamin D intake
Teach correct administration of bisphosphonates (take on an empty stomach with water, stay upright for 30-60 min)


Foods rich in vitamin D are most fish, egg yolks, fortified milk, and cereal.
Foods rich in calcium are milk products, green leafy vegetables, fortified orange juice and cereals, red and white beans, and figs. Some soy and rice products are fortified with vitamin D and calcium.


Risk for injury related to fragile bones
Impaired physical mobility due to pain or fractures
Chronic pain related to vertebral fractures
Deficient knowledge related to disease management and prevention
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cancer
item.description:
Uncontrolled growth and spread of abnormal cells that can invade nearby tissues and metastasize to other parts of the body.
Can originate in any organ or tissue and is classified based on cell type and location (e.g., carcinoma, sarcoma, leukemia, lymphoma).
Stages: Ranges from localized (Stage 1) to widespread metastasis (Stage 4)
Cell Changes:

Normal
hyperplasia - increased # of cells, appear normal
dysplasia - abnormal cells present
carcinoma in situ - abnormal cells that stay in one location without spreading
malignant - mutated, changed, replicate faster, spread to other areas


Genetic mutations: Inherited or acquired DNA changes that lead to uncontrolled cell growth.
Environmental factors: Exposure to carcinogens like tobacco, radiation, and chemicals.
Lifestyle factors: Poor diet, obesity, and lack of physical activity increase risk.
Infections: Certain viruses (e.g., HPV => cervical cancer, hepatitis B, Epstein-Barr) contribute to cancer development.


Genetic predisposition: Family history of cancer increases risk.
Age: Risk increases with age due to accumulated genetic mutations, body unable to remove damaged cells
Smoking and tobacco use: Major cause of lung and other cancers.
Alcohol consumption: Associated with liver, esophageal, and breast cancer.
Obesity and poor diet: Linked to colorectal, breast, and pancreatic cancer.
Radiation exposure: UV rays cause skin cancer, while ionizing radiation increases risk for leukemia and thyroid cancer


C: Change in bowel or bladder habits => may indicate obstruction or tumors in GI tract
A: A sore that does not heal => indicates poor immune response or skin cancers
U: Unusual bleeding or discharge => tumors eroding blood vessels
T: Thickening or lump in the breast or elsewhere => tumor growth
I: Indigestion or difficulty swallowing => esophageal, gastric, or throat cancers
O: Obvious changes in warts or moles = > skin cancers
N: Nagging cough or hoarseness => Lung, laryngeal, or thyroid cancers irritate airways
Other manifestations:

pain from cancer tumors and treatment (radiation, chemotherapy)
Neutropenic Precautions => decreased WBC, high risk for sepsis
unintentional weight loss
Lymphedema: swelling of the interstitial tissues as a result of increased lymph fluid (example: one arm may be swollen while other one is not)
Peripheral Neuropathy: can be sensory (numbness), motor (weakness, loss of balance), autonomic (constipation, diarrhea, sexual function impairment, etc.)
infertility
sleep disturbance, insomnia, anxiety
Delirium in advanced cancer
fatigue
Chemotherapy/Radiation Therapy Side Effects:

Neutropenia (lowered WBC), may lead to sepsis
N/V => increased risk of dehydration, metabolic abnormalities, etc
dry mouth, mouth ulcers
decreased taste sensation
fatigue: chemo-anemia or from stress
alopecia
flaky skin
Pancytopenia (a deficiency of WBCs, RBCs, and platelet count) is an expected adverse effect of chemotherapy.


Bone Marrow Suppression: chemotherapy or metastasis, causing Anemia, leukopenia (low WBC), and Thrombocytopenia.
hypercalcemia - usually from myeloma (blood cancer) and breast cancers
spinal cord compression - breast cancer
Superior Vena Cava Syndrome (SVC) - structural complication caused by a tumor compressing the SVC
Malignant Pericardial Effusion - cancerous fluid accumulates around the heart
Tumor Lysis Syndrome - metabolic emergency that is triggered by cancer treatment
Med-Surg/GU/SIADH
death


Imaging: X-rays, CT scans, MRI, PET scans to detect tumors.
Biopsy: Gold standard for confirming cancer type and grading.
Blood tests: Tumor markers (e.g., CA-125 for ovarian cancer, PSA for prostate cancer).
Genetic testing: Identifies inherited cancer syndromes (e.g., BRCA1/2 mutations).


Surgery: Removal of tumors when localized.
Chemotherapy: Systemic drug therapy to kill or slow cancer cells.
Radiation therapy: High-energy radiation to target and destroy cancer cells.
Immunotherapy: Boosts immune system to recognize and attack cancer.
Targeted therapy: Drugs that block specific cancer cell growth pathways.
Hormone therapy: Used for hormone-sensitive cancers like breast and prostate cancer.
Palliative care: Focus on symptom management and improving quality of life in advanced stages.


Pain Management
Manage Side Effects: N/V, mucositis, Peripheral Neuropathy, bone marrow suppression
Support: emotional, nutritional
Infection prevention: Neutropenic Precautions


a lot of stuff is radioactive: their bodily wastes, sheets, clothes, etc
patient must have separate everything: towels, utensils, dishes
no seggs, kissing
6 feet apart from others
avoid pregnant, infants, children
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cancer Treatment
item.description:
is a type of radiation therapy during which the radiation source is in direct contact with the client's tumor.
DIFFERENT FROM CHEMO - chemo is directed throughout the whole body
MORE precise therapy - directly into cancer cells
During the therapy, the client emits radiation and is potentially hazardous to others. The client should be in a private room with a private bathroom, and the nurse should keep the door to the client's room closed.
PER ATI:

2-5 treatment, one or twice a week
no restriction on proximity - no excreted radiation between treatments (you can stand close to them)
there should be no blood - report immediately if there is!
patient will stay still


Systemic treatment using cytotoxic drugs to destroy or inhibit cancer cell growth
Administered orally, intravenously, intramuscularly, subcutaneously, or intrathecally
Contraindications:

Severe immunosuppression
Active infection
Organ dysfunction (e.g., liver or kidney failure)
Pregnancy (specific agents may be contraindicated)
Nursing Tasks

Administer chemotherapy safely following protocols and PPE guidelines
Monitor for immediate reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis, infusion site issues)
Assess for side effects such as nausea, vomiting, fatigue, or myelosuppression
Provide patient education on side effect management and treatment schedule
Ensure proper handling, disposal, and spill management of cytotoxic agents
Nursing Considerations

Monitor CBC, renal, and liver function before and during treatment
Assess for signs of infection, bleeding, or anemia
Implement supportive care measures (e.g., antiemetics, hydration, pain control)
Educate on neutropenic precautions and infection prevention
AVOID DIRECT SUNLIGHT! - skin on radiation path is sensitive to sun damage
Provide emotional support and address psychosocial concerns
Chemotherapy Combination Meds - Different chemotherapeutic agents act at various stages of cellular mitosis (division). By combining agents, medication therapy is more effective in stopping or slowing the growth of cancerous cells by interfering with their ability to multiply.


Do NOT remove the markings - they are guides for treatment - important for accuracy!
use hands instead of wash cloth in doing skin care - skin is sensitive during therapy
avoid direct sunlight for at least 6 months
skin is more sensitive to burns
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Colostomy
item.description:
empty bag when it is one-third to one-half full => too much can cause leakage
DO NOT:

use antimicrobial ointment on peristomal skin - these disrupt adhesion unless prescribed by provided (usually with infection)
apply skin barrier while skin is moist => dry first
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Nephrostomy
item.description:
Percutaneous tube placed directly into renal pelvis to drain urine
Used when normal urinary flow is obstructed


Ureteral obstruction (e.g., stones, tumors)
Postoperative urinary diversion
Infection with impaired drainage
Trauma causing urinary tract damage


Uncorrected coagulopathy
Severe infection at insertion site
Anatomical abnormalities preventing safe placement


Assess and document urine output, color, and consistency
Perform site care with sterile technique
Ensure tubing is free from kinks and secured properly
Flush the tube only if prescribed and trained to do so
Educate patient on care, infection signs, and activity restrictions


Monitor for infection (e.g., fever, site redness, purulent drainage)
Ensure drainage bag remains below kidney level
Avoid excessive manipulation to prevent dislodgement
Encourage fluid intake unless contraindicated
Assess for signs of urine leakage or skin irritation
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PICC)
item.description:
A long-term intravenous (IV) access device inserted into a peripheral vein (usually the basilic, cephalic, or brachial vein) and advanced to the superior vena cava.
Used for long-term medication administration, total parenteral nutrition (TPN), and frequent blood draws.


Long-term IV therapy (e.g., antibiotics, chemotherapy).
Parenteral nutrition when enteral feeding is not possible.
Frequent blood sampling to minimize vein trauma.
Central venous pressure (CVP) monitoring in some cases.


Local infection or vascular abnormalities at the insertion site.
Thrombosis or occlusion in target veins.
End-stage renal disease (preferably preserving veins for future dialysis access).


Dressing Changes:
Use aseptic technique (sterile gloves, chlorhexidine prep).
Change transparent dressing every 7 days (or if soiled).
Flushing Protocol:
Use 10 mL saline before and after use to prevent occlusion.
Heparin flush per facility policy (often for non-valved catheters).
Blood Draws:
Discard 5 mL blood before sampling.
- Flush with 20 mL normal saline post-draw.
Assessment:
Check for redness, swelling, drainage, or pain at the site.
Measure and document external catheter length to detect migration.
Patient Education:
Avoid heavy lifting with the affected arm.
Do not submerge in water (cover during showers).


Infection Prevention: Monitor for signs of local (redness, swelling) and systemic infection (fever, chills).
Clot Prevention: Flush regularly and assess for sluggish flow or resistance.
Catheter Migration: Sudden difficulty flushing or aspiration may indicate dislodgment.
Air Embolism Prevention: Clamp the catheter when not in use, and place the patient in Trendelenburg if air embolism is suspected.
Regular monitoring and proper care reduce the risk of complications such as infection, thrombosis, or catheter migration.
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/Med-Surg/Z - Misc Topics/Lines Drains/Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PICC).html
item.guid: Med-Surg/Z - Misc Topics/Lines Drains/Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter (PICC).md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Venous Access Port
item.description:
should be flushed after each use, and at least once a month => prevents blood clots
flush with 5 mL heparin with 100 units
use non coring needle, 22 guage
does not require dressing
item.guid: Med-Surg/Z - Misc Topics/Lines Drains/Venous Access Port.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: End of Life
item.description:
Stages:

Early Stage: Loss of mobility, reduced desire/ability to eat or drink, cognitive changes (delirium, increased sleep).
Middle Stage: Further mental decline, brief wakefulness, "death rattle" from mucus/saliva pooling due to weak cough reflex.
Late Stage: Fever, apnea, mottled skin from peripheral circulation loss; progression varies from 24 hrs to over 14 days.
Good Death: Typically pain-free, in a preferred location, surrounded by loved ones.

Clinical Death: Heart/lungs stop, but brain remains viable; timely CPR may restore function. Brain damage starts after 4 min without oxygen, death in 4-6 min.
Biologic Death (Brain Death): No brain activity or blood flow; diagnosed by apnea, absent brainstem reflexes, coma from known cause.
Causes of Biologic Death: Intracranial (subarachnoid hemorrhage, TBI) or extracranial (cardiac arrest, inadequate CPR, trauma, drowning, overdose, stroke, aneurysm).
Pathophysiology of Biologic Death: Brain oxygen deprivation → increased edema → raised intracranial pressure → reduced cerebral perfusion → herniation.
Organ Donation: Mechanical support can maintain lung/heart function, but brain death is required for organ donation eligibility.


General Changes: Profound weakness, fatigue, increased sleep, disorientation, visions of deceased individuals.
Food & Fluids: Decreased interest in eating/drinking, weight loss, dehydration, difficulty swallowing (choking/coughing).
Urinary Function: Decreased output, urinary incontinence, dark concentrated urine due to low fluid intake.
Skin Changes: Mottling (purple/dark pink in lighter skin, brown in darker skin), pressure injuries from immobility and poor perfusion.
Cardiac & Circulation Changes: Reduced cerebral perfusion (drowsiness, confusion, terminal delirium), peripheral cyanosis, mottling, hypotension, tachycardia, cooling extremities.
Respiratory Changes: Pooling secretions causing "death rattle," weak/absent cough reflex, dyspnea, Cheyne-Stokes respirations (shallow, rapid breathing with apnea periods).


Absence of resp, HR, responsiveness, voluntary movement, muscle function, and nervous system activity
Complete muscle relaxation
Algor mortis causes body cooling, pale skin, and loss of turgor
Rigor mortis causes muscle stiffness, beginning within 2-6 hours and peaking at 12 hours
Livor mortis causes blood pooling in dependent areas, leading to purple or reddish discoloration, which becomes fixed after 6-12 hours


Specialized care for clients with serious illnesses to improve quality of life.
Treatment Approach: Can include symptom management alongside or instead of curative treatments.
Client Support: Helps clients understand treatment options and make informed choices.
Interprofessional Team: Includes nurses, social workers, dietitians, chaplains, and providers; tailored to client needs.
Goals: Supports clients in living actively until death, focusing on comfort and symptom control.
Common Symptoms Managed: Dyspnea and pain are primary concerns.
Early Implementation Benefits: More effective when started early, reducing unnecessary hospitalizations. Palliative Sedation
Used for terminally ill or actively dying clients with distressing symptoms
Relieves pain, agitation, and anxiety to prevent unnecessary suffering
Not intended to hasten death
Common medications: opiates, benzodiazepines, antipsychotics
Risks: respiratory depression, aspiration, delirium-related agitation
Requires informed consent from the client or legal proxy
Must align with advanced directives if applicable


Definition: Focuses on comfort, quality of life, and support for clients nearing the end of life.
Eligibility: For clients with a terminal illness, typically with a prognosis of fewer than six months, though it can be extended.
Care Approach: Provides comfort care rather than curative treatment.
Settings: Can be provided at home, in hospitals, hospice centers, or nursing homes.
Interprofessional Team: Offers medical, emotional, physical, spiritual, and social support.
Home Hospice: Primarily managed by family and friends with hospice team support.
Respite Care: Temporary relief for caregivers to prevent burnout.
Nursing Role: Collaborates with clients, families, and the care team to honor patient wishes and provide education.
Palliative vs. Hospice Care Comparison

Palliative Care:
Provided alongside curative treatments or as symptom management
Can begin at any stage of a serious illness
Aims to improve quality of life and relieve symptoms
Available in hospitals, outpatient clinics, and nursing homes
Hospice Care:
For clients with a terminal illness, typically with a prognosis of ≤6 months
Focuses on comfort rather than curative treatment
Provided at home, in hospice centers, hospitals, or nursing homes
Primarily managed by family with hospice team support
Both:
Aim to improve quality of life
Use an interprofessional team for medical, emotional, social, and spiritual support
Manage symptoms such as pain and dyspnea
Respect client autonomy and end-of-life wishes





Identifying Potential Donors:
Clients must meet brain death criteria (irreversible loss of all brain function).
Brain death is confirmed through apnea, known-cause coma, and absent brainstem reflexes.
Clients near death (not brain dead) may still be assessed for potential donation.
Organs & Tissues Eligible for Donation:
Organs: Kidneys, liver, lungs, heart, pancreas, intestines.
Tissues: Corneas, middle ear, heart valves, bone, veins, ligaments, tendons, cartilage, skin.
Other Donations: Hands, face, bone marrow, cord blood, blood stem cells, blood, platelets.
Live Organ Donation: One kidney, one lung, part of the liver, pancreas, or intestine.
Assessment & Scoring:
CGS: Score of 3 with the absence of at least three brainstem reflexes indicates imminent brain death.
FOUR Score: Evaluates respiration, eye response, brainstem response, and motor response (score of 0 suggests brain death).
Nurse’s Role in Brain Death & Donation Process:
Assess and document brainstem reflexes and neurological status.
Maintain circulation and respiratory function with mechanical ventilation and vasopressors.
Work closely with the organ donation coordinator to evaluate donor suitability.
Shift care focus from treatment of the client to organ preservation.
Priorities in Donor Care:
Maintain a patent airway and normal body temperature.
Ensure adequate oxygenation and perfusion of organs.
Maintain fluid and electrolyte balance to prevent complications.
Family Communication & Support:
Nurses play a key role in discussing organ donation due to their relationship with the family.
Use clear, compassionate communication, explaining brain death and prognosis.
Respect cultural and spiritual beliefs regarding death and organ donation.
Families are more likely to consent when they experience compassion, commitment, and clear information.
Education & Training for Nurses:
Ongoing training on organ donation, brain death criteria, grief counseling, and facility protocols.
Sensitivity to the death and dying process is crucial.


Pain & Symptom Management: Assess and manage pain, dyspnea, agitation, and secretions using medications (opioids, benzodiazepines, anticholinergics).
Comfort Care: Reposition frequently, provide skin care, and use moisture barriers to prevent breakdown. Keep the client clean, dry, and comfortable.
Respiratory Support: Elevate the head of the bed, use oxygen if needed for comfort, and provide suctioning or anticholinergic medications for excessive secretions.
Emotional & Psychological Support: Offer reassurance, provide presence, and support the client and family emotionally. Encourage open discussions about end-of-life wishes.
Communication: Speak softly, use simple phrases, and ensure the client and family understand changes occurring. Provide honest but compassionate information.
Hydration & Nutrition: Do not force food or fluids; provide oral care to prevent dryness and cracking of lips. Use ice chips or moistened swabs for comfort.
Urinary & Bowel Care: Monitor for incontinence, use absorbent pads, provide perineal care, and consider catheterization if needed.
Skin Integrity: Turn and reposition frequently, use pressure-relieving devices, and assess for skin breakdown.
Cultural & Spiritual Considerations: Respect religious or cultural practices related to death and dying; involve chaplains or spiritual leaders as requested.
Family Support: Encourage family presence, educate about the dying process, and provide opportunities to say goodbye. Offer grief resources.
Postmortem Care: Respect cultural practices, clean the body, remove tubes (unless an autopsy is required), and prepare the body for the family’s final moments.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Intro to Critical Care & Emergency Nursing
item.description:
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing



Primary Triage - in the field
Secondary - at ED, triage nurse assigns 3 or 5 tier categories
Tertiary - when the client exits the ED and is moved into the ICU or operating room


Emergent - life-threatening illness or injury
Urgent - treatment can be delayed, not immediately life-threatening
Delayed - minor injuries or illnesses, higher priority patients are dealt with first


Patient assessment

Primary Survey- ABCDE
Secondary Survey - Head to Toe assessment
Tertiary Survey - final step to uncover injuries that have been missed => anytime and before hospital discharge


External Regulations in Nursing: state laws
Internal Regulations in Nursing: organization policy & procedures
critical care nurses are except from state nurse practice acts when they work in Federal entities: VA, DOD, Indian Health Service
EMTALA

Emergency Medical Treatment and Active Labor Act (EMTALA) - law that prevents refusing care to uninsured patients
EMTALA: patients need to be stabilized first before transferring to another facility
EMTALA - exception during during disasters, patients can be transferred without being stabilized first
all documentation should be transferred with the patient
SEXUAL ASSAULT

fear of being stigmatized => #1 reason why victims do not report
Sexual Assault Nurse Examiner (SANE) should be assigned to the client who has experienced sexual assault: provide support, forensic exams, collect evidence "rape kit"
sexual assault victims - collect evidence, test HIV with PEP, emergency contraception
Certified Forensic photographer must take photos
Consent must be obtained prior to exam
Collect evidence ASAP
HIV prophylaxis must be given within 72 hours
provide contraception ASAP


Breaking bad news: provide information in bit and pieces to allow for digestion of information
Media relations: do no talk with them, follow protocols
Social media: avoid sharing information, follow HIPAA
nurse should also be aware of the location of the Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) on all chemicals used in the facility.


hazard vulnerability analysis, Emergency Operations Plan - required by joint commission
PPE Shortage - reuse them by cleaning, do not conserve: PPE usage is still required
Phases:

Planning - risk assessment, identifying hazards, creating disaster plan
Response = activation of plan, command post, lines of communication, nurse provides triage and care
Recovery - continued care, monitor, transport, watch mental health of team and patients, evaluate


Green Tag - minor injuries, obeys commands: lacerations, sprains
Yellow - delayed: fractures, open wounds, deep lacerations
Red - immediate, may survive if treated, neuro injury, shock, major burns, CPR is applied, hemcon
Black - deceased or not expected to live


provide power to government officials to activate authorities and resources


bystander CPR programs - offered by AHA
Stop the Bleed program - teach bystanders to stop blood loss
#medsurg #criticalcare #nursing

item.title: Perioperative Care
item.description:
#preop #periop #postop #nursing #medsurg
#preop #periop #postop #nursing #medsurg
check the ATI textbook as well

3 Phases:

preop - begins as soon as client is scheduled for surgery
intraop
postop - ends with transfer or discharge
Nurse primary role: advocate
Classification of Surgical Procedures:
By Purpose:

diagnostic
ablative - remove body part or tissue to destroy it (colectomy, removal of tumors)
palliative - provides relief/lessen pain
constructive - restore lost function that was present in birth
restorative/reconstructive - repair or restore a missing body part/organ
transplant
cosmetic
Seriousness:

major - risky
minor
Urgency:

emergent - ASAP, within minutes
urgent - life-saving, within hours of presentation
expedited - not emergency, within days
elective - not urgent, based on convenience
ASA Physical Class system

Class I-VI (healthy to braindead)
Class I - normal healthy adult
Class II - mild medical condition
Class V - critical condition who will die w/o procedure
Class VI - brain dead, organs to be donate
AORN Perioperative Patient Focused Model:

4 dimensions: Health System, Safety, Behavioral Responses and Physiological Responses.

Informed Consent:
- needs:
- procedure, potential risks, type of anesthesia, type of anesthesia, risk of anesthesia, any other potential procedures during surgery, postop plan, potential complications, risk and benefits, complications to client
- provider explains and obtains, nurse verifies and witnesses informed consent
- family member or guardian if patient is unconscious or mentally incompetent
Preop Tasks:

medical surgical hx obtained, check allergies
baseline head-to-to, VS, height, weight
prep skin: avoid shaving if possible
NPO and meds
hygiene, remove all jewelry
remove nail polish to notice signs of cyanosis
don surgical gown and cap, slippers
Preop Diagnostic Tests:

CBC, Hgb, Hct
Coags: PT, INR, aPTT, platelet
Metabolic: electrolyte, ck, BUN
HCG, urinalysis
CXR, ECG
Bloodtype & screen: if possibility of heavy bleeding (hip replacement)


phase start/end: operating table to PACU/ICU
Nurse role: circulating/scrub
know type of surgery & anesthesia
assist, client positioning
maintain aseptic environment, document, monitor complications


phase start/end: PACU until recovery from procedure
pain assessment- begins in preop stage to establish baseline pain
Enhanced Recovery After Surgery (ERAS)

surgical protocol implemented to drive client-centered process postoperatively to improve client outcomes
must involve whole team
focuses: mobility, nutrition, pain, manage N/V, discontinue IV fluids ASAP, continue client education


begins in preop stage
teach specific equipment, medications, recovery exercises (breathing, coughing, spirometer, leg exercises, position changes), pain management, coping techniques, etc.
Diaphragm Breathing Exercise

lie supine, hands on stomach, inhale nose, exhale pursed lips, repeat 5 times
Deep Breathing Exercise

sit back, inhale 4 seconds nose, hold breath for 8 seconds, exhale 8 seconds pursed lips, repeat 3 times
Incentive Spirometer

sit, set goal marker, breath in, once goal reached, hold for as long as possible
exhale slowly, pause then repeat 10 times
done every hour for 10 times
Postop Education Topics:

proper nutrition
meds
lifestyle
wound care
follow-up


Malignant Hyperthermia - genetic disorder triggered by anesthesia/succinylcholines, life-threatening
treatment: dantrolene
tachycardia, tachypnea, cardiac arrhythmias, hyperkalemia, hypercarbia, and muscular rigidity.
Note: postop clients are at increased risk of:
delayed wound healing
infection
increased length of stay
aspiration
DVT
Note: OSA = higher risk of difficult intubation
Note: PACU priority: maintain airway and respiratory status
Note: cardiac postop = increased risk for hypothermia
Dehiscence Treatment: cover with sterile dressing soaked in saline and then notify provider
prevention: limit vomiting, coughing, constipation
Aldrete Score - scoring system determines if patient can be safely discharged from PACU
must be 8-10 for discharge
criteria: oxygenation, RR, circulation, LOC, activity


similar to periop nursing
nurse provides support, care, fluids, and blood if ordered and monitors the client closely for organ rejection
Note precautions: immunocompromised from the medications and procedures
Note: critical time in first 24 hours after transplant
main complication: rejection of organ
Types of Organ Rejection:

Hyperacute rejection - minutes or hours after transplantation, caused by antibodies
Acute rejection - caused by certain lymphocytes that detect antigens in the transplanted tissue or organ days or weeks after transplantation
Chronic rejection - months or years following organ or tissue transplantation.

Exam 2 - week 3 & 4

You can retake - quizzes, and ATI prace A&B, minimum of 75%
