EBook is free
Nursing Diagnosis - must include CULTURE, there should be x2 ND's: one for mom and baby
neonatal - first 28 days
death rates (death per 1000 births)


APA format
reference must be last 5 years

Education - aimed at mom and dad
Skin to skin - examples of EBP

recudes pain in baby and mom
soothes baby, resolves respiratory difficulties
reduces cold stress
wait 12 hours after birth prior to bathing (reduce cold stress)
Quantitative Blood Loss (QBL) - another example of EBP, weigh, measure blood loss (instead of estimated blood loss) => more accurate
Prevention Levels

Primary - before disease happens
Secondary - early detection & treatment
Tertiary - reduction or limitation of the progress, supportive/restorative


Intertility
tx clomid - women
surrogacy
Natural Family Planning
Ovulate on Day 14
Contraception Behavioral Methods

abstinence
fertility awareness
withdrawal
lactational amenorrhea method - breast feeding => high levels of estrogen, prolactin => not fertile
barrier methods - condoms, diaphragm, cervical cap, contraceptive sponge
diaphragm & cap = need prescription, need sizing, exam
hormonal methods
Emergency Contraception - plan B
Depo-Provera

Bacterial Vaginitis (BV)

STI: trichomonas
non-STI - candida (fungus), garnerella (bacterium
Risk Factors: douching
VDRL - screens for STD's, routine for prenatal care

venereal disease research laboratory
RPR - rapid plasma reagin
Pre-natal panel
Group B Streptoccocus (GBS)

SBAR - includes baby and mom

Do all 4 reflections, the rest will be orally (week 5 and beyond)
Maternal Care Map - 2 times, integrated into ATI

rounding :
.1-.04 - round DOWN
.5-.9 - round up
IV infusions - round to the nearest whole number
IV infusions with medications - carry answer to the 10th place
ex. 125.67 mL/hr => 125.7
NO rounding of IVP, I'm, SQ, ID

Normal HR fetal - 110-160
TOCO - Tocodynanometer - external monitor "pressure transducer"
IUPC - untrauterine pressure catheter - internal monitor, invasive, potential
Contractions - usually documented in terms of frequency per 10 minutes
Primagravida - first pregnancy
Tachycardia - common cause: maternal infection, terbutaline (given to relax mom's uterus)


how to succeed: look at power points
come prepared during clinicals
CKA - due on this sunday
Fetal Monitoring - due the following sunday
Posrtpartum Assessment
BUBBLE-HEAVN
Breast
Uterus
Bowel
Bladder - pullout indwelling before 24 hours
Lochia - discharge
Episiotomy - REEDA (redness, edema, ecchymosis, drainage, approximation to access)
Homan's Sign - assess DVT, flex foot, pain in calf?
Emotional Status
Abdomen
Vital Sign
Nutrition
Study all reflexes for finals

item.description:
Questions for lecture

chapter 10 includes GENETICS but not included in powerpoint, so study it?

see powerpoint in clinical
know the causes for variability, decelerations, implications for each type

Terbutaline - help prevents pre-term labor, cutoff 120 HR, sub-q (does burn)
Magnesium Sulfate - neuroprotection for the fetus, also helps relax the uterus (a little bit), loading dose-4-6 g over 20 min, maintainance dose of 2g per hour
=> mag levels drawn every 2 hours (too much mag can impair breathing)
=> lab may call for a critical dose but that's okay coz the therapeutic range is above the reference range
=> check DTR (may be absent if too much)
Becamethasone - steroid, 12.5mg IM, purpose: to mature fetal lungs, repeat in 12-24 hours (12 if delivery is imminent)


see Ch.10 - Fetal Development

kahoot id 8026784
Age of majority = 18
Health screenings are an important part of prenatal visit - false
increased vaignal discharge is a normal finding - t
which of the procedures should be performed for prenatal - fundal height and urine dip - no pap, no blood sugar
recurrent HSV infections are usually less severe that the initial episode - True

STD that has fish order - Bacterial vaginosis
pregnant craves ice - pica
ligament tightening - FALSe - ligaments loosen
enlarged uterus - not a positive sign

- Biophysical Profile

item.title: Fetal Heart Monitoring Cheat Sheet
item.description:
1 second = 1 mm ÷ (3 cm/min) = 0.2 cm/sec
So, every 1 mm (small box) on the paper = 10 seconds
6 small boxes (1 cm) = 60 seconds / 1 minute
A 10-minute strip is typically 30 cm long
1 Red Line Divider = 1 minute
1 small box = 10 seconds

Category I: Normal

Baseline rate: 110–160 bpm
Baseline variability: moderate (6–25 bpm)
No late or variable decelerations
Early decelerations: present or absent
Accelerations: present or absent
→ Indicates normal fetal acid-base status; no intervention needed.
Category II: Indeterminate

Includes any tracing not categorized as I or III
Examples:
Bradycardia with variability
Tachycardia
Minimal, absent, or marked variability
Absence of accelerations after stimulation
Recurrent variable decels with minimal/moderate variability
→ Requires close monitoring and clinical evaluation.
Category III: Abnormal - LV "luis vitton" => late & variable decels

Absent variability and any of the following:
Recurrent late decelerations
Recurrent variable decelerations
Bradycardia
Sinusoidal pattern
→ Indicates abnormal fetal acid-base status; requires prompt intervention (e.g., oxygen, repositioning, delivery if unresolved).


Fluctuations in the baseline FHR that are irregular in amplitude and frequency
Reflects the interplay between sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems
Key indicator of fetal well-being
1. Absent

No detectable fluctuations
May indicate fetal hypoxia, acidosis, or neurologic depression
Concerning—requires immediate evaluation
prepare for emergency delivery
2. Minimal

Amplitude range: ≤5 bpm
Causes: sleep cycle, sedation (e.g., opioids, magnesium sulfate), prematurity, or hypoxia
Evaluate context and other FHR patterns
3. Moderate (Normal)

Amplitude range: 6–25 bpm
Indicates well-oxygenated fetus with intact CNS
Most reassuring variability
4. Marked

Amplitude: >25 bpm
Causes: acute hypoxia, fetal stimulation, or cord compression
May be transient but warrants monitoring
Moderate variability = reassuring
Absent/minimal = concerning when persistent, especially with decels or bradycardia
Marked = assess for cause, monitor for fetal stress

1. Early Decelerations

Cause: Head compression (normal response during contractions)
Timing: Mirrors the contraction; nadir aligns with peak
Appearance: Gradual onset/return, uniform shape
Significance: still type 1!, benign, usually not concerning
2. Variable Decelerations

Cause: Umbilical cord compression
Timing: Abrupt onset; varies in timing with contractions
Appearance: Sharp drop (V, U, or W shaped), quick recovery
Significance: May require intervention if recurrent or severe
3. Late Decelerations

Cause: Uteroplacental insufficiency (e.g., hypoxia, hypertension, post-dates)
Timing: Begins after contraction starts; nadir after peak
Appearance: Gradual onset/return
Significance: Concerning—indicates fetal distress, requires evaluation and possible intervention
Late decels = LIONS (L → Left side, I → IV fluids, O → Oxygen, N → Notify provider, S → Stop oxytocin)
4. Prolonged Decelerations

Cause: Interruption in fetal oxygen (e.g., cord prolapse, hypotension, uterine rupture)
Timing: Lasts 2–10 minutes
Appearance: Sharp drop, sustained
Significance: Emergent—requires prompt evaluation and action

item.title: Tachysystole
item.description:
Definition – More than 5 uterine contractions in 10 minutes, averaged over 30 minutes
Causes – Excessive oxytocin (Pitocin), uterine stimulants, spontaneous labor hyperstimulation
Risks – Fetal hypoxia, uterine rupture, placental abruption, decreased fetal oxygenation
Assessment – Frequent contractions with little rest, fetal heart rate changes (late decels, bradycardia), increased uterine tone
Nursing Interventions
Stop or reduce oxytocin infusion
Reposition mother (left lateral)
Administer oxygen via face mask (8–10 L/min)
IV fluid bolus
Notify provider
Prepare for emergency interventions if unresolved
Monitoring – Continuous fetal heart rate and contraction pattern via external or internal monitor

item.title: VEAL-CHOP
item.description: FOR DECELARTIONs ONLY
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: GTPAL
item.description:
GP System
Gravida - pregnancy numbers
Para - Number of pregnancies delivered after 20 weeks (regardless if delivered alive or not)

GTPAL System - more details

G: Gravida – Total number of pregnancies, including the current pregnancy if applicable.
T: Term births – Number of full-term births (deliveries at 37 weeks or later).
P: Preterm births – Number of preterm births (deliveries between 20 and 36 weeks).
A: Abortions – Number of pregnancies that ended in miscarriage or abortions
L: Living children – Number of living children the woman has.
Example of GTPAL Notation:

G3T1P1A1L2
G3: The woman has been pregnant 3 times (includes current pregnancy if applicable).
T1: She has had 1 full-term delivery (after 37 weeks).
P1: She has had 1 preterm delivery (between 20 and 36 weeks).
A1: She has had 1 miscarriage or elective abortion before 20 weeks.
L2: She has 2 living children
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hormones
item.description:
Detected in maternal serum by 8-10 days after conception
Signals corpus luteum not to degenerate until placenta secretes adequate estrogen and progesterone.
Prevents immunological rejection of implanting embryo.
Has thyroid-stimulating ability

stimulates maternal metabolism to produce nutrients needed for fetal growth
facilitates glucose transfer across placenta
prepares maternal breast development to prepare for lactation

Maintains endometrium
Decreases contractility of uterus
Stimulates maternal metabolism and development of alveolar tissue

By 7th week, placenta produces more estrogen than corpus luteum – primarily as estriol
Measuring maternal serum estriol levels is one way to test for placental function during pregnancy
Estrogens stimulate uterine growth and uteroplacental blood flow
Production increases greatly toward end of pregnancy
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Menstruation Cycle
item.description:
aka Ovarian Cycle

Follicular phase (day 1 through ovulation, approximately days 10 to 14)
Ovulation (day 14 of a 28-day cycle)
Luteal phase (day 15 through day 28 of a 28-day cycle)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Naegel's Rule
item.description:
add: +9 months, +7 days
Naegele's Rule is a method used to estimate the expected due date of a pregnancy, based on the first day of the woman's last menstrual period (LMP). I
common tool for quickly getting a rough estimate of the delivery date, particularly in the early stages of pregnancy.
How it Works:
Start with the LMP: Identify the first day of the woman's last menstrual period. Subtract three calendar months: Count back three full calendar months from the LMP date. Add seven days: Add seven days to the date obtained in step 2. Add one year (if needed): If the date falls in the previous year, add one year to the date.
Example:
Let's say the first day of a woman's LMP was September 9, 2023.
Subtract three months: September - 3 months = June. Add seven days: June 9 + 7 days = June 16. Add one year (if needed): Since the date is in the current year (2024), we don't add a year.
Therefore, the estimated due date would be June 16, 2024
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Physical Assessment Findings of Pregnancy
item.description:
Weight gain appropriate to gestational age (approx. 25–35 lbs total for normal BMI)
Fatigue especially in the first and third trimesters


Linea nigra: dark line from pubis to umbilicus
Striae gravidarum: stretch marks on abdomen, breasts, thighs
Chloasma: "mask of pregnancy"—hyperpigmentation on face
Palmar erythema due to increased estrogen
Increased perspiration and sebaceous activity


Mild thyroid enlargement can be normal
Increased hair growth during pregnancy (may shed postpartum)


Slight corneal thickening (reversible postpartum)
Dry eyes or blurred vision occasionally


Tenderness, enlargement, and heaviness
Darkened areolas and Montgomery tubercles
Colostrum production in late pregnancy


Slight increase in respiratory rate
Shortness of breath in 3rd trimester (uterus pressing diaphragm)
Nasal congestion or epistaxis due to estrogen-induced vascular changes


Systolic murmurs may be present (common and usually benign)
Increased heart rate (10–15 bpm)
Lower blood pressure in 2nd trimester, returns to baseline by 3rd
Dependent edema (especially feet/ankles)
Varicose veins or hemorrhoids may develop due to venous stasis


Nausea/vomiting (especially 1st trimester)
Heartburn due to relaxed lower esophageal sphincter
Constipation due to progesterone slowing GI motility
Abdominal distension and decreased bowel sounds


Increased urinary frequency (especially 1st and 3rd trimesters)
Chadwick’s sign: bluish discoloration of cervix/vagina
Goodell’s sign: softening of cervix
Hegar’s sign: softening of uterine isthmus
Leukorrhea: increased vaginal discharge


Lordosis: compensatory curvature due to weight of uterus
Waddling gait from pelvic joint relaxation
Round ligament pain or backache
Diastasis recti: separation of abdominal muscles


Carpal tunnel syndrome (numbness/tingling in hands)
Leg cramps (especially at night)
Mood swings or emotional lability
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/OB/i. Maternal Assessment/Physical Assessment Findings of Pregnancy.html
item.guid: OB/i. Maternal Assessment/Physical Assessment Findings of Pregnancy.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Alfa-Fetoprotein (AFP) Analysis
item.description:
What is it – Blood test screening for fetal neural tube defects and chromosomal anomalies
Clinical Presentation – Routine prenatal screening, especially at 16–18 weeks
Treatment – Not a treatment; may prompt further testing (e.g., amniocentesis, ultrasound)
Nursing Interventions – Confirm LMP, weight, race, gestational age; educate on venipuncture procedure
Diagnostic Tools – Maternal serum AFP ± triple/quad/penta screen
Causes of ↑AFP – Neural tube defect, underestimated gestational age, multiples, GI defect
Causes of ↓AFP – Overestimated age, fetal death, Down syndrome, trisomy 18, molar pregnancy
Risk Factors – Incorrect dating, maternal weight extremes, diabetes, multiple gestation
Systemic Effects – None directly; indicates risk for fetal abnormality
Complications – False positives → anxiety, unnecessary follow-up tests, financial/emotional stress
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Biophysical Profile
item.description:
Prenatal test assessing fetal well-being
Combines ultrasound + nonstress test (NST)
Evaluates 5 parameters, each scored 0 or 2
Max score = 10, modified BPP (no US) = out of 8


NST (Nonstress Test):
2 = Reactive (≥2 accelerations in 20 mins)
0 = Nonreactive
Fetal Breathing Movements:
2 = ≥1 episode ≥30 seconds in 30 mins
0 = Absent or <30 seconds
Fetal Movement:
2 = ≥3 discrete body/limb movements
0 = <3 movements
Fetal Tone:
2 = ≥1 episode of flexion-extension-return (e.g., hand or limb)
0 = Slow return or no movement
Amniotic Fluid Volume (AFV):
2 = ≥1 vertical pocket ≥2 cm
0 = No pocket ≥2 cm



8–10 = Normal (low risk of asphyxia)
6 = Equivocal → repeat in 24 hrs or delivery if term
≤4 = Abnormal → delivery indicated (especially if term or deteriorating)
Modified BPP = NST + AFV only (max score = 8)



Decreased fetal movement
Nonreactive NST
Suspected IUGR
Post-term pregnancy
Hypertensive disorders, DM, or other high-risk conditions
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Fundal Height in Pregnancy
item.description:
Fundal Height = weeks of pregnancy in terms of cm
McDonald Method - lying down, top of pubic bone to top of fundus => knees flexed
=> if growth curve flattens or stable - indicates FGR (fetal growth restriction)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Nonstress Test
item.description:
Pre-test – Explain procedure, empty bladder, semi-Fowler position, apply belts
Documentation – Note start time, client info, reason, vitals, baseline strip (15–30 min)
During test – Watch for fetal movement with HR accelerations
Interpretation – Reactive = 2 accelerations (15 bpm × 15 sec in 20 min)
Nonreactive – No 15×15 accelerations after 40 min → possible distress/IUGR
Follow-up – May need BPP or further testing
Post-test – Help off table, give fluids, restroom, review results and warning signs,
Nonstress Test (NST) – Interpretation

Reactive (normal) – ≥2 accelerations in 20 minutes, each ↑15 bpm for ≥15 sec (≥32 wks)
Reactive (before 32 wks) – ≥2 accelerations ↑10 bpm for ≥10 sec in 20 minutes
Nonreactive – Lacks sufficient accelerations; may indicate fetal sleep, immaturity, or distress
Follow-up for nonreactive – Extend test to 40 min, use vibroacoustic stimulation, consider BPP or CST
Significance – Reactive = reassuring; Nonreactive = requires further assessment
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pregnancy Discomforts
item.description:
see p.405
N/V

Eat 6 small meals/day
avoid empty stomach at all times!
Avoid highly seasoned or greasy foods
Drink at least 8 (8oz) glasses of water/day
Ask for medication
Urinary Frequency - d/t compression of bladder
Fatigue
Breast Tenderness
Exessive salivation & increased discharge - d/t increased estrogen => bathe daily, no douching
Heartburn: ↑ progesterone, ↑ pressure => Use antacids, small meals, sit upright for 30 min after eating

Backache
Varicosities of the vulva and legs
Hemorrhoids
Flatulence with bloating

Return of first trimester discomforts
Shortness of breath and dyspnea
Heartburn and indigestion
Dependent edema
Braxton Hicks contractions
2nd & 3rd Trim Discomforts

Ankle Edema - ↑ sodium & cap permeability, circulatory congestion, prolonged standing/sitting, Frequent dorsiflexion
Get up and move for at least 5 min Q hr, Supportive hose (used for varicosities too)
Hemorrhoids - constipation, pressure, sitz bath, witch hazel pads, ointments
Constipation/Flatulence: ↑ progesterone, ↓ fluids, ↓ exercise => tx: ↑ fluids, ↑ fresh fruit/veggies (non-gassy), stool softeners
Backache: ↑ lumbar curve, ↑ hormones
Proper body mechanics and pelvis-tilt exercise
Leg cramps: ↑ nerve pressure, electrolyte imbalances, ↓ circulation
Dorsiflexion, dietary changes, heating pad
Syncope: Anemia, postural hypotension
Keep body temp normal, stand up slowly, check H&H
Dyspnea: ↓ vital capacity, anemia
Sleep propped on pillows
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cardiovascular Disorders in OB
item.description:
Include congenital or acquired heart diseases that may be exacerbated by physiological changes of pregnancy
Pregnancy increases blood volume, cardiac output, and heart rate, placing added stress on the heart
Can lead to maternal and fetal complications if not well managed



Congenital heart defects (e.g., septal defects, coarctation of aorta)
Rheumatic heart disease - caused by rheumatic fever, which in turn is a complication of untreated strep throat or scarlet fever
Cardiomyopathy (especially peripartum)
Arrhythmias
Valvular Dysfunctions (e.g., mitral stenosis)
Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy


Pre-existing cardiac disease
Obesity
Advanced maternal age
Hypertension
Diabetes
History of cardiac events or surgery


Dyspnea, fatigue (especially with exertion)
Orthopnea
Palpitations
Chest pain
Syncope
Cyanosis or clubbing in severe cases
Edema, jugular vein distension


Heart failure
Pulmonary edema
Arrhythmias
Thromboembolism
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
Preterm labor or fetal demise


Echocardiogram
ECG
Chest X-ray (with shielding)
BNP levels
Fetal ultrasound for growth monitoring


Individualized based on type and severity of heart disease
Beta-blockers, diuretics (cautiously), anticoagulants (heparin preferred)
Oxygen therapy as needed
Limit physical activity
Planned delivery with multidisciplinary team (usually vaginal unless contraindicated)


Monitor vital signs, oxygenation, and signs of decompensation
Limit stress and exertion
Positioning to maximize cardiac output (left lateral)
Administer medications as ordered and monitor effects
Educate patient on signs of worsening condition
DO NOT ADMINISTER WARFARIN (COUMADIN) => crosses placenta


Importance of regular prenatal care and cardiac follow-up
Activity restrictions and rest periods
Medication compliance and safety
Recognize signs of worsening cardiac status
Plan for labor and delivery with appropriate medical support
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: L&D - Anemia
item.description:
Hemoglobin levels are lower than normal, reducing oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood
Most common type is iron-deficiency anemia, but folate and vitamin B12 deficiencies can also occur
See also:
L&D - Thalassemia => mild form form of anemia that does not respond to iron supplements
L&D - Sickle Cell Anemia
Criteria for Iron-Deficiency Anemia:

low hemoglobin (less than 11 g/dL or 110 g/L)
low hematocrit (less than 35% or 0.35)
low serum iron (less than 30 μg/dL or 5.37 μmol/L)
microcytic and hypochromic cells
low serum ferritin (less than 100 ng/dL or 100 μg/L)


Increased iron demand due to fetal growth
Poor dietary intake or absorption of iron, folate, or B12
Blood loss (e.g., GI bleeding, frequent pregnancies close together)
Hemoglobinopathies (e.g., sickle cell, thalassemia)


Inadequate prenatal nutrition
Multiple gestations
Close pregnancy spacing
Adolescents or underweight individuals
History of heavy menstruation or chronic illness


Fatigue, weakness, pallor
Dizziness or lightheadedness
Shortness of breath on exertion
Palpitations
Headaches
Pica


Preterm birth
Low birth weight
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
Postpartum hemorrhage
Increased maternal morbidity
intellectual disability


CBC showing low hemoglobin and hematocrit
Low serum ferritin and iron levels
Elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC)
Peripheral smear for red blood cell morphology


Iron supplements (oral ferrous sulfate preferred) => take with Vitamin C
side effect: black stool, constipation, nausea, abdominal pain
take on empty stomach => if tolerated
do not take with coffee, tea, chocolate, high fiber foods
Increase dietary iron (red meat, leafy greens, fortified cereals)
Vitamin C to enhance iron absorption => orange juice
MILK WILL INHIHBIT ABSORPTION
Folic acid and B12 supplements if deficient
Severe cases may require parenteral iron or transfusion


Educate on iron-rich diet and supplement adherence
Administer iron between meals with vitamin C
Monitor for side effects (constipation, GI upset)
Track hemoglobin and ferritin levels over time
Reinforce importance of prenatal visits and labs


Take iron supplements on an empty stomach if tolerated
Avoid taking iron with calcium, dairy, or antacids
Include iron-rich foods and stay hydrated
Report persistent fatigue, palpitations, or dizziness
Follow up for blood work as scheduled
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: L&D - Asthma
item.description:
affects oxygenation for both mother and fetus; poor control increases risks of complications
Goal: maintain optimal pulmonary function throughout pregnancy


Triggered by allergens, respiratory infections, exercise, stress, or environmental irritants
Hormonal and physiological changes in pregnancy can affect airway reactivity


Maternal hypoxia
Preeclampsia
Preterm birth
Low birth weight
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
Increased cesarean delivery risk


Rescue: albuterol, ipratropium
Maintenance: beclomethasone, salmeterol


Monitor respiratory status and fetal well-being
Reinforce medication adherence and trigger avoidance
Educate about recognizing signs of exacerbation
Coordinate care with OB and pulmonary specialists
Monitor for signs of preeclampsia or growth restriction


Avoid known asthma triggers
Continue prescribed medications, even during pregnancy
Use peak flow meter to track lung function
Seek immediate care for severe shortness of breath or decreased fetal movement
Stay current with flu and pertussis vaccines
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: L&D - Autoimmune Disorders
item.description:
see Lupus
High-risk pregnancy due to increased risk of complications (e.g., preeclampsia, preterm birth, miscarriage, fetal growth restriction)
Plan pregnancy during remission (≥6 months remission recommended before conception)
Avoid pregnancy during flare-ups – worsens maternal and fetal outcomes
Monitor for hypertension, proteinuria, edema (may mimic or mask preeclampsia)
Increased risk of neonatal lupus and congenital heart block (monitor fetal heart rate via ultrasound/ECHO)
Medications: Some immunosuppressants (e.g., hydroxychloroquine) may be continued; avoid methotrexate and cyclophosphamide
Risk of flare-ups during pregnancy and postpartum
Monitor renal function closely (SLE nephritis may worsen)
Encourage rest, hydration, and infection prevention
May require antenatal corticosteroids or aspirin for preeclampsia prevention


see Multiple Sclerosis
Pregnancy often reduces MS relapse rate; however, relapse risk increases postpartum
No increase in miscarriage or congenital anomalies
Encourage vaginal delivery unless physical disability or fatigue impedes labor
Fatigue, weakness, and muscle spasticity may affect ability to push or care for newborn
Risk for neurogenic bladder → assess urinary retention or UTIs
Avoid live vaccines if on immunosuppressive therapy
Corticosteroids (e.g., methylprednisolone) may be used during relapse, especially postpartum
Delay breastfeeding for several hours if high-dose corticosteroids are administered
Avoid teratogenic MS drugs before and during pregnancy (e.g., fingolimod, methotrexate)


see Rheumatoid Arthritis
Symptoms often improve during pregnancy, flare postpartum
RA does not affect fertility, but joint pain/fatigue may impair caregiving
NSAIDs and methotrexate are contraindicated during pregnancy
Safe medications: hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, low-dose corticosteroids
Monitor for joint pain, stiffness, fatigue, especially in third trimester and postpartum
Assess ability to perform activities of daily living (ADLs) and care for infant
Encourage joint protection strategies, rest, and physical therapy
Support breastfeeding plans; some RA meds are safe, others must be avoided
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: L&D - HIV
item.description:
see HIV-AIDS
it poses a risk of vertical (mother-to-child) transmission during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding
NOT passing HIV to fetus IS POSSIBLE with proper treatment:

Without treatment: Risk of transmission is 15–45%
With effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) during pregnancy and labor plus appropriate newborn care:
Risk is reduced to <1–2%
C-section at 38 weeks if viral load >1,000 copies/mL also reduces risk Avoiding breastfeeding further minimizes postnatal transmission in countries where formula is safe and accessible


Placenta
During delivery
breastfeeding


Vertical transmission to fetus
Preterm labor
Low birth weight
Opportunistic infections
Increased risk of maternal morbidity and mortality


Initial: Rapid HIV test, ELISA with confirmatory Western blot
Monitor: Viral load, CD4+ count, resistance testing
Prenatal: Routine HIV screening early in pregnancy


ART (antiretroviral therapy) for all HIV-positive pregnant patients
Zidovudine (ZDV) during labor and to newborn (w/in 6-12 hours of birth)
C-section recommended if viral load >1000 copies/mL at delivery
No breastfeeding in high-resource settings


Ensure ART adherence to reduce transmission risk => zidovudine
Scheduled C-section at 38 weeks if viral load >1,000 copies/mL
Avoid breastfeeding unless viral suppression is confirmed and supported by national guidelines
Avoid amniocentesis, fetal scalp electrodes, and artificial ROM when possible to reduce transmission risk
Newborn receives ZDV for 4–6 weeks postpartum


Avoid breastfeeding
Infant will receive ART prophylaxis and monitoring
Discuss safe sexual practices and partner testing
Follow-up for infant HIV testing at birth, 2 weeks, 4–6 weeks, and 4–6 months
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: L&D - Infectious Diseases
item.description:
Overview: Member of herpesvirus family; transmitted via contact with urine, saliva, blood, breast milk, and other body fluids
Transmission to fetus: Transplacental, during delivery, or via breast milk
Risk to fetus: Sensorineural hearing loss, seizures, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delays
Nursing considerations: No approved treatment during pregnancy; avoid exposure to young children's secretions; reinforce strict hand hygiene


Overview: RNA virus spread via respiratory droplets; usually mild in adults
Transmission to fetus: Transplacental
Risk to fetus: Congenital rubella syndrome – cataracts, cardiac defects, deafness, microcephaly, intellectual disability
Nursing considerations: Assess rubella immunity at first prenatal visit; avoid exposure to infected individuals; MMR vaccine contraindicated during pregnancy but given postpartum if nonimmune


Overview: HSV-1 (oral) and HSV-2 (genital); causes lifelong recurrent outbreaks
Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery if maternal lesions are present
Risk to fetus: Neonatal HSV – encephalitis, disseminated disease, skin/eye/mouth infections, death
Nursing considerations: Start suppressive therapy (acyclovir) at 36 weeks for women with history; perform C-section if lesions or prodromal symptoms at labor onset


Overview: Bloodborne liver infection; transmitted via blood, sexual contact, and perinatal exposure
see Hepatitis
Transmission to fetus: During delivery (contact with infected blood and vaginal fluids)
Risk to fetus: Chronic HBV infection, liver damage, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma
Nursing considerations:
Screen all pregnant women
administer HBIG and first HBV vaccine dose within 12 hours of birth
breastfeeding permitted if infant receives immunoprophylaxis


Overview: DNA virus that causes chickenpox and later shingles; transmitted via airborne droplets and direct contact
Transmission to fetus: Transplacental or perinatal if maternal infection occurs near delivery
Risk to fetus: Congenital varicella syndrome (limb hypoplasia, eye defects, skin scarring); neonatal varicella can be severe if maternal infection 5 days before to 2 days after delivery
Nursing considerations: Check immunity at booking; nonimmune exposed women may receive VZIG; vaccine contraindicated during pregnancy, given postpartum


Overview: Viral illness in children with “slapped cheek” rash; spread by respiratory droplets
Transmission to fetus: Transplacental
Risk to fetus: Fetal anemia, hydrops fetalis, miscarriage, especially in early pregnancy
Nursing considerations: No vaccine or treatment; advise avoiding exposure to infected children; serial ultrasounds and Doppler if maternal infection confirmed


Overview: Bacteria colonizing vagina/rectum in many women; usually asymptomatic in mother
Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery
Risk to fetus: Neonatal sepsis, pneumonia, meningitis (early-onset GBS disease)
Nursing considerations: Screen between 36–37 weeks; if positive, give intrapartum IV penicillin; treat if status unknown and risk factors present (e.g., fever, ROM ≥18 hr)


Overview: Protozoan infection from raw meat or cat feces; often asymptomatic in healthy adults
Transmission to fetus: Transplacental
Risk to fetus: Hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, developmental delay
Nursing considerations: Educate to avoid undercooked meat (cook to 160F), soil, and cat litter; treat confirmed fetal infections with spiramycin or pyrimethamine-sulfadiazine plus folinic acid
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: L&D - Sickle Cell Anemia
item.description:
see Sickle Cell Anemia
Pregnancy increases risk of complications due to higher oxygen demands and vascular stress
must screen before conception


Preeclampsia
Miscarriage or stillbirth
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
Preterm labor
Placental abruption
Infection/sepsis => spleen (w/c fights infections) can become fibrotic and nonfunctional
Impaired leukocyte function (in some cases) can increase risk of sepsis


Hemoglobin electrophoresis to confirm type
CBC showing chronic hemolytic anemia
Monitor fetal growth and placental function via ultrasound


Folic acid supplementation => chronic hemolysis causes increased demand for erythropoiesis (needs folic acid for DNA synthesis )
Prophylactic antibiotics (e.g., penicillin)
Blood transfusions as needed to reduce sickling events
Pain management during crises (avoid NSAIDs in 3rd trimester)
Hydration and oxygen therapy
Close maternal-fetal monitoring


Monitor for signs of crisis and intervene early: severe abdominal pain, muscle spasms, leg pain, joint pain, fever, stiff neck, N/V
Prevent triggers (dehydration, infection, hypoxia)
Monitor fetal well-being and maternal oxygenation
Pain control plan in labor and postpartum
Coordinate care with hematology and maternal-fetal medicine


Importance of hydration and infection prevention
Report early signs of crisis or decreased fetal movement
Adherence to prenatal appointments and lab monitoring
Avoid overexertion and stay warm
Discuss genetic counseling and implications for the baby
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: L&D - STDs
item.description:
Cause: Treponema pallidum (bacterial)
Transmission to fetus: Transplacental
Risk to fetus:
Congenital syphilis
Miscarriage, stillbirth, preterm labor
Bone deformities, hepatosplenomegaly, rash, anemia, neurologic damage
Nursing considerations:
Screen all pregnant patients at first prenatal visit; repeat at 28–32 weeks if high risk
Treat with *IM benzathine penicillin G
Desensitize if allergic (penicillin is the only safe and effective treatment)
Monitor for Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction post-treatment
Educate on abstinence until treatment is completed
Treat and notify all sexual partners


Cause: Neisseria gonorrhoeae (bacterial)
Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery
Risk to fetus:
Neonatal conjunctivitis → blindness
Preterm birth, PROM
Nursing considerations:
Screen at first prenatal visit; rescreen in 3rd trimester if high risk
Treat with ceftriaxone IM plus azithromycin (or doxycycline if not pregnant)
Administer erythromycin eye ointment to newborn within 1 hour of birth
Educate patient and partner on abstinence until both are treated
No test of cure required unless symptoms persist


Cause: Chlamydia trachomatis (bacterial)
Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery
Risk to fetus:
Neonatal pneumonia
Neonatal conjunctivitis (not fully prevented by eye ointment)
Preterm labor, low birth weight
Nursing considerations:
Screen at first prenatal visit; repeat in 3rd trimester if <25 or high risk
Treat with azithromycin 1g PO once (amoxicillin is an alternative)
Retest in 3–4 weeks to confirm cure
Educate patient to abstain from sex until both partners are treated
Erythromycin ointment still administered to prevent gonorrhea-related conjunctivitis


Cause: HPV virus (viral)
Transmission to fetus: Rare; possible *during vaginal delivery
Risk to fetus: Rare neonatal laryngeal papillomatosis (benign airway growths)
Nursing considerations:
HPV does not routinely affect pregnancy outcome
C-section only if large genital warts obstruct the birth canal
HPV vaccine *not given during pregnancy
Remove warts with cryotherapy or chemical treatment if symptomatic
Resume cervical screening postpartum
Encourage safe sex practices


Cause: Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoan parasite)
Transmission to fetus: During vaginal delivery
Risk to fetus: Preterm labor, PROM, low birth weight
Nursing considerations:
Treat with metronidazole 2g PO once
Safe during pregnancy; avoid alcohol during and 24 hrs after treatment
Treat all partners; no intercourse until treatment complete
Symptoms: frothy green discharge, foul odor, vulvar irritation
Not typically part of routine STI screen—test if symptomatic or high risk
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: L&D - TB
item.description:
infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Can be active or latent
Early detection and treatment are essential to prevent maternal and fetal complications*


Airborne transmission through inhalation of droplets from an infected person
Reactivation of latent TB due to immune changes in pregnancy
NOTE: TB does not cross placenta => airborne only


Close contact with someone with active TB
History of TB infection
HIV or other immunocompromised states
Living in or traveling to TB-endemic areas
Homelessness, incarceration, or substance use


Persistent cough (>3 weeks)
Hemoptysis (coughing up blood)
Fever and night sweats
Fatigue and weight loss
Chest pain and shortness of breath


Preterm labor
Low birth weight
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
Maternal dissemination (miliary TB, TB meningitis)
Vertical transmission (rare, but possible in active TB)


Tuberculin skin test (TST) or interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA)
Chest X-ray with abdominal shielding
Sputum acid-fast bacilli (AFB) smear and culture
Nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs) for rapid diagnosis


Latent TB: treated after delivery unless at high risk of activation
Active TB: treated during pregnancy with first-line drugs (e.g., isoniazid, rifampin, ethambutol) for at least 6 months
Avoid streptomycin (teratogenic)
Monitor liver function and adherence


do not breast feed if mother is untreated for TB during child birth - no direct contact until after 2 weeks of starting TB meds


Take all medications as prescribed, even if feeling better
Practice good cough etiquette
Avoid exposing others, especially infants, until non-infectious
Keep follow-up appointments for monitoring and testing
Inform healthcare team about TB history during labor and delivery
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: L&D - Thalassemia
item.description:
inherited blood disorder causing abnormal hemoglobin production, leading to chronic anemia
Can be alpha or beta thalassemia, with minor (trait) and major (disease) forms
Pregnancy may worsen anemia and increase maternal-fetal risks
Management depends on severity


Genetic mutation affecting globin chain production
Alpha: missing genes for alpha globin
Beta: mutation in beta globin gene


Family history of thalassemia
Ethnic backgrounds: Mediterranean, Middle Eastern, South Asian, African


Asymptomatic or mild anemia => does NOT respond to iron therapy
Severe form: fatigue, pallor, bone deformities, splenomegaly
In pregnancy: worsening fatigue, hemoglobin drop, transfusion needs


Fetal growth restriction
Preterm birth
Hemolysis and transfusion-related risks
Cardiac strain in mother
Increased risk of iron overload with transfusions


CBC with microcytic anemia
Hemoglobin electrophoresis confirms type
Ferritin and iron studies
Genetic counseling and partner testing


Mild: nutritional support, folic acid
Severe: regular transfusions, iron chelation postpartum if needed
Avoid iron unless iron-deficiency confirmed
Close fetal monitoring for growth


Monitor hemoglobin levels and symptoms of anemia
Educate on importance of follow-ups and transfusion safety
Avoid iron unless deficiency proven
Coordinate care with hematologist and maternal-fetal medicine


Importance of prenatal care and genetic counseling
Adherence to folic acid and transfusion schedule
Report fatigue, SOB, or signs of worsening anemia
Avoid iron supplements without provider direction
Consider testing of partner and fetal screening if both parents are carriers
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Vulnerable Populations
item.description:
very less likely to get prenatal care => high risk
no resources
no knowledge of sexual heath, contraception => unplanned pregnancies

Advanced Maternal Age = over 35
Same assessment as any pregnant woman
Amniocentesis & Genetic Screenings - routinely offered to allow detection of chromosomal abnoys
Higher Risk for

infertility
pregnancy loss
fetal abnormalities
still birth
Gestational Diabetes
Gestational Hypertension => Preeclampsia
small for GA
C-section


BMI>30
High risk for: everything: Gestational Diabetes, Hypertension, thromboembolism, macrosomia
Plan for possible anesthesia complications and fetal monitoring difficulties during labor
Encourage thromboprophylaxis postpartum if risk is high


Risk for poor prenatal care, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), fetal anomalies, neonatal abstinence syndrome, placental abruption
no prenatal care
Alcohol = > Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorder - FASD
down syndrome
cerebral palsy
CF, spina bifida
SIDS
Manifestations:
low nasal bridge
short nose
flat midface
short palpebral fissures
epicanthal folds
minor ear abnormalities
thin upper lip
receding jaw
Opioid - Neonatal Abstinence Syndrome (NAS) => very dangerous
irritability, hypertonicity, jitteriness, fever, cry, V/D, etc
treatment: oral methadone + psycotherapy
Nursing Considerations:

Use trauma-informed, nonjudgmental approach
Screen with validated tools (CRAFFT)
Provide referrals to addiction services and social work
Monitor fetal growth and signs of withdrawal in newborn
Caffeine - keep less than 200 mg/day
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Chronic Hypertension - (ObGyn)
item.description:
more than 140/90 BEFORE pregnancy or 20 weeks gestation
should be monitored for Preeclampsia
also called pre-existing
if it is after 20 weeks => Gestational Hypertension
140-149 sys - mild/moderate => no treatment
160+ sys => treat d/t risk for stroke or acute renal failure


main: lifestyle
meds => severe hypertension
Labetalol
Hydralazine
Nifedipine
Low-dose aspirin (81mg/day) after 12 weeks => preventative
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia
item.description: has high BP but developed other end-organ damage
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Hypertensive Disorders/Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia.html
item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Hypertensive Disorders/Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Eclampsia
item.description:
Onset of seizures in a woman with Preeclampsia
MEDICAL EMERGENCY!
A severe progression of hypertensive disorder in pregnancy
Life-threatening for both mother and fetus


Progression from untreated or severe preeclampsia
Cerebral edema, ischemia, or vasospasm may trigger seizures


Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
facial twitching
generalized muscle rigidity
facial distortion
protruding eyes
foaming at mouth
Severe headache
Visual disturbances (blurred vision, flashing lights)
RUQ/epigastric pain
Altered mental status or unresponsiveness
Increased DTR


Maternal injury from seizure
Intracranial hemorrhage
Placental abruption
Fetal distress or death
Cardiopulmonary arrest


Magnesium sulfate IV to prevent and treat seizures
Antihypertensives to manage severe BP (labetalol, hydralazine)
Stabilize and plan for delivery once maternal condition is controlled
Maintain airway and oxygenation
Position on Left Side


Seizure precautions (padded side rails, suction, oxygen)
Continuous fetal and maternal monitoring
Assess deep tendon reflexes and respiratory status for Mg toxicity
Prepare for possible emergency delivery
Provide calm environment > dim lights, quiet
Provide emotional support
Monitor serum magnesium levels, rr, reflexes, OUP => avoid mag tox


Importance of early prenatal care and reporting symptoms
Inform about seizure warning signs (aura, headache, vision changes)
Adherence to magnesium sulfate protocol and monitoring
Need for follow-up postpartum due to risk of recurrence or chronic hypertension
Encourage high protein diet (per Ricci)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Gestational Hypertension
item.description:
New-onset hypertension (≥140/90 mmHg) after 20 weeks gestation
No proteinuria or signs of end-organ damage
Temporary condition that typically resolves postpartum
temporary diagnosis for women that do not meet criteria for Preeclampsia


Exact cause unknown
Thought to involve abnormal placental development and vascular resistance


First pregnancy
Multiple gestation
History of preeclampsia or hypertension
Obesity
Maternal age <20 or >35
Diabetes


Elevated blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg after 20 weeks
Typically no proteinuria
No significant systemic symptoms unless progresses


Risk of progression to preeclampsia
Placental abruption
Preterm birth
Fetal growth restriction


BP monitoring on two occasions at least 4 hours apart
Urinalysis to rule out proteinuria
Labs to assess for liver/kidney involvement if symptoms develop


Close monitoring of BP and fetal growth
Antihypertensives if BP ≥160/110 (labetalol, hydralazine)
Delivery if condition worsens or at term
Weekly or biweekly prenatal visits


Educate on home BP monitoring
Monitor for signs of progression to preeclampsia
Promote rest and reduce stress
Support adherence to follow-up and medication plan


Report symptoms like headache, visual changes, swelling
Avoid high-sodium foods
Adhere to prenatal appointments and testing
Know potential signs of preeclampsia for early intervention
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: HELLP
item.description:
a severe form of Preeclampsia
Acronym: Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelet count
Can occur during pregnancy or postpartum
Life-threatening for mother and fetus
Diagnostic Criteria:
H - schistocytes, elevated bilirubin, elev. BUN
EL - elevated LFT => LDH, AST, ALT, bilirubin
LP - platelets <100k (normal is 150-450k)
also: high uric, Cr, LOW hematocrit


Unknown exact cause
Believed to result from abnormal placental development and systemic endothelial dysfunction
Often a complication of preeclampsia


History of Preeclampsia or HELLP
First pregnancy
Maternal age over 35
Multiple gestation
Hypertension or autoimmune disease


RUQ or epigastric pain (liver involvement)
Nausea, vomiting
Headache, blurred vision
Malaise or flu-like symptoms
Hypertension and proteinuria
Jaundice (in severe cases)


Liver hematoma or rupture
Disseminated intravascular coagulation DIC
Placental Abruption
AKI
Eclampsia
Maternal or fetal death
Cerebral Hemorrhage
Retinal Detachment
Pulmonary Edema


CBC: low platelets, evidence of hemolysis (schistocytes, elevated bilirubin)
LFTs: elevated AST and ALT
Coagulation panel, urinalysis for protein
Fetal monitoring for distress


Immediate delivery if gestational age ≥34 weeks or maternal/fetal instability
Corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) to mature fetal lungs if <34 weeks
Magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures
Antihypertensives PRN (hydralazine or labetalol)
Blood products (platelets) if bleeding risk is high => PRBC, FFP, platelets


Monitor vitals, bleeding, and labs closely
Seizure precautions and magnesium sulfate monitoring
Prepare for emergency delivery
Support maternal and fetal hemodynamic stability
Monitor urine output, liver function, and signs of DIC


Report RUQ pain, severe headache, or vision changes
Adhere to follow-up appointments and lab work
Explain possible need for early delivery
Discuss future pregnancy risks and early monitoring for preeclampsia recurrence
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy
item.description:
Overview

Chronic Hypertension - (ObGyn) - exists prior to pregnancy or develops before 20 weeks gestation, BP more than 140/90
Gestational Hypertension - new-onset blood pressure elevation (140/90 mm Hg) identified after 20 weeks’ gestation without proteinuria; blood pressure returns to normal by 12 weeks’ postpartum
Preeclampsia & HELLP
develops with proteinuria after 20 weeks’ gestation
accompanied by at least 1:
proteinuria
elevated creatinine - decreased renal perfusion due to vasoconstriction and endothelial dysfunction.
liver involvement - hepatic endothelial injury causing fibrin deposition and periportal hemorrhage.
epigastric pain - stretching of Glisson’s capsule from hepatic swelling and subcapsular hematoma.
neuro complications - Cerebral edema and vasospasm causing headaches, visual changes, or seizures.
hematologic complications - microangiopathic hemolytic anemia and platelet consumption from endothelial activation.
uteroplacental dysfunction - impaired trophoblast invasion and spiral artery remodeling leading to placental ischemia.
Eclampsia - seizure activity develops
Chronic hypertension with superimposed preeclampsia - develops after 20 weeks gestations
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Hypertensive Disorders/Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy.html
item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Hypertensive Disorders/Hypertensive Disorders of Pregnancy.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Preeclampsia
item.description:
pregnancy-specific hypertensive disorder that typically occurs after 20 weeks of gestation
characterized by new-onset hypertension and proteinuria or signs of organ dysfunction.
CRITERIA: any BP that is over 140/90 on two separate occasions
2 Stages:

Widespread vasospasm
high BP
Liver Perfusion => decreased (elev. LFTs)
Brain Perfusion - decreased (headaches, visual disturbances, high DTR)
GFR => decreased (low UOP, high BUN, high Uric acid, high cr => edema)
response to abnormal placentation - HTN, proteinuria, HA, N/V, retinal vascular changes (blurred vision), hyperreflexia d/t hypoperfusion
Patho:

placenta didn't have good vascular connection
leaky vessels - protein in blood stream => edema (where protein goes, water goes)
Liver and Kidney - damaged d/t protein in blood stream
SEVERE PREECLAMPSIA

≥160/110 mmHg (x2, 4 hrs apart)
Urine protein ≥ 500mg/24 hours
Hyperreflexia
Severe edema


💡 Note:

“Mild” preeclampsia is better referred to as “without severe features” in updated guidelines.
Eclampsia = severe preeclampsia + seizures, with no other identifiable neurologic cause.


Exact cause unknown
Likely due to abnormal placental development and vascular dysfunction
Immune response, genetic, and inflammatory factors contribute


First pregnancy (nulliparity)
Maternal age <20 or >35
History of pre-eclampsia or family history
Multiple gestation (twins, etc.)
Chronic hypertension or kidney disease
Diabetes mellitus
Obesity
Autoimmune disorders (e.g., lupus, antiphospholipid syndrome)


Blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg on two occasions 4 hours apart
Proteinuria ≥300 mg/24 hours or protein/creatinine ratio ≥0.3
Headache (persistent and severe)
Visual disturbances (blurred vision, flashing lights)
Upper abdominal pain (especially RUQ)
Edema (especially hands and face)
Hyperreflexia
Sudden weight gain
Oliguria
Elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia (severe pre-eclampsia)


Eclampsia (seizures)
HELLP syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets)
Placental Abruption
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
Preterm labor or delivery
Maternal stroke or organ failure
Fetal hypoxia or demise
DIC


Blood pressure monitoring
Urinalysis for proteinuria
CBC => platelets may be DECREASED d/t consumption for endothelial damage
very low <100k if it progresses to HELLP (normal is 150-450k)
liver function tests => elevated
Serum creatinine, uric acid
Fetal assessment (NST, BPP, ultrasound for growth)
24-hour urine collection (for definitive proteinuria)


Mild cases: Close monitoring, rest, frequent prenatal visits
Antihypertensives (e.g., labetalol, hydralazine, nifedipine)
Magnesium sulfate to prevent seizures (during labor and 24 hours postpartum) => therapeutic range: 4-7 mEq/L (normal range is 1.5-2.5)
Corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) to promote fetal lung maturity if preterm delivery likely
prenatal low dose aspirin - prevention during 12 weeks GA to delivery for high risk
Delivery of placenta => definitive treatment — timing depends on severity and gestational age
Mild HTN: bed rest at home => avoid strenuous activity like walking!
lateral recumbent position - improve placental blood flow, promote diuresis


Monitor BP => q4-6 hours while awake
Monitor urine output closely
record daily kick counts - report decreased fetal movements
Assess for signs of worsening (e.g., headache, vision changes, RUQ pain)
Administer meds as ordered (antihypertensives, magnesium sulfate)
Maintain seizure precautions
Monitor for magnesium toxicity (↓ DTRs, ↓ respirations, hypotension, urine retention)
administer calcium gluconate for magnesium toxicity
Support fetal monitoring and prep for potential delivery
Provide emotional support to patient and family


Report symptoms: headache, vision changes, swelling, decreased fetal movement
Adhere to follow-up appointments
Take prescribed medications as directed
Reduce stress and increase rest
Understand potential need for hospitalization or early delivery
Avoid NSAIDs postpartum (can raise BP further)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Placenta Accreta Spectrum
item.description:
abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall
Can cause severe bleeding during placental delivery
potentially life-threatening due to risk of hemorrhage during labor (manual attempts to detach placenta)
Classification:
Accreta - attaches to myometrium; most common; highest risk of pp hemorrhage
Increta - invades myometrium, goes further in
Percreta - penetrates uterus; gone OUTSIDE the uterus => implants to other organs like bladder


largely unknown
Defective decidua basalis layer during implantation
Often associated with scarring from previous uterine surgeries


Previous cesarean section (risk increases with number of C-sections)
Placenta previa
Prior uterine surgery or curettage
Advanced maternal age
Multiparity


Often asymptomatic until delivery
May present with bleeding in third trimester if previa is also present
Difficulty separating placenta after delivery
Massive postpartum hemorrhage


Life-threatening hemorrhage
Uterine rupture
Need for hysterectomy
Maternal shock or death
Preterm birth
Post-partum hemorrhage


Usually diagnosed after birth
Prenatal diagnosis with ultrasound and MRI => not reliable
Signs include loss of clear zone, placental lacunae, and abnormal vascularity
High index of suspicion with placenta previa and uterine scar


Planned cesarean delivery with possible hysterectomy (C-hyst)
Multidisciplinary team (OB, anesthesiology, blood bank)
Blood products and surgical prep essential


Monitor for prenatal bleeding
Prepare patient for potential early delivery and hysterectomy
Blood type and crossmatch
Support patient and family emotionally


Importance of prenatal imaging if at risk
Discuss delivery planning and possible hysterectomy
Alert signs of bleeding or contractions
Emotional support and counseling for fertility loss if hysterectomy needed
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Placental Disorders/Placenta Accreta Spectrum.html
item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Placental Disorders/Placenta Accreta Spectrum.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Placenta Previa
item.description:
Placenta previa occurs when the placenta partially or completely covers the cervical os => opening is covered
Major cause of painless third-trimester bleeding
Can lead to complications during labor and delivery
high risk of prenatal and postpartum hemorrhage, perinatal mortality
Actually two subtypes:

Low Lying Placenta - placental edge is less than 2 cm from the internal os but does not cover it
Placentia Previa proper - covers internal os


Abnormal implantation of the placenta in the lower uterine segment
Exact cause unknown, but linked to uterine scarring or anomalies


Previous placenta previa
History of C-Sectionor uterine surgery
Multiparity
Advanced maternal age - AMA, 35 yo
Smoking
Multiple gestation
infertility treatment
previous abortion


Painless bright red vaginal bleeding in the second or third trimester => signature symptom
=> note that Placental Abruption is DARK RED BLOOD (KNOW THE DIFFERENCE)
Soft, non-tender uterus
Normal fetal heart rate unless severe bleeding occurs
Often detected on routine ultrasound



Hemorrhage
Preterm birth
Placenta accreta (if previa and scarring co-exist) - placenta attaches too deeply into the uterine wall
Fetal growth restriction
Emergency cesarean delivery


Transvaginal or transabdominal ultrasound confirms placental location
Avoid digital vaginal exam if previa suspected
Serial ultrasounds used to monitor placental position


"wait and see" approach - mom and fetus stable
Pelvic rest (no intercourse, tampons, or vaginal exams)
Monitor bleeding and fetal well-being
Corticosteroids if early delivery is likely
Cesarean section if previa persists near term => highly likely


Monitor for bleeding and signs of labor
Avoid vaginal exams unless previa ruled out
Prepare for possible preterm delivery
Maintain IV access and blood type/crossmatch if active bleeding
Rhogam if Rh negative at 28 weeks
Tocolytics - MINT if preterm (meds to delay preterm labor by inhibiting contractions)
Potocin / Oxytocin PRN


Avoid activities that could trigger bleeding
Immediately report any vaginal bleeding
Explain importance of follow-up ultrasounds
Discuss possible need for cesarean delivery
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Placental Abruption
item.description:
early separation of the placenta from the uterine wall
MEDICAL EMERGENCY!
It can be partial or complete
Leads to compromised fetal oxygenation and maternal hemorrhage
Classification: based on extent of separation (maybe too in-depth for this course)
Can also be concealed or apparent
SEE Comparison Chart 19.1 in textbook


Sudden trauma (e.g., car accident, fall, abuse)
Chronic hypertension or preeclampsia => very common
Cocaine or tobacco use
Premature rupture of membranes
Previous abruption


Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy => most common (i.e., Preeclampsia, Eclampsia)
Abdominal trauma
Multiple gestation
History of placental abruption
AMA - 35yo
multifetal pregnancy
substance abuse
male fetal gender
chorioamnionitis
prolonged prelabor ROM
oligohydramnios
pre-eclampsia


Sudden onset of painful vaginal bleeding
per ATI = > Abruptio is DARK RED VAGINAL BLEEDING (Placenta Previa is RED)
Firm, tender uterus
Uterine hypertonicity (frequent contractions or constant tone)
Non-reassuring fetal heart rate or fetal demise => ABSENT FETAL HEART TONES
Hypovolemic shock in severe cases
increased fundal height - may be sign of bleeding because of blood stuck in womb
DIC symptoms: bleeding gums, tachy, petechiae, bleeding from IV site (complication)



Fetal hypoxia or death
Maternal Hemorrhage or Shock
DIC
Preterm labor and delivery
Uterine rupture (rare)


Clinical presentation is key
Ultrasound may detect retroplacental clot but not always reliable
CBC
coagulation profile - fibrinogen levels, clotting cascade
Kleihauer-Betke test to detect fetal cells in maternal blood = > ATI QUESTION
Nonstress test - findings of fetal jeopardy manifested by late decelerations or bradycardia.
Biophysical profile: Aids in evaluating clients with chronic abruption; a low score (less than 6 points) suggests possible fetal compromise


Monitor maternal and fetal status closely => treatment guided by fetal viability, severity, maternal status
IV fluids and blood products as needed
Immediate delivery if severe or fetal compromise present
Cesarean delivery often required for unstable cases
Treat DIC: blood products, ffp w/ cryoprecipitate, heparin


Assess bleeding amount, pain, and fetal heart tones
immediately on bed rest
Prepare for emergency delivery
Avoid vaginal exams if abruption suspected
Monitor vital signs and signs of shock
Support emotional needs of patient and family
resources: neonatal intensive care


Report any abdominal trauma or sudden pain/bleeding
Importance of prenatal care and managing blood pressure
Avoid smoking, drug use, and high-risk behaviors
Understand emergency delivery may be needed
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Blood Incompatibility
item.description:
refers to Rh incompatibility or ABO incompatibility between mother and fetus
Can lead to maternal immune response against fetal red blood cells, causing hemolysis
ABO compatibility is LESS important than RH in fetus-mother



Rh-negative mother with Rh-positive fetus → maternal immune system produces anti-D antibodies
in most cases - first born RH+ infants are not affected because of short exposure period
risk increases with each pregnancy => each infant is more anemic
Less commonly, ABO incompatibility (mother is type O, fetus is A or B)


Rh-negative maternal blood type
Previous pregnancy with Rh-positive fetus
No administration of Rhogam - Rho(D) immune globulin
Trauma, amniocentesis, or procedures that mix maternal-fetal blood


Often asymptomatic in the mother
Fetal effects: anemia, jaundice, hydrops fetalis, heart failure, stillbirth
Newborn may present with hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN)


Hemolysis of fetal red blood cells
If a mom is Rh-negative and her baby is Rh-positive, her body can get "tricked" into thinking the baby’s red blood cells are invaders. So, her immune system makes anti-D antibodies that can attack and destroy the baby's Rh-positive blood cells, like tiny soldiers fighting what they think is a threat.
Neonatal jaundice and kernicterus
Hydrops fetalis (severe fetal edema)
Intrauterine fetal demise if untreated


Maternal blood type and Rh factor screening early in pregnancy
Indirect Coombs test (detects maternal anti-D antibodies) => if negative, no antibodies (okay to give Rhogam)
if Coombs positive => RhoGAM is useless; mom already attacking Rh blood cells
Negative is good!
Fetal monitoring via ultrasound for signs of anemia or hydrops
Doppler studies of fetal middle cerebral artery


Rho(D) immune globulin (Rhogam) given to Rh-negative mothers at 28 weeks and within 72 hours postpartum if baby is Rh-positive
Intrauterine transfusions for severely affected fetuses
Phototherapy or exchange transfusion in newborn if jaundice develops


Verify maternal blood type and Rh status at initial prenatal visit
Ensure administration of Rhogam as scheduled
Educate about signs of fetal distress or anemia
Monitor newborn for jaundice or anemia
Provide emotional support if complications arise


Importance of early prenatal care and blood typing
Purpose and timing of RhoGAM injections
Monitor newborn for yellowing of skin or eyes
Report any trauma or bleeding during pregnancy immediately
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cardiac Arrest
item.description:
Uterine displacement in second half of pregnancy
Defibrillation paddles must be placed one rib space higher.

Lacerations of liver or spleen
Fracture of sternum or ribs
If CPR is not effective within 4 to 5 minutes, consider perimortem cesarean birth.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cervical Insufficiency
item.description:
aka premature dilation of the cervix
Painless cervical dilation during the second trimester
Leads to recurrent pregnancy loss or early preterm birth
Often asymptomatic until advanced cervical change or membrane rupture


largely unknown
cervical weakness
Congenital cervical or uterine anomalies
Prior cervical trauma (e.g., dilation and curettage, cervical surgery)
Connective tissue disorders (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos)
In-utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES)


Previous second-trimester losses without contractions
Short cervix noted on ultrasound (<25 mm before 24 weeks)
History of cervical surgery (e.g., LEEP, cone biopsy)
Multiple gestation


Pelvic pressure or vaginal fullness => hallmark sign
Increased vaginal discharge
Painless cervical dilation => may continue to PROM, contractions delivery
Possible vaginal spotting or bulging membranes
cramping
Funneling - inner OS is starting to open up like a funnel


Recurrent second-trimester losses
Preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
Chorioamnionitis
Preterm labor


Transvaginal ultrasound showing cervical shortening or funneling
Cervical length <25 mm before 24 weeks => high RISK of preterm labor
History of painless cervical dilation and pregnancy loss


Cervical cerclage placement (prophylactic or emergent) - placing a stitch or band around the cervix to prevent it from opening too early during pregnancy
Cervical Pessary - a round, silicone device at the mouth of the cervix
Progesterone therapy for short cervix
Activity and pelvic rest in some cases
Serial ultrasound monitoring of cervical length
avoid heavy lifting


Monitor for pre-term labor: contractions, backache, PROM
monitor vaginal bleeding, or signs of infection
Provide emotional support after pregnancy loss
Post-cerclage care: monitor for signs of rupture or labor
Educate on follow-up and lifestyle modifications


Avoid heavy lifting, prolonged standing, or intercourse if advised
Report symptoms: leaking fluid, pelvic pressure, bleeding, or contractions
Adhere to follow-up appointments and cervical length checks
Understand cerclage procedure and when to seek emergency care
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Ectopic Pregnancy
item.description:
fertilized ovum implants outside the uterine cavity
embryo draws blood supplies from site of abnormal implantation
potential for organ rupture = MEDICAL EMERGENCY
most common site for implantation - fallopian tubes, can also happen in intestine, ovary, cervix, abdominal cavity


Conditions that obstruct or slow the passage of the fertilized ovum through the fallopian tube to the uterus


Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
Chlamydia history
tubal surgery
infertility
previous pregnancy loss
IUDs
multiple sex partners
progestin-only oral contraceptives
postpartum or postabortion infection
douching
35+ age
cigarette smoking
DES


Unilateral lower abdominal pain
Vaginal bleeding (light to heavy spotting)
Missed menstrual period
Positive pregnancy test but no intrauterine pregnancy on ultrasound
Referred shoulder pain (from diaphragmatic irritation if ruptured)
Signs of shock: hypotension, tachycardia, dizziness (if ruptured)


Tubal rupture
Hemorrhage and hypovolemic shock => monitor VS
Infertility or increased risk for future ectopic pregnancies


Transvaginal ultrasound (no gestational sac in uterus)
Serial hCG levels => normal pregnacy: continuous increase until 60-90 days, ectopic: LOW (means impending abortion)
Pelvic exam (may show adnexal tenderness or mass)


Methotrexate (if stable and unruptured) to stop fetal cell growth
conditional: no bleeding, low HCG (<5k), mass must be unruptured
Methotrexate - treats cancer by slowing growth of cells
Surgical intervention (e.g., salpingostomy or salpingectomy) if ruptured or unstable
Salpingostomy - removal of tube
Rh immunoglobulin (Rhogam) for Rh-negative women


Monitor vital signs for signs of bleeding or shock
Assess pain level and administer analgesics
Administer medications as ordered (e.g., methotrexate)
Provide emotional support and education
Prepare for surgery if indicated


Avoid alcohol and folic acid with methotrexate (interferes with drug action)
Report worsening abdominal pain, heavy bleeding, or dizziness
Follow up with serial hCG monitoring until undetectable => VERY IMPORTANT! (blood test?)
Delay attempts at conception for at least 3 months post-methotrexate
Use contraception as advised until cleared for future pregnancy
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Endometriosis
item.description:
a chronic gynecologic condition where endometrial-like tissue grows outside the uterus.
ectopic tissues respond to hormonal cycles, leading to inflammation, pain, and possible infertility.

unknown: possibly retrograde menstruation, genetics, immune dysfunction


Family history (first-degree relatives)
Early menarche or late menopause
Short menstrual cycles (<27 days)
Heavy menstrual bleeding
Nulliparity
Obstructed menstrual flow


Chronic pelvic pain
Dysmenorrhea (painful menstruation)
Dyspareunia (painful intercourse)
Infertility
Pain with bowel movements or urination (especially during menstruation)
Abnormal bleeding


Infertility
Ovarian cysts (endometriomas)
Adhesions and pelvic scarring
Bowel or bladder dysfunction (rare but possible with advanced disease)
Emotional stress or depression


Pelvic exam (may reveal tender nodules or masses)
Transvaginal ultrasound (limited sensitivity)
Laparoscopy (gold standard for diagnosis and staging)
MRI (for deep or extensive disease)


NSAIDs for pain relief
Hormonal therapy including oral contraceptives and GnRH agonists
Progestin therapy
Surgical removal of endometrial implants
Hysterectomy in severe, refractory cases
Fertility treatments if conception is a goal

Discuss fertility options if relevant
Inform about potential need for surgery
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Fetal Growth Restriction
item.description:
FGR

Fetal Growth Restriction (FGR) is a condition where a fetus does not grow at the expected rate during pregnancy. This can lead to low birth weight and may increase the risk of complications during labor and delivery.


Placental insufficiency (most common cause)
Maternal hypertension or pre-eclampsia
Chronic maternal illness (e.g., diabetes, kidney disease)
Infections (e.g., cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella)
Substance abuse (e.g., smoking, alcohol, drugs)
Multiple gestation (twins or higher-order multiples)
Genetic abnormalities (e.g., chromosomal disorders)
Poor maternal nutrition
Uterine anomalies


Hypertension (pre-eclampsia or chronic hypertension)
Obesity or underweight
Multiple pregnancies (twins, triplets)
Advanced maternal age (>35 years)
Smoking or substance abuse
Inadequate prenatal care
History of FGR in previous pregnancies


Small for gestational age (SGA) on ultrasound
Increased fundal height discrepancy
Decreased fetal movement (late sign)
Ultrasound measurements (growth scans) reveal that the fetus is smaller than expected for gestational age
Oligohydramnios (low amniotic fluid)


Preterm birth
Stillbirth
Neonatal hypoglycemia
Respiratory distress syndrome
Meconium aspiration
Neonatal infection
Long-term developmental issues
Increased risk of metabolic syndrome and cardiovascular disease in later life


Ultrasound (most accurate tool for diagnosing FGR)
Doppler ultrasound to assess blood flow in the umbilical artery
Biophysical profile (BPP) or Non-stress test (NST) to monitor fetal well-being
Amniotic fluid index (AFI) to check for oligohydramnios
Symphysis fundal height measurement (to assess for discrepancies)


Maternal management (control underlying conditions like hypertension or diabetes)
Early delivery if FGR is severe or if fetal distress is observed
Increased prenatal visits for close monitoring of fetal growth
Steroid therapy to accelerate fetal lung maturity if preterm delivery is anticipated


Monitor fetal movements and educate the mother on how to do so (e.g., "count-to-ten" method)
Educate on signs of preterm labor and when to seek medical care
Monitor maternal health (e.g., blood pressure, weight, urine for protein)
Support maternal nutrition (adequate caloric intake, balanced diet)
Encourage cessation of smoking and avoid alcohol and drugs
Prepare for potential early delivery and complications


Signs of FGR: Decreased fetal movements or small abdomen
Importance of prenatal visits for early detection and monitoring
Nutrition: Ensure a balanced, nutritious diet to support fetal growth
Smoking cessation and avoiding alcohol/substance abuse
Understand fetal monitoring techniques (e.g., NST, BPP)
Discuss delivery plans if early induction or cesarean section is needed
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: GBS Positive
item.description:
Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is a common bacterial colonizer of the lower GI and genitourinary tracts in women, often asymptomatic.
In pregnancy, GBS can be passed to the newborn during labor/delivery, potentially causing serious infections.


Natural colonization by Streptococcus agalactiae in the vaginal or rectal area
Not sexually transmitted, but may ascend during labor


Previous infant with GBS disease
GBS bacteriuria during current pregnancy
Preterm labor (<37 weeks)
Prolonged rupture of membranes (>18 hours)
Maternal fever during labor (>100.4°F or 38°C)


Maternal: Often asymptomatic
Neonate: Sepsis, pneumonia, meningitis, lethargy, poor feeding, respiratory distress


Neonatal sepsis or meningitis
Preterm labor
Fetal demise (in rare severe cases)
Increased neonatal morbidity/mortality if untreated


Vaginal and rectal swab culture between 36–37 weeks gestation
Urine culture if GBS bacteriuria suspected earlier in pregnancy


Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis (IAP) during labor
Penicillin G is the first-line treatment
Alternatives include ampicillin or cefazolin (if penicillin allergic without anaphylaxis risk)
Clindamycin if allergic with high anaphylaxis risk and sensitivity confirmed


Ensure GBS culture is obtained at 36–37 weeks
Review GBS status upon admission to labor and delivery
Administer antibiotics at least 4 hours prior to delivery when possible
Monitor mother and infant for signs of infection
Educate on importance of IAP for GBS-positive women


GBS is common and not harmful to the mother in most cases
Prophylactic antibiotics during labor protect the baby
No treatment is needed before labor unless GBS bacteriuria is present
GBS status should be communicated to all care providers during delivery planning
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Gestational Diabetes
item.description:
Diabetes in pregnancy includes pre-existing diabetes (Type 1 or 2) and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)
GDM develops during pregnancy and usually resolves after delivery
All types require close monitoring to avoid complications for mother and baby



Hormonal changes during pregnancy cause insulin resistance
Placental hormones (e.g., human placental lactogen) increase glucose levels
Pre-existing impaired glucose tolerance or obesity


Obesity
Family history of diabetes
Previous large baby (>9 lbs)
History of GDM in prior pregnancy
Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
Maternal age >25


Often asymptomatic
May include polyuria, polydipsia, fatigue, or recurrent infections
Elevated fasting or postprandial blood glucose levels


Maternal: preeclampsia, cesarean delivery, infections
Fetal: macrosomia (large BW), hypoglycemia, respiratory distress syndrome, congenital anomalies (in pregestational diabetes)
Neonatal: hypoglycemia, hyperbilirubinemia (macrosomia => more O2 demands => inc. RBC prodution => RBC die after birth => more bili excreted)


Screening with 1-hour glucose challenge test (24–28 weeks)
Diagnostic 3-hour oral glucose tolerance test if 1-hour is abnormal
Fasting blood glucose and A1C in early pregnancy for high-risk women
glucose targets (Durnwald, 2020) are:
- Fasting blood glucose level: Less than 95 mg/dL
- At 1 hour: Less than 140 mg/dL
- At 2 hours: Less than 120 mg/dL
- At 3 hours: Less than 95 mg/dL
One or more abnormal result = Gestational Diabetes


Goal: glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) level < 7%
Diet modification (carbohydrate-controlled meals)
Blood glucose monitoring (fasting and postprandial)
Insulin therapy if diet/exercise insufficient => does not cross placenta
Oral hypoglycemics (metformin or glyburide) in some cases => also does not cross
Delivery planning (usually by 39 weeks if well controlled)


Monitor blood glucose and fetal growth
Teach glucose monitoring and insulin administration
Assess for signs of complications (e.g., preeclampsia, infections)
Collaborate with dietitian for meal planning
Encourage compliance with prenatal visits and testing


Importance of diet and exercise to manage glucose
Eat 3 meals a day plus 3 snacks to promote glycemic control:
45% carbs
35% protein
25% fat
small frequent feedings are recommended
bed time snacks are okay
How to perform self-monitoring of blood glucose - 4x/day or fasting, post meals
Signs of hypo/hyperglycemia and when to seek care
Risk of recurrence in future pregnancies or development of Type 2 DM
Postpartum follow-up glucose testing (6–12 weeks after birth)
record daily kick counts
Insulin => eat breakfast within 30 minutes after admin
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Gestational Trophoblastic Disease
item.description:
abnormal cells grow instead of a healthy baby "empty egg"
group of rare tumors involving abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue after conception
all male chromosomes - 46
no circulation is established; no baby
Most forms are benign, but some can become malignant
signature manifestation: HCG levels are present
Types:

Complete mole – no fetal tissue, empty egg fertilized, benign
Partial mole – abnormal fetus/placenta, egg fertilized by two sperm
Invasive mole – mole invades uterine wall, local spread
Choriocarcinoma – malignant, fast-growing, spreads to lungs/brain


Abnormal fertilization of an egg
Complete mole: empty egg fertilized by sperm
Partial mole: egg fertilized by two sperm or one sperm that duplicates


Extremes of maternal age (<20 or >35)
History of GTD
Nutritional deficiencies (low carotene or folic acid)
History of miscarriage


Vaginal bleeding in first trimester
Uterus larger than expected for gestational age
usual pregnancy symptoms
fetal parts not evident with palpation
Severe nausea and vomiting (hyperemesis gravidarum)
Absent fetal heart tones
High hCG levels
Grape-like vesicles passed vaginally
Preeclampsia signs before 20 weeks gestation
fluid retention


Hemorrhage
Anemia
Hyperthyroidism
Trophoblastic embolism
Progression to choriocarcinoma
increased risk of cancer


Transvaginal ultrasound (shows snowstorm or cluster-of-grapes appearance)
Quantitative serum hCG (markedly elevated)
Chest X-ray to rule out metastasis if malignancy is suspected
Histologic examination after uterine evacuation


Removal of uterine contents ASAP!
D&C - dilation and curettage => remove tissue from uterus
Suction curettage for mole removal
Serial hCG levels post-evacuation until undetectable (usually 1 year)
elevated HCG = tissue still there
Chemotherapy if malignant (usually methotrexate)
Avoid pregnancy for 1 year during follow-up => can interfere with HCG trends
follow-up for 1 year => d/t increased risk of cancer


Monitor vaginal bleeding and uterine size
Administer Rho(D) immune globulin if Rh-negative
Provide emotional support and grief counseling
Educate on importance of hCG follow-up
Monitor for signs of malignancy


Avoid pregnancy during monitoring period
Use reliable contraception (oral contraceptives preferred)
Report return of symptoms such as bleeding or pelvic pain
Follow all lab appointments for hCG testing
future pregnancy = possible after close follow-up 1 yr
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hemorrhage
item.description:
obstetric hemorrhage - highest mortality in pregnancy and childbirth
can occur early or late


Spontaneous abortion - unintentional loss of pregnancy before 20 weeks
Uterine fibroids - benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus
Ectopic pregnancy - implantation of fertilized egg outside the uterus
Gestational trophoblastic disease - abnormal growth of trophoblastic tissue during pregnancy
Cervical insufficiency - premature cervical dilation leading to pregnancy loss


Placenta previa - placenta covers all or part of the cervical opening
Placental abruption - premature separation of the placenta from the uterus
Placenta accreta - abnormal attachment of placenta into the uterine wall


Oxytocin - stimulates uterine contractions to reduce bleeding; monitor for uterine tone, assess for water intoxication and hypotension
Ergometrine - causes sustained uterine contractions to control hemorrhage; monitor blood pressure closely, contraindicated in hypertension
Prostaglandins - promote uterine contraction and vasoconstriction; assess for fever, nausea, vomiting, and monitor for bronchospasm in asthmatic patients


Balloon tamponade - inserts device into uterus to apply pressure and stop bleeding; monitor for proper placement, bleeding control, and signs of infection or uterine rupture
Compression sutures - stitches placed to compress uterus and control bleeding; monitor for return of uterine tone, bleeding, and potential complications from impaired uterine perfusion
Arterial ligation - surgical tying of uterine or pelvic arteries to reduce blood flow; monitor for hemodynamic stability, assess for signs of ischemic complications and ongoing bleeding
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hyperemesis Gravidarum
item.description:
Severe and persistent nausea and vomiting during pregnancy
Leads to dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, and weight loss
