More severe than typical morning sickness


Exact cause unknown
Possibly linked to high levels of hCG and estrogen
May have genetic, hormonal, or psychological factors


First pregnancy
Multiple gestation
History of motion sickness or migraines
H. Pylori infection
Molar pregnancy
Previous hyperemesis gravidarum


Persistent vomiting not relieved by typical measures
Weight loss >5% of pre-pregnancy weight
Dehydration (dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor)
Electrolyte imbalance (especially hypokalemia)
Ketonuria


Wernicke’s encephalopathy (thiamine deficiency)
Esophageal rupture
Fetal growth restriction
Preterm birth
Metabolic Alkalosis
ketosis
hypokalemia
retinal hemorrhage


Clinical symptoms
Electrolytes, BUN, creatinine for dehydration
Urinalysis for ketones
Ultrasound to rule out molar pregnancy or multiples
LFT - rule out Hepatitis, Pancreatitis, etc
CBC - assess hydration h/h
Urine ketones - positive when body breaks down fat in absence of adequate intake
TSH T4 - r/o thyroid disease
U/S - evaluate multiple gestation, molar pregnancy


IV fluids for rehydration
Electrolyte replacement
NPO => allow GI rest
Vitamin supplementation (especially thiamine)
Antiemetics (ondansetron, promethazine)
Nutritional support if oral intake not possible (NG or TPN)


Monitor weight, intake/output, and lab values
Encourage small, frequent meals if tolerated
Fluid volume deficit - hypotension
Assess for signs of dehydration and nutritional deficits
Provide emotional support


Report inability to keep food or fluids down
Importance of rest and hydration
Avoid triggers (strong smells, spicy foods)
Follow-up for weight and fetal growth monitoring
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy
item.description:
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (ICP) is a liver disorder during pregnancy characterized by impaired bile flow.
Presents in the third trimester, resolves postpartum.


Hormonal changes (estrogen, progesterone) leading to bile acid buildup.
Genetic predisposition.


Multiple gestations.
Personal or family history of ICP.
History of liver disease.


Pruritus (especially on palms and soles).
Elevated bile acids (>10 µmol/L).
Mild jaundice in some cases.
Dark urine, pale stools.


Fetal distress.
Preterm labor.
Stillbirth (monitor bile acids >40 µmol/L).
Maternal vitamin K deficiency (risk of PPH).


Serum bile acids: >10 µmol/L diagnostic.
LFTs: ↑ ALT, AST.
Rule out other causes: hepatitis panel, ultrasound.


Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA): First-line to reduce bile acids.
Early delivery (typically 37–38 weeks).
Antihistamines for pruritus (symptomatic relief).
Vitamin K supplementation to reduce bleeding risk.


Monitor fetal well-being (NST, BPP).
Educate on fetal kick counts and when to report decreased movement.
Counsel on symptom relief (cool baths, loose clothing).
Monitor for PPH due to vitamin K deficiency.
Administer UDCA as prescribed, monitor LFTs and bile acids.
Reinforce early delivery plan (coordinate with OB).
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy.html
item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/High Risk/Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Multiple Gestation
item.description:
pregnancy with more than one fetus (e.g., twins, triplets)
Can be monozygotic (identical) or dizygotic (fraternal)
Increases maternal and fetal risks compared to singleton pregnancies
Monozygotic (identical) - single, fertilized ovum splits during the first 2 weeks after conception
Dizygotic (fraternal) - two sperm fertilizing two ova


Assisted reproductive technology (e.g., IVF)
Fertility medications (e.g., clomiphene)
Family history of multiples (especially fraternal)
Advanced maternal age


Use of fertility treatments
Maternal age over 35
Multiparity
Race (higher incidence in African descent)


Rapid uterine growth
Elevated hCG levels
More pronounced pregnancy symptoms
Detection of multiple fetal heart tones
Confirmed via ultrasound


Pre-term Labor & birth
Polyhydramnios
Hyperemesis Gravidarum
Preeclampsia
Antepartum Hemorrhage
Prematurity
Respiratory Distress Syndrome
Asphyxia
Congenital Anomalies
Twin-to-twin transfusion Syndrome
IUGR
Conjoined Twins


Ultrasound for number of fetuses and chorionicity
Fundal height measurement
Elevated hCG and AFP levels
Routine monitoring for complications (e.g., growth scans, NSTs)
CBC - anemia may be expected


Increased prenatal surveillance
Early and frequent ultrasounds
Monitor for signs of preterm labor and complications
Possible hospitalization for high-risk cases
Scheduled delivery by 38 weeks if uncomplicated


Educate on signs of preterm labor and complications
Monitor maternal nutrition and weight gain
Ensure adequate rest and support
Coordinate care with high-risk OB team
Support emotional well-being


Importance of frequent prenatal visits
Nutritional needs and weight gain goals
Signs of preterm labor, preeclampsia, and fetal concerns
Discuss birth plans, delivery options (vaginal vs. cesarean)
Prepare for neonatal care, especially if premature birth occurs
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Oligohydramnios
item.description:
too little amniotic fluid (less than 500 mL) => normal is based on AFI
Defined as amniotic fluid index (AFI) <5 cm or deepest vertical pocket <2 cm
increased risk of perinatal morbidity and mortality
see also Polyhydramnios (too much water)


Fetal renal anomalies (e.g., bilateral renal agenesis, obstructive uropathy)
Premature rupture of membranes (PROM)
Placental insufficiency
Post-term pregnancy => pregnancy longer than 42 weeks, amniotic fluid naturally dries up
Maternal dehydration or hypertension
Maternal Diabetes
IUGR
Polycystic Kidney Disease
Urinary Tract Obstructions


Post-term pregnancy
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)
Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy
Use of NSAIDs
History of PROM or prior oligohydramnios


Fundal height smaller than expected for gestational age
Reduced fetal movement
Difficult palpation of fetal parts
May be asymptomatic and discovered on ultrasound


Fetal compression leading to musculoskeletal deformities
Pulmonary hypoplasia
Umbilical cord compression
Intrauterine growth restriction
Increased risk for cesarean delivery


Ultrasound (AFI <5 cm or single pocket <2 cm)
Non-stress test or biophysical profile for fetal well-being
Assess for rupture of membranes


Address underlying cause (e.g., rehydration, treat hypertension)
usually outpatient => no intervention needed if no fetal concerns; otherwise:
Amnioinfusion during labor to relieve cord compression => add amniotic fluid to the uterus to improve fetal heart rate and prevent cord compression
Maternal hydration (oral or IV)
Delivery if fetal compromise or term gestation


Monitor fetal heart tones closely
Observe for signs of labor or distress
Prepare for possible amnioinfusion or early delivery
Provide emotional support for maternal anxiety
Encourage hydration if appropriate


Report decreased fetal movement
Maintain hydration
Attend regular prenatal visits and follow-up ultrasounds
Understand possible need for early delivery or interventions
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Parvovirus B19
item.description:
Viral infection caused by parvovirus B19
Spread through respiratory droplets or transplacental transmission
Known as “Fifth disease” in children (slapped cheek rash)
Dangerous in pregnancy due to risk of fetal anemia and hydrops


Human parvovirus B19 infection
Transmission via respiratory secretions or vertical (mother-to-fetus) route


Pregnant women without prior immunity
Close contact with young children (e.g., teachers, daycare workers)
Infection during first or second trimester


Often asymptomatic in pregnant women
Flu-like symptoms including low-grade fever, fatigue, myalgia
Arthralgia or arthritis, especially in hands and knees
Fetal effects include hydrops fetalis, intrauterine growth restriction, or fetal demise


Fetal hydrops due to severe anemia
Intrauterine fetal death, especially if infected before 20 weeks
Rare maternal complications like aplastic anemia or thrombocytopenia


Maternal serology for IgM (recent) and IgG (immunity)
PCR testing of amniotic fluid if fetal infection suspected
Ultrasound to detect fetal hydrops or ascites
Doppler ultrasound of middle cerebral artery to assess fetal anemia


No specific antiviral treatment
Intrauterine transfusion if fetal anemia or hydrops is detected
Serial ultrasounds to monitor fetal condition
Supportive care for maternal symptoms


Screen for exposure history and occupational risks
Educate on infection control practices like hand hygiene
Coordinate follow-up with maternal-fetal medicine if infection confirmed
Monitor for fetal complications with ultrasound and Doppler
Provide emotional support due to risk of fetal loss


Inform about common exposure in children and potential pregnancy risks
Emphasize hygiene and avoidance of sick contacts
Explain the need for testing and monitoring if exposed
Reassure that most pregnancies with infection have favorable outcomes
No vaccine available, so prevention is key
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Polyhydramnios
item.description:
excessive amniotic fluid accumulation (more than 2000 mL) during 32-36 weeks
Typically defined as amniotic fluid index (AFI) >24 cm or deepest vertical pocket >8 cm
associated with poorer fetal outcomes:
more preterm births
fetal malpresentation
cord prolapse
increased cesarean births
low 5-min APGAR
congenital anomalies
NICU admission
see also Oligohydramnios


Maternal diabetes mellitus
Fetal anomalies (e.g., anencephaly, esophageal/duodenal atresia)
Multiple gestation
Fetal anemia or infections
Idiopathic in many cases


Pre-existing or gestational diabetes
Fetal structural or chromosomal abnormalities
Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome
Rh incompatibility


Rapid uterine growth => uterus is large as fuck (maternal abdominal girth and fundal height)
Difficulty breathing or discomfort due to uterine distension
Increased fundal height => discrepancy with gestational age
Fetal parts may be difficult to palpate
Increased fetal movement


Preterm labor or premature rupture of membranes
Placental abruption
Umbilical cord prolapse
Malpresentation
Postpartum hemorrhage


Ultrasound to measure AFI or deepest vertical pocket or estimate volume
Fetal anatomy scan
Glucose tolerance test for maternal diabetes
Amniocentesis for karyotyping or infection studies


Treat underlying cause (e.g., control maternal diabetes)
Indomethacin (reduces fetal urine output; used cautiously) => prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (may cause premature closing of ductus arteriosus)
Amniocentesis or artificial ROM for severe cases
Close fetal monitoring
Consider early delivery if complications develop


Monitor for signs of preterm labor and PROM
Educate on symptoms of complications (e.g., contractions, fluid leakage)
Assist with procedures like amnioreduction if ordered
Support maternal comfort and respiratory function
Monitor fetal status closely


Report increased abdominal pressure, contractions, or leaking fluid
Importance of follow-up ultrasounds
Blood sugar control if diabetic
Signs of labor or cord prolapse to watch for at home
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: PROM
item.description:
spontaneous rupture of the amniotic sac before the onset of labor
If it occurs before 37 weeks, it's referred to as preterm PROM (PPROM)
Can lead to complications for both mother and fetus if not managed appropriately
Prolonged PROM (>24 hrs) can lead to infection => chorioamnionitis, endometritis, sepsis, neonatal infections
NOTE: do not confuse with PPROM!

<37wks = preterm
37 weeks = early term
39-40 weeks = full term


largely unknown (per ricci) => mostly vaginal bleeding
spontaneous
Infection (e.g., chorioamnionitis, urinary tract infection)
Uterine overdistension (e.g., polyhydramnios, multiple gestation)
Cervical insufficiency or trauma
Previous preterm birth or PROM
Smoking or substance use


Prior PROM or preterm birth
Genital tract infection or UTIs
Short cervical length
Low socioeconomic status => no prenatal care
Invasive procedures (e.g., amniocentesis)
tobacco, drug use
History of Placenta Previa, Placenta Previa
Cerclage - stitched cervix
Amniocentesis


Sudden gush or steady leakage of clear fluid from the vagina
Absence of contractions initially
Fluid may test positive for amniotic markers (e.g., nitrazine, ferning)
Risk for infection increases over time


Chorioamnionitis
Preterm labor and birth
Cord prolapse
Placental abruption
Neonatal infection or sepsis


Sterile speculum exam to confirm fluid pooling => inspect only
Nitrazine paper test (alkaline pH) => blue=amniotic fluid
Fern Test - sample taken, Ferning pattern under microscope
Ultrasound for amniotic fluid volume
Avoid digital vaginal exams unless delivery is imminent
Meconium - fetal distress R/T hypoxia


Hospitalization and monitoring (especially with PPROM)
Antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infection
Corticosteroids to promote fetal lung maturity if <34 weeks
Tocolytics in select cases to delay labor briefly
Induction of labor if term and no contraindications
Amnioinfusion if indicated per policy


Monitor fetal heart rate and signs of infection
NO UNSTERILE DIGITAL EXAMS
Assess amount, color, and odor of amniotic fluid
Limit vaginal exams to reduce infection risk
Provide emotional support and education
Prepare for potential preterm delivery if PPROM


Report fever, foul-smelling discharge, or contractions
Monitor for decreased fetal movement
Importance of follow-up and hospitalization if ordered
Avoid sexual activity and insertion of anything into the vagina
Understand risks and signs of preterm labor
Activity restrictions
Record daily kick counts
Take temp daily
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Spontaneous Abortion
item.description:
most common complication of early pregnancy - usually before week 20 GA
loss of fetus from natural causes
aka "miscarriage"
clarification: "stillbirth" => occurs later in pregnancy


fetal genetic abnormalities => usually first semester
cervical insufficiency
uterine septum or fibroid
hypothyroidism
diabetes mellitus
chronic nephritis
substance abuse - alcohol, smoking, drugs
thrombophilia
lupus
polycystic ovary syndrome
severe hypertension
infections: rubella, cytomegalovirus, HSV, BV, toxoplasmosis


history of previous miscarriages
maternal age over 35
chronic conditions
exposures to environmental toxins


vaginal bleeding
low back pain
abdominal cramping
Possible absence of fetal heartbeat on ultrasound


Hemorrhage
Infection (especially if tissue remains)
Emotional distress or grief
Future pregnancy complications (depending on cause)


Ultrasound to assess fetal viability and contents of uterus
Serial hCG levels (typically fall in a non-viable pregnancy)
Pelvic exam to check for cervical dilation or passage of tissue
CBC and blood type/Rh factor


Expectant management (wait for natural passage)
Medication (e.g., misoprostol to expel tissue)
PGE₂ (Prostaglandin E2, e.g., dinoprostone) - soften and dilate the cervix or induce uterine contractions to evacuate the uterus after spontaneous abortion.
administered intravaginally, or cervix => sterile technique
After administration, the patient should be monitored for at least 30 minutes to 1 hour for:
Uterine response
Vital signs
Adverse effects such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fever, or uterine hyperstimulation
Dilation and curettage (D&C) if incomplete or excessive bleeding
Rh immunoglobulin (Rhogam) if Rh-negative mother


assess ASAP: note color, consistency, presence of clot or tissue
bright red - concerning
provide psychological support r/t loss and grief
administer RhoGAM if RH-neg within 72 hours after abortion
Ensure Rh status is known and treated accordingly


Avoid intercourse and heavy lifting until bleeding stops
Monitor for fever, foul-smelling discharge, or increased bleeding
Discuss grief and emotional health resources
Follow-up appointments for hCG monitoring or ultrasound
Wait a recommended time (often 1–3 menstrual cycles) before attempting to conceive again
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: x - template
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Ch.10 - Fetal Development
item.description:
Fetal Development

measured n number of weeks
pregnancy duration is 40 weeks from time of fertilization = 9 months or 266-280 days
Stages of Human Development:

Zygotic Stage - fertilization of sperm and egg through the second week.
Blastocyst Stage - Zygote divides into a solid ball of cells which attaches to the uterus.
outer layer of cells around the blastocyst is known as trophoblast (eventually becomes the placenta)
inner cells of the blastocyst form the fetus
Embryonic Stage - major organs and structures begin to emerge
begins at Day 15 to week 8
Amniotic sac = maintians body temp of fetus, cushion, promote fetal movement
oligohydramnios - <500 ml, low amniotic fluid volume => high risk of surgical birth, low BW infant
hydramnios - >2000ml, associated with maternal diabetes, neural tube defects, chromosomal deviations, etc
Fetal Stage - differentiation and structures specialize by end of the eighth week until birth
HCG - Human Chroionic Gonadotropin

a hormone that ensures that the endometrium will be receptive to the implanting embryo.
signals corpus lutem not to degenerate until placenta secretes adequate hormones
present 3 days after conception

Placenta - develops at end of 2nd week, complete by week 12

protects fetus from immune attack by mother
removes waste, regulates hormones
depends on maternal BP => impaired function if there is obstruction of blood
Serving as the interface between the mother and fetus
Making hormones to control the physiology of the mother to ensure fetus is supplied with nutrients and oxygen needed for growth
Inducing the mother to bring more food to the placenta
Producing hormones that mature into fetal organs
Causes of Decreased Placental Blood Flow:

Vasoconstriction or hypertension – maternal blood vessels constrict due to chronic hypertension, preeclampsia, smoking, or drug use (e.g., cocaine), reducing uteroplacental perfusion
Decreased maternal blood pressure or cardiac output – maternal hypotension, cardiac disease, hemorrhage, epidural-induced hypotension, or shock reduce overall blood volume and delivery of oxygen and nutrients to the placenta
Supine hypotension – gravid uterus compresses inferior vena cava when mother lies flat, decreasing venous return and cardiac output, leading to reduced placental perfusion
=> have mom lay on the side
Excessive maternal exercise – prolonged intense activity diverts blood flow to skeletal muscles and away from uterus and placenta, transiently decreasing oxygen and nutrient delivery to the fetus
Decreased blood flow to fetus:

intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) or small for gestational age infant (IGA)
weighs less than the 10th percentile for gestational age due to prolonged reduction in placental blood flow, leading to lower birth weight and potential long-term health effects
Placental Barrier - fetal tissues that prevent the fetus and mother's blood from mixing


Human Chorionic gonadotropin – preserves corpus luteum and progesterone, to maintain endometrium, basis of pregnancy tests
Prolactin – regulates insulin production and sensitivity, supports lactation
Human placental lactogen – modulates metabolism, develops maternal breasts, decreases insulin sensitivity to increase fetal nutrition
Estrogen – enlarges breasts, uterus, genitalia, stimulates myometrial contractility
Progesterone – maintains endometrium, decreases uterine contractility, stimulates metabolism and breast development, nourishes early conceptus
Relaxin – vasodilates, regulates hemodynamics, works with progesterone, maintains pregnancy, relaxes pelvic ligaments, softens cervix for birth


has unique shunts and vessels that close after birth
lung finish developing after birth; fetal lungs are nonfunctional
placenta functions as lungs => oxygenation and gas exchange
fetal liver - non functioning
Only brain and heart is maintained by fetus
liver & lungs = > maintained by placenta
3 Important Shunts

Ductus venosus — bypasses the liver and connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava.
short cut of the liver
goes from umbilical vein directly to IVC
Ductus arteriosus — bypasses the lungs and connects the main pulmonary artery to the descending aorta.
Foramen ovale — bypasses the right ventricle and lungs via an anatomic opening between the right and left atrium.
=> aka hole in the middle of the heart
Umbilicus - 2 arteries, 1 Vein
At birth:

foramen ovale closes with 1-2 hours, permanent closure by 6 months
ductus venosus (links IVC with umbilical vein) - closes with clamping of umbilicus
ductus arteriosus - closes within 72 hours after birth, permanent closure at 3-4 weeks (delayed closure results in innocent or functional murmur)
L/S Ratio - helps determine lung maturity (amino only), not used as much

Formed from the amnion
Lifeline from the mother to the growing embryo
Contains one large vein and two small arteries
Wharton jelly surrounds the vein and arteries to prevent compression
At term, the average umbilical cord is 22 in long and about 1 in wide

Functions:
Maintain steady thermal environment
Cushion against trauma
Source of oral fluid
Allows the infant freedom of movement
Variable decelerations may be present if there is not enough fluid
Formed from:

Diffusion of fluids from maternal blood
Fetal urine
Fetus swallows amniotic fluid
Fetus breathes amniotic fluid
Plays a role in lung maturation
Normal volume is 800-1200 ml by term
Oligohydrominos "oligo" - too little amnio, <500 ml
Polyhydraminos = too much >2000 ml (might have kidney issues, check with US then check after delivery)
no need to memorize critical periods of embryonic development
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Ch.11 - Maternal Adaptation
item.description:
Signs & Symptoms of Pregnancy:

Presumptive
Probable
Positive

least reliable indicators (amenorrhea => can be menopause, endocrine dysfunction, malnutrition, etc)
Subjective:

fatigue
breast tenderness
N/V
amenorrhea
urinary frequency
hyperpigmentation of skin
fetal movements =>"quickening"
uterine enlargement
breast enlargement

more reliable but are also not 100% in confirming
tumors, infections can also change uterine shape, size, consistency
ovarian cancer, choriocarcinoma can also elevate HCG levels

Hegar Sign - softening of the lower uterine segment or isthmus
Goodell Sign - softening of the cervix => good gooey gervix
Chadwick Sign - bluish-purple coloration of the vaginal mucosa and cervix
change in shape/size of uterus, abdominal enlargement
Braxton Hicks Contractions - aka practice contractions or false labor, are sporadic uterine contractions that may start around six weeks into a pregnancy
Ballottement - rebound from the floating fetus
Pregnancy Test - also a probable sign; usually thru HCG detection (5 mIU/mL or lower is negative, 25 mIU/mL or higher is positive)

Fetus is growing inside uterus
can be as early as 2 weeks after missed menses
**IMPORTANT:

Ultrasound verification of embryo or fetus
Fetal movement felt by experienced clinician
Auscultation of fetal heart tones via Doppler


Increase in size, weight, length, width, depth, volume, and overall capacity
Pear shape to ovoid shape; positive Hegar sign
Enhanced uterine contractility; Braxton Hicks contractions
Ascent into abdomen after first 3 months
Fundal height by 20 weeks’ gestation at level of umbilicus; 20 cm; reliable determination of gestational age until 36 weeks’ gestation
=> top of the pubic bone until fundus
Fundus = top of uterus; is at level of umbilicus by 20 weeks

reaches highest level (xyphoid process) at 36 weeks
presses against diaphragm = SOB
at 36-38 weeks, fetus descends, fundus drops, pressess against bladder = more urinary frequency
Lightening - fetal head begins to descend and engage in the pelvis

Softening (Goodell sign) => vasocongestion
More mucus => plug formation (purpose: to keep infection off the baby)
Increased vascularization (Chadwick sign) => cyanosis or bluish purple discoloration
Ripening about 4 weeks before birth

Increased vascularity, hypertrophy => preparing to give birth
mucosa thickening
Lengthening of vaginal vault
Secretions more acidic, white, and thick; leukorrhea
Candida albicans, a monilial vaginitis => common, benign, but uncomfortable => can be transmitted to neonate at birth (thrush)

Enlargement until 12th to 14th week of gestation
Cessation of ovulation => caused by elevated estrogen and progesterone (blocks secretion of FSH and LH)

Increase in size and nodularity to prepare for lactation; increase in nipple size, becoming more erect and pigmented
Production of colostrum: antibody-rich, yellow fluid that can be expressed after the 12th week; conversion to mature milk after delivery

LES => relaxed, GERD
Gums: hyperemic, swollen, and friable
Ptyalism => excessive salivation
Dental problems; gingivitis
Decreased peristalsis and smooth muscle relaxation
Constipation + increased venous pressure + pressure from uterus = hemorrhoids
Slowed gastric emptying; heartburn
Prolonged gallbladder emptying
Nausea and vomiting
progesterone preserves the uterus but causes several side effects

Increase in blood volume (50% above prepregnancy levels)
Anemia => large volume expansion with small increase in RBC, hemodilution
Increase in cardiac output; increased venous return; increased heart rate
BP - slight decrease until midpregnancy, then returning to prepregnancy levels
Increase in iron demands, fibrin and plasma fibrinogen levels, and some clotting factors, leading to hypercoagulable state


Breathing more diaphragmatic than abdominal due to increase in diaphragmatic excursion, chest circumference, and tidal volume
oxygen needs increase for fetus placenta and maternal organs
increased oxygen demand and structural changes raise risk of decompensation in women with respiratory conditions
estrogen-driven vascular congestion leads to nasal stuffiness, epistaxis, rhinitis, and voice changes
increased vascularity => frequent nosebleeds

Dilation of renal pelvis; elongation, widening, and increase in curve of ureters
Increase in length and weight of kidneys
Increase in glomerular filtration rate; increased urine flow and volume
Increase in kidney activity with woman lying down; greater increase in later pregnancy with woman lying on side => more frequent urination
lying on side puts less pressure on vena cava

Softening and stretching of ligaments holding sacroiliac joints and pubis symphysis => make childbirth easier
Postural changes: increased swayback and upper spine extension => lower back pain
Forward shifting of center of gravity
Increase in lumbosacral curve (lordosis); compensatory curve in cervicodorsal area
Waddle gait

Hyperpigmentation; mask of pregnancy (facial melasma)
Linea nigra
Striae gravidarum => stretch marks
Varicosities => result from distention, poor circulation
Vascular spiders => common in white women, d/t estrogen levels
Palmar erythema => palm
Decline in hair growth; increase in nail growth

Thyroid gland: slight enlargement; increased activity; increase in BMR
Pituitary gland: enlargement; decrease in TSH, GH; inhibition of FSH and LH; increase in prolactin, MSH; gradual increase in oxytocin with fetal maturation
Pancreas: insulin resistance due to hPL and other hormones in second half of pregnancy (see Box 11.2)
Adrenal glands: increase in cortisol and aldosterone secretion
Prostaglandin secretion
Placental secretion: hCG, hPL, relaxin, progesterone, estrogen (see Table 11.3)

Increased innate immunity
suppressed adaptive immunity (foreign antigen)


inadequate intake = low BW, preterm, congenital anomalies
excessive = fetal macrosomia, difficult birth, continued obesity, neonatal hypoglycemia
supplements => iron, folic acid => support new blood cells, prevent anemia (take iron with juice or gummies)
folic acid - prevent neural tube defects in early weeks
Increase in protein, iron, folate, and calories (see Table 11.5)
Use of USDA’s Food Guide MyPlate (see Figure 11.5)
Avoidance of some fish due to mercury content
Listeria => listeriorsis: avoid raw, unpasteurized food, can be passed down to newborn


Healthy weight BMI: 25 to 35 lb
First trimester: 3.5 to 5 lb
Second and third trimesters: 1 lb/wk
BMI <19.8: 28 to 40 lb 
First trimester: 5 lb
Second and third trimesters: +1 lb/wk
BMI >25: 15 to 25 lb 
First trimester: 2 lb
Second and third trimesters: 2/3 lb/wk
Special Considerations:

Lactose Intolerance => need for calcium supplements
Vegetarian => low gestational weight, iron-deficiency anemia, low protein, low mineral absorption => substitute and supplement accordingly
Pica - intense craving r eating nonfood items for at least a month
Couvade Syndrome - husband also partakes in cravings
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Ch.12 - Nursing Management in Pregnancy
item.description:
should occur any time a health care provider sees a woman of reproductive age
avoid live vaccines: MMR, Varicella, etc
also avoid: HPV
Risk Factors in Adverse Pregnancies:

Isotretinoins (accutane) - birth defects, cleft palate, congenital heart defects, hearing loss, microcephaly
alcohol - FAS
Antiepileptic drugs - valproic acid => lower dose
diabetes
Folic Acid Deficiency - must have at least 400-800 mcg of folic acid daily to reduce neural tube defects by 2/3
Hepatitis B
HIV-AIDS
Rubella - must vaccinate
Obesity - maternal obesity associated with neural tube deffects, pre-term delivery, diabetes, cesarean, HTN, thromboembolic disease
STI - chlamydia, neisseria gonorrhoeae - ectopic pregnancy, infertility
smoking - low BW, pre-term birth
Assess the following:
Immunization status
Underlying medical conditions
Reproductive health care practices
Sexuality and sexual practices
Nutrition
Lifestyle practices
Psychosocial issues
Medication and drug use
Support system


delayed prenatal care => associated with increased rates of NICU admissions
2 approach: individual and centering (group or cohort moms)
Gestational diabetes => maintain A1cc lower than 6.5, fasting BSL of 95mg/dL or lower


determine LMP to get EDD
History: medical & surgical; smoking, alcohol drugs
Reproductive History = GP or GTPAL system
Estimating Expected Date of birth or delivery: EDB/EDD => Naegel's Rule
birth wheel
ultrasound = more accurate to determine GA and date the pregnancy


empty bladder first => collect urine while at it (clean catch)
soft systolic murmur = may be normal
Estrogen => relaxation of ligaments of joints and ribs = larger chest diameter = increase in RR
Linea Nigra - runs thru umbilicus
Palpate fundus
DVT, edema, pulses, varicose veins
Cervix Expected findings
Gooddell sign - sofetened
Hegar Sign - uterine isthmus softened
Chadwick's sign = bluish discoloration of cevix and vaginal mucosa
Papanicolaou (Pap) Smear - screen for gonorrhea and chlamydia
More assessments:

assess fundal height
fetal heart rate
BP, weight
urinalysis: glucose, protein
Pelvic shape:
gynecoid
android
anthropoid
platypelloid
Pelvic measurements:
diagonal conjugate
true (obstetric) conjugate
ischial tuberosity
Rhogam - used to prevend development of antibodies to Rh-positice cells, such as during amniocentesis or spontaneous abortion
Fundal Height = weeks of pregnancy in terms of cm
McDonald Method - lying down, top of pubic bone to top of fundus => knees flexed
=> if growth curve flattens or stable - indicates FGR (fetal growth restriction)
Fetal Movements - lack of these can mean asphyxia and FGR
Education: count fetal movemnts, and it's significance
Contractions

Early contraction => lead to preterm birth
not to be confused with Braxton Hicks contractions => stop with rest or sleep and are usually felt in the abdomen, not the lower back
Signs of preterm labor: contractions every 10 minutes or more frequently, vaginal discharge changes, pelvic pressure, cramps, low backache, and diarrhea.
Early detection is crucial, as medications can sometimes stop labor if cervical dilation hasn't progressed.
If symptoms arise =>lie on her left side, drink 2–3 glasses of water, and monitor for 1 hour—if symptoms persist or worsen, she should contact her provider.

GP System
Gravida - pregnancy numbers
Para - Number of pregnancies delivered after 20 weeks
GTPAL System - more details

G: Gravida – Total number of pregnancies, including the current pregnancy if applicable.
T: Term births – Number of full-term births (deliveries at 37 weeks or later).
P: Preterm births – Number of preterm births (deliveries between 20 and 36 weeks).
A: Abortions – Number of pregnancies that ended in miscarriage or elective abortion before 20 weeks.
L: Living children – Number of living children the woman has.
Example of GTPAL Notation:

G3T1P1A1L2
G3: The woman has been pregnant 3 times (includes current pregnancy if applicable).
T1: She has had 1 full-term delivery (after 37 weeks).
P1: She has had 1 preterm delivery (between 20 and 36 weeks).
A1: She has had 1 miscarriage or elective abortion before 20 weeks.
L2: She has 2 living children

CBC
Albumin, Glucose, ketones, bacteria
Blood Typing
HEP B
STI
Protein in urine = pre-eclampsia
Glucose in Urine => Gestational Diabetes Mellitus
at 37 weeks: repeat all, in addition to GBS, gonorrhea, clap


Ultrasonography
Doppler flow studies - use of sound waves to examine the flow of blood in blood vessels
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) analysis = elevated => neural tube defects
Marker screening tests - aneuploidy (trisomies 13, 18, and 21) and neural tube defects
Nuchal translucency screening
usually done in 11-14 weeks
detects fetal chromosomal and structural abnormalities
Amniocentesis - transabdominal puncture of the amniotic sac to obtain a sample of amniotic fluid
empty bladder first to avoid risk of bladder puncture
fetal monitoring strip is obtained to evaluate fetal well being and baseline
Chorionic villus sampling (CVS). - 18g thru suction cathere thru cervix under US guidance; alternative to amniocentesis; rule out genetic disorders, fewer risks
Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS)
Nonstress test; contraction stress test => most common, provides measurement of uteroplacental function
must have empty bladder
reactive: at least 2 FHR accelerations from baseline
Non reactive: if it's not the above for at least 15 sec within 20 min timeframe
Contraction stress test
Biophysical profile - real-time ultrasound and NST to allow assessment of various parameters of fetal well-being that are sensitive to hypoxia

see p.405
N/V

Eat 6 small meals/day
avoid empty stomach at all times!
Avoid highly seasoned or greasy foods
Drink at least 8 (8oz) glasses of water/day
Ask for medication
Urinary Frequency - d/t compression of bladder
Fatigue
Breast Tenderness
Exessive salivation & increased discharge - d/t increased estrogen => bathe daily, no douching
Heartburn: ↑ progesterone, ↑ pressure => Use antacids, small meals, sit upright for 30 min after eating

Backache
Varicosities of the vulva and legs
Hemorrhoids
Flatulence with bloating

Return of first trimester discomforts
Shortness of breath and dyspnea
Heartburn and indigestion
Dependent edema
Braxton Hicks contractions
2nd & 3rd Trim Discomforts

Ankle Edema - ↑ sodium & cap permeability, circulatory congestion, prolonged standing/sitting, Frequent dorsiflexion
Get up and move for at least 5 min Q hr, Supportive hose (used for varicosities too)
Hemorrhoids - constipation, pressure, sitz bath, witch hazel pads, ointments
Constipation/Flatulence: ↑ progesterone, ↓ fluids, ↓ exercise => tx: ↑ fluids, ↑ fresh fruit/veggies (non-gassy), stool softeners
Backache: ↑ lumbar curve, ↑ hormones
Proper body mechanics and pelvis-tilt exercise
Leg cramps: ↑ nerve pressure, electrolyte imbalances, ↓ circulation
Dorsiflexion, dietary changes, heating pad
Syncope: Anemia, postural hypotension
Keep body temp normal, stand up slowly, check H&H
Dyspnea: ↓ vital capacity, anemia
Sleep propped on pillows

First trimester

spotting or bleeding possible miscarriage
Painful urination may indicate infection
Severe persistent vomiting may indicate hyperemesis gravidarum
Fever over 100°F 37.7°C may indicate infection
Lower abdominal pain with dizziness and shoulder pain may indicate ruptured ectopic pregnancy
Second trimester

regular uterine contractions may indicate preterm labor
Calf pain worse with foot flexion may indicate DVT
Sudden gush or fluid leakage may indicate prelabor rupture of membranes
No fetal movement over 12 hours may indicate fetal distress or demise
Third trimester

sudden weight gain or facial swelling may indicate gestational hypertension or preeclampsia
Severe upper abdominal pain headache or visual changes may indicate preeclampsia
Decreased fetal movement over 24 hours may indicate possible fetal demise

see slides



Perinatal education
Childbirth education
Lamaze (psychoprophylactic) method: focus on breathing and relaxation techniques
Bradley (partner-coached childbirth) method: focus on exercises and slow, controlled abdominal breathing
Dick-Read (natural childbirth) method: focus on fear reduction via knowledge and abdominal breathing techniques
Options for birth setting
Hospitals: delivery room, birthing suite
Birth centers
Home birth
Options for care providers
Obstetrician
Midwife
Doula
Feeding choices
Breast-feeding: advantages and disadvantages
Bottle feeding: advantages and disadvantages
Teaching
Final preparation for labor and birth

item.guid: OB/ii. Pregnancy/Ch.12 - Nursing Management in Pregnancy.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Fetal Circulation
item.description:
Key Purpose: Designed to bypass the non-functional fetal lungs and liver, prioritizing oxygenated blood to the brain and heart.
Oxygenation Source: Placenta (maternal blood).
Major Shunts:
Ductus Venosus: Bypasses the liver, shunting oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein directly to the inferior vena cava.
Foramen Ovale: An opening between the right and left atria, shunting oxygenated blood from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs.
Ductus Arteriosus: Connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta, shunting blood from the pulmonary artery away from the lungs into the systemic circulation.
Vessels:
Umbilical Vein (1): Carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.
Umbilical Arteries (2): Carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus back to the placenta.
Blood Flow Path: Oxygenated blood from placenta Umbilical vein Ductus venosus Inferior vena cava Right atrium Foramen ovale Left atrium Left ventricle Aorta (to head/upper body) / Some from right atrium Right ventricle Pulmonary artery Ductus arteriosus Aorta (to lower body) / Small amount to lungs Hypogastric (internal iliac) arteries Umbilical arteries Placenta.


Underlying Issues: Conditions that compromise uteroplacental function or fetal cardiovascular development.
Examples of Risk Factors/Conditions:
Placental Insufficiency: Reduced blood flow or damage to the placenta (e.g., preeclampsia, chronic abruption, maternal hypertension/diabetes) leading to inadequate oxygen/nutrient exchange.
Intrauterine Growth Restriction (IUGR): Often a consequence of compromised placental function, leading to adaptive fetal circulatory changes (e.g., brain-sparing effect where blood is preferentially shunted to the brain).
Congenital Heart Defects (CHDs): Structural abnormalities of the heart or great vessels that alter normal fetal shunting patterns and blood flow, potentially leading to cardiac strain or inadequate oxygenation (e.g., hypoplastic left heart syndrome, transposition of the great arteries).
Fetal Anemia: Reduces oxygen-carrying capacity, forcing the fetal heart to work harder.
Fetal Infection: Some infections (e.g., TORCH) can directly damage the fetal heart or vasculature, impacting circulation.
Persistent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) / Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO) after birth: Failure of these fetal shunts to close post-natally leads to abnormal shunting, increased pulmonary blood flow (PDA), or deoxygenated blood entering systemic circulation (PFO with right-to-left shunt).
Pulmonary Hypertension (PPHN): Failure of pulmonary vascular resistance to decrease at birth, leading to persistent shunting away from the lungs (via PFO and PDA), resulting in hypoxemia.
Manifestations of Compromise:
Abnormal Doppler flow studies (e.g., absent/reversed end-diastolic flow in umbilical artery).
Fetal bradycardia or tachycardia (indicating distress).
Hydrops fetalis (fluid accumulation in fetal compartments).
Altered fetal growth.
Abnormal shunting patterns observed on fetal echocardiogram.
Clinical Significance: These high-risk variations require close monitoring and often intervention to optimize fetal well-being or prepare for postnatal management.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Patient Education
item.description:
Live Vaccines (Rubella) - do not cross breast milk, can continue breastfeeding
cannot get pregnant for at least 1 month
do not administer during pregnancy

Every 4 weeks up to 28 weeks (7 months)
Every 2 weeks from 29 to 36 weeks
Every week from 37 weeks to birth
Note: Frequency may increase with high-risk pregnancies or complications.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Placental Hormones
item.description:
Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG): Maintains the corpus luteum to ensure continued progesterone production in early pregnancy.
Progesterone: Maintains the uterine lining, relaxes uterine muscles, and prevents preterm contractions.
Estrogen (primarily Estriol): Stimulates uterine growth, promotes uteroplacental blood flow, and prepares the breasts for lactation.
Human Placental Lactogen (hPL) / Human Chorionic Somatomammotropin (hCS): Modifies maternal metabolism to provide nutrients for the fetus and prepares mammary glands for lactation.
Relaxin: Relaxes pelvic ligaments and softens the cervix, aiding in childbirth.
Placental Growth Hormone: Regulates maternal metabolism and fetal growth, becoming predominant later in pregnancy.
Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH): Influences the timing of labor and fetal lung maturation.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Amniotic Fluid Analysis
item.description:
Amniotic fluid analysis involves assessing fluid obtained from ruptured membranes (spontaneous or artificial) during labor
Helps evaluate fetal well-being, infection, and labor progression


Confirm membrane rupture
Assess fetal lung maturity (if indicated, but usually done antenatally)
Evaluate infection risk (chorioamnionitis)
Identify meconium presence (fetal distress)


Color
Clear/slightly cloudy: normal
Greenish/brown: meconium-stained → possible fetal distress or post-term
Yellow: hemolytic disease (Rh incompatibility)
Red: possible abruption or bleeding
Odor
Foul smell = chorioamnionitis (infection)
Volume
Oligohydramnios: <500 mL at term → risk of cord compression, growth restriction
Polyhydramnios: >2000 mL at term → risk of prolapsed cord, preterm labor
pH/Nitrazine test
pH > 6.5 = amniotic fluid (alkaline)
Vaginal secretions = acidic (pH 4.5–5.5)
Ferning test
Microscopic exam shows fern pattern → confirms rupture of membranes
Leukocytes
Elevated WBC (>30/mm³) → infection


Nitrazine paper turns blue if fluid is alkaline (ruptured membranes)
Fern test: Dry fluid on slide → microscopic fern-like crystals
Meconium-stained fluid = fetal stress; may need neonatal resuscitation
Cloudy, foul-smelling fluid = possible infection → start antibiotics


Explain procedure and obtain informed consent if needed
Use sterile gloves when collecting samples to prevent infection
Document color, odor, amount, and time of rupture
Monitor for infection: maternal fever, fetal tachycardia, uterine tenderness
Notify provider immediately if meconium is present → risk of meconium aspiration syndrome
Prepare for neonatal resuscitation if meconium-stained fluid
Teach patient to report changes in color, odor, or amount of fluid
Reinforce hand hygiene and peri-care after fluid leaks


Prolonged rupture (>18 hours) → increased risk of infection → monitor for chorioamnionitis
Yellow fluid → think Rh hemolytic disease
Always confirm ferning test before assuming membranes have ruptured
Blue Nitrazine paper alone can yield false positives (e.g., blood, semen) → confirm with ferning test
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Continuous Fetal Monitoring
item.description:
Chapter 13 - Ricci Text book

provides information on fetal oxygenation during labor
goal: detect FHR changes early before they are prolonged
can be internal or external


two ultrasound transducers, each of which is attached to a belt, are applied around the woman’s abdomen
Tocotransducer - placed over the uterine fundus in the area of greatest contractility to monitor uterine contractions
Other transducer - baseline FHR, long-term variability, accelerations, and decelerations
placed midline between the umbilicus and the symphysis pubis
Pros
Noninvasive
Can be used before ROM (membranes intact)
Quick to apply
No risk of uterine perforation or infection
Detects FHR baseline, variability, accelerations, and decelerations
good continuous data
Cons
limits maternal movement, encourage supine positioning => reduces placental perfusion
Less accurate FHR detection in obese women
May pick up maternal heart rate artifact
Cannot measure uterine contraction intensity—only frequency and duration
May need frequent repositioning due to fetal/maternal movement
Less reliable in multiples (twins, etc.)


for higher risk labor: multiple gestation, decreased fetal movement, abnormal FHR, Preeclampsia, etc
spiral electrode into the fetal presenting part, usually the parietal bone on the head
pressure transducer placed internally within the uterus to record uterine contractions
Pros
More accurate FHR detection; less artifact
Measures true uterine contraction intensity with IUPC
Not affected by maternal position or movement
Directly records beat-to-beat variability
Cons
Requires ROM (artificial or spontaneous)
Requires cervical dilation ≥2 cm
Invasive—risk of infection and uterine perforation
Contraindicated in cases of placenta previa, herpes, HIV, hepatitis
Potential fetal injury from electrode placement
CRITERIA FOR INTERNAL MONITORING:

Ruptured membranes
Cervical dilation ≥2 cm
Presenting part engaged (not floating)
No maternal infections (e.g., HIV, herpes)
Skilled provider available
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: FHR Patterns
item.description:
normal: 110-160 BPM
see Fetal Heart Monitoring Cheat Sheet
Bradycardia

below 110
Causes: hypoxia, prolonged maternal hypoglycemia, fetal acidosis, administration of analgesic drugs to the mother, hypothermia, anesthetic agents (epidural), maternal hypotension, fetal hypothermia, prolonged umbilical cord compression, and fetal congenital heart block
Tachycardia:

greater than 160
Causes: hypoxia, maternal fever, maternal dehydration, amnionitis, drugs (e.g., cocaine, amphetamines, nicotine), maternal hyperthyroidism, maternal anxiety, fetal anemia, prematurity, fetal infection, chronic hypoxemia, congenital anomalies, fetal heart failure, and fetal arrhythmias
Can be an ominous sign if it is accompanied by a decrease in variability and late decelerations


clinical indicator that is predictive of fetal acid–base balance and cerebral tissue perfusion
Key indicator of fetal well-being
1. Absent

No detectable fluctuations
May indicate fetal hypoxia, acidosis, or neurologic depression
Concerning—requires immediate evaluation
prepare for emergency delivery
2. Minimal

Amplitude range: ≤5 bpm
Causes: sleep cycle, sedation (e.g., opioids, magnesium sulfate), prematurity, or hypoxia
Evaluate context and other FHR patterns
3. Moderate (Normal)

Amplitude range: 6–25 bpm
Indicates well-oxygenated fetus with intact CNS
Most reassuring variability
4. Marked

Amplitude: >25 bpm
Causes: acute hypoxia, fetal stimulation, or cord compression
May be transient but warrants monitoring
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Intermittent FHR with Doppler
item.description:
Periodic assessment of fetal heart rate (FHR) using handheld Doppler or fetoscope
Uses ultrasound waves to detect fetal heart echoes
Acceptable for low-risk laboring women
Promotes mobility and physiologic birth


Allows maternal mobility during labor
Less restrictive than continuous EFM
Encourages natural labor progression


Cannot detect variability or types of decelerations
Does not provide a continuous record of fetal status
May miss transient or late decelerations


Use Leopold maneuvers to locate fetal back
Apply water-soluble gel to abdomen
Place Doppler in lower abdominal quadrant (cephalic) or umbilicus level (breech)
Palpate maternal radial pulse to differentiate from maternal HR
Baseline FHR: auscultate for 1 minute after contraction
Routine checks: 30 seconds x 2 (if no changes)


Initial: 10-20 min continuous FHR upon admission
Low-risk active labor: q30min
High-risk active labor: q15min
Second stage low-risk: q15min
Second stage high-risk: q5min
Assess FHR before and after vaginal exams, ROM, meds, ambulation


Monitor FHR after position changes, pain meds, or other interventions
FHR may shift location as fetus descends
Not recommended for undiagnosed high-risk labor
Safe for low-risk women with no evidence of fetal compromise
Does not replace continuous monitoring for high-risk cases


Late decels: best detected by listening at end of contraction
Chorioamnionitis: monitor for maternal fever & fetal tachycardia
Document: FHR baseline, rhythm, rate, and maternal VS
For low-risk patients, no difference in Apgar or outcomes vs. continuous EFM
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/OB/iii. Labor/Assessments - Fetal/Intermittent FHR with Doppler.html
item.guid: OB/iii. Labor/Assessments - Fetal/Intermittent FHR with Doppler.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Bishop Score
item.description:
Max score: 13, Min score: 0



Pharmacologic: Misoprostol (Cytotec), Dinoprostone (Cervidil, Prepidil)
Mechanical: Foley balloon catheter, Laminaria
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Leopold Maneuvers
item.description:
Systematic abdominal palpation technique to determine fetal lie, presentation, position, and engagement
Essential tool in prenatal assessment starting around 28 weeks gestation
Helps guide delivery planning and monitor fetal well-being


First Maneuver (Fundal Grip)
Palpate top of uterus (fundus) to identify fetal part (head = hard/round/moveable; buttocks = soft/irregular)
Second Maneuver (Lateral Grip)
Palpate sides of uterus to locate fetal back (smooth/firm) vs. small parts (limbs, irregular)
Third Maneuver (Pawlik’s Grip)
Grasp just above symphysis pubis to determine presenting part (head or breech) and mobility
Fourth Maneuver (Pelvic Grip)
Facing mother’s feet, slide hands down sides of uterus to assess fetal descent into pelvis and attitude of head (flexed = easier delivery; extended = possible complications)


Lie: Relationship of fetus’s spine to mother’s spine (longitudinal/transverse/oblique)
Presentation: Part of fetus that enters pelvis first (cephalic/breech/shoulder)
Position: Relationship of presenting part to maternal pelvis (e.g., LOA)
Attitude: Fetal flexion/extension


Head = hard, round, moves independently
Buttocks = soft, irregular, moves with trunk
Back = smooth, firm
Limbs = small, irregular, kicking


Explain procedure to patient; ensure privacy and comfort
Ask patient to empty bladder to improve accuracy
Position patient supine with knees flexed and slight head elevation*
Use warm hands to avoid discomfort
Perform fetal heart rate monitoring before and after maneuvers to ensure fetal well-being
Document findings: lie, presentation, position, engagement
Remember accuracy decreases with obesity, polyhydramnios, anterior placenta, or multiple gestation


Recognize LOA (left occiput anterior) as most common, optimal position for delivery
Engagement means the presenting part has passed the pelvic inlet (station 0)
Flexed head = easier vaginal delivery; deflexed head may cause complications
Never perform Leopold maneuvers during contractions (wait until relaxation phase)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Perineal Trauma
item.description:
Firm fundus with bright red blood trickling: laceration
Boggy fundus with red blood flowing: uterine atony (need pit)
Boggy fundus with dark blood and clots: retained placenta
Inspecting the perineum for condition of episiotomy if performed
Assessing for perineal lacerations and ensuring repair by birth attendant
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Placental Separation
item.description:
Occurs during Third Stage of Labor
Signs of Placental Separation:

Firmly contracting uterus
Change in uterine shape from discoid to globular ovoid
Sudden gush of dark blood from vaginal opening
Lengthening of umbilical cord protruding from vagina
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Uterine Contractions
item.description:
Frequency – Time from the start of one contraction to the start of the next; measured in minutes
Duration – Length of a single contraction from start to end; measured in seconds
Intensity – Strength of contraction (mild, moderate, strong); assessed by palpation or internal monitor (IUPC)
=> Mild - tip of the nose
=> Moderate - like chin
=> Strong - like forehead
IUPC - 30 mmHg or greater => cervical dilation
Resting tone – Pressure in the uterus between contractions; should remain soft; assessed by palpation or IUPC
Pattern – Evaluate for regularity, adequate recovery time, and tachysystole (more than 5 contractions in 10 minutes)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Vaginal Exam
item.description:
Chapter 13 - Ricci Text book Nursing Management During Labor and Birth => Maternal Assessment During Labor & Birth

vaginal exam or U/S if not bleeding upon admission
Assess:
Dilation
Effacement
Fetal Membrane Status
Presentation
Position
Station
Degree of fetal head flexion
presence of skull swelling or molding
Position - on her back
Sterile technique
Insert index and middle fingers


Measures how open the cervix is (0–10 cm)
10 cm = fully dilated and ready for pushing
0 cm: external cervical os is closed
5 cm: external cervical os is halfway dilated
10 cm: external os is fully dilated and ready for birth passage


Thinning and shortening of the cervix
Expressed as a percentage
0%: cervical canal is 2 cm long
50%: cervical canal is 1 cm long
100%: cervical canal is obliterated


Refers to fetal head position relative to ischial spines
Measured from -5 (high) to +4 (crowning)
0 station = at ischial spines


Describes fetal presenting part’s orientation in the pelvis
Includes occiput anterior (OA), posterior (OP), or transverse (OT)
OA is most favorable for vaginal birth


Indicates whether amniotic sac is intact or ruptured
Document as "intact" or "ruptured"
Note color, odor, and time of rupture if applicable
Nitrazine Yellow Swab:
=> Yellow = acidic; vaginal fluid
=> Blue = basic; amniotic fluid
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Amniotic Fluid Embolism
item.description:
Rare, life-threatening obstetric emergency
Amniotic fluid enters maternal circulation, triggering systemic inflammatory and anaphylactoid reaction


Amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enter maternal bloodstream, usually during labor, delivery, or shortly postpartum


Advanced maternal age
Multiple gestation
Placenta Previa, Placental Abruption
Eclampsia
C-Section or instrumental delivery => Forceps or Vacuum Assisted Birth
Uterine Rupture
Induction of labor


Sudden shortness of breath => signature first sign
Hypotension
Cyanosis
Pulmonary Edema
Tachycardia
Seizures
Altered mental status
Cardiac arrest
Coagulopathy or DIC => bleeding
Uterine atony and massive hemorrhage


Cardiopulmonary collapse
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
Multi-organ failure
Neurologic injury
Maternal death
Fetal distress or death


Clinical diagnosis based on sudden onset of symptoms
Rule out other causes (e.g., pulmonary embolism, anaphylaxis)
Lab: Coagulation studies (may show DIC), ABGs (hypoxemia), CBC
Imaging: Chest X-ray or echocardiogram to rule out other conditions


Immediate supportive care
Oxygen, mechanical ventilation
Hemodynamic support with IV fluids and vasopressors
Blood products for coagulopathy
Emergency delivery if not yet delivered
ICU monitoring


Rapid recognition and activation of emergency response
Maintain airway and breathing
Administer oxygen and assist with intubation if needed
Monitor vital signs and fetal heart tones
Initiate IV access and fluid resuscitation
Prepare for emergency C-section
Administer blood products and medications per orders
Emotional support to family


Very rare and unpredictable condition
Emphasis on close monitoring in high-risk pregnancies
Provide information post-event to help with psychological recovery
Encourage follow-up care and mental health support
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: C-Section
item.description:
Cesarean birth (C-section) is a surgical procedure to deliver a baby through incisions in the abdomen and uterus.
May be planned or performed emergently based on maternal or fetal conditions.


Previous cesarean or uterine surgery
Fetal distress
Placenta previa or Placental Abruption
Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD)
Malpresentation (e.g., breech)
Multiple gestation
Failed labor progression
Maternal health conditions (e.g., active herpes, severe Preeclampsia)

Maternal:

Hemorrhage
Infection
Injury to bladder, bowel, or uterus
Anesthesia complications
Thromboembolism
Fetal:

Respiratory distress (especially if early)
Lacerations or minor trauma
Delayed bonding or breastfeeding


Skin Incision: Horizontal (Pfannenstiel) or vertical
Uterine Incision: Low transverse (preferred), low vertical, or classical


Pre-op: NPO status, IV access, labs (CBC, type & screen), fetal monitoring, informed consent
Intra-op: Assist with positioning, monitor vital signs, support patient and partner
Post-op: Monitor lochia (vaginal discharge), incision site, pain, respiratory function, bowel sounds, and urinary output, VS q15min first hr, then q30min
Encourage early ambulation and deep breathing exercises
Promote bonding and breastfeeding as soon as possible


Explain reasons for C-section and what to expect during and after surgery
Review signs of infection and complications to report (fever, heavy bleeding, wound issues)
Encourage use of incentive spirometer and mobility
Provide emotional support, especially if unplanned
Teach proper incision care and pain management strategies
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Dystocia
item.description:
Abnormal or difficult labor resulting from problems with components of labor: 4 P's
powers - expulsive forces
passageway
passenger or fetal development
psyche or maternal stress
It is a leading cause of cesarean delivery
Umbrella Term for "failure to progress" with labor due to:

lac of progressive cervical dilation
lack of descent of fetal head
or both

POWERS

Ineffective uterine contractions (hypotonic or hypertonic)
Hypertonic Uterine Dysfunction - erratic contractions; irregular, uncoordinated, ineffective => uterus never fully relaxes between contractions
treatment: sedate, analgesia, hydrate, reposition
Hypotonic Uterine Dysfunction - Contractions become poor in quality and lack sufficient intensity to dilate and efface the cervix; high risk for hemorrhage
treatment: augment via Pitocin, amniptomy to enchance labor, hydrate
Protracted disorders - very slow dilation and descent
Arrest Disorders - no progress or failure of descent
Precipitate Labor - completed in 3 hours or less; "cannonball baby"
=> too fast of delivery => cervical lacerations, uterine rupture
PASSENGER

Positioning => any position other than occiput anterior (head down and anterior facing) = higher risk
Persistent Occiput Posterior - most common
Shoulder Distocia - head delivered but shoulder is blocking; EMERGENCY
=> can lead to brachial plexus palsy - no nerve control, shoulder is drooping
=> high risk for uterine lacerations, bleeding
=> "turtling" - head of the baby emerging from the birth canal, then retracting back
Multiple Gestation - twins or more (plan for vaginal birth if twins are VERTEX)
Macrosomia - 4kg or more baby
PASSAGEWAY

Pelvis Shape = "Good Anatomy Allows Passage"
Gynecoid - good; best shape, round
Anthropoid - oval, "ape-like", okay for delivery
Android - "andro" => male pevis, difficult!
Platypelloid - platypus=flatl POOR FIT!
obstructions of maternal birth canal - swelling of cervix
FetoPelvic Disproportion (FPD) - Fetal head is too large or pelvis is too small
PSYCHE

mom emotions => psychological stress
hormones from intense anxiety
anxiety => increased fer, tension, pain tolerance


First-time pregnancy (nulliparity)
Advanced maternal age
Obesity
Epidural anesthesia
Prolonged labor
Hydramnios
Short maternal status (less than 5 ft tall)
More than 8.8 lbs fetus
GA >41 wks
Abnormal fetal presentation (e.g., occiput posterior, breech)
Chorioamnionitis
high caffeine intake
Ineffective uterine contractions
High fetal station at complete cervical dilation
note: acrocyanosis is normal


Slowed or stalled cervical dilation
Lack of fetal descent despite adequate contractions
Abnormal contraction patterns
Maternal fatigue
Fetal distress may develop


Prolonged labor
Fetal hypoxia or distress
Uterine rupture (especially with prior C-section)
Maternal infection or hemorrhage
Increased likelihood of operative delivery
Erb's Palsy


Monitor Progress of Labor - 1cm per hour dilation is standard
Physical exam to assess dilation, effacement, and fetal station
Ultrasound for fetal position and estimated weight
Intrauterine pressure catheter (IUPC) to measure contraction strength
Pelvimetry in suspected CPD


Amniotomy to augment labor => breaking water
Oxytocin (Pitocin) for hypotonic contractions
Upright positioning - promote fetal rotation and descent; change frequently
Operative delivery (vacuum, forceps) if indicated
Cesarean delivery if labor fails to progress or complications arise
suprapubic bone for shoulder dystocia


Monitor labor progression closely
Assess fetal heart rate and uterine contraction pattern
Encourage position changes and ambulation if appropriate
Administer pain management and oxytocin as ordered
backrubs to promote fetal rotation


Explain interventions and rationale (e.g., amniotomy, oxytocin)
Discuss signs of labor progress and when to alert staff
Provide reassurance and emotional support
Prepare patient for possible surgical delivery if needed
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Forceps or Vacuum Assisted Birth
item.description:
Forceps- or vacuum-assisted birth (operative vaginal delivery) helps deliver the baby when spontaneous delivery is not progressing adequately during the second stage of labor.
It uses instruments—either forceps or a vacuum extractor—to guide the fetal head out through the birth canal.


Prolonged second stage of labor
Non-reassuring fetal heart rate needing urgent delivery
Maternal exhaustion
Maternal medical conditions that limit pushing (e.g., cardiac issues)
Malposition of the fetal head (e.g., occiput posterior)


Incomplete cervical dilation
Unengaged fetal head
Suspected fetal bleeding disorders (e.g., hemophilia)
Gestational age <34 weeks (vacuum)
Face or breech presentation
Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD)

Maternal:

Vaginal or perineal lacerations
Postpartum hemorrhage
Pelvic floor injury
Fetal:

Scalp lacerations or cephalohematoma (vacuum)
Caput Succedaneum - common with vacuum; swelling of scalp across suture lines
Succ = vacuum; literally translates to HEAD SUCKS
Facial nerve injury or skull fracture (forceps)
Intracranial hemorrhage (rare)


Ensure informed consent is obtained
Monitor fetal heart rate continuously
Assist with positioning and support during procedure
Anticipate possible need for neonatal resuscitation
Assess newborn for trauma or complications post-delivery
Monitor for maternal bleeding and perineal injury
Provide emotional support and explain procedure to patient


Explain purpose and process of assisted delivery before or during labor
Reassure safety and commonality of procedure when indicated
Inform about potential postpartum discomfort and recovery
Discuss reasons for intervention during debriefing after birth
Encourage questions and provide emotional support
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/OB/iii. Labor/Complications/Forceps or Vacuum Assisted Birth.html
item.guid: OB/iii. Labor/Complications/Forceps or Vacuum Assisted Birth.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Intrauterine Fetal Demise
item.description:
Intrauterine Fetal Demise (IUFD) refers to the death of a fetus in utero after 20 weeks of gestation but before the onset of labor.
Also known as stillbirth, it requires prompt emotional, medical, and obstetric care.


Placental insufficiency
Chromosomal abnormalities
Infections (e.g., TORCH, syphilis)
Cord accidents (knots, prolapse)
Preeclampsia, eclampsia
Maternal chronic conditions (e.g., diabetes, lupus)
Trauma or substance use


Advanced maternal age
Smoking, drug or alcohol use
Previous history of IUFD
Poorly controlled chronic disease
Multiple gestation
Obesity
Fetal growth restriction


Absence of fetal movement reported by the mother
No fetal heart tones detected by Doppler or ultrasound
Loss of uterine growth
Possible signs of labor or infection if fetal death is prolonged


Coagulopathy (especially DIC if fetus retained >4 weeks)
Infection
Hemorrhage
Psychological trauma, grief, depression, PTSD
Impaired future fertility if complications arise


Ultrasound confirms absence of fetal cardiac activity
Doppler unable to detect fetal heart tones
Blood tests for maternal clotting profile and infection screen
Autopsy or placental exam may determine cause


Induction of labor is recommended to deliver the fetus
Cesarean not routinely indicated unless obstetrically necessary
Misoprostol or oxytocin used for induction
Emotional support and bereavement counseling provided
Discussion of options for memory-making (e.g., photos, keepsakes)


Support patient and family emotionally
Use compassionate, non-judgmental communication
Prepare the family for delivery and appearance of fetus
Provide privacy and facilitate time with the baby if desired
Monitor for signs of hemorrhage, infection, and coagulopathy
Coordinate spiritual or cultural needs


Discuss potential causes and options for future pregnancy planning
Offer resources for grief support and counseling
Review signs of complications post-delivery (bleeding, fever)
Explain follow-up appointments and emotional health screening
Discuss autopsy and genetic testing if appropriate and consented
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Post-Term Labor
item.description:
Post-term labor refers to a pregnancy that extends beyond 42 weeks of gestation.
It increases the risk of complications for both the mother and fetus due to aging placenta and decreased amniotic fluid.


Unknown in many cases
Miscalculated due date


History of post-term pregnancy
Obesity
Genetic predisposition
Nulliparity
male fetus


Decreased fetal movement
Dry, peeling skin of the fetus (if already delivered)
Overgrown nails and hair
Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
Oligohydramnios => amniotic fluid drying up


Fetal macrosomia => big baby
Meconium aspiration syndrome => fetus is hypoxic and stressed from Oligohydramnios
Placental insufficiency
Birth trauma or stillbirth
Increased risk of cesarean delivery


Accurate dating with early ultrasound
Non-stress test (NST)
Biophysical profile (BPP)
Amniotic fluid index (AFI)


Induction of labor typically recommended at or after 41 weeks
Cervical ripening => softening of cervix => (prostaglandins or Foley balloon)
=> mechanical: foley balloon, hygroscopic dilators, laminaria (use of seaweeds to use as giant tampons = swell and open cervix)
=> surgical: stripping of membranes + amniotomy
=> pharmacologic: prostaglandins => misoprostol, dinoprostone gel
Oxytocin to stimulate labor if cervix is favorable
Cesarean section if induction fails or complications arise


Discontinue Oxytocin, uterine hyperstimulation, or CATII or CATIII
Assess amniotic fluid volume regularly
Observe for signs of fetal distress or meconium-stained fluid
Support and educate patient regarding induction process and potential outcomes
Monitor for uterine hyperstimulation from Oxytocin => leads to fetal demise


Importance of fetal movement counting
Risks of prolonged pregnancy
Methods and expectations of labor induction
Signs to report immediately, such as decreased fetal movement or fluid leakage
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pre-Term Labor
item.description:
The Onset of regular uterine contractions causing cervical changes (dilation and/or effacement) before 37 weeks of gestation.
It increases the risk of neonatal complications due to immature organ development.
Pre-Term - 37wks or younger
Full Term - 39-40wks +6d
Post-Term Labor - 42wks +


Infections (e.g., UTIs, chorioamnionitis)
Multiple gestation
Placental abnormalities
Uterine overdistention
Trauma or stress
Smoking, substance abuse


History of preterm birth
Short cervical length
Incompetent cervix
Low socioeconomic status
Limited prenatal care
Maternal age extremes (<17 or >35)


Uterine contractions (more than 6/hour)
Pelvic pressure or menstrual-like cramps
Lower back pain
Vaginal discharge or spotting
Cervical dilation and/or effacement


Preterm birth
Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
Intraventricular hemorrhage
Necrotizing enterocolitis
Long-term neurodevelopmental delays
death


Fetal fibronectin test
Cervical length via transvaginal ultrasound
Vaginal/cervical cultures
Urinalysis for infection
Electronic fetal monitoring


Tocolytics - MINT (e.g., nifedipine, indomethacin) to suppress labor (2-7 days only)
=> usually before 34 weeks
=> only delays, not treat pre-term birth
=> contraindicated: Placental Abruption, Preeclampsia / Eclampsia, active vaginal bleeding, PROM, fetal distress, and more
Corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone) to accelerate fetal lung maturity
Magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection <32 weeks => reduces muscle contraction strength
Indocin (indomethacin, cyclooxygenase inhibitr) - reduces prostaglandin synthesis
Antibiotics prophylaxis for GBS Positive
Bed rest or activity restriction (individualized)
Pelvic Rest - no vaginal exam


Monitor uterine activity and fetal heart rate
Administer and monitor response to tocolytics and corticosteroids
Ensure hydration and manage underlying conditions (e.g., infections)
Provide emotional support and prepare for possible NICU care
Educate on signs of preterm labor and when to seek care


stop whatever you are doing
empty bladder
lie down on left side
drink 2-3 glasses of water
note contraction strength and notify provider


Recognize signs of preterm labor (contractions, pressure, discharge)
Importance of hydration and avoiding heavy activity
Medication instructions if discharged on tocolytics
Keep prenatal appointments and follow restrictions as advised
Discuss NICU and neonatal outcomes if preterm birth is likely
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Shoulder Distocia
item.description:
an obstetric emergency
fetal anterior shoulder becomes lodged behind the maternal pubic bone during delivery
delaying birth after the head is delivered.


Large fetal size (macrosomia)
Maternal diabetes
Prolonged labor
Excessive maternal weight gain
History of shoulder dystocia in previous delivery


Short maternal stature => small pelvis
Maternal Age over 35 => decreased uterine efficiency
Breech fetal presentation
Gestational diabetes - big baby
Obesity - big baby

Post-term pregnancy - big baby

Previous shoulder dystocia
Instrumental delivery (forceps or vacuum)


Head delivers but shoulders fail to follow
Turtle sign (retraction of the fetal head against the perineum)
Prolonged second stage of labor
Fetal distress (abnormal heart rate)

Fetal:

Brachial plexus injury (Erb’s palsy)
Clavicle or humerus fracture
Hypoxia, brain injury, or death
Maternal:

Postpartum hemorrhage
Vaginal or perineal lacerations
Uterine rupture (rare)


Immediate maneuvers to relieve shoulder impaction (McRoberts maneuver, suprapubic pressure)
Episiotomy to enlarge the vaginal opening
Delivery of posterior arm
Advanced maneuvers or emergency cesarean if unsuccessful


Recognize and report shoulder dystocia immediately
Prepare for neonatal resuscitation
Assist with positioning and application of maneuvers
Provide emotional support to mother and family
Document the event, interventions, and outcomes thoroughly
DO NOT PROVIDE ABDOMINAL PRESSURE
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Umbilical Cord Prolapse
item.description:
Umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting fetal part, typically after membrane rupture, leading to cord compression and impaired fetal oxygenation.
It is an obstetric emergency!
CALL FOR MORE RESOURCES ASAP! DO NOT LEAVE PATIENT
Requiring immediate intervention to prevent fetal hypoxia or death.


Premature rupture of membranes
Malpresentation (breech, transverse lie)
Polyhydramnios
Long umbilical cord
Multiple gestation
High station at time of membrane rupture
External cephalic version


Pre-Term Labor
Low birth weight
Multiparity
Pelvic tumors or uterine abnormalities
Artificial rupture of membranes (amniotomy)


Sudden fetal bradycardia or decelerations after ROM
Visible or palpable cord in or outside the vagina
Cord may protrude from the introitus
Reports of cord pulsations or pressure


Fetal hypoxia or anoxia
Stillbirth or neonatal death
Emergency cesarean delivery
Maternal distress or trauma


Visual inspection or vaginal exam reveals cord in vagina
Continuous fetal monitoring shows bradycardia or variable decelerations
Ultrasound may confirm cord position if not palpable


Immediate manual elevation of presenting fetal part off the cord
per Petitte: keep your hand in the vagina to open cervix => "apply vertical pressure to presenting part"
Place mother in knee-chest, SIMS, or Trendelenburg position
Administer oxygen and IV fluids
Do not attempt to push cord back inside
Prepare for emergency cesarean section
Minimize cord handling to prevent vasospasm
Prepare for imminent C-section


Stay with the patient and call for emergency assistance
Reposition mother to relieve cord pressure
Monitor fetal heart tones continuously
Provide emotional support and updates
Assist with rapid transport to OR for cesarean
Document time of ROM, cord prolapse, and interventions
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Uterine Rupture
item.description:
Full-thickness tear through the uterine wall, often at a previous cesarean scar, that can result in life-threatening maternal and fetal complications.
It is a rare obstetric emergency requiring immediate surgical intervention.


Previous cesarean delivery (especially classical incision)
Trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC)
Trauma (e.g., motor vehicle accident)
Overdistended uterus (e.g., polyhydramnios, macrosomia)
Excessive uterine stimulation (oxytocin or prostaglandins)
Obstructed labor


Previous uterine surgery (cesarean, myomectomy)
High parity
Induction or augmentation of labor
Multifetal gestation
Congenital uterine anomalies


FETAL DISTRESS (e.g., bradycardia, decelerations)
Sudden, severe abdominal pain unrelieved by contractions
Vaginal bleeding
Loss of fetal station
Cessation of uterine contractions
Maternal tachycardia, hypotension, or signs of shock


Fetal hypoxia, brain injury, or death
Maternal hemorrhage
Hysterectomy
Infection
Maternal death


Based on clinical signs and symptoms
Fetal heart rate monitoring for sudden abnormalities
Ultrasound may help in some cases
Confirmed surgically


Immediate emergency cesarean section
Blood transfusion if needed
Possible hysterectomy if bleeding is uncontrollable
Intensive care support for mother and neonate


Recognize early warning signs (sudden pain, fetal distress)
Notify provider immediately
Discontinue oxytocin if in use
Monitor vital signs and fetal heart rate
Prepare for rapid surgical intervention
Support patient and family emotionally
Document all observations and interventions


Discuss risks if considering VBAC (vaginal birth after cesarean)
Educate on signs of uterine rupture during labor
Emphasize importance of hospital birth with prior uterine surgery
Review future pregnancy planning and surgical history implications
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: VBAC
item.description:
Vaginal Birth After Cesarean (VBAC) refers to delivering a baby vaginally after having had a previous cesarean delivery.
It is an option for many women, depending on the type of uterine incision and individual risk factors.


Desire to avoid repeat surgery
Previous low transverse cesarean incision => best candidate
Absence of contraindications to vaginal birth
Adequate pelvis and favorable cervix


Vertical/classical uterine incision
History of uterine rupture
More than two previous cesarean deliveries
Short interval between pregnancies (<18 months)
Macrosomia or fetal malpresentation


Normal progression of labor similar to any vaginal delivery
Continuous fetal monitoring to detect signs of uterine rupture
Pain, bleeding, or abnormal fetal heart rate may indicate complications


Uterine rupture (most serious)
Emergency cesarean section
Hemorrhage
Infection
Neonatal complications if labor becomes prolonged or complicated


Review of prior surgical records to confirm uterine incision type
Pelvic assessment to evaluate feasibility of vaginal delivery
Ultrasound to assess fetal position and growth


Trial of Labor After Cesarean (TOLAC) under close monitoring
Emergency response plan available for complications
Oxytocin may be used cautiously for labor augmentation
Epidural analgesia may be offered


Verify eligibility for VBAC
Continuous electronic fetal monitoring
Monitor for signs of uterine rupture (sudden pain, loss of fetal station, abnormal fetal heart tones)
Prepare for emergency cesarean if needed
Provide emotional support and pain management


Discuss benefits and risks of VBAC vs repeat cesarean
Explain signs of labor and when to come to hospital
Emphasize importance of delivering in facility equipped for emergency cesarean
Review birth plan and involve patient in decision-making process
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Factors Affecting Labor Process
item.description:
Chapter 13: Labor and Birth Process (Ricci)
Original 5 P's

Passageway
Passenger
Powers
Position
Psychological Response


birth canal
Pelvis: must be at least 11.5 cm diagonal conjugate, true conjugate 10cm or more
Soft Tissues: must efface (thin out)
Pelvic Floor muscles => help rotate fetus during labor (Kegels!)
Pelvic Shapes:

Gynecoid - "G for Good", best, round shape, roomy outlet
Anthropoid - "Anthro = average", not ideal but better than ANDROID or PLATYPELLOID
Android - "male robot = male pelvis"; funnel shape, not good, usually C-section
Platypelloid (flat) - least common, not good

HEAD

largest part
cranial sutures & soft fontanelle = >help head elongate with pressure
overlapping sutures = molding; elongated
Caput succedaneum - edema of the scalp at the presenting part (resolves in 3-4 days)
Cephalohematoma - Collection of blood between the periosteum and the bone that occurs several hours after birth.
Fetal Attitude

posturing or FLEXION or EXTESION of joints
FULL FLEXION - good; more compressed body
FETAL LIE - relationship of long spin to spine of mother
LIE to LTO

longitudinal - parallel to maternal spine
transverse
oblique - fetal long axis is at an angle to the bony inlet
FETAL PRESENTATION - part that is peeking out of the vajayjay

Cephalic - head first; more common
1. Vertex - occipital lobe first; most preferred
2. Military
3. Brow - Largest diameter presents; labor often does not progress; usually requires C-section
4. Face - May cause facial edema, bruising; larger presenting diameter makes vaginal delivery challenging.
Breech - pelvis first; umbilical cord can compress; largest part last; risk for birth trauma, head entrapment, often c-section
