Frank Breech - baby's legs are straight up in front, with the feet near the head, and the buttocks present first.
Complete - knees bent
Single Footling - one foot down
Double Footling - two feet down
Shoulder - scapula first; risk for Shoulder Distocia, cannot be delivered vaginally; high risk of cord prolapse; requires C-section.
TURTLE SIGN - neonate’s head slowly extends and emerges over the perineum but then retracts back
FETAL POSITION - position in the womb j described by the baby’s head, back, and limbs relative to the mother’s pelvis
Jay Loa & Roa = baby's most favorable position
Left Occiput Anterior (LOA)- most favorable
Right Occiput Anterior (ROA) - 2nd most favorable
Posterior (xOP)- least favorable

L or R - left or right
O/S/M/A/D - Occupit, Sacrum, Mentum, Acrominion, Dorsal
A/P/T - anterior, posterior, transverse
FETAL STATION - relationship of the presenting part to the level of the maternal pelvic ischial spines

scale of -4 not +4
-4 not engage, +4 crowning, ready to delivery
0 stations - head aligned with ischial spine in pelvis, considered as "engaged"
FETAL ENGAGEMENT - largest diameter of the fetal presenting part
CARDINAL MOVEMENTS OF LABOR - EDFIREEE

Engagement
Fetal head enters pelvic inlet (0 station)
Indicates head is engaged and labor is progressing normally
Descent
Head moves deeper into pelvis with contractions and maternal effort
Indicates progression toward delivery; continued descent is necessary for successful vaginal birth
Flexion
Fetal chin tucks to chest, presenting the smallest diameter
Allows for easier passage through the pelvis
Internal Rotation
Head rotates to align with the anteroposterior diameter of the pelvis
Proper rotation reduces risk of prolonged labor and aids in head alignment for delivery
Extension
Fetal head extends as it passes under the pubic symphysis
Facilitates delivery of the head; guides provider to prepare for crowning
External Rotation (Restitution)
Head realigns with shoulders after head is delivered
Allows shoulders to align with pelvis; prepares for shoulder delivery
Expulsion
Shoulders and body are delivered
Marks the completion of delivery and transition to newborn care

UTERINE CONTRACTIONS - involuntary; responsible for thinning and dilating cervix

Effacement - % based on cervical canal length
2 cm = 0%
1 cm = 50%
0 cm = 100%.
Dilation
Frequency & Duration: early labor => 30 sections, 5-7 minutes apart
Intensity - measured by internal intrauterine pressure catheter
Contraction Phase:

increment - start to peak
acme - actual peak
decrement - peak to baseline; relaxation of the uterine muscle fibers
INTRA-ABDOMINAL PRESSURE - caused by voluntary muscle contractions
more pressure, the better expulsion
sedation decreases


upright maternal positioning uses gravity to bring fetus down, less risk of aorta compression
common practice - adopt maternal position of comfort
peanut ball can decrease time of labor


more emotional support = better
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Nonpharmacologic Pain Management
item.description:
Continuous Labor Support
Hydrotherapy - showering, regular tub, whirlpool, helps release muscle tension
Hypnosis
Ambulation - walking and upright position in 1st stage reduce length of labor d/t gravity
Maternal Position Changes
Transcutaneous Electrical Nerve Stimulation (TENS)
Acupuncture
Acupressure
Attention Focusing and Imagery
Therapeutic Touch
Massage
Breathing Techniques
Effleurage - light, stroking, superficial touch of the abdomen, in rhythm with breathing during contractions
Lamaze is a method of childbirth preparation that focuses on natural techniques like controlled breathing, relaxation, and movement to help manage labor and potentially reduce the need for pain medication.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Nursing Management
item.description:
high-touch, low-tech care
admission history:
- EDD
- prmonitory labor signs experienced
- GTPAL
- contractions description, ROM
- suport
lab results: GBS, HIV
birth plan
physical assessment:
- Leopold Maneuvers
- Fundal Height
- FHR
- Vaginal Exam


nurses should not be controlling this stage of labor but rather empowering women to achieve a satisfying experience
Goal: direct patient to push to shorten second stage
assess Perineal Lacerations
Episiotomy - incision made to enlarge vaginal outlet
midline - most common; least amount of pain
right and left mediolateral


assess for Placental Separation
assess for Perineal Trauma

Goals:

close observation for hemorrhage
provision of comfort measures
promotion of family attachment.
Vitals - q15min for first hour, then q30 for next hour if needed
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pain Management in Labor
item.description:
onset - within minutes and lasts for several hours
complication: respiratory depression
Opioids: morphine, demerol, fentanyl
can cross placenta
Antiemetics: hydroxyzine, promethazine, Compazine
Benzodiazepines
Midazolam/Versed - amnesia effect, adjunct for anesthesia
Diazepam - enhance pain relief, sedation
Inhaled Analgesics - nitrous oxide, self-administered => empowering, less perception of pain


local anesthetic agents with or without added opioids to bring about pain relief or numbness through the drug’s effects on the spinal cord and nerve roots
pain relief without loss of consciousness
usually T8 to T10
The woman can participate in the birthing process and still have good pain control


administration of opioids or anesthetics into the epidural or intrathecal space
small catheter is then passed through the epidural needle
Epidural analgesia increases the duration of the second stage of labor
meds: combination of lidocaine anesthetic, opioid analgesic
Contraindication: receiving anticoagulants


indwelling epidural catheter with an infusion of medication and a programmed pump allows patient controlled dosing


injection of local anesthetic into the superficial perineal nerves to numb the perineal area


injection of a local anesthetic agent into the pudendal nerves near each ischial spine
provides pain relief in the lower vagina, vulva, and perineum


injection of an anesthetic “caine” agent with or without opioids into the subarachnoid space
usually used in c-sections
contraindications: bleeding precautions
intrathecal narcotics


state of unconsciousness and insensitivity to pain during surgery
Usually: barbiturate + propofol (unconsciousness) + muscle relaxant
crosses placenta
Complications: fetal depression, uterine relaxation, vomiting/aspiration, inability to intubate
Considerations: ensure NPO, IV line, administer clear oral antacid or PPI and H2 Blockers
Ensure placement of wedge on right hip to prevent vena cava compression
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Premonitory Signs of Labor
item.description:
cervical softening and possible cervical dilation
descent of presenting par
elongated cervix to shortened, thinned segment
ripening and softening


fetal presenting part begins to descend into the true pelvis
uterus lowers and moves into a more anterior position
breathing much easier
Increased pelvic pressure, leg cramping, dependent edema in the lower legs, and low back discomfort
increase in vaginal discharge and more frequent urination

nesting
24-48 hours before onset of labor

small amount of blood mixed with mucus => pink-tinged secretions
mucus plug that fills the cervical canal during pregnancy is expelled

felt as a tightening or pulling sensation of the top of the uterus
primarily in the abdomen and groin and gradually spread downward before relaxing
NOTE: TRUE LABOR CONTRACTIONS are in the LOWER BACK
reshape the cervix: ripen and shorten, more anterior

loss of amniotic fluid prior to the onset of labor
only occurs in 8-10% of pregnancies
barrier to infection is gone and an ascending infection is possible
increased risk of cord prolapse!
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Stages of Labor
item.description:
Notes:

sedation can increase duration of dilation process
primagravida - 1st stage of labor can last up to 20 hours
Epidural - dulls the urge to push
Fundus should be firm and well contracted at 4th stage; massage it if boggy
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: True vs False Labor
item.description: 411 or 511 rule - contractions 4–5 minutes apart, lasting 1 minute each, and persisting for at least 1 hour). come to the hospital!
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: BUBBLE HEVN
item.description:
BUBBLE - Breast, Uterus, Bowel, Bladder, Lochia, Episiotomy
HEAVN: Homan's, Emotional, Affect, Vitals, Nutrition


Assess for redness, pain, tenderness
Check for engorgement or fullness
Examine for striae and skin integrity
Inspect nipples for redness, cracks, fissures, bleeding, colostrum, and signs of latching problems


Palpate fundus for boggy or firm consistency
Assess position of fundus (midline or deviated)
Check proper height according to postpartum day
Support lower uterine segment during assessment
Massage gently if uterus is soft
If C/S delivery, inspect abdominal dressing for drainage and/or REEDA (redness, edema, ecchymosis, drainage, approximation)


Auscultate bowel sounds in all quadrants
Note presence, absence, or hypoactivity of bowel sounds
Assess for firmness or softness of abdomen
Inquire about passing gas or stool, note frequency, consistency, constipation


Confirm bladder assessment was completed prior to postpartum assessment
Ask if bladder has been emptied
Document urine output amount and color
If Foley catheter present, confirm patency, inspect amount and color, note signs of infection


Inspect perineal pad for bleeding
Note character, quality, presence of clots, and odor


Assess perineum for healing
Inspect episiotomy or lacerations using REEDA (redness, edema, ecchymosis, drainage, approximation)


Assess calves for pain with dorsiflexion, tenderness, redness, striae, swelling, warmth, or induration


Observe maternal emotional status
Note interaction with infant, bonding behaviors, family and caregiver support
Screen for postpartum depression or anxiety


Refer to bowel section for bowel sounds and distention
Palpate for tenderness, distention, or surgical incision (if C/S)
Assess for diastasis recti


Review temperature, pulse, respiratory rate, blood pressure, pain level
Compare to postpartum norms


Assess intake and output
Educate on balanced diet postpartum, adequate fluids, extra calories if breastfeeding
Recommend iron-rich and protein-rich foods
Discuss foods to promote healing and lactation
Advise on avoiding certain foods if contraindicated
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Emotional
item.description:
per Ricci
Bonding = close emotional attraction to a newborn by the parents that develops during the first 30 to 60 minutes after birth
Attachment = development of strong affection between an infant and a significant other (mother, father, sibling, and caregiver).


Contact: The sensory experiences of touching, holding, and gazing at the infant are part of proximity-seeking behavior.
Emotional state: The emotional state emerges from the affective experience of the new parents toward their infant and the parental role.
Individualization: Parents are aware of the need to differentiate the infant’s needs from themselves and to recognize and respond to them appropriately, making the attachment process also, in a way, one of detachment.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Fundal Height Postpartum
item.description:
Fundus is at or just below the umbilicus (midline)

Fundus remains at or slightly above the umbilicus

Fundus at level of umbilicus, may rise slightly (1 cm above umbilicus) but should be firm and midline

Fundus begins to descend (involution)
Each postpartum day thereafter

Fundus descends approximately 1 fingerbreadth (1 cm) per day
Day 1: 1 cm below umbilicus
Day 2: 2 cm below umbilicus
Day 3: 3 cm below umbilicus
And so on

Fundus is no longer palpable abdominally
Returns to pre-pregnancy size by 6 weeks
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Lochia
item.description:
Color: dark red or bright red
Consistency: moderately heavy flow may contain small clots
Content: primarily blood with decidual tissue fetal membrane fragments and some mucus
Smell: fleshy (foul odor = infection)


Color: pink brownish or watery red
Consistency: thinner flow less clotted
Content: blood serum leukocytes cervical mucus and tissue debris


Color: yellow white or creamy
Consistency: light scant discharge
Content: mostly leukocytes mucus epithelial cells and bacteria minimal to no blood


Scant: a 1- to 2-in lochia stain on the perineal pad or approximately a 10-mL loss
Light or small: an approximately 4-in stain or a 10- to 25-mL loss
Moderate: a 4- to 6-in stain with an estimated loss of 25 to 50 mL
Large or heavy: a pad is saturated within 1 hour after changing it
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Perineal Lacerations
item.description:
extent of the laceration is defined by depth

First Degree - extends through the skin
Second Degree - extends through the muscles of the perineal body
Third Degree - continues through the anal sphincter muscle
=> risk for fecal incontinence
Fourth Degree - involves the anterior rectal wall
=> risk for fecal incontinence
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Phases of Maternal Role Attainment
item.description:
24-48 hrs
focus on meeting personal needs
rely on others for assistance
excited, talkative
need to review birth experience with others
"he has my nose"


day 2-3
lasts 10 days to several weeks
focus on baby care, improving caregiving competency
learn and practice
deal with physical and emotional discomforts
"BABY BLUES"
want to take charge but need acceptance from others


focus on family as a unit
resumption of role (intimate partner, individual)
reestablishes relationships with other people
establishes a lifestyle that includes the infant
relinquishes the fantasy infant and accepts the real one.
item.link: https://rpb-rn.github.io/nu-bsn/OB/iv. Postpartum/Assessments/Phases of Maternal Role Attainment.html
item.guid: OB/iv. Postpartum/Assessments/Phases of Maternal Role Attainment.md
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Weight Loss
item.description: 1 kg (2.2 lb) per month if lactating
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Breast Engorgement
item.description:
Swelling, firmness, and discomfort in breasts due to increased blood flow and milk production postpartum
Commonly occurs 3–5 days after delivery
Can affect breastfeeding and cause pain or difficulty latching


Sudden increase in milk volume (lactogenesis II)
Infrequent or ineffective breastfeeding or pumping
Breast milk stasis and venous/lymphatic congestion


Primiparity
Delayed breastfeeding initiation
Infrequent feedings
Formula supplementation
Poor infant latch or ineffective suck


Bilateral breast fullness, hardness, warmth, pain
Shiny, tight skin with flattened nipples
Low-grade fever possible (< 100.4°F)
Baby may struggle to latch due to breast firmness


Plugged ducts
Mastitis
Breast abscess
Breastfeeding cessation


Clinical diagnosis based on symptoms and timing postpartum
Rule out mastitis if fever > 100.4°F, redness, systemic symptoms


Breastfeed or pump frequently (q2–3h)
Warm compresses before feeding (↑ milk flow)
Cold compresses or chilled cabbage leaves after feeding (↓ swelling)
Gentle breast massage during feeds
NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) for pain/inflammation


Assess for signs of mastitis
Encourage early and frequent breastfeeding
Teach proper latch and positioning
Support hand expression if too full to latch
Monitor for maternal discomfort, fever
Document breast exam findings and interventions


Engorgement is temporary and improves with regular milk removal
Breastfeed 8–12x/day; don’t skip night feedings
Use cold packs post-feed to reduce swelling
Wear supportive, non-restrictive bra
Avoid tight bras or binding (can worsen engorgement)
Contact provider if fever, redness, or flu-like symptoms occur
🧠 NCLEX Tip: Warm before, cold after. Frequent emptying prevents complications.
🧠 Mnemonic: ENGORGED = Express milk, NSAIDs, Gentle massage, Offer feed often, Relieve with cold, Get baby to latch well, Educate, Detect mastitis early.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Mastitis
item.description:
Infection of the breast tissue, commonly occurring during breastfeeding
Involves pain, redness, and swelling in affected area


Milk stasis due to incomplete emptying
Bacterial entry (often Staphylococcus aureus) via cracked nipples
Overproduction of milk


Nipple trauma or cracks
Poor latch or infrequent breastfeeding
Blocked ducts
Stress and fatigue


Localized, painful, red, warm area on the breast
Fever (>38.4°C/101°F), chills, malaise
Flu-like symptoms
May have breast engorgement


Breast abscess (requires drainage)
Sepsis if untreated


Clinical presentation
Ultrasound if abscess suspected
Culture of milk if severe, recurrent, or unresponsive


Continue breastfeeding or milk expression to empty breast
Warm compresses and massage
Analgesics (e.g., ibuprofen) for pain and inflammation
Antibiotics: dicloxacillin or cephalexin; clindamycin if penicillin allergy
Rest and hydration


Educate on correct latch and breastfeeding techniques
Encourage frequent and complete emptying of affected breast
Monitor for signs of abscess (fluctuant mass, worsening pain)
Advise supportive bra, avoid tight clothing
Explain that breastfeeding can continue on affected side unless abscess forms
Teach proper nipple care to prevent cracks and infection
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Post-Partum Hemorrhage
item.description:
Blood loss of after vaginal birth or after C-section within 24 hours of birth (Primary/Early PPH).
Or, blood loss occurring 24 hours to 6-12 weeks postpartum (Secondary/Late PPH).
A leading cause of maternal morbidity and mortality worldwide.

5 T's

Tone: uterine atony (most common), distended bladder
Tissue: retained placenta and clots; uterine subinvolution
Trauma: lacerations, hematoma, inversion, rupture
Thrombin: coagulopathy (preexisting or acquired)
Traction: too much pulling on umbilical cord


Uterine Atony:
Overdistension of uterus (multiples, polyhydramnios, macrosomia).
Prolonged labor, rapid labor.
Grand multiparity ( pregnancies).
Oxytocin use during labor.
MgSO4 administration.
Chorioamnionitis.
Trauma: Operative vaginal delivery (forceps, vacuum), precipitous delivery, large infant.
Tissue: Placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta.
Thrombin: Pre-existing bleeding disorders, severe preeclampsia, placental abruption, sepsis.


Early signs: Excessive vaginal bleeding (saturating pads quickly, steady trickle), boggy uterus (not firm).
Late signs (Hypovolemic Shock): Hypotension, tachycardia, pallor, dizziness, oliguria, altered mental status.
NCLEX Tip: Don't wait for signs of shock; recognize and act on early signs of excessive bleeding!


Hypovolemic shock.
Anemia.
Acute kidney injury.
Sheehan's Syndrome (postpartum pituitary necrosis due to severe blood loss).
Peripartum hysterectomy.
Maternal death.


Clinical assessment: Quantify blood loss (weighing pads/chux, collecting blood in calibrated drapes). Visual estimation often underestimates.
Physical exam: Fundal massage, inspection for lacerations, assessment for retained placental fragments.
Laboratory tests: CBC (H&H), type and crossmatch, coagulation studies (PT/INR, PTT, fibrinogen).


Atony (Fundal Massage & Medications):
First-line: Firm uterine fundal massage.
Uterotonics:
Oxytocin (Pitocin): IV bolus or infusion. NCLEX Tip: Always first-line uterotonic.
Methylergonovine (Methergine): IM. Contraindicated in hypertension/preeclampsia.
Carboprost tromethamine (Hemabate): IM. Contraindicated in asthma.
Misoprostol (Cytotec): Rectal or oral.
Trauma: Repair of lacerations, evacuation of hematomas.
Tissue: Manual removal of retained placenta, D&C (Dilation & Curettage).
Thrombin: Administer blood products (pRBCs, FFP, platelets, cryoprecipitate) as indicated.
Surgical intervention: Uterine artery embolization, B-Lynch suture, hysterectomy (last resort).
Fluid resuscitation: IV crystalloids, blood transfusion.


Assess Fundus: Immediately after birth and frequently. Should be firm, midline, at or below umbilicus. If boggy, massage until firm.
Assess Lochia: Quantity, color, presence of clots. Quantify blood loss accurately.
Vital Signs: Monitor every 5-15 minutes in acute hemorrhage. Recognize subtle changes.
Bladder: Ensure bladder is empty (full bladder can displace uterus and prevent contraction). Straight catheterize if needed.
IV Access: Ensure at least two large-bore (18-gauge) IVs for fluid and blood product administration.
Medication Administration: Understand mechanism of action, dosages, routes, and contraindications of uterotonics.
Emotional Support: Keep patient and family informed. Maintain a calm environment.
Team Communication: Alert provider immediately for signs of PPH. Initiate rapid response if indicated.
Post-PPH Care: Monitor for anemia, fatigue. Administer iron supplements as prescribed.


Warning Signs: Educate patient on signs of excessive bleeding (e.g., soaking more than one pad per hour, large clots, dizziness).
Activity: Gradual increase in activity; avoid heavy lifting.
Nutrition: Importance of iron-rich foods to replenish stores (e.g., red meat, leafy greens, fortified cereals).
Rest: Emphasize importance of rest and sleep.
Follow-up: Stress importance of postpartum follow-up appointments.
NCLEX Tip: Teach signs of infection and when to seek immediate medical attention (e.g., fever, foul-smelling lochia).
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Postpartum Depression
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Subinvolution of the Uterus
item.description:
Failure of the uterus to return to its normal size and condition after childbirth
Leads to prolonged uterine enlargement and bleeding


Retained placental fragments
Infection (endometritis)
Pelvic inflammatory disease
Poor uterine contractions postpartum


Prolonged labor
Multiple pregnancies
Overdistended uterus
Cesarean section or complicated delivery
Poor postpartum care


Persistent vaginal bleeding beyond expected postpartum period
Enlarged, soft uterus on palpation
Pelvic pain or tenderness
Possible foul-smelling lochia if infection present


Secondary Post-Partum Hemorrhage
Infection spreading to pelvic organs
Anemia due to prolonged bleeding
Infertility if untreated


Pelvic exam showing enlarged uterus
Ultrasound to detect retained placental tissue or infection
CBC for anemia and infection markers
Culture if infection suspected


Removal of retained products (D&C if needed)
Antibiotics for infection
Uterotonic agents to stimulate contractions
Adequate rest and hydration


Monitor amount and character of vaginal bleeding
Assess uterine size regularly
Educate patient on signs of infection and when to seek care
Administer prescribed antibiotics and uterotonics
Promote good hygiene to prevent infection
Encourage follow-up appointments for uterine involution check
NCLEX Tip: Subinvolution often presents with prolonged bleeding and an enlarged uterus after the expected postpartum period.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Uterine Atony
item.description:
Uterine atony is failure of the uterus to contract effectively after delivery

Leading cause of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)
Results in heavy bleeding due to poor uterine muscle tone


Prolonged labor or rapid labor
Overdistended uterus (e.g., multiple gestation, polyhydramnios)
Use of uterine relaxants (Tocolytics - MINT, MgSO4)
High parity (multiple previous births)
Retained placenta fragments
General anesthesia


5 pregnancies (multiparity)
Large baby (>4000g)
Prolonged Oxytocin use during labor
History of Uterine Atony or PPH
Chorioamnionitis or infection
Magnesium sulfate therapy


Excessive, bright red vaginal bleeding
Soft, boggy uterus on palpation ("boggy uterus")
Tachycardia and hypotension (signs of hypovolemia)
Pallor, weakness, dizziness
Decreased urine output if hypovolemia progresses


Severe postpartum hemorrhage
Hypovolemic shock
Anemia
DIC
Need for blood transfusion or hysterectomy


Clinical diagnosis: heavy vaginal bleeding + boggy uterus
Ultrasound to rule out retained products of conception
CBC for anemia assessment
Coagulation profile if bleeding persists


Immediate fundal massage to stimulate contractions
IV fluids and blood transfusion if needed
Uterotonic drugs: => Post-Partum Hemorrhage Meds = MCTOM
Oxytocin (first line)
Methylergonovine (avoid if hypertensive)
Carboprost tromethamine (avoid in asthma)
Misoprostol (rectal or oral)
TXA
Surgical intervention if conservative measures fail (e.g., uterine tamponade, hysterectomy)


Monitor vital signs closely, watch for hypovolemic shock
Assess uterine tone and vaginal bleeding frequently
Administer uterotonic meds as ordered, know contraindications
Educate patient on importance of reporting heavy bleeding or dizziness
Maintain IV access, prepare for possible transfusion
Provide emotional support and explain interventions
Monitor urine output as indicator of perfusion
Prepare for potential surgical interventions if bleeding uncontrolled
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Uterine Inversion
item.description:
Uterus turns inside out, protruding through the cervix or vagina after delivery
MEDICAL EMERGENCY!
rare but life-threatening
Causes severe hemorrhage and shock


Excessive traction on umbilical cord during placenta delivery
Fundal pressure before placenta detaches
Weak uterine tone or atony
Short umbilical cord


Fundal implantation of placenta
Rapid or prolonged labor
Use of oxytocin causing uterine hyperstimulation
Manual removal of placenta


Sudden severe vaginal bleeding
Severe lower abdominal pain
Visible mass protruding from the vagina (if complete inversion)
Shock disproportionate to blood loss (due to vagal response)
Uterus not palpable abdominally or very depressed


Hypovolemic shock
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
Uterine rupture
Death if untreated


Clinical diagnosis by physical exam
Visualization of inverted uterus through cervix or vagina
Ultrasound to confirm if uncertain


Immediate manual repositioning of uterus (Johnson maneuver)
General anesthesia or tocolytics may be needed for relaxation => Terbutraline
Replace uterus gently into correct position
Uterotonics after repositioning to maintain tone (e.g., oxytocin)
Surgical intervention if manual reposition fails
IV fluids and blood transfusion as needed


Call for emergency help immediately
Monitor vital signs closely, prepare for shock management
Provide emotional support, explain urgent procedures
Administer medications as ordered (tocolytics before reposition, uterotonics after)
Maintain large-bore IV access for fluids/blood
Monitor bleeding, uterine tone, and signs of infection post-reposition
Document event and interventions clearly
NCLEX Tip: Uterine inversion presents with sudden bleeding and shock disproportionate to visible blood loss—immediate manual replacement is critical.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Endometritis
item.description:
Infection and inflammation of the endometrium (uterine lining) postpartum or post-procedure
Common cause of postpartum fever and morbidity


Bacterial invasion during or after delivery, miscarriage, or gynecologic procedures
Polymicrobial: often Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, anaerobes
Retained placental fragments increase risk


Cesarean section (especially emergency)
Prolonged labor or membrane rupture (>18 hours)
Multiple vaginal exams during labor
Poor aseptic technique
Retained products of conception
Immunosuppression


Fever (>38°C/100.4°F), chills
Lower abdominal/pelvic pain and tenderness
Foul-smelling, purulent lochia
Uterine tenderness on palpation
Tachycardia
Malaise and fatigue


Pelvic abscess
Sepsis
Infertility from scarring
Chronic pelvic pain


Clinical diagnosis based on symptoms and signs
CBC: elevated WBC with left shift
Blood cultures if febrile/septic
Ultrasound to identify retained products or abscess


Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (e.g., clindamycin + gentamicin)
Removal of retained products if present (D&C)
Antipyretics and pain control
Hydration and rest


Monitor vital signs and temperature regularly
Assess uterine size, tenderness, and vaginal discharge
Educate on importance of hygiene and reporting fever or foul discharge
Administer antibiotics on time, monitor for side effects
Encourage early ambulation and hydration
Provide comfort measures and emotional support
Teach signs of worsening infection or sepsis for early intervention
Mnemonic for endometritis risks: "C-PROM"
Cesarean, Prolonged Rupture Of Membranes
NCLEX Tip: Fever, uterine tenderness, and foul lochia after cesarean or prolonged labor strongly suggest endometritis.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: APGAR
item.description:
xz
if it's below 7 at 5 min, do it again in 5 min
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Birth Weight - Gestational Age
item.description:
Usual weight range: 2,500 to 4,000 g
Usual height: 44 to 55 cm (17 to 22 in)

Head disproportionately large compared with rest of body (asymmetric)
Wasted appearance of extremities
Reduced subcutaneous fat stores
Jittery secondary to hypoglycemia
Decreased amount of breast tissue
Scaphoid abdomen (sunken appearance)
Temperature instability
Wide skull sutures secondary to inadequate bone growth
Poor muscle tone over buttocks and cheeks
Loose and dry skin that appears oversized
Thin umbilical cord

Large body and appears plump and full faced
The increase in body size is proportional.
head circumference and body length are in the upper limits of intrauterine growth
poor motor skills
difficulty in regulating behavioral states
more difficult to arouse to a quiet alert state

Low birth weight (LBW): Weight of 2,500 g or less at birth
Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR): Growth rate does not meet expected norms.

Early term is defined as occurring from 37 0/7 weeks through 38 6/7 weeks.
Full term is defined as occurring from 39 0/7 through 40 6/7 weeks.
Late term is defined as occurring from 41 0/7 weeks through 41 6/7 weeks.
Preterm or premature: Born prior to 37 0/7 weeks of gestation.

Late preterm is defined as occurring from 34 0/7 through 36 6/7 weeks.
Postterm:**** Born after the completion of 42 0/7 weeks of gestation.
Postmature: Born after the completion of 42 weeks of gestation with evidence of placental insufficiency.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Gestational Age
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Head
item.description:
Fontanels:
Anterior fontanel: 4 to 6 cm, diamond-shaped, closes by 12–18 months
Posterior fontanel: 0.5 to 1 cm, triangular, closes by 2–3 months
Molding:
Overlapping of cranial bones during birth; resolves in a few days
Caput succedaneum:
Edema crossing suture lines; resolves within 48–72 hours
Cephalohematoma:
Rupture of blood vessels during delivery; does not cross suture lines; resolves over weeks to months
Sutures:
Should be palpable, not fused; allow for brain growth
Scalp hair:
Soft, may have varying patterns or bald spots from intrauterine position
Facial symmetry:
Assess for nerve injury (e.g., facial nerve palsy)
Bruising:
Common from delivery; monitor for jaundice due to increased bilirubin from breakdown of RBCs
Craniotabes:
Soft skull bones near suture lines; common in preterm infants; resolves as bones harden
Subgaleal hemorrhage:
Fluctuant mass that crosses suture lines; requires urgent evaluation due to risk of significant blood loss


Microcephaly
Head circumference >2 SD below average or <10% normal parameters for gestational age

Due to failed brain development, reduced neuron production, reduced brain/skull size

Affects 1 in 800–5,000 infants/year in the US

Severe microcephaly: >3 SD below mean, often with imaging abnormalities, severe developmental impairments

Associated with: seizures, developmental delay, intellectual disability, hearing loss, vision/movement/balance/feeding problems

Causes: genetics, infections (CMV, rubella, toxoplasmosis), Zika, trisomies 13/18/21, alcohol/drugs exposure

Macrocephaly
Head circumference >90% of normal

Often benign, no treatment needed

Related to hydrocephalus, often familial (autosomal dominant)

May be isolated or part of other conditions (hydrocephalus, skeletal disorders like achondroplasia)

Large Fontanels
more than 6 cm anterior or >1 cm posterior diameter

Causes: malnutrition, hydrocephalus, congenital hypothyroidism, trisomies 13/18/21, osteogenesis imperfecta

Small/Closed Fontanels
Smaller-than-normal or closed at birth

Causes: craniosynostosis (premature suture fusion), abnormal brain development

Associated with microcephaly

Management: multidisciplinary subspecialty teams, reconstructive approaches
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: MSK Assessments
item.description:
Purpose: Detects dislocated hip that can be reduced (congenital hip dysplasia)
Technique: With infant supine, hips and knees flexed 90°, gently abduct the thighs while applying anterior pressure on greater trochanters
Positive sign: Feel or hear a “clunk” as the femoral head relocates into the acetabulum


Purpose: Detects dislocatable hip (can be pushed out of socket)
Technique: With infant supine, hips and knees flexed 90°, gently adduct the thighs while applying posterior pressure on the knees
Positive sign: Feeling the femoral head slip out of the socket (a “clunk” or sensation of instability)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Neonatal Reflexes
item.description:
Rooting: turns head toward touch on cheek, opens mouth (disappears by 4 months)
Sucking: sucks when roof of mouth is touched (present at birth)
Moro (startle): arms extend and fan out when startled, then flex back (disappears by 4–6 months)
Palmar grasp: grasps object placed in palm (disappears by 3–4 months)
Plantar grasp: toes curl when sole is touched (disappears by 8 months)
Babinski: toes fan outward when sole is stroked (normal up to 1 year)
Stepping: makes stepping motions when held upright (disappears by 2 months)
Tonic neck (fencing): head turned to one side, arm extends on that side while opposite arm flexes (disappears by 4 months)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: New Ballard Score
item.description:
Higher score = more mature = higher GA
Scores range from -10 (very preterm) to 50 (post-term)



Posture:
Very preterm: Extended limbs
Term: Arms & legs flexed
Square Window (Wrist Flexion):
Term: 0–30° angle
Preterm: >90°
Arm Recoil:
Term: Quick recoil after extension
Preterm: Slow or no recoil
Popliteal Angle (Knee):
Term: <90°
Preterm: >120°
Scarf Sign (Elbow across chest):
Term: Elbow doesn’t cross midline
Preterm: Elbow crosses easily
Heel to Ear:
Term: Resistance before heel reaches ear
Preterm: Heel easily reaches ear


Skin:
Term: Opaque, cracks, few veins
Preterm: Thin, transparent, many veins
Lanugo:
Term: Mostly gone
Preterm: Abundant
Plantar Surface:
Term: Creases over entire sole
Preterm: Smooth or few creases
Breast:
Term: Well-developed areola, palpable nodule
Preterm: Barely perceptible areola
Eye/Ear:
Term: Thick cartilage, forms instant recoil
Preterm: Thin cartilage, slow recoil
Genitals:
Male: Term: Testes fully descended, rugae on scrotum
Female: Term: Labia majora cover labia minora and clitoris
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Physiological Changes
item.description:
Closure of foramen ovale, ductus arteriosus, and ductus venosus
Increase in systemic vascular resistance and decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance
Heart rate initially high (120–160 bpm) then stabilizes
Blood volume approximately 80–85 mL/kg
Increase in red blood cells, but rapid decrease over first weeks (physiological anemia)


First breath establishes functional residual capacity
Surfactant reduces surface tension, prevents alveolar collapse
Respiratory rate 30–60 breaths per minute
Periodic breathing is common (pauses <15 seconds normal)
Risk of transient tachypnea if fluid clearance delayed


Thermoregulation immature; prone to heat loss
Brown fat metabolism generates heat (non-shivering thermogenesis)
Requires neutral thermal environment to prevent cold stress


Bilirubin levels decline to normal adult after 14 days
Limited glycogen stores; risk for hypoglycemia
Immature conjugation of bilirubin; risk for jaundice
Coagulation factors dependent on vitamin K (administer vitamin K at birth) => need gut bacteria from Breast Milk
Slow metabolism of certain drugs
Iron stored in the liver from maternal transfer during third trimester


Stomach capacity increases rapidly (30–90 mL)
Cardiac Sphincter or LES immature => leads to vomiting after feeding
Suck-swallow coordination matures over first few days
Meconium passed within 24–48 hours
Limited enzyme function (low amylase, pancreatic lipase)


Immature kidney function
GFR low, limits urine concentrating ability
First void usually within 24 hours
Risk for dehydration and electrolyte imbalance


Passive immunity from maternal IgG
Skin and mucous membranes immature; risk for infection
Limited inflammatory response


Vernix caseosa protects skin in utero; gradually absorbed
Lanugo fine hair present on back and shoulders
Milia, erythema toxicum, and other benign rashes common
Skin thin and prone to injury and heat loss


Reflexes present (Moro, rooting, grasp)
Myelination incomplete
Sleep-wake cycles irregular
CNS sensitive to hypoglycemia and hypoxia



Begins at birth, lasts 30 min–2 hours
Alert, moving, may appear hungry
Myoclonic eye movements, spontaneous Moro reflex
Sucking motions, chewing, rooting, fine tremors
Increased muscle tone, motor activity
Elevated heart and respiratory rates, gradually slow
Ideal time for parent-newborn bonding
Sucking and rooting behaviors; opportunity to initiate breastfeeding


Starts at 30–120 min of age
Sleep phase; decreased activity
Less jerky, less frequent movements
Decline in heart and respiratory rates
Relaxed muscles, diminished response to stimuli
Difficult to arouse; no interest in sucking
Quiet time for mother-newborn rest


Begins as newborn awakens
Lasts 2–8 hours
Increased heart and respiratory rates
Increased peristalsis; possible meconium passage or voiding
Increased motor activity, muscle tone, coordination
Encouraged mother-newborn interaction
Opportunity for parents to bond, ask questions
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Skin Variations
item.description:
Milia: Small white papules on nose and cheeks; clogged sebaceous glands; resolves spontaneously
Erythema toxicum: Red macules with yellow-white papules (flea-bite rash); common in first week; no treatment needed
Mongolian spots: Bluish-gray pigmentation over sacrum/buttocks; common in darker-skinned infants; fades over time
Vernix caseosa: White, cheese-like protective covering; present at birth; absorbs into skin
Lanugo: Fine hair on back, shoulders, face; common in preterm; disappears with age
Acrocyanosis: Blue hands and feet; normal in first 24–48 hours due to immature circulation
Nevus simplex (salmon patch/stork bite): Flat pink/red mark on nape of neck, eyelids, or forehead; blanches; fades with time
Milia: Tiny white bumps; nose, cheeks; due to immature sweat glands; no treatment
Transient pustular melanosis: Superficial pustules that rupture and leave hyperpigmented spots; more common in darker-skinned infants
Harlequin color change: Transient red-to-pale color split; resolves spontaneously
Sebaceous hyperplasia: Small yellowish spots from maternal hormones; resolves spontaneously
Neonatal acne: Papules/pustules on cheeks/forehead; from maternal hormones; resolves without treatment
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Vital Signs
item.description:
Respiratory Rate

30 to 60 breaths per minute.
Periods of apnea less than 15 seconds are normal during REM sleep.
Apnea lasting longer than 15 seconds should be evaluated.
Crackles and wheezing can indicate fluid or infection.
Grunting and nasal flaring suggest respiratory distress.
obligatory nose breathers
Heart Rate

110 to 160 beats per minute.
Brief fluctuations may occur depending on activity (crying, sleeping).
Apical pulse is assessed for 1 full minute at the fourth or fifth intercostal space, left midclavicular line.
Heart murmurs should be documented and reported.
Blood Pressure

60 to 80 mm Hg systolic.
40 to 50 mm Hg diastolic.
Temperature

36.5°C to 37.5°C (97.7°F to 99.5°F).
Average of 37°C (98.6°F).
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cold Stress
item.description:
newborns lose heat faster than they can produce it, leading to hypothermia and metabolic complications
Also called hypothermia in neonates


Evaporation: Wet skin after birth
Conduction: Contact with cold surfaces
Convection: Air movement over skin
Radiation: Heat loss to nearby cold objects


Prematurity (less brown fat, thin skin)
Low birth weight
Prolonged resuscitation
Delivery room cold environment


Hypothermia: Excessive heat loss through evaporation, conduction, convection, and radiation
Lethargy: Decreased metabolic rate and energy availability
Poor feeding: Energy diverted from feeding to maintaining body temperature
Hypoglycemia: Increased glucose consumption to generate heat
Respiratory distress: Increased oxygen demand and metabolic rate to produce heat
Metabolic acidosis: Anaerobic metabolism due to increased energy expenditure leading to lactic acid buildup
Jaundice
Decreased Surfactant production


Hypoglycemia
Metabolic acidosis
Respiratory distress
Increased oxygen consumption leading to hypoxia


Axillary temperature monitoring (<36.5°C)
Blood glucose levels (rule out hypoglycemia)
Blood gases (check for acidosis)


Dry and warm the baby immediately after birth
Skin-to-skin contact (Kangaroo care)
Radiant warmer or incubator
Warmed IV fluids if needed
Monitor glucose levels


Maintain neutral thermal environment
Educate parents on keeping baby warm
Monitor for signs of cold stress and hypoglycemia
Avoid exposing baby to drafts or cold surfaces
Implement early feeding to prevent hypoglycemia
Remember: Cold stress increases oxygen consumption → respiratory distress → hypoxia (NCLEX Tip)
Clinical Pearl: "Keep the baby warm, feed early, and monitor closely."


Avoiding the placement of a skin temperature probe over a bony area or one with brown fat => does not give an accurate assessment
each parents to keep the baby warm using skin-to-skin contact, warm clothing, and blankets
Instruct on avoiding exposure to cold air, drafts, and cold surfaces
Explain the importance of feeding early and regularly to maintain energy stores
Show how to check baby's temperature (axillary) and recognize signs of cold stress (cool skin, lethargy, poor feeding)
Emphasize the need to report any symptoms like excessive sleepiness, poor feeding, or rapid breathing
Reinforce that preventing cold stress reduces risk of hypoglycemia and respiratory distress
Provide guidance on maintaining a warm environment during bathing and diaper changes
Review safe sleep practices: room temperature (avoid overheating but prevent cold stress)
Encourage use of hats and warm wraps especially in colder climates
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Erb's Palsy
item.description:
aka Erb-Duchenne Paralysis (Erb’s Palsy)

Paralysis of upper brachial plexus (C5–C6)
Caused by traction injury during birth
Results in characteristic arm weakness and positioning
Most common type of neonatal brachial plexus injury


Shoulder Distocia during vaginal delivery
Excessive lateral traction on the head/neck during birth
Breech delivery with arm extended
Trauma or traction to brachial plexus outside birth (less common)


Macrosomia
Prolonged second stage of labor
Instrumental delivery (forceps, vacuum)
Maternal diabetes
Shoulder dystocia history


Affected arm hangs limp and internally rotated
Elbow extended, forearm pronated ("waiter's tip" position)
Absent Moro reflex on affected side
Intact grasp reflex
Decreased or absent biceps and brachioradialis reflexes


Permanent motor deficits if not resolved
Muscle atrophy or joint contractures
Limb length discrepancy
Functional impairment in severe or untreated cases


Clinical diagnosis based on physical findings
MRI or nerve conduction studies if persistent beyond 3–6 months
Rule out fractures or clavicle injury


Passive range of motion exercises
Physical and occupational therapy
Surgical nerve grafting or transfer if no improvement by 3–6 months
Splinting may be used early to prevent contractures


Handle affected arm gently; avoid traction or overextension
Educate parents on passive ROM and splint care
Monitor motor improvement and reflex recovery
Encourage bonding and normal developmental activities
Collaborate with PT/OT for early intervention


Explain typical prognosis (most recover by 3–6 months)
Teach safe handling and positioning of infant
Emphasize importance of therapy adherence
Report signs of worsening function or lack of improvement
Provide emotional support and referral to early intervention if needed
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Intraventricular Hemorrhage
item.description:
Bleeding into the brain’s ventricular system, common in preterm infants
Often originates from germinal matrix due to fragile vasculature


Prematurity: fragile capillaries in germinal matrix
Hypoxic-ischemic injury
Rapid changes in cerebral blood flow
Mechanical ventilation


Birth <32 weeks gestation
Very low birth weight (<1500g)
Respiratory distress syndrome
Fluctuating cerebral blood flow (e.g., rapid volume expansion)


Asymptomatic (mild cases)
Sudden apnea, bradycardia
Lethargy, hypotonia
Bulging fontanel, seizures
Anemia


Hydrocephalus
Cerebral palsy
Developmental delay
Seizure disorders


Cranial ultrasound (preferred)
CT or MRI for detailed evaluation


Supportive care: manage oxygenation, ventilation, and perfusion
Monitor for hydrocephalus (serial head circumference)
Neurosurgical intervention for hydrocephalus (ventriculoperitoneal shunt)


Monitor head circumference and fontanels
Minimize handling to reduce stress and fluctuations in cerebral blood flow
Maintain neutral head position to optimize venous drainage
Educate parents on long-term developmental monitoring
Provide emotional support and counseling regarding prognosis and outcomes
Clinical Pearl: Keep oxygenation and perfusion stable to prevent further bleeding
NCLEX Tip: Preemies at highest risk due to fragile germinal matrix; watch for bulging fontanel and sudden neurologic changes
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Meconium Aspiration Syndrome
item.description:
Inhalation of meconium-stained amniotic fluid during or before birth
Causes airway obstruction, chemical pneumonitis, and surfactant dysfunction
Common cause of respiratory distress in term and post-term newborns
Surfactant is a phospholipid that assists in alveoli expansion. Surfactant keeps alveoli from collapsing and allows gas exchange to occur.


Meconium passage in utero (due to fetal distress or hypoxia)
Gasps in utero or during delivery → aspiration of meconium


Post-term pregnancy (>42 weeks)
Fetal distress (hypoxia, cord compression)
Maternal hypertension or diabetes
Prolonged labor or difficult delivery


Respiratory distress: tachypnea, grunting, nasal flaring, retractions
Cyanosis, decreased breath sounds, coarse crackles
Barrel-shaped chest from overinflation
Meconium-stained skin, nails, or umbilical cord


Airway obstruction → hypoxia
Pneumothorax or pneumomediastinum
Persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN)
Severe respiratory failure, death


History of meconium-stained amniotic fluid
Chest x-ray: patchy infiltrates, hyperinflation, flattened diaphragm
Blood gases: hypoxemia, respiratory acidosis
Clinical presentation


Suction only if visible meconium in airway and baby is non-vigorous
Oxygen therapy, mechanical ventilation as needed
Surfactant therapy to reduce surface tension
Beractant, calfactant, lucinactant
Nitric oxide or ECMO for severe cases with PPHN
Antibiotics if infection is suspected


Monitor respiratory status closely (rate, effort, oxygen saturation)
Prepare for possible intubation and ventilation
Maintain neutral thermal environment
Provide parental education and emotional support
Administer oxygen cautiously to avoid oxygen toxicity
Monitor for signs of PPHN and pneumothorax
Document all assessments and interventions accurately
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: NEC
item.description:
Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC) in Neonates

Acute inflammatory disease causing intestinal necrosis
Primarily affects preterm and low birth weight neonates
Most common GI emergency in neonates


Ischemia and hypoxia → mucosal injury
Bacterial colonization of sterile gut
Enteral feeding (especially formula) triggers inflammation


Prematurity (underdeveloped gut and immune system)
Formula feeding (vs. breast milk)
Hypoxia or perinatal asphyxia
Patent ductus arteriosus, sepsis, or hypotension
Prolonged antibiotic use
Intestinal ischemia (e.g., from Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Newborn or heart defects)


Abdominal distention and tenderness
Bloody stools or hemoccult-positive stools
Feeding intolerance, vomiting (may be bilious)
Lethargy, temperature instability, apnea
Decreased bowel sounds


Bowel perforation → peritonitis, sepsis
Short bowel syndrome if resection is needed
Strictures, abscesses
Death if not promptly treated


Abdominal X-ray: pneumatosis intestinalis (air in bowel wall)
CBC: leukocytosis or leukopenia, thrombocytopenia
Blood cultures (r/o sepsis)
Electrolyte imbalances
C-reactive protein ↑


NPO (bowel rest), IV fluids, TPN
Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics
Nasogastric decompression
Serial abdominal X-rays and labs
Surgery if perforation or necrosis present


Monitor abdominal girth every shift
Assess for bloody stools, emesis, or signs of sepsis
Maintain strict NPO status if suspected
Support thermoregulation and oxygenation
Prepare for possible surgical intervention
Minimize stress and handling
Educate parents on signs of NEC and long-term risks


Encourage breast milk feeding (protective antibodies)
Report feeding intolerance, abdominal swelling, or bloody stools
Stress importance of follow-up care if discharged after NEC
Explain potential long-term GI complications
Provide emotional support due to high morbidity
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Pathologic Jaundice in Newborns
item.description:
Jaundice (yellow discoloration of skin and sclera) in a newborn that is not benign physiological jaundice.
Characterized by early onset (within the first 24 hours of life), rapid rise in bilirubin levels, very high total serum bilirubin (TSB) levels, or prolonged duration.
Indicates an underlying pathological condition.
NOTE DIFFERENCE between: Physiological Jaundice of the Newborn => occurs after 24 HOURS


Hemolysis:
Blood group incompatibility (most common): ABO incompatibility (mother O, baby A or B), Rh incompatibility (mother Rh-, baby Rh+).
G6PD deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (enzyme deficiency in red blood cells leading to hemolysis).
Other red blood cell abnormalities: Hereditary spherocytosis, alpha-thalassemia.
Extravasated blood: Cephalohematoma, significant bruising, intracranial hemorrhage (breakdown of blood increases bilirubin load).
Infection: Sepsis, TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other [syphilis, varicella, parvovirus], Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, Herpes simplex virus).
Liver disease/Biliary Obstruction: Biliary atresia, choledochal cyst, neonatal hepatitis, metabolic disorders (e.g., galactosemia, alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency).
Increased enterohepatic circulation: Pyloric stenosis, bowel obstruction.
Hypothyroidism.
Crigler-Najjar syndrome, Gilbert syndrome (rare genetic conditions affecting bilirubin metabolism).


Jaundice appearing within the first 24 hours of life.
TSB levels increasing rapidly (e.g., per day).
TSB levels higher than expected for age in hours on a nomogram.
Prolonged jaundice (persisting weeks in term infants, weeks in preterm infants).
Signs of underlying illness (lethargy, poor feeding, dark urine, pale stools).
Positive family history of hemolytic disease.
Exclusive breastfeeding with poor intake/weight loss.
Prematurity (immature liver, less efficient bilirubin excretion).
East Asian ethnicity.
Sibling who had significant jaundice requiring treatment.


Yellowing of skin and sclera: Appears within 24 hours of birth, may be intense or spread rapidly (cephalocaudal progression).
Other symptoms indicating underlying pathology or complications:
Dark urine (cola-colored) or pale/acholic (clay-colored) stools (suggestive of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or biliary obstruction).
Lethargy, poor feeding, irritability, high-pitched cry.
Fever.
Vomiting.
Hypo/hypertonia, arching of the back (opisthotonus) - signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy.
Seizures.


Acute Bilirubin Encephalopathy (ABE): Bilirubin crosses the blood-brain barrier and is toxic to brain cells. Early signs: lethargy, poor feeding, high-pitched cry, hypotonia.
Kernicterus (Chronic Bilirubin Encephalopathy): Irreversible brain damage resulting from prolonged exposure to high bilirubin levels. Can lead to:
Athetoid cerebral palsy (involuntary, uncontrolled movements).
Permanent upward gaze.
Hearing loss.
Enamel dysplasia of teeth.
Intellectual disability.
Anemia (from hemolysis).
Liver damage (if underlying liver disease).


Total Serum Bilirubin (TSB) and Conjugated/Direct Bilirubin levels:
TSB percentile for age in hours on a nomogram.
Jaundice within 24 hours of life is always pathologic.
Direct bilirubin or of TSB is always pathologic and requires immediate workup for cholestasis/liver disease.
Blood type and Coombs test (direct and indirect): To check for ABO/Rh incompatibility.
CBC with differential and reticulocyte count: To assess for anemia and hemolysis.
G6PD screen.
Liver function tests (LFTs).
Thyroid function tests (TFTs).
Urine for reducing substances, cultures (blood, urine, CSF) if infection suspected.
Abdominal ultrasound: If biliary atresia or other structural liver/biliary abnormalities suspected.


Phototherapy: Uses blue-green light to convert unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers that can be excreted.
Intensity and duration depend on TSB level, age, and risk factors.
May involve single, double, or triple phototherapy.
Exchange Transfusion: Used for extremely high TSB levels, rapid rise despite phototherapy, or signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy. Involves removing small amounts of infant's blood and replacing with donor blood to quickly lower bilirubin and remove antibodies.
Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): May be used in immune-mediated hemolytic jaundice (e.g., ABO/Rh incompatibility) to reduce antibody-mediated hemolysis and decrease need for exchange transfusion.
Treat underlying cause:
Antibiotics for sepsis.
Surgery for biliary atresia.
Specific treatments for metabolic disorders.
Hydration: Ensure adequate fluid intake (oral or IV) to promote bilirubin excretion.


Monitoring:
Frequent TSB levels: As ordered, plot on nomogram.
Vital signs: Especially temperature (phototherapy can cause hyperthermia) and respiratory rate.
Hydration status: Assess for signs of dehydration (urine output, fontanelles, skin turgor, weight loss).
Feeding patterns: Ensure adequate intake to promote bowel movements.
Neurological status: Monitor for signs of acute bilirubin encephalopathy (lethargy, poor feeding, high-pitched cry, abnormal tone, seizures).
Phototherapy Care:
Maximize skin exposure: Undress infant (diaper only), ensure maximum surface area exposure to light.
Eye protection: Apply opaque eye patches to prevent retinal damage.
Reposition frequently: To expose all skin surfaces to light.
Maintain thermoregulation: Use radiant warmer/isolette, monitor temperature closely.
Increase fluid intake: Offer frequent feedings or IV fluids to prevent dehydration from increased insensible water loss and promote bilirubin excretion.
Skin integrity: Monitor for rashes, bronzing baby syndrome (rare side effect with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia).
Parent-infant bonding: Encourage parents to remove baby for brief feeding and cuddling breaks if TSB levels allow; otherwise, encourage touch and presence at bedside.
Education: Provide clear explanations to parents about the condition, treatment, and potential complications.
NCLEX Tip: Jaundice within the first 24 hours is always pathologic and requires immediate investigation.


Causes and Importance: Explain that this type of jaundice is serious and caused by specific underlying problems, needing prompt treatment to prevent brain damage (kernicterus).
Phototherapy:
Explain why it's needed and how it works.
Emphasize importance of eye patches and maximizing skin exposure.
Discuss the need for frequent feedings/hydration.
Reassure about the safety of phototherapy.
Signs to Watch For:
Worsening yellow color (especially palms/soles).
Changes in behavior: lethargy, difficulty waking, poor feeding, high-pitched cry, irritability.
Fever.
Dark urine or pale stools.
Any unusual movements or arching.
NCLEX Tip: Always provide written instructions on when to call the provider after discharge (e.g., specific bilirubin level thresholds, worsening jaundice, behavioral changes).
Follow-up: Stress the critical importance of all follow-up appointments for TSB checks and developmental assessments.
Feeding: Encourage frequent and effective feeding (breastfeeding or formula) to promote bilirubin excretion through stools. May need temporary formula supplementation or IV fluids if intake is poor or levels are very high.
No sunlight for treatment: Emphasize that household lights or direct sunlight are not effective or safe treatments for pathologic jaundice.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Periventricular-Intraventricular Hemorrhage (PIVH)
item.description:
Hemorrhage (bleeding) that occurs in the brain of premature newborns.
Specifically, it involves bleeding into the periventricular (area around the ventricles) and intraventricular (within the ventricles, spaces containing cerebrospinal fluid) regions.
The bleeding originates from the germinal matrix, a highly vascularized and fragile area of the brain found in premature infants, which largely involutes (disappears) by 33-34 weeks gestation.
Graded I to IV based on severity (Papile grading):
Grade I: Hemorrhage confined to the germinal matrix (subependymal).
Grade II: Intraventricular hemorrhage without ventricular dilation.
Grade III: Intraventricular hemorrhage with ventricular dilation (blood fills and expands the ventricles).
Grade IV: Hemorrhage extends into the brain parenchyma (tissue) adjacent to the ventricle (often termed periventricular hemorrhagic infarction).


Fragile Germinal Matrix Vessels: Premature infants have delicate, immature blood vessels in the germinal matrix that are prone to rupture.
Fluctuations in Cerebral Blood Flow (CBF): Premature infants have impaired cerebral autoregulation (ability to maintain stable CBF despite changes in systemic blood pressure). Sudden increases or decreases in systemic blood pressure can lead to rupture of fragile vessels.
Hypoxia-Ischemia: Lack of oxygen or blood flow to the brain can damage vessels.
Reperfusion Injury: After an ischemic event, restoration of blood flow can cause vessel damage and bleeding.


Prematurity: Gestational age weeks (especially extremely low birth weight infants, ).
Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS): Requires mechanical ventilation, which can cause fluctuations in blood pressure and CBF.
Mechanical Ventilation: Especially if unstable (e.g., rapid changes in ventilatory settings).
Perinatal Asphyxia/Hypoxia.
Rapid changes in blood pressure: Hypotension followed by rapid fluid resuscitation or use of vasopressors.
Acidosis.
Pneumothorax.
Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA).
Sepsis/Infection.
Coagulopathy/Bleeding disorders.
Rapid volume expansion.
Umbilical cord clamping delays.
Traumatic delivery.
Maternal factors: Chorioamnionitis, maternal hypertension (some studies).
NCLEX Tip: The more premature the infant, the higher the risk of PIVH.


Often asymptomatic, especially Grade I/II, detected by screening ultrasound.
Acute Deterioration (more common in Grade III/IV, "saltatory" course):
Apnea and bradycardia (sudden onset).
Pallor.
Cyanosis.
Poor muscle tone (hypotonia).
Weak cry, lethargy.
Bulging or tense fontanelle (indicates increased intracranial pressure).
Seizures (focal or generalized).
Decreased reflexes.
Metabolic acidosis.
Drop in hematocrit.
NCLEX Tip: Be alert for sudden, unexplained changes in a preterm infant's neurological status, breathing pattern, or vital signs.


Hydrocephalus (Post-hemorrhagic hydrocephalus): Most common complication, especially with Grade III/IV, due to obstruction of CSF flow by blood clots. Requires ventricular taps or shunt placement.
Periventricular Leukomalacia (PVL): Damage to the white matter, often due to ischemia or infarction near the hemorrhage, leading to motor deficits.
Cerebral Palsy (CP): Especially spastic diplegia (affecting legs more), related to white matter injury.
Neurodevelopmental Impairment: Cognitive deficits, learning disabilities, behavioral problems.
Seizure disorder.
Vision and hearing impairment.
Death: More common with severe (Grade III/IV) hemorrhage.


Cranial Ultrasound (CUS): Primary diagnostic tool. Non-invasive, bedside, highly effective.
Recommended for all infants weeks gestation:
At 7-14 days of life (when most bleeds manifest).
Repeat at 4-6 weeks corrected age, or if clinical signs suggest deterioration.
Earlier screening within the first 72 hours for high-risk infants.
MRI: May be used for more detailed evaluation, especially in later follow-up or if CUS is inconclusive.


No specific treatment to stop the bleeding once it occurs.
Supportive Care (primary focus is prevention and minimizing secondary injury):
Stabilize blood pressure: Avoid wide fluctuations (both hypotension and hypertension).
Respiratory support: Optimize ventilation, minimize hypercapnia or hypocapnia.
Maintain normal acid-base balance.
Minimize handling/stress: Cluster care, gentle movements.
Head in midline position: Avoid neck hyperextension/flexion.
Strict fluid and electrolyte management.
Correct coagulopathies.
Management of Hydrocephalus (if develops):
Serial lumbar punctures/ventricular taps: To remove CSF and reduce pressure.
Ventricular reservoir placement: Temporary measure to drain CSF.
Ventricular-peritoneal (VP) shunt: Surgical insertion of a permanent drain from brain to abdomen for CSF drainage.
Neuroprotection (Prevention):
Antenatal Corticosteroids: Administered to mothers at risk of preterm birth (reduces incidence and severity of PIVH).
Delayed cord clamping: May help stabilize CBF.
Avoidance of rapid intravenous fluid boluses.
Indomethacin (for PDA): May reduce PIVH risk, but controversial.


Prevention: Adhere strictly to prevention protocols for preterm infants (e.g., gentle handling, neutral head position, minimal stimulation, careful fluid management).
Neurological Assessment: Frequent and thorough neurological assessments, looking for subtle changes in tone, activity, reflexes, fontanelle, and cry.
Vital Sign Stability: Meticulous monitoring of HR, BP, RR, SpO2. Report significant fluctuations promptly.
Respiratory Support: Ensure optimal ventilatory settings, minimize suctioning trauma.
Fluid Management: Accurately measure intake and output. Administer fluids and medications precisely.
Head Circumference: Measure daily and plot on a growth chart to detect rapid increases indicative of hydrocephalus.
Clustering Care: Organize care activities to minimize disturbances and allow for longer periods of uninterrupted rest.
Pain Management: Assess for and manage pain/discomfort appropriately.
Parental Support: Provide clear, compassionate communication about the infant's condition, prognosis, and potential long-term outcomes. Encourage bonding and involvement in care.
NCLEX Tip: Any sudden change in neurological status, feeding, or vital signs in a preterm infant should raise immediate suspicion for PIVH or its complications.


Explanation of PIVH: Explain what the bleed is, why it happened (fragile vessels, prematurity), and its potential implications using clear, simple language.
Grading System: Explain the Papile grading (I-IV) and what each grade signifies in terms of severity and potential outcome.
Prognosis: Be honest but hopeful. For Grade I/II, explain good prognosis. For Grade III/IV, discuss potential for hydrocephalus, cerebral palsy, and developmental delays, emphasizing that outcomes vary.
Monitoring: Explain the need for frequent ultrasounds and other tests.
Signs of Complications: Educate parents on signs of increasing head circumference, bulging fontanelle, vomiting, irritability, lethargy, or seizures, and when to seek immediate medical attention.
Long-term Follow-up: Stress the importance of developmental follow-up programs (e.g., NICU follow-up clinic, early intervention services) to monitor and support neurodevelopment.
Home Care: If discharged with a shunt, provide detailed instructions on shunt care and signs of malfunction or infection.
Support Resources: Provide information on support groups or resources for parents of preterm infants or children with special needs.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN)
item.description:
Pulmonary Hypertension (PH) in newborns, most commonly refers to Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN).
PPHN is a condition where the normal drop in pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) at birth fails to occur, or it increases after initially falling.
This results in high blood pressure in the arteries supplying the lungs, leading to reduced blood flow to the lungs for oxygenation.
Deoxygenated blood then bypasses the lungs via fetal shunts (foramen ovale, ductus arteriosus), leading to severe hypoxemia.
It is a failure of the normal circulatory transition from fetal to extrauterine life.


Failure of Normal Circulatory Transition: Pulmonary vessels remain constricted or become constricted after birth.
Underlying Lung Diseases:
Meconium Aspiration Syndrome (MAS) - most common cause.
Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Newborn (RDS) - especially if severe.
Pneumonia or Sepsis.
Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH) - leads to underdeveloped lungs (pulmonary hypoplasia).
Pulmonary Hypoplasia (e.g., due to oligohydramnios).
Maldevelopment of Pulmonary Vasculature: Abnormal structure or number of pulmonary vessels.
Idiopathic PPHN: No clear underlying cause.
In Utero Closure of Ductus Arteriosus.


Perinatal Asphyxia: Lack of oxygen before, during, or after birth.
Meconium Aspiration Syndrome (MAS).
Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS).
Sepsis/Pneumonia.
Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH).
Maternal factors: Diabetes, preeclampsia, chorioamnionitis, maternal obesity, smoking, use of SSRIs or NSAIDs during late pregnancy.
Delivery: Cesarean section (without labor), precipitous delivery.
Fetal factors: Large for gestational age (LGA), small for gestational age (SGA), post-term gestation.
Congenital Heart Defects: Such as transposition of the great arteries.


Signs usually appear within the first 12-72 hours of life.
Severe Hypoxemia: Low oxygen levels despite receiving 100% oxygen.
Labile Oxygenation: Oxygen saturation fluctuates wildly.
Respiratory Distress: Tachypnea (rapid breathing), retractions (subcostal, intercostal), nasal flaring, grunting.
Cyanosis: Bluish discoloration of skin and mucous membranes, may be differential (pink upper body, cyanotic lower body) if ductus arteriosus is open with right-to-left shunt.
Tachycardia.
Hypotension.
Heart Murmur: Due to shunting through patent ductus arteriosus or patent foramen ovale.
Cool extremities.
Poor perfusion.
NCLEX Tip: Persistent hypoxemia despite maximal oxygen support is a hallmark of PPHN.


Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE): Brain damage due to lack of oxygen.
Multi-organ dysfunction: Kidney injury, liver dysfunction.
Pulmonary Hemorrhage.
Barotrauma/Volutrauma: Due to mechanical ventilation (e.g., pneumothorax).
Hearing loss.
Neurodevelopmental Impairment: Learning disabilities, developmental delays, cerebral palsy.
Chronic Lung Disease (Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia).
Death.


Clinical Suspicion: Based on symptoms of respiratory distress and persistent hypoxemia.
Hyperoxia Test: Administering 100% oxygen. If PaO2 remains low, suggests shunting (PPHN or cyanotic heart disease).
Pre- and Post-Ductal Pulse Oximetry: Significant difference () suggests right-to-left shunting across the ductus arteriosus.
Echocardiogram (Cardiac Ultrasound): Definitive diagnosis. Visualizes heart structure, assesses pulmonary artery pressure, identifies shunting (ductus arteriosus, foramen ovale), and assesses right ventricular function.
Chest X-ray: May show underlying lung disease (e.g., MAS, pneumonia) but often appears normal in primary PPHN.
Arterial Blood Gas (ABG): Shows hypoxemia, often with respiratory or metabolic acidosis.


Goal: Reduce PVR, improve oxygenation, support systemic blood pressure.
Supportive Care:
Optimal Thermoregulation: Maintain neutral thermal environment.
Minimize Stimulation/Handling: Cluster care, sedation to reduce agitation and oxygen consumption.
Fluid and Electrolyte Balance: Strict monitoring.
Nutrition: IV fluids or gavage feedings.
Oxygen Therapy: Maintain adequate oxygenation.
Mechanical Ventilation: Often required, carefully managed to avoid lung injury, optimize lung volume, and minimize PVR.
Pharmacological Agents:
Inhaled Nitric Oxide (iNO): First-line specific pulmonary vasodilator. Selectively relaxes pulmonary blood vessels without affecting systemic blood pressure.
Sildenafil (Viagra/Revatio): Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor, used orally or IV to relax pulmonary vessels.
Milrinone: Phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor, improves cardiac contractility and causes pulmonary vasodilation.
Prostaglandins (e.g., Iloprost): Pulmonary vasodilators.
Vasopressors/Inotropes: (e.g., Dopamine, Dobutamine) to maintain systemic blood pressure and cardiac output, ensuring adequate perfusion and preventing shunting.
Surfactant Therapy: If underlying RDS or MAS with surfactant deficiency.
Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO): Cardiopulmonary bypass used for severe, refractory PPHN when maximal conventional therapy fails.


Continuous Monitoring: Intensive care setting. Continuous monitoring of HR, BP, RR, SpO2 (pre- and post-ductal). Arterial line for continuous BP and ABG sampling.
Respiratory Management: Meticulous ventilator management. Avoid sudden changes in settings. Frequent assessment for air leaks (pneumothorax).
Fluid and Electrolyte Balance: Strict I&O, monitor electrolytes, acid-base status.
Medication Administration: Administer iNO (requires special equipment/monitoring), vasodilators, inotropes, and sedatives precisely. Monitor for desired effects and adverse reactions (e.g., hypotension with vasodilators).
Minimize Stimulation: Create a quiet, dark environment. Cluster care, handle gently, avoid unnecessary procedures. Sedation often used.
Thermoregulation: Maintain normothermia to minimize oxygen consumption.
Neuroprotection: Monitor for signs of HIE.
Parental Support: This is a critical illness. Provide consistent updates, answer questions honestly, facilitate bonding, and offer emotional support and resources.
NCLEX Tip: Prioritize oxygenation and ventilation, followed by maintaining systemic blood pressure and reducing pulmonary vascular resistance. Recognize signs of deterioration quickly.


Explanation of PPHN: Explain the condition simply – that the blood vessels in the lungs are too tight, making it hard for the baby to get enough oxygen.
Causes and Risk Factors: Discuss why their baby might have developed PPHN (e.g., MAS, premature birth, C-section).
Treatment Plan: Detail the various treatments (oxygen, ventilation, iNO, other medications), explaining their purpose and what to expect (e.g., baby will be on a breathing machine, may need special IVs).
Critical Care: Explain the need for intensive monitoring and the equipment in the NICU.
Prognosis and Complications: Be honest about the severity of the condition, potential for long-term complications (brain injury, hearing loss, developmental delays), but also offer hope and emphasize the importance of early intervention and follow-up.
Parental Role: Explain how parents can help (e.g., minimizing stimulation, talking gently, touch).
Long-term Follow-up: Stress the importance of developmental follow-up clinics, early intervention services, and hearing screenings for neurodevelopmental monitoring.
NCLEX Tip: Reassure parents that PPHN is not their fault and provide them with clear, consistent information to reduce anxiety.

item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Physiological Jaundice of the Newborn
item.description:
Benign, common, and transient yellow discoloration of the skin and sclera in newborns due to elevated unconjugated (indirect) bilirubin levels.
Occurs in most newborns as part of normal physiological adaptation after birth.
Typically appears after 24 hours of life, peaks at 3-5 days, and resolves within 1-2 weeks.
NOTE: difference in Pathologic Jaundice in Newborns => appears WITHIN 24 hours


Increased Bilirubin Production:
High red blood cell (RBC) volume in newborns.
Shorter lifespan of fetal RBCs (approx. 70-90 days vs. 120 days in adults).
Increased breakdown of RBCs (hemolysis) releasing bilirubin.
Impaired Bilirubin Conjugation:
Immature neonatal liver has lower levels and activity of UDP-glucuronyl transferase (UGT), the enzyme responsible for conjugating bilirubin.
Increased Enterohepatic Circulation:
Higher levels of beta-glucuronidase in the neonatal gut, which deconjugates bilirubin in the intestines.
Slower gut motility and less frequent stools in newborns mean more unconjugated bilirubin is reabsorbed into circulation.


Breastfeeding (Breastfeeding Jaundice/Breast Milk Jaundice):
Breastfeeding Jaundice (Early-onset): Due to insufficient milk intake, leading to dehydration and increased enterohepatic circulation. Occurs in the first week.
Breast Milk Jaundice (Late-onset): Due to substances in breast milk (e.g., glucuronidase) that interfere with bilirubin conjugation or increase enterohepatic circulation. Can last for several weeks or months.
Prematurity (even late preterm, 34-36 weeks).
East Asian ethnicity.
Family history of physiologic jaundice.
Maternal diabetes.
Male gender.
Polycythemia.
History of cephalohematoma or significant bruising.


Yellowing of skin and sclera: Typically visible when total serum bilirubin (TSB) levels reach .
Appears after 24 hours of life.
Progression is usually cephalocaudal (starts on face, progresses to trunk and extremities).
Jaundice typically resolves spontaneously within 1-2 weeks in term infants.
Infant usually appears otherwise healthy, feeding well, and active.
NCLEX Tip: Differentiating between physiologic and pathologic jaundice is crucial. Remember: physiologic jaundice never appears in the first 24 hours of life.


Generally no complications as it's a benign process.
Untreated severe hyperbilirubinemia (even if initially physiologic) can become pathologic and lead to:
Acute bilirubin encephalopathy.
Kernicterus (chronic bilirubin encephalopathy) - permanent neurological damage. This happens when bilirubin levels are excessively high and toxic to the brain.


Clinical assessment: Visual inspection (blanch skin to check for yellowing), typically done every 8-12 hours in the first few days.
Transcutaneous Bilirubin (TcB) measurement: Non-invasive device used for screening. If TcB is high, a TSB (Total Serum Bilirubin) blood test is performed.
Total Serum Bilirubin (TSB) measurement: Blood test is the gold standard.
Levels are plotted on a nomogram based on the infant's age in hours to assess risk for hyperbilirubinemia.
Assessment of feeding and hydration.
Rule out pathologic causes: If jaundice is severe, early onset, or persists, further investigation is needed (e.g., direct Coombs test, blood type, CBC, direct bilirubin).


No specific treatment often required: Many infants with physiologic jaundice do not need intervention beyond monitoring.
Frequent and effective feedings:
Breastfed infants: Nurse times in 24 hours to promote bilirubin excretion through stools and ensure adequate hydration. Avoid water or dextrose water supplementation.
Formula-fed infants: Ensure adequate intake.
Phototherapy: If TSB levels cross specific thresholds on the nomogram for the infant's age and risk factors.
Blue-green light converts unconjugated bilirubin into water-soluble isomers for excretion.
Discontinuation of breastfeeding (temporarily): Rarely indicated for breast milk jaundice if bilirubin levels are dangerously high and other measures fail. Mother can pump to maintain supply.


Assessment:
Visual assessment for jaundice: Check skin color (blanching on forehead/nose), sclera. Note progression.
Feeding assessment: Observe latch, suck, swallow, and number of wet diapers/stools. Promote effective feeding.
Hydration status: Assess fontanelles, skin turgor, mucous membranes.
Vital signs: Especially temperature (phototherapy can cause hyperthermia).
Monitoring:
Bilirubin levels: Track TcB/TSB results and plot on nomogram.
Weight: Monitor for excessive weight loss.
Output: Document number of wet diapers and stools.
Patient Education:
Explain physiologic jaundice as a normal process.
Teach parents how to assess for jaundice and when to seek medical attention.
Emphasize the importance of frequent feedings and adequate hydration.
Phototherapy Care (if needed):
Maximize skin exposure (diaper only).
Apply eye patches.
Monitor temperature closely.
Ensure adequate fluid intake.
Promote parent-infant bonding during breaks.
NCLEX Tip: Focus on education and supportive measures. Early and effective feeding is key in preventing severe physiologic jaundice.


Normal vs. concerning jaundice: Explain that mild yellowing after 24 hours is common and usually resolves, but explain signs that warrant concern.
Monitoring at home: Teach parents how to check for jaundice (blanching skin) and how far it has progressed.
Feeding is key: Emphasize the importance of frequent (8-12 times/day) and effective feedings to help baby pass bilirubin in stools.
Warning signs to call the provider:
Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours of life.
Jaundice spreads rapidly or appears very deep yellow/orange.
Baby is difficult to wake, not feeding well, excessively sleepy, irritable, has a high-pitched cry.
Fewer wet diapers or stools than expected.
Fever.
No home remedies: Advise against using using sunlight or other unproven methods for treating jaundice, as they are ineffective and potentially harmful.
Follow-up: Stress the importance of all scheduled bilirubin checks and well-baby visits.
