item.title: Post-Mature
item.description:
Newborn born after 42 weeks gestation (post-term)
At risk for complications due to aging placenta


True post-term pregnancy (>42 weeks)
Unknown triggers; may involve placental factors or fetal genetics


First pregnancy
Prior post-term pregnancy
Maternal obesity
Male fetus


Dry, cracked, peeling skin
Overgrown nails
Abundant scalp hair
Little or no vernix (Vernix caseosa, also known as vernix, is the waxy white substance found coating the skin of newborn human babies)
Meconium-stained skin and nails
Long, thin body with decreased subcutaneous fat
Alert, wide-eyed appearance
Signs of placental insufficiency (oligohydramnios, hypoglycemia, meconium aspiration risk)


Meconium aspiration syndrome
Hypoglycemia due to depleted glycogen stores
Polycythemia from chronic hypoxia
Birth trauma (macrosomia)
Hypothermia from decreased fat
Neonatal asphyxia due to placental aging


Gestational age assessment (Ballard score)
Amniotic fluid volume (decreased in post-maturity)
Monitor for meconium in amniotic fluid


Close monitoring during labor (NST, biophysical profile)
Induction of labor if risk factors present
Early detection of fetal distress
Manage complications promptly (e.g., glucose for hypoglycemia)


Monitor glucose levels regularly (risk of hypoglycemia)
Watch for signs of meconium aspiration (tachypnea, cyanosis, grunting)
Maintain neutral thermal environment (prevent hypothermia)
Monitor oxygenation and support respiratory function
Educate parents about increased risk and monitoring needs
Document signs of post-maturity and interventions
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Newborn
item.description:
Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also called hyaline membrane disease
Common cause of respiratory distress in preterm newborns
Due to insufficient surfactant production leading to alveolar collapse


Prematurity (before 34 weeks) → immature lungs, low surfactant
Maternal diabetes → delayed surfactant synthesis
Perinatal asphyxia → surfactant inactivation


Prematurity (most significant)
Maternal diabetes mellitus
Cesarean delivery without labor
Male infants
Second-born twin


Tachypnea (>60 breaths/min)
Nasal flaring, grunting, intercostal/substernal retractions
Cyanosis, decreased breath sounds
Hypoxia and respiratory acidosis
Ground-glass appearance on chest x-ray


Hypoxia → organ damage
Pneumothorax (air leak)
Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) with prolonged oxygen use
Intraventricular hemorrhage


Chest x-ray: ground-glass opacities, air bronchograms
Blood gases: hypoxemia, respiratory acidosis
Clinical signs + risk factors


Antenatal corticosteroids (betamethasone) to promote surfactant production if preterm delivery expected
Exogenous surfactant administration via ET tube after birth
Oxygen therapy (careful to avoid oxygen toxicity)
CPAP or mechanical ventilation as needed
Maintain neutral thermal environment


Monitor respiratory rate, effort, and oxygen saturation
Provide supplemental oxygen, titrate to avoid hyperoxia
Maintain warmth and minimize handling
Educate parents about prematurity and RDS treatment
Monitor for signs of complications (pneumothorax, BPD)
Administer medications as ordered (surfactant, corticosteroids)
Encourage kangaroo care if stable
Mnemonic for RDS risk factors: "Premature Males Can Die"

Prematurity, Male, Cesarean, Diabetes
NCLEX Tip: RDS is due to surfactant deficiency; exogenous surfactant and respiratory support are key interventions.

item.guid: OB/v. Newborn/Complications/Respiratory Distress Syndrome in Newborn.md

item.title: Transient Tachypnea of the Newborn
item.description:
Self-limiting respiratory condition in newborns characterized by rapid breathing shortly after birth.
Caused by delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid.
Also known as "wet lung" or "Type II RDS."


Delayed Clearance of Fetal Lung Fluid: During vaginal birth, the thoracic squeeze helps expel fluid from the lungs. In TTN, this mechanism is impaired or incomplete.
Commonly seen in:
C-section births (especially elective, without labor).
Rapid vaginal births.
Infants of diabetic mothers.
Late preterm infants (34-36 weeks gestation).


Cesarean section delivery (especially without labor onset).
Preterm or late preterm birth (34-36 weeks gestation).
Macrosomia (large-for-gestational-age infant).
Maternal diabetes.
Male gender.
Perinatal asphyxia.
Maternal asthma.


Tachypnea: Respiratory rate often breaths/minute (can be breaths/minute).
Retractions: Subcostal, intercostal, or xiphoid retractions.
Nasal flaring.
Grunting: Audible expiratory grunt.
Cyanosis: Mild perioral or circumoral cyanosis, or central cyanosis (if severe).
Increased anteroposterior diameter of the chest.
Symptoms usually appear within the first few hours of birth and resolve within 24-72 hours.


Generally benign and self-limiting.
Rarely, severe cases may lead to:
Pulmonary hypertension (due to persistent high pulmonary vascular resistance).
Pneumothorax (rare).
Aspiration (if fed orally while tachypneic).
Hypoxia requiring prolonged respiratory support.


Clinical presentation: Based on the characteristic signs of respiratory distress appearing shortly after birth and rapid improvement.
Chest X-ray:
Classic findings: Prominent perihilar streaking, fluid in the fissures, hyperexpansion, flattened diaphragms, possible cardiomegaly.
Differs from RDS (Hyaline Membrane Disease) which shows diffuse ground-glass appearance and air bronchograms.
Blood gas: May show mild hypoxemia.
Rule out other causes: Important to differentiate from more serious conditions like sepsis, pneumonia, or respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).


Supportive Care:
Oxygen therapy: Humidified oxygen via nasal cannula or oxygen hood to maintain SpO2 .
Nasal CPAP: Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) may be used for persistent hypoxemia or significant retractions.
Thermoregulation: Maintain neutral thermal environment to minimize oxygen consumption.
Nutritional support: IV fluids until respiratory status improves enough for oral feedings to prevent aspiration. Gavage feedings may be used.
Monitoring: Continuous pulse oximetry, respiratory rate and effort.
Antibiotics: May be initiated empirically if sepsis cannot be immediately ruled out, especially if risk factors for infection are present. Discontinued if cultures are negative.


Respiratory Assessment: Frequent and thorough assessment of respiratory rate, effort, presence of retractions, grunting, nasal flaring, and cyanosis.
Oxygen Administration: Ensure proper setup and monitoring of oxygen delivery.
Thermoregulation: Keep infant warm to prevent cold stress, which increases oxygen demand.
Hydration/Nutrition: Administer IV fluids as prescribed. Withhold oral feedings if respiratory rate is high () to prevent aspiration; initiate gavage feedings.
Positioning: Head of bed slightly elevated, or "sniffing" position to optimize airway.
Parental Support: Explain the condition to parents, reassuring them it is usually temporary and self-limiting. Educate on signs of worsening distress.
Differentiation: Be vigilant for signs that might indicate a more serious underlying condition.
NCLEX Tip: Remember "Too Tired to Nourish": Infants with TTN are often too tachypneic to safely breastfeed or bottle-feed, necessitating gavage feeding or IV fluids.


Nature of TTN: Explain that it's a temporary condition due to "wet lungs" that usually resolves quickly.
Symptoms: Describe the symptoms observed (fast breathing, grunting) and why the baby needs monitoring.
Treatment: Explain the purpose of oxygen, IV fluids, and temporary feeding tubes (if used).
Monitoring: Inform parents about the continuous monitoring of breathing and oxygen levels.
Reassurance: Emphasize that most babies recover fully without long-term problems.
Expected Course: Explain that symptoms typically improve within 24-72 hours.
When to Call: Educate parents on signs of respiratory distress to watch for after discharge.

item.title: Spina Bifida Occulta
item.description:
Mildest form of neural tube defect
Incomplete fusion of vertebral arch without protrusion of spinal cord or meninges
Often found at lumbosacral area, typically asymptomatic
Covered by skin, may have visible skin markers


Failure of neural tube closure during 3rd to 4th week of embryonic development
Genetic predisposition
Folate (vitamin B9) deficiency during pregnancy
Environmental exposures like anti-seizure meds (valproate, carbamazepine)


Maternal folate deficiency
Family history of neural tube defects
Maternal diabetes or obesity
Use of teratogenic medications in early pregnancy


Often asymptomatic at birth
Cutaneous signs over lower spine (tuft of hair, dimple, lipoma, hemangioma)
Rarely associated with subtle motor or bladder issues
No external sac or bulge


Tethered cord syndrome (may develop later in life)
Bladder or bowel dysfunction
Lower limb weakness or sensory deficits in rare cases
Orthopedic problems like foot deformities (late-onset)


Prenatal ultrasound may miss occulta type
Postnatal diagnosis via physical exam and spinal ultrasound or MRI
X-ray may show vertebral arch defect
MRI confirms occult spinal dysraphism if symptoms present


Usually no treatment if asymptomatic
Neurosurgical evaluation if neurologic symptoms or tethered cord suspected
Ongoing monitoring for late-onset complications
Family reassurance and education


Assess for skin markers over lumbosacral spine
Monitor for changes in bowel, bladder, or lower extremity function
Educate parents on signs of tethered cord (e.g., gait changes, incontinence)
Support parental concerns and provide genetic counseling if needed


Most cases are benign and require no intervention
Teach importance of routine monitoring for neuro or urologic symptoms
Emphasize prenatal folic acid supplementation (400–800 mcg/day)
Reassure that condition is often stable and non-progressive
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Newborn Behavior
item.description:
Characteristics: Alert, active, hungry appearance; myoclonic eye movements, Moro reflexes, sucking/rooting, fine tremors.
Physiology: Elevated heart/respiratory rates, increased muscle tone.
Significance: Ideal for initial parent-newborn interaction and initiating breastfeeding.


Characteristics: Sleep phase, decreased activity, relaxed muscles, diminished responsiveness.
Physiology: Declining heart/respiratory rates.
Significance: Quiet time for rest for both mother and newborn; difficult to arouse or feed.


Characteristics: Awakens, interested in stimuli, increased motor activity and coordination.
Physiology: Increased heart/respiratory rates, increased peristalsis (may pass meconium/void).
Significance: Good for continued parent-newborn interaction, examination, and questions.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Cycle of Violence Against Women
item.description:
Phase 1: Tension Building – Victim walks on eggshells, internalizes blame to prevent violence.

Phase 2: Physically Abusive Phase – Violence erupts; victim minimizes harm and avoids care.

Phase 3: Honeymoon – Abuser apologizes; victim clings to hope and feels responsible.
Phases of Rape Victims

Acute phase (disorganization) – Overwhelmed by shock, fear, and intense emotional distress.

Outward adjustment phase (denial) – Appears stable but suppresses trauma and avoids help.

Reorganization – Struggles resurface, survivor seeks change and emotional distance.

Integration and recovery – Regains trust, feels empowered, may support others.

item.description:
#nursing #pediatrics
#nursing #pediatrics
asdsad

item.title: Analgesia
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing

Prototype Drugs:

Acetaminophen
NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen, aspirin) (see also Antipyretic and Anti-Inflammatory)
Mechanism of Action (MOI):

Acetaminophen: Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes in the brain, reducing pain and fever.
NSAIDs: Inhibit COX enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), blocking the formation of prostaglandins, reducing inflammation, pain, and fever.
Indications:

Mild to moderate pain (headache, muscle pain, arthritis)
Fever reduction
Inflammatory pain (NSAIDs)
Contraindications:

Acetaminophen: Liver disease, alcohol use, or overdose risk (liver toxicity).
NSAIDs: History of GI ulcers, kidney disease, or bleeding disorders.
Nursing Considerations:

Monitor liver function (acetaminophen) and renal function (NSAIDs).
Educate on avoiding alcohol with acetaminophen to prevent liver damage.
NSAIDs may cause GI upset, ulcers, or bleeding; recommend taking with food.


Prototype Drugs:

Morphine
Hydrocodone
Oxycodone
Fentanyl (patch, IV)
Mechanism of Action (MOI):

Bind to opioid receptors (mu, kappa) in the brain and spinal cord, blocking pain signals and altering the perception of pain.
Indications:

Severe pain (post-surgery, cancer pain, injury)
Acute pain management (short-term)
Palliative care
Contraindications:

Respiratory depression
Acute or severe asthma
Paralytic ileus or bowel obstruction
Caution in elderly, liver, or renal impairment
Nursing Considerations:

Monitor for respiratory depression, sedation, and constipation (side effects).
Administer stool softeners to prevent constipation.
Assess pain level and effectiveness of medication regularly.
Educate on safe use to avoid dependency and overdose.
always have narcan ready


Prototype Drugs:

Gabapentin (for nerve pain)
Amitriptyline (tricyclic antidepressant for pain)
Mechanism of Action (MOI):

Gabapentin: Inhibits excitability of nerve cells, reducing nerve pain (neuropathy).
Amitriptyline: Blocks reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin, modulating pain signals.
Indications:

Neuropathic pain (e.g., diabetic neuropathy, shingles)
Fibromyalgia
Chronic pain syndromes
Contraindications:

Gabapentin: Renal impairment (dose adjustment needed).
Amitriptyline: History of arrhythmias, MAOIs within 14 days, or narrow-angle glaucoma.
Nursing Considerations:

Assess for sedation, dizziness, or confusion (especially in elderly).
Gabapentin may require gradual dose adjustments.
Amitriptyline can cause dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation—monitor for these anticholinergic effects.
Educate on slowly tapering off medications to avoid withdrawal symptoms.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Antipyretic and Anti-Inflammatory
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing
Anti-Inflammatory Drugs

NSAIDS
First line of drugs for mild-moderate inflammation
inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandins
Ibuprofen
Mechanism
treatment of mild to moderate pain, fever, and inflammation.
efficacy is equivalent to that of aspirin and other NSAIDs
Due to inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis
indications include pain associated with chronic musculoskeletal disorders, such as RA and osteoarthritis, headache, dental pain, and dysmenorrhea.
Administration Alerts
Give on empty stomach
Asthma or allergies may have hypersensitivity
Caution: pregnancy. NSAID increases pregnancy risk.
DO NOT USE IN LATE PREGNANCY! (may prematurely close fetal ductus arteriosus)
Adverse Effects
nausea, heartburn, epigastric pain, and dizziness
Serious: GI bleeding, ulceration, and perforation of the stomach or intestines
may cause an increased risk of thrombotic events, MI, and stroke, which can be fatal
Contraindications
for the treatment of perioperative pain in those undergoing coronary artery bypass graft surgery
CKD or hepatic impairment
Corticosteroids - should only be used for 1-3 weeks, then switch to NSAID
Prednisone
Class - anti-inflammatory, corticosteroid
Actions and Uses
allergic and inflammatory disorders
metabolized to an active form, which is also available as a drug called prednisolone
When used for inflammation, duration of therapy is commonly limited to 4 to 10 days.
For long-term therapy, alternate-day dosing is often used, and the dosage is gradually lowered.
occasionally used to terminate acute bronchospasm in patients with asthma and as an antineoplastic drug for patients with certain cancers, such as Hodgkin’s disease, acute leukemia, and lymphomas.
Available in tablet and oral solution forms.
Administration Alerts
Administer with food and do not chew or divide tablets.
Do not use it if signs of a systemic infection are present.
When using the drug for more than 10 days, the dose must be slowly tapered.
May cause fetal harm
Do not use if breastfeeding
Do not stop abruptly! Taper of if used longer than 1-2 weeks
Adrenal insufficiency and crisis may occur with profound hypotension, tachycardia, and other adverse effects if the drug is stopped abruptly.
Adverse Effects
few serious adverse effects.
Long-term therapy may result in Cushing syndrome, a condition that includes hyperglycemia, fat redistribution to the shoulders and face, muscle weakness, bruising, and bones that easily fracture.
Because gastric ulcers may occur with long-term therapy, an antiulcer medication may be prescribed prophylactically. Use with caution in patients with peptic ulcer, ulcerative colitis, or diverticulitis. Mood changes, increased appetite, and weight gain may occur.
Contraindications:
Patients with serious viral, bacterial, fungal, or protozoan infections should not take prednisone.
Antipyretics

Acetaminophen
Class - antipyretic, analgesic, para-aminophenol derivative
Actions and Uses
Reduces fever by direct action at the level of the hypothalamus and dilation of peripheral blood vessels, which enables sweating and dissipation of heat.
has no anti-inflammatory properties; therefore, it is not effective in treating arthritis or pain caused by tissue swelling following injury.
The primary therapeutic is for the treatment of fever in children and for relief of mild to moderate pain when aspirin is contraindicated.
may be combined with opioids - for synergistic dosing
Acetaminophen has no effect on platelet aggregation and does not exhibit cardiotoxicity.
Does not cause GI bleeding or ulcers or cause Reye syndrome in children (unlike NSAIDs)
Administration Alert
Never administer to patients who consume alcohol regularly due to the potential for drug-induced hepatotoxicity.
extreme care must be taken to not duplicate doses by taking several products concurrently
safe for pregnant
Adverse
generally safe, and adverse effects are uncommon at therapeutic doses.
Excessive acetaminophen use, especially when combined with alcohol use, is the number one cause of acute liver failure in the United States.
Chronic ingestion results in neutropenia, pancytopenia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenic purpura, and CKD.
Stevens–Johnson syndrome
Contraindications
Hypersensitivity to acetaminophen or phenacetin and chronic alcohol consumption.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Opioids
item.description:
Opioids are potent analgesics that act on the central nervous system (CNS)
Used for moderate to severe pain management
High risk for dependence, tolerance, and addiction


Acute pain (postoperative, trauma)
Chronic pain (cancer, palliative care)
Severe cough (codeine)
Diarrhea (loperamide)


Bind to opioid receptors (mu, kappa, delta) in the CNS and peripheral nervous system
Inhibit pain signal transmission and alter pain perception
Cause CNS depression, leading to sedation and euphoria


Morphine (strong opioid agonist)
Fentanyl (synthetic opioid, highly potent)
Oxycodone (moderate to strong opioid)
Codeine (mild opioid, antitussive)


Respiratory depression (dose-dependent)
Sedation, dizziness, confusion
Nausea, vomiting, constipation
Urinary retention
Hypotension, bradycardia
Tolerance, dependence, withdrawal symptoms
Pruritus (histamine release)


Respiratory depression, severe asthma or COPD
Head injury (risk of increased intracranial pressure)
Hypotension or shock
Severe liver or kidney impairment
History of substance use disorder


Monitor respiratory rate, hold if RR <12/min
Assess pain level before and after administration
Encourage hydration and fiber intake to prevent constipation
Implement fall precautions due to sedation and dizziness
Educate on proper use, risk of dependence, and avoiding alcohol
Use naloxone (opioid antagonist) for overdose reversal
Gradually taper long-term use to prevent withdrawal symptoms

item.title: Herpes
item.description: Acyclovir
