item.title: Anticoagulants
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing
Note Difference between anticoags vs antiplatelets

Anticoagulants - interfere with clotting cascade
Antiplatelets - inhibit activation of platelets
Anticoags from NurseintheMaking

Anticoagulants
prevent new clots from forming, prevent current clots from getting bigger; not blood thinners!
Uses: DVT, PE, A-Fib, post-op patients
Heparin (LMWH - Low Molecular Weight Heparin: Lovenox - generic enoxaparin)
IV or SQ
Rapid onset, Heparins Happens Fast - great for short term therapy
Monitor:
aPTT (heparin has “P” in it) - Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time - how fast blood clots
“If numbers are high, the patient will die”, if low - clots will grow - must be therapeutic range
Antidote: Protamine Sulfate
Educate: subq 2” from umbilicus, 90deg, do not massage site, bruising/pain is common
Warfarin (Coumadin)
Commonly PO
Slow - hours-day / “Warfarin you have to Wait”
Can be given with Heparin together
Monitor:
INR - International Normalized Ratio - how fast blood clots
“If numbers are high, the patient will die”, if low - clots will grow - must be therapeutic range
Antidote: Vitamin K (during War, Vitamin K KILLS Warfarin!)
Educate:
Be consistent with Vit K intake - green leafy, liver
Know the Difference!
Anticoagulants - interfere with the body's clotting factors (proteins) in the coagulation cascade to prevent clot formation
Uses: prevention of venous thromboembolisms (VTE), deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism, stroke, afib
Antiplatelets - inhibit platelet aggregation (clumping) to prevent the formation of clots in arteries
Uses: prevent heart attacks strokes, and other cardiovascular events related to atherosclerosis
Hemostasis - delicate balance regulated by substances in blood: procoagulants vs anticoagulants

Thromboembolic Disorder - too much clotting (leads to thrombi or emboli)
Coagulation Disorder - too little clotting, leads to excessive bleeding
Thrombocytopenia - decreased platelet production or super platelet destruction
Labs to diagnose bleeding disorder:
prothrombin time (PT)
thrombin time
activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)
in some instances, a bleeding time.
Prefilled Subcutaneous Injection - Enoxaparin

do not expel air bubbles - they make sure that full dose is given
inject med into anterolateral abdominal wall
DO NOT MASSAGE site after injection => can cause bruising & tissue damage with anticoagulants
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Antiplatelets
item.description:
Note Difference between anticoags vs antiplatelets

Anticoagulants - interfere with clotting cascade
Antiplatelets - inhibit activation of platelets


Prevent platelet aggregation to reduce clot formation
Used for stroke, myocardial infarction (MI) prevention, peripheral artery disease (PAD), and after stent placement
Do not dissolve existing clots but prevent new ones from forming


Inhibit platelet activation and aggregation by blocking specific pathways
Common targets: thromboxane A₂, ADP receptors, or glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptors


Aspirin – Irreversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2, reducing thromboxane A₂ production
Clopidogrel (Plavix) – Blocks P2Y₁₂ ADP receptors on platelets, preventing aggregation
Ticagrelor (Brilinta) – Reversible P2Y₁₂ ADP receptor blocker, faster onset than clopidogrel
Abciximab, Eptifibatide, Tirofiban – Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors, used in acute coronary syndromes


Bleeding (GI bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage)
Bruising, easy bleeding (nosebleeds, prolonged bleeding from cuts)
Gastrointestinal irritation, ulcers (aspirin)
Thrombocytopenia (rare but serious)


Active bleeding disorders (e.g., GI ulcers, hemorrhagic stroke)
Severe liver disease
Aspirin allergy (especially in asthma patients)
Recent surgery (risk of excessive bleeding)
Pregnancy (some agents contraindicated, especially in the third trimester)


Monitor for signs of bleeding (bruising, black stools, hematuria)
Educate on avoiding NSAIDs and alcohol (increases bleeding risk)
Assess platelet count and coagulation labs if prolonged therapy
Encourage adherence, especially post-stroke or post-MI
Advise patients to inform healthcare providers before surgery or dental procedures
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Diuretics
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing
Loop Diuretics

Block reabsorption of Sodium and Chlorine in nephron Loop (Henle)
Increase UOP (even with diminished blood flow to kidney)
Where sodium goes, water flows
used to reduce the edema associated with heart failure, hepatic cirrhosis, or CKD
furosemide (Lasix) - furiously gets rid of water!
Uses
HF, HTN, moderate to severe fluid retention
beneficial when cardiac output and renal blood flow are severely diminished.
remove large amounts of excess fluid from the patient in a short period of time
IV: quick relief, 5 minutes onset
Actions
RAPID DIURESIS! The Nuclear bomb of diuretics
See above
Nursing Considerations
Report below normal potassium levels
Caution in infants, pregnant
Administer before 5pm (so patient does not pee all night)
Weigh daily, monitor I’s Os, monitor electrolytes
Increase potassium
Administer slowly! - can cause ototoxicity
Adverse Effects
Dehydration
Thirst, dry mouth, weight loss, HA, hypotension
electrolyte imbalance
Most important: Hypokalemia (can cause dysrhythmia or arrest)
Rare: ototoxicity - check for hearing loss!
Contraindications
Hypersensitivity
anuria, hepatic coma, and severe fluid or electrolyte depletion
Interactions
may diminish the hypoglycemic effects of insulin
Enhance K depleting effect of corticosteroids
Thiazide Diuretics

Largest and most prescribed class of diuretics
Not as strong as loop (entire loop), thiazide (ascending loop only)
hydrochlorothiazide (Microzide) - “hydro” + “chloro” - gets rid of water & sodium chloride (NaCl)
Uses
HTN, edema
Actions
Block reabsorption of NA, CL, and water at DCT
Increase excretion of K, Ca, Mg
Nursing Considerations
Administer before 5pm (so patient does not pee all night)
Weigh daily, monitor I’s Os, monitor electrolytes
Increase potassium
Adverse Effects
Dehydration
HypOkalemia
HypOnatremia
Precipitate gout attacks from hyperuricemia (was in my wife’s NCLEX)
Contraindications
Preeclampsia
Interactions
Potassium Sparing Diuretics

spironolactone (Aldactone) - “spiro” will SPARE your potassium!
Uses
Mild HTN, edema, HF, ascites, nephrotic syndrome
most widely prescribed diuretic for HTN
May need other drugs for severe HTN
WEAK diuretic
Actions
Blocks aldosterone
Excretes water and Na, but retains K!!!
Nursing Considerations
Monitor K
Do not give K supplements
Avoid salt substitutes!
Adverse Effects
HypERkalemia
muscle weakness, fatigue, and bradycardia
Amenorrhea - no menstruation
Gynomastia - men get boobies
Impotence
Contraindications
Severe kidney failure
hyperkalemia
Interactions
Salicylates = increased K
Hyperkalemia - potassium supplements, ACE inhibitors, and angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARBs)
Misc
Osmotic - mannitol (?) - for increased ICP
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Heart Failure
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing
GOAL of HF meds: increase cardiac output, increase O2 to the body
ABCDD - calm heart or low BP/HR. Choose the right tool or right situation!

Aldosterone (ACE/ARB)
BetaBlockers
CCBs
Digoxin
Diuretics


lowers BP only (not HR) (can give for brady!)
ACE, end in “-pril” (lisinopril) = “chill pill” for the heart, (angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor)
Not for pregnant
Monitor for: ACE

Angioedema
Cough
E+ Imbalances (electrolytes => low Na, high K)
ARBS -sartan (losartan, telmisartan) (angiotensin receptor blockers)

“Sartan” = “relax man”. Less workload on the heart, more relaxed blood pressure
diuretic
Hold only if BP is too low

Ends in -olol (metoprolol, propranolol)
Caution: 4 B’s (consistent with sympathetic inhibiting drugs)

Bradycardia & heart blocks (do not give if HR<60)
Bottomed out BP (hypotension)
Breathing - COPD, asthma - contraindicated
Blood sugar masking


C = calms the heart (low BP, low HR) - block movement of Ca, lessening contractility
Very Nice Drugs: Verapamil, Nifedipine, Diltiazam
Do not give if:

Apical pulse < 60
Below 100 SYS, MAP below 60
IV drip: big drops in BP


cardiac glycoside. D for DEEP CONTRACTION.
Increase contractility, decrease HR
second line of meds for HF/AFib due to high risk of toxicity
monitor for serum digoxin & K levels regularly
Do not give if:

Apical pulse < 60
K < 3.5 (risk for dig toxicity)
Dig toxicity (over 2.0) - vision changes, N/V, fatigue, dizzy


K Wasting - furosemide, hydrochlorothiazide
K Retaining - spironolactone
see Diuretics
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hypertension
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing
Same meds as Heart Failure
AABCDD
Drug Choice - Drug Classes for Hypertension - Table 26.3 / ch.26.5
1st Line
ACE-i, ARB
CCB
Thiazide
2nd Line
A/B Blockers, Vasodilators, Direct Renin Inhibitors, Loop and Potassium-sparing Diuretics
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Lipid Disorders
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing
Super Cholesterol Fuckers!!! - Statins, Cholestyramine, Fibrates

Statins - HMG-CoA Reductase Inhibitors
ends in “-statins”, statins are not a cure!
Prototype Drug:
atorvastatin (Lipitor)
Uses
Hyperlipidemia => reduce risk of: MI, stroke
Prevent: ASCVD (patients with dm, smoking, HTN, fam hx heart disease)
Prevent: CAD, stabilize fatty plaques
Actions
inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase
Liver creates less cholesterol
less LDL receptors => ↑ removal of chol.
2 weeks before effects are realized
need approved exercise program and cardiac diet to maximize therapeutic
Contraindications
Liver disease, hypersensitivity, pregnant
Side Effects
Common: GI cramping, diarrhea, constipation
Rare: hepatotoxicity, rhabdo
Nursing Considerations
Monitor liver enzymes : ALT/AST
Monitor rhabdo (creatinine kinase - CK)
Monitor: glucose
No grapefruit, no alcohol
Administer with food, breastfeeding not recommended
Mnemonic: “STAT”
Sore muscles
Toxic liver
Avoid grapefruit + st john’s wort
Take at night
Bile Acid Sequestrants/Resins
Bile acid resins bind to bile acid => excreted feces=> less bile
=> liver uses cholesterol to make more bile => ↓ cholesterol => 🙂
Not used as first-line drug for hyperlipidemia (statins are first line) ch. 23.6
Cause more adverse effects
Interacts with: digoxin and warfarin
Used for patients with contraindications for statins
Sometimes combined with statins
Prototype Drug:
cholestyramine (Prevalite) - “chole” => cholecystitis => gallbladder => bile acid sequestrant
Uses
reduce the risk for serious ASCVD events
Actions
Med binds into bile acid in intestine
not absorbed or metabolized once it enters the intestine;
does not produce any systemic effects.
may take 30 days or longer to produce its maximum effect.
Contraindications
Biliary obstruction (note: gallbladder), hypersensitivity
Drug Interactions:
Do not take: digoxin, tetracyclines, thyroid hormone, statins, thiazide diuretics
Side Effects
Common: constipation, bloating, gas, and nausea that sometimes limit its use.
Interferes with digestion of fats preventing absorption of fat-soluble vitamins - ADEK
I’m ADEK-ted to fatties!
Nursing Considerations
Give other drugs more than 2 hours before or 4 hours after the patient takes this
mix with water! Drink ASAP! Separate with other drugs!
Increase fiber and fluids, use stool softener, exercise
Caution - pregnant
Fibric Acid Drugs - Fibrates
First line of drug for hypertriglyceridemia
Prototype Drug:
gemfibrozil (Lopid)
Uses
For hypertriglyceridemia
LESS EFFECTIVE THAN STATINS at lowering LDL
Action
50% Reduce VLDL, increase in HDL (unknown mechanism per book)
Contraindications
Hepatic impairment
Severe CKD
Gallbladder disease
hypersensitivity
Drug Interactions
May potentiate anticoags
With statins: increase risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis
May increase effect of certain DM drugs, statins, insulin
Adverse Effects
Rare but monitor for: Gallstones, liver function
Common: dyspepsia, diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain
Nursing Considerations
Administer 30 minutes prior to morning and evening meals
Monitor: CBC, CK, LFT, Serum Glucose
Other Drugs:
Ezetimibe (Zetia)
Use
Lower LDL-C
Combined with statins for increased efficacy
Not to be taken with bile acid sequestrants
Action - blocks cholesterol absorption in small intestine
Drawback: body compensates and produces more cholesterol
Most prescribed nonstatin therapy for lowering LDL
Monitor for:
Hepatotoxicity, CK
Niacin - B3
Use
Lower cholesterol
Decrease VLDL, lowers triglycerides
Less effective than statins, more adverse effects
Adverse
Flushing and hot flashes - your face doesn’t look NICE with NIACIN
GI upset, N/D
Nursing Clinical Judgment: Lipid-Lowering Pharmacotherapy
Recognize and Analyze Cues
Evaluate: liver function and lipid studies
Prioritize and Generate Solutions
If possible, take cholesterol meds at night: cholesterol biosynthesis is at its highest.
Take Action
Adverse Effects
Statins - Report muscle tenderness, pain, numbness, or tingling
Bile Acids - Report nausea, heartburn, constipation, straining with passing stool, tarry stool, yellowing of sclera
Fibric Acid drugs - RUQ pain, unusual bleeding/bruising, cramping, change in stool color
Monitor glucose for DM
Lifestyle
Encourage intake of omega-3 and CoQ10- rich foods
For long term therapy, ensure intake of fat soluble vitamins - ADEK, folic acid
Evaluate Outcomes
Med effectiveness
Assess total cholesterol, LDL, HDL
Lipid profilles, LFT, CK, uric acid
Administration
Statins: Take with evening meals; avoid grapefruit/juice to prevent toxicity.
Bile acid sequestrants: Take before meals with fluids; mix powders/granules well. Take other meds 2 hours before or 4 hours after.
Niacin: Take with cold water to reduce flushing. Consider 81-325 mg aspirin 30 minutes before.
Fibric acid drugs: Take with meals.
PCSK9 inhibitors: Administer subcutaneously every 2 weeks.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Biguanides - Metformin
item.description:
Metformin is an oral biguanide hypoglycemic agent primarily used for Diabetes T2 management. It lowers blood glucose levels without causing significant hypoglycemia.
MMM
Mini chance of low sugar
Massive weight gain
Major liver + kidney = toxic


Decreases hepatic glucose production (inhibits gluconeogenesis).
Increases insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues (muscles and fat).
Decreases intestinal glucose absorption.


First-line therapy for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
Used in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) to improve insulin resistance.
May be used off-label for prediabetes to delay progression to T2DM.


Severe renal impairment (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73m²).
Metabolic acidosis (including diabetic ketoacidosis).
Severe liver disease (risk of lactic acidosis).
Heart failure with hypoperfusion.
Alcoholism (increased risk of lactic acidosis).
Use of iodinated contrast dye (hold before and after procedures).


Gastrointestinal distress (nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain).
Lactic acidosis (rare but serious, increased risk in renal/liver impairment).
Vitamin B12 deficiency (long-term use).
Metallic taste (occasionally reported).


Monitor renal function (check eGFR before starting and periodically).
Take with food to reduce GI side effects.
Assess for lactic acidosis (muscle pain, weakness, fatigue, difficulty breathing).
Hold 48 hours before and after contrast dye procedures to prevent acute kidney injury.
Monitor vitamin B12 levels in long-term use to prevent deficiency.
Avoid excessive alcohol intake due to increased risk of lactic acidosis.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: GLP-1
item.description:
Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists are injectable (some oral) antidiabetic agents that mimic incretin hormones, enhancing insulin secretion and lowering blood glucose.

Exenatide (Byetta, Bydureon)
Liraglutide (Victoza, Saxenda – for weight loss)
Semaglutide (Ozempic, Rybelsus – oral form available)
Dulaglutide (Trulicity)
Tirzepatide (Mounjaro – dual GLP-1/GIP agonist, not strictly GLP-1)


Stimulate insulin release from pancreatic beta cells (glucose-dependent).
Inhibit glucagon secretion, reducing hepatic glucose production.
Slow gastric emptying, increasing satiety and promoting weight loss
offer improved efficacy, longer duration of action, and additional benefits like weight loss and cardiovascular protection
some are once a week


Diabetes T2 (T2DM)** (improves glycemic control).
Obesity or overweight with comorbidities (certain GLP-1 agonists approved for weight loss).
Cardiovascular risk reduction (for high-risk T2DM patients).


Personal or family history of medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC).
Multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 2 (MEN2).
Severe gastrointestinal disease (e.g., gastroparesis).
History of pancreatitis (use with caution).


Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (most common, usually improves over time).
Delayed gastric emptying (may affect drug absorption).
Pancreatitis (rare but serious).
Thyroid tumors (animal studies) (black box warning).
Hypoglycemia (when combined with insulin or sulfonylureas).


Monitor GI symptoms, especially nausea and weight loss.
Assess for pancreatitis (severe abdominal pain, vomiting).
Educate on slow eating habits to minimize nausea.
Monitor renal function (some formulations affect hydration status).
Caution with other gastric-emptying drugs (may affect absorption of oral meds).
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Insulin
item.description:
note: give food when insulin peaks (glucose less than 70)
Rapid-acting insulin (e.g., Lispro/Humalog, Aspart/NovoLog)

Onset: 15-30 minutes
Peak: 1–2 hours
Duration: 3–5 hours
Given before meals to control postprandial blood sugar spikes
ASSPART = move you ass, this is fast
REGULAR or SHORT-acting insulin (e.g., Regular insulin, Humulin R, Novolin R)

Onset: 30–60 minutes
Peak: 2–4 hours
Duration: 4-12 hours
Often used in hospital settings for acute control.
Intermediate-acting insulin (e.g., NPH - aka CLOUDY insulin) => N = not fast

Onset: 1–2 hours
Peak: 4–12 hours
Duration: 14-24 hours
slower release, kind of like regular gas, but with a longer burn time => basal control
usually taken twice a day
never IV
Long-acting insulin (e.g., Glargine/Lantus, Detemir)

Onset: 1–2 hours
Peak: No pronounced peak
Duration: Up to 24 hours
Provides basal insulin coverage, typically administered once daily.
Premixed insulin

A combination of short or rapid-acting and intermediate-acting insulins.
Given for those who require both rapid and basal control with fewer injections.


commonly mixed: NPH (intermediate) and Regular (short acting)
ROLL THE VIAL for CLOUDY - do not shake
clean with alcohol swab
Lantus cannot be mixed with anything
NR-RN: I am NOT RETIRED, I am an R-N

insert AIR ONLY in order : NPH first, then Regular (not-retired)
once air is inside on both vials, proceed to draw from pressurized vials
Draw in order R-N: Regular first, NPH last
Alternative way of remembering: Cloudy to clear, clear to cloudy (air then draw)


Subcutaneous injection (most common) - rotate sites regularly (abdomen, upper arms, thighs, or buttocks)
Insulin pump (continuous infusion)
Rotation of injection sites (avoid lipodystrophy)
Check blood sugar levels before administration (to adjust dose accordingly).
Vials vs. pens (insulin pens are easier for patients and caregivers to use).
Correct storage (refrigerate unused insulin, do not freeze).


Blood glucose monitoring before meals and at bedtime (typically 4 times a day, but can vary).
A1C levels (target: <7% for most patients).
Signs of hypoglycemia (shakiness, sweating, confusion, dizziness, headache).
Signs of hyperglycemia (increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, blurred vision).
Monitor for signs of insulin resistance (requiring dose adjustment).


Mild hypoglycemia (BG <70 mg/dL): Consume 15-20g of quick-acting carbohydrate (e.g., 4 oz fruit juice, 3–4 glucose tablets).
Severe hypoglycemia: Administer glucagon (IM) or 25–50mL of D50 (IV) if unconscious or unable to ingest oral glucose.
Recheck BG after 15 minutes and repeat treatment if needed.


Signs of hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia and how to respond to each.
Insulin self-administration technique (rotation of injection sites, proper needle disposal).
Dietary management (counting carbs, meal timing).
Exercise considerations (adjusting insulin doses based on activity levels).
Stress management (stress can raise blood sugar).
Glucagon use (for patients at risk of severe hypoglycemia).
Importance of regular follow-up (A1C checks, eye exams, kidney function).


Adjust insulin doses based on current blood glucose levels, meal plans, and physical activity.
Ensure proper patient education on the correct insulin use, lifestyle changes, and recognizing symptoms of hypo/hyperglycemia.
Monitor for complications such as infection at injection sites or delayed wound healing.
Assist with managing insulin pumps (ensure proper site placement, troubleshoot equipment).
Coordinate care with dietitians and endocrinologists for individualized care plans.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: SGLT2 Inhibitors
item.description:
Sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitors are oral antidiabetic agents that lower blood glucose by increasing urinary glucose excretion.
Prototype: Canagliflozin (Invokana)


Inhibit SGLT2 in the proximal renal tubules, preventing glucose reabsorption.
Increase glucose excretion in urine (glycosuria), lowering blood glucose.
Induce osmotic diuresis, leading to mild BP reduction and weight loss.


Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) (as monotherapy or adjunct).
Heart failure (HFrEF & HFpEF) (reduces hospitalizations & mortality).
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) (slows progression and reduces cardiovascular risk).


Severe renal impairment (eGFR <30 mL/min/1.73m² for most drugs).
Type 1 diabetes (increased risk of diabetic ketoacidosis).
Recurrent UTIs or genital infections (due to glycosuria).
Pregnancy & breastfeeding (insufficient safety data).


Genitourinary infections (UTIs, fungal infections).
Dehydration & hypotension (from osmotic diuresis).
Euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) (rare but serious).
Lower limb amputation risk (seen with canagliflozin).
Acute kidney injury (especially in volume-depleted patients).


Monitor renal function (assess eGFR before starting).
Educate on hydration (prevent dehydration & hypotension).
Assess for signs of infection (UTIs, genital infections).
Monitor for ketoacidosis (even if blood glucose is normal).
Caution in elderly & hypotensive patients (risk of falls from volume loss).
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: 5-Alpha Reductase Inhibitors
item.description:
Finasteride (Proscar)
Dutasteride (Avodart)


Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) → reduces prostate size, improves urinary flow
Androgenic alopecia (male pattern baldness)


Inhibits 5-alpha reductase enzyme → prevents conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT)
Decreases prostate size by reducing DHT levels
Slows disease progression but takes months for full effect


Pregnancy (Category X) → teratogenic, can cause fetal male genital abnormalities
Women of childbearing age should avoid handling crushed or broken tablets
Hypersensitivity to drug components
Caution in liver impairment


Decreased libido, erectile dysfunction
Gynecomastia (breast enlargement, tenderness)
Orthostatic hypotension
Ejaculatory dysfunction
Depression, mood changes


Assess urinary function and symptom improvement (may take 3–6 months)
Monitor PSA levels (drug decreases PSA; continued elevation may indicate prostate cancer)
Educate patients about sexual dysfunction risk
Warn pregnant women to avoid handling medication
Encourage regular follow-ups to assess response and screen for complications
Teach patients to rise slowly from sitting/lying positions due to hypotension risk
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: 5-ASA
item.description:
Anti-inflammatory medication used to treat inflammatory bowel diseases like ulcerative colitis and Crohn's by reducing gut inflammation. Common brands include Asacol, Pentasa, and Rowasa.
Mechanism of Action
Inhibits the production of inflammatory chemicals (like prostaglandins) in the gut, reducing inflammation and symptoms in conditions like ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s disease.
Contraindications

Hypersensitivity to salicylates (e.g., aspirin)
Active gastrointestinal bleeding or severe liver/kidney disease
Caution in pregnancy (especially in the first trimester) and breastfeeding.
Nursing Considerations

Monitor for adverse effects like nausea, headache, and rash
Assess renal function (BUN, creatinine) and liver enzymes regularly
Encourage adequate fluid intake to avoid kidney complications
Educate on taking with food to reduce GI upset
Instruct patient to report signs of bleeding (e.g., dark stools, bruising)
Ensure regular follow-ups to monitor treatment efficacy and side effects
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: PPI and H2 Blockers
item.description:
Block enzyme responsible for HCL secretion in stomach
Reduce acid secretion better than H2 antagonist
#1 choice for PUD and GERD
Needs 3-5 days for therapeutic effects
Activated by food intake - should be taken 20 to 30 minutes before the first major meal of the day
omeprazole (Prilosec)
Use - or the short-term, 4- to 8-week therapy of active peptic ulcers and GERD, ZES
Adverse Effects

Common: headache, nausea, diarrhea, and abdominal pain
Rare: blood disorders may occur, causing unusual fatigue and weakness
Nursing Considerations

administer before breakfast on an empty stomach
Can be taken with antacids
2 months max only
Increases CNS depressants


responsible for increasing acid secretion in stomach
Famotidine
Do not give antacids
Do not smoke
Need regular CBC - reduces RBC and WBC
Needs 4-8 weeks for ulcers to heal


Action: Inhibits gastric acid secretion and increases mucous production in the stomach to protect the organ
Therapeutic Effects: Prevents the development of PUD due to NSAIDs
Adverse Effects: Headache, abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, nausea, vomiting, and miscarriage—contraindicated in the event of pregnancy or hypersensitivity to prostaglandins
Client Teaching: Do not share medication with others. Take medication as prescribed. Female clients of childbearing age should be informed that the medication will cause a spontaneous abortion. If they should become pregnant, they must stop the medication immediately and notify their health care provider.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: DMARDs
item.description:
Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs) slow disease progression in autoimmune conditions
Reduce inflammation, prevent joint and tissue damage
Classified into conventional synthetic (csDMARDs), biologic (bDMARDs), and targeted synthetic (tsDMARDs)


Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
Psoriatic arthritis (PsA)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
Ankylosing spondylitis
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) (e.g., Crohn’s, ulcerative colitis)


Suppress immune system to reduce inflammatory response
csDMARDs: inhibit cell replication, alter immune pathways (e.g., methotrexate inhibits folate metabolism) => RA, some cancers, dissolve ectopic pregnancies
bDMARDs: target specific immune mediators (e.g., TNF inhibitors block tumor necrosis factor)
tsDMARDs: inhibit intracellular signaling pathways (e.g., Janus kinase inhibitors)


Methotrexate (csDMARD)
Adalimumab (TNF inhibitor, bDMARD)
Tofacitinib (JAK inhibitor, tsDMARD)


Immunosuppression increases infection risk
Hepatotoxicity, nephrotoxicity (methotrexate)
Bone marrow suppression (anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia) => monitor CBC
GI upset, nausea, diarrhea
Pulmonary fibrosis (methotrexate)
Injection site reactions (biologics)


Active infections (TB, hepatitis, sepsis)
Pregnancy (methotrexate is teratogenic)
Severe liver or kidney disease
Live vaccines while on biologics


Monitor infection: temp, fever
avoid live vaccines
limit visitors
avoid large crowds
no fresh flowers
no fresh fruits/veggies
visitor masks
cook food thoroughly
Educate on infection precautions


MTX: Very high risk for bleeding (d/t thrombocytopenia)
Monitor CBC, liver, and kidney function tests => due to risk of bone marrow suppression
Screen for TB, hepatitis before biologic therapy
Folic acid supplementation with methotrexate to reduce toxicity
Assess for signs of bone marrow suppression (bruising, fatigue, infection)
Monitor respiratory function for methotrexate-induced lung toxicity
Rotate injection sites for biologics, monitor for hypersensitivity reactions
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Osmotic Diuretics
item.description:
Osmotic diuretics increase urine output by drawing water into renal tubules
Primarily used for conditions requiring rapid fluid reduction
Do not significantly affect electrolyte balance compared to other diuretics


Increased intracranial pressure (ICP)
Increased intraocular pressure (IOP) (e.g., glaucoma)
Acute renal failure (to prevent tubular necrosis)
Drug toxicity (enhances renal excretion)


Increases plasma osmolality, pulling water from tissues into bloodstream
Freely filtered in glomerulus, not reabsorbed, increasing urine volume
Reduces cerebral edema and intraocular pressure by shifting fluid


Mannitol (most commonly used osmotic diuretic)


Fluid and electrolyte imbalances
Dehydration, hypotension
Pulmonary edema (fluid shift into vasculature)
Headache, nausea, vomiting


Active intracranial hemorrhage (risk of worsening bleeding)
Severe dehydration or hypovolemia
Pulmonary edema or heart failure
Anuria (ineffective if kidneys cannot produce urine)
Hypernatremia


Monitor fluid status, urine output, and electrolytes
Assess for signs of dehydration (dry mucous membranes, hypotension)
Use filter when administering mannitol (crystallization risk)
Monitor neurological status in ICP patients
Avoid use in heart failure due to risk of pulmonary edema
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Methylergonovine
item.description:
Indications
Prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage caused by uterine atony or subinvolution
Control of uterine bleeding after delivery or abortion
part of Post-Partum Hemorrhage Meds
Contraindications
Hypertension or preeclampsia/eclampsia
Severe liver or kidney disease
Known hypersensitivity to ergot alkaloids
Pregnancy (except during delivery/postpartum)
Coronary artery disease, peripheral vascular disease
Nursing Considerations
Monitor blood pressure closely; risk of severe hypertension
Assess uterine tone and vaginal bleeding before and after administration
Administer intramuscularly (IM); avoid IV due to risk of hypertensive crisis
Educate patient on possible side effects: headache, nausea, vomiting, chest pain
Have emergency hypertensive treatment ready if needed
Do not administer if patient has elevated blood pressure or pre-existing cardiovascular disease
Document response to drug and uterine firmness
Side Effects
Hypertension (most serious)
Headache
Nausea, vomiting
Dizziness
Chest pain, palpitations
Adverse Effects
Severe hypertensive crisis
Myocardial infarction or stroke (rare but serious)
Uterine cramping causing pain or ischemia
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Misopristol
item.description:
synthetic prostaglandin E1 analog
used for GI and OB indications
promotes gastric mucosa protection
induces uterine contractions - cervical ripening
more indicated for inducing labor than Oxytocin


prevention of NSAID-induced gastric ulcers
induction of labor
medical termination of pregnancy (with mifepristone)
postpartum hemorrhage treatment


binds prostaglandin receptors in stomach and uterus
decreases gastric acid secretion
increases bicarbonate and mucus secretion
stimulates uterine smooth muscle contractions


pregnancy (if used for ulcer prevention)
hypersensitivity to prostaglandins
prior uterine surgery or C-section (for labor induction)
cardiovascular disease (relative, caution advised)


abdominal cramps
diarrhea
nausea
flatulence
headache


uterine rupture (especially with prior uterine surgery)
severe bleeding or incomplete abortion
hypotension
allergic reactions


confirm pregnancy status before use for ulcers
educate patient on expected effects if used for induction
monitor uterine activity and fetal heart rate if used in OB
assess GI symptoms and hydration status
instruct patient to take with food to reduce GI upset


category X for pregnancy (unless used intentionally for OB purposes)
use effective contraception during treatment for ulcers
black box warning: not for pregnancy use unless indicated
must be administered with careful monitoring in obstetric use
educate patient on complete medication regimen if used for abortion
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Post-Partum Hemorrhage Meds
item.description:
MCTOM
Methergine
Carboprost Tromethamine
TXA
Oxytocin
Misoprostol


Indications: Prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) caused by uterine atony or subinvolution.
Mechanism of Action: Directly stimulates smooth muscle of the uterus, causing rapid, sustained tetanic uterine contraction; also constricts peripheral and coronary blood vessels.
Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to methergine, hypertension (pre-eclampsia, eclampsia, chronic hypertension), cardiac disease, peripheral vascular disease, hepatic or renal impairment, sepsis, threatened spontaneous abortion (before delivery of placenta), induction of labor.
Expected Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain/cramping, dizziness, headache, diaphoresis.
Adverse Effects: Severe hypertension (potentially leading to cerebral hemorrhage), seizures, palpitations, chest pain, myocardial infarction, dyspnea, pulmonary edema, stroke, allergic reactions (rash, anaphylaxis), ergotism (rare, with prolonged use or overdose: peripheral vasospasm, cyanosis, cold extremities).
Nursing Considerations: Assess blood pressure frequently (every 15 minutes or more often as indicated) during administration and for several hours afterward; monitor uterine tone, vaginal bleeding, and fundal height; administer IV slowly over at least 60 seconds (rapid IV push can cause severe hypertension and cerebrovascular accident); monitor for signs of ergotism; educate patient about potential side effects and to report any severe headache, chest pain, or vision changes; typically given IM; IV is reserved for emergent situations due to risk of severe hypertension.
Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: 140/90 BP or greater; signs of severe hypertension or neurological symptoms (e.g., severe headache, visual disturbances, seizures); chest pain or signs of myocardial ischemia.


Indications: Treatment of postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony that is unresponsive to other oxytocic agents; used in pregnancy termination.
Mechanism of Action: Potent prostaglandin F2-alpha analog; directly stimulates sustained contraction of uterine smooth muscle; also causes contraction of bronchial and vascular smooth muscle.
Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to carboprost or prostaglandins, acute pelvic inflammatory disease, active cardiac, pulmonary, renal, or hepatic disease, asthma (absolute contraindication due to bronchoconstriction); caution with hypertension, hypotension, anemia, jaundice, diabetes, epilepsy, previous uterine surgery (e.g., C-section).
Expected Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (very common due to smooth muscle stimulation), fever, chills, flushing, headache, tachycardia.
Adverse Effects: Bronchospasm, wheezing, dyspnea, hypertension or hypotension, pulmonary edema, Uterine Rupture (rare, especially with overuse or in grand multiparas), uterine hypertonus, tetanic contractions, arrhythmias, DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation, rare).
Nursing Considerations: Administer deep IM only; avoid IV administration; rotate injection sites if multiple doses are needed; monitor uterine tone, vaginal bleeding, and vital signs (BP, pulse, respirations, temperature) frequently; have antiemetics and antidiarrheals readily available and consider pre-medication; auscultate lung sounds for signs of bronchospasm; assess for fever, which is a common but usually transient side effect; educate patient about common GI side effects.
Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: Severe bronchospasm or respiratory distress; sustained severe hypertension or hypotension refractory to treatment; signs of uterine rupture.


Indications: Treatment of postpartum hemorrhage when conservative management is insufficient; reduces blood loss in various surgical procedures and trauma.
Mechanism of Action: Antifibrinolytic agent; reversibly binds to plasminogen and plasmin, preventing fibrinolysis (breakdown of blood clots); stabilizes existing clots.
Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to TXA, active intravascular clotting (e.g., DIC, unless primary fibrinolysis is predominant), history of thrombosis (DVT, PE, stroke, MI), unless benefits clearly outweigh risks, severe renal impairment (dose adjustment needed), history of seizures (may increase seizure risk), color vision impairment (can mask retinal toxicity).
Expected Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, headache, hypotension (if administered too rapidly IV), abdominal pain.
Adverse Effects: Thromboembolic events (DVT, PE, stroke, MI) – although studies suggest low risk in PPH; seizures (especially with rapid IV administration or high doses); visual disturbances, impaired color vision; allergic reactions; renal cortical necrosis (rare, with prolonged use/high doses).
Nursing Considerations: Administer intravenously slowly over 10 minutes to prevent hypotension; monitor for signs of thrombosis (e.g., leg pain, swelling, chest pain, shortness of breath, neurological changes); assess for any changes in vision or color perception; monitor vital signs, uterine tone, and blood loss; ensure proper hydration; typically given within 3 hours of birth for PPH benefit.
Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: Signs of active thrombosis (e.g., new onset chest pain, dyspnea, calf pain, neurological deficits); severe allergic reaction; new onset or worsening seizures; significant visual changes.


Indications: Prevention and treatment of postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony; induction and augmentation of labor; to promote milk let-down (nasal spray, rare).
Mechanism of Action: Synthetic polypeptide hormone structurally identical to natural oxytocin; acts on oxytocin receptors in the uterus, causing rhythmic contractions of uterine smooth muscle; increases the frequency and intensity of contractions; also has antidiuretic effects at high doses.
Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to oxytocin, cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD), unfavorable fetal position or presentation, significant placenta previa or vasa previa, umbilical cord prolapse, uterine hypertonicity or fetal distress when delivery is not imminent, severe toxemia, active genital herpes, undelivered placenta (before delivery of placenta in PPH management, it's typically given after delivery).
Expected Side Effects: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain/cramping, headache, flushing.
Adverse Effects: Maternal: Uterine hyperstimulation/tetany (leading to uterine rupture, placental abruption, fetal distress), water intoxication (hyponatremia, cerebral edema, seizures, coma) with high doses and large volumes of hypotonic fluids, hypotension or hypertension (less common), arrhythmias, postpartum hemorrhage (paradoxical, if receptors are saturated or overstimulated), allergic reactions; Fetal: Fetal distress (due to uterine hyperstimulation), bradycardia, hypoxia, acidosis.
Nursing Considerations: Administer as a dilute IV infusion via a pump, typically as a piggyback into a main IV line; never administer undiluted IV push in PPH management (can cause severe hypotension or cardiac arrhythmias); monitor uterine activity (frequency, duration, intensity of contractions), uterine resting tone, and vaginal bleeding; monitor vital signs (BP, pulse) frequently; assess intake and output to monitor for water intoxication; assess for signs of uterine hyperstimulation (contractions lasting >90 seconds, less than 2 minutes apart, or resting tone >20 mmHg); have tocolytics (e.g., terbutaline) available to relax the uterus in case of hyperstimulation.
Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: Signs of uterine hyperstimulation (contractions too frequent, too long, or resting tone too high); signs of fetal distress (if used antepartum); signs of water intoxication (e.g., hyponatremia, decreased urine output, confusion, seizures); significant maternal hypotension or arrhythmia.


Indications: Treatment of postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony; cervical ripening and labor induction; abortion (medical); prevention of NSAID-induced gastric ulcers.
Mechanism of Action: Synthetic prostaglandin E1 analog; causes strong uterine contractions; also causes cervical softening and dilation.
Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to misoprostol or other prostaglandins, known allergy to other prostaglandins; in the context of PPH, generally few absolute contraindications once the baby and placenta are delivered, as it's a critical situation; however, caution in patients with glaucoma, asthma (less of a concern than carboprost but still a prostaglandin), or severe cardiovascular disease; active gastrointestinal disease (if given orally for ulcer prevention).
Expected Side Effects: Shivering, chills, fever (very common), nausea, vomiting, diarrhea (common), abdominal pain/cramping, headache.
Adverse Effects: Uterine hyperstimulation/tetany (leading to uterine rupture, especially with high doses or in cases of previous uterine surgery), hypotension or hypertension, bradycardia or tachycardia, allergic reactions, bronchospasm (less common than with carboprost), DIC (rare).
Nursing Considerations: Can be administered orally, sublingually, rectally, or vaginally for PPH; rectal administration is often preferred in emergent PPH due to rapid absorption and less GI side effects; monitor uterine tone, vaginal bleeding, and vital signs (BP, pulse, temperature) frequently; anticipate and manage shivering/chills with warm blankets; provide comfort measures for nausea and vomiting; educate patient about common side effects; ensure accurate dosage and route of administration.
Specific Parameters to Discontinue Med: Sustained uterine hypertonus not responding to other measures; signs of uterine rupture; severe allergic reaction.
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Abortion Medications
item.description:
Indication: Medical abortion, cervical ripening, postpartum hemorrhage
Mechanism: Prostaglandin E1 analog — stimulates uterine contractions and cervical softening
Nursing Implications:
Monitor for uterine cramping and bleeding
Assess for complete expulsion in medical abortion
Educate on expected side effects (e.g., chills, fever, diarrhea, N/V, dyspepsia)
Monitor for signs and symptoms of shock, such as tachycardia, hypotension, and anxiety.


Indication: Medical abortion (often combined with misoprostol)
Mechanism: Progesterone receptor antagonist — blocks progesterone, leading to decidual breakdown and detachment of pregnancy
Nursing Implications:
Monitor for headache, vomiting, diarrhea, and heavy bleeding.
Anticipate administration of antiemetic prior to use to reduce nausea and vomiting.
Encourage client to use acetaminophen to reduce discomfort from cramping.


Indication: Cervical ripening and labor induction
Mechanism: Prostaglandin E2 analog — promotes cervical softening and stimulates uterine contractions
Administration: gel form, warm it first, sterile technique, lie supine for 30 minutes
Nursing Implications:
Monitor fetal heart rate and uterine activity continuously
Remove insert if uterine tachysystole occurs
Educate on potential side effects (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea)
Sterile technique, supine position for 30 minutes after admin


Indication: Prevention of Rh alloimmunization in Rh-negative mothers
Mechanism: Passive immunization — binds Rh-positive fetal cells in maternal circulation to prevent immune response
Nursing Implications:
Confirm mother’s Rh-negative status and absence of sensitization
Administer at 28 weeks and within 72 hours postpartum (or after procedures like amniocentesis)
Educate mother on purpose and timing of administration
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Betamethasone
item.description:
Corticosteroid used to accelerate fetal lung maturity
Commonly used glucocorticoid for antenatal corticosteroid therapy
Indications
Pregnant women at risk for preterm delivery between 24–34 weeks gestation
May be considered between 22–23+6 weeks or 34–36+6 weeks in select cases
Dosage
12 mg IM every 24 hrs × 2 doses
Mechanism of Action
Stimulates surfactant production in fetal lungs
Reduces risk of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), and neonatal death
Benefits
Decreases incidence/severity of RDS
Lowers risk of neonatal complications
Promotes lung and brain maturity
Side Effects
Maternal: hyperglycemia, immunosuppression, fluid retention
Fetal: transient decrease in fetal movement and HR variability
Nursing Interventions
Administer IM in ventrogluteal or vastus lateralis
Monitor maternal blood glucose (especially in diabetics)
Educate patient on purpose and benefits
Assess fetal heart rate and movement
Watch for infection due to immunosuppressive effects
Contraindications
Systemic infection (relative)
Caution in poorly controlled diabetes
Timing
Ideally given at least 24 hours before birth
Full benefit seen if delivery occurs at least 48 hrs after first dose
Effects last ~7 days
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Hydralazine
item.description:
Direct-acting vasodilator used primarily for hypertension and heart failure; often given IV or PO; rapid onset especially with IV form

Severe hypertension including hypertensive emergency
Heart failure (especially in combination with nitrates)
Pregnancy-induced hypertension or preeclampsia (off-label)

Directly relaxes arteriolar smooth muscle → ↓ systemic vascular resistance (afterload) → ↓ blood pressure; triggers reflex sympathetic activation (↑ HR, ↑ renin)

Coronary artery disease
Mitral valve rheumatic heart disease
Hypersensitivity
Caution in cerebrovascular disease or hypotension

Monitor BP closely, especially after IV administration
Watch for reflex tachycardia or hypotension
Assess for fluid retention or edema
May cause lupus-like syndrome with long-term use
Often combined with beta-blockers to blunt reflex tachycardia
Educate patient on signs of hypotension (dizziness, lightheadedness)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Miperidine
item.description:
Opioid analgesic
Acts on CNS opioid receptors to alter pain perception and response
Class: Schedule II controlled substance


Moderate to severe pain in L&D
Analgesia during labor when epidural not used or contraindicated
May be used adjunctively in postpartum for severe uterine cramping
Rare use in PPH pain management (not first-line)


Binds to mu-opioid receptors in CNS
Inhibits ascending pain pathways
Produces analgesia, sedation, and respiratory depression
Onset: 10–15 min IM/SC, 5 min IV
Peak: 30–60 min
Duration: 2–4 hrs


MAOI use within 14 days (risk of serotonin syndrome)
Severe respiratory depression
Laboring patients if birth expected within 1–4 hrs (risk of neonatal CNS/respiratory depression)
Hypersensitivity


Maternal: sedation, dizziness, hypotension, N/V, respiratory depression
Neonatal: decreased variability, CNS depression, delayed respiration if given near delivery
May cause tachycardia (metabolite normeperidine can be neurotoxic with repeated dosing)


Assess pain, VS, FHR before/after admin
Monitor for sedation, hypotension, respiratory depression
Use cautiously if delivery imminent
Keep naloxone (Narcan) on hand for newborn or maternal reversal
Avoid repeated dosing — risk of normeperidine accumulation and seizures
Crosses placenta — can depress neonatal respiration, especially if administered 1–4 hrs before birth


IM: 50–100 mg q3–4h PRN
IV: 25–50 mg slow push over ≥5 min
Onset is rapid IV, but duration is short — not ideal for prolonged labor pain


May cause drowsiness — avoid standing or walking unassisted
Avoid other CNS depressants (alcohol, sedatives)
Report decreased fetal movement or unusual sedation
Medication will reduce pain but may not eliminate it fully
Inform that it may affect baby temporarily after birth (esp. if given close to delivery)
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Oxytocin
item.description:
aka Pitocin
Synthetic hormone identical to endogenous oxytocin
stimulates uterine smooth muscle contractions
does not cross placenta

For Induction: 0.5-1 mUnit/min IV, titrate 1-2 mUnit/min q15-60min until contraction pattern reached that is similiar to normal labor


Labor induction or augmentation
Management of postpartum hemorrhage
Incomplete or inevitable miscarriage (to aid uterine evacuation)

Binds to oxytocin receptors in uterine smooth muscle → increases intracellular calcium → promotes rhythmic uterine contractions; also promotes milk let-down reflex via myoepithelial contraction in breasts


Fetal distress without imminent delivery
Unfavorable fetal position (e.g., transverse lie)
Previous uterine surgery (e.g., classical C-section or extensive myomectomy)
Placenta previa or vasa previa
Active genital herpes
Hypertonic uterine patterns or hypersensitivity


Mild hypotension
Flushing
Headache
Nausea and vomiting
Abdominal cramping
Uterine hypertonicity or tachysystole
Pelvic discomfort or pain
Water retention or hyponatremia (due to antidiuretic properties)
Restlessness or anxiety
Drowsiness or confusion (in cases of water intoxication)


Uterine Tachysystole: >5 contractions in 10 minutes, may reduce fetal oxygenation
Uterine Hypertonicity: Sustained contractions or inadequate uterine relaxation, increases risk of fetal distress
Fetal Distress: Late decelerations, bradycardia, or decreased variability due to reduced placental perfusion
Uterine Rupture: Especially in patients with prior uterine surgery or high-dose/prolonged use
Postpartum Hemorrhage: From uterine atony following prolonged stimulation
Water Intoxication/Hyponatremia: Rare but serious, due to oxytocin’s antidiuretic effect
Hypotension: Especially with rapid IV bolus
Nausea/Vomiting: Mild but possible GI effects
Anaphylaxis or hypersensitivity: Rare, but must be monitored
High vigilance and titrated dosing are essential to minimize these risks.


Continuous fetal and contraction monitoring (risk of uterine tachysystole or fetal distress)
Monitor for uterine hyperstimulation (>5 contractions in 10 min or contractions lasting >90 sec)
Assess I&O due to risk of water intoxication (oxytocin has antidiuretic effect)
Titrate infusion per protocol (commonly in milliunits/min)
Stop infusion and notify provider if fetal decelerations or uterine hypertonicity occur
Monitor BP, HR, and uterine tone postpartum
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Rhogam
item.description:
RhoGAM is an injection of Rh immunoglobulin given to prevent Rh-negative individuals from developing antibodies against Rh-positive blood cells.


Rh-negative pregnant women with potential exposure to Rh-positive fetal blood
After miscarriage, abortion, ectopic pregnancy, or trauma
Postpartum if baby is Rh-positive
After procedures like amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling

RhoGAM contains anti-D antibodies that destroy any fetal Rh-positive red blood cells in the mother's bloodstream before her immune system can react and form permanent antibodies.


Rh-positive individuals
Already sensitized (positive indirect Coombs test)
Allergy to human immunoglobulin or components of the product


Confirm mother is Rh-negative and not already sensitized
Administer IM, usually at 28 weeks and within 72 hours postpartum
Monitor for allergic reactions
Verify correct timing and dose based on event (e.g., delivery, trauma)


Explain purpose is to protect future pregnancies
RhoGAM does not harm the current baby
Report signs of allergic reaction (e.g., rash, difficulty breathing)
Importance of receiving RhoGAM after each potential Rh exposure
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Terbutraline
item.description:
beta-2 adrenergic agonist
used off-label as a tocolytic
short-term uterine relaxant
not a first-line agent due to maternal side effects


short-term tocolysis to delay preterm labor (usually <48–72 hrs)
emergency management of uterine tachysystole with fetal distress
bronchodilator (original FDA indication)


stimulates beta-2 receptors in uterine smooth muscle
causes uterine relaxation
decreases frequency and intensity of contractions
also relaxes bronchial smooth muscle


maternal heart disease
poorly controlled hyperthyroidism or diabetes
significant hemorrhage
intrauterine infection
gestational age >34 weeks (tocolysis no longer recommended)


palpitations
tremors
nervousness
nausea
headache
hyperglycemia


tachycardia (maternal and fetal)
arrhythmias
hypotension
pulmonary edema => dyspnea
myocardial ischemia
hypokalemia => ATI question


monitor maternal HR, BP, glucose, and respiratory status
hold dose if maternal HR >120 bpm or chest pain occurs
assess fetal heart rate and uterine activity continuously
monitor for signs of pulmonary edema: dyspnea, crackles, hypoxia
ensure IV access and emergency equipment available
typically administered subQ or IV in L&D


FDA black box warning: not for prolonged tocolysis (>48–72 hrs)
use lowest effective dose for shortest time
caution with concurrent corticosteroid use (↑ risk of pulmonary edema)
educate patient about side effects (especially palpitations, jitteriness)
requires close monitoring; high-risk medication in OB
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Tocolytics - MINT
item.description:
Medications used to suppress preterm labor by inhibiting uterine contractions; typically used short-term (up to 48 hours) to allow for fetal lung maturity interventions (e.g., corticosteroids)
MINT
Mag Sulfate
Indomethacin
Nifedipine
Terbutraline


Preterm labor before 34 weeks gestation with no contraindications to prolonging pregnancy
To facilitate maternal transfer or corticosteroid administration
Sometimes used during procedures (e.g., external cephalic version)

Varies by drug class:

Beta-agonists (e.g., terbutaline): relax uterine smooth muscle via β2 stimulation
Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine): reduce calcium influx in smooth muscle
NSAIDs (e.g., indomethacin): inhibit prostaglandin synthesis
Magnesium sulfate: decreases uterine muscle contractility (less common as first-line)

Maternal: severe preeclampsia, hemorrhage, cardiac disease, infection
Fetal: intrauterine fetal demise, lethal anomaly, non-reassuring fetal status, gestational age >34 weeks

Maternal Hypotension: SBP <90 mmHg or symptomatic hypotension (especially for nifedipine)
Maternal Tachycardia: HR >120–130 bpm (common with beta-agonists like terbutaline)
Maternal Respiratory Depression: RR <12/min or signs of distress (critical for magnesium sulfate use)
Fever: Maternal temp >38°C (100.4°F), suggestive of chorioamnionitis
Oxygen Saturation: SpO₂ <95% or signs of hypoxia
Fetal Distress: Non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns (e.g., persistent late decelerations)
Uterine Findings: Uterine infection, abruption, or evidence of fetal compromise
Additional labs or findings to monitor:

Elevated WBC + uterine tenderness: Suggestive of infection
Abnormal LFTs or platelets: Especially relevant in severe preeclampsia/HELLP
Signs of cardiac instability: Especially with beta-agonists or underlying maternal heart disease


Monitor maternal VS (especially HR, BP, respiratory status)
Assess fetal status via continuous monitoring
Watch for side effects (e.g., tachycardia with terbutaline, hypotension with nifedipine, GI issues with indomethacin)
Educate patient on signs of labor and medication side effects
Ensure corticosteroids are administered if under 34 weeks
Monitor fluid balance, especially with magnesium sulfate
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Anesthetics
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing

Local Anesthetics - loss of sensation to a relatively small part of the body for a brief medical or dental procedure.
Esters
Benzocaine, Procaine (Novocain)
Adverse: CNS depression, burning, stinging, redness
Amidies
Articaine, lidocaine
Adverse: burning, stinging, redness at site
General Anesthetics
IV
Propofol (Diprivan)
MOA - N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor agonist
Primary Actions
Most widely used IV anesthetics due to efficacy and safety profile
indicated for the induction and maintenance of general anesthesia
immediate onset of action and is used effectively for conscious sedation
Emergence is rapid and few adverse effects occur during recovery.
Has an antiemetic effect that can prevent nausea and vomiting.
Alerts
faster onset and deeper sedation compared to benzo
not showed evidence of fetal harm
Adverse effects on breastmilk => neonate
Adverse
Pain, apnea, resp depression, hypOtension
collection of metabolic abnormalities and organ system failures, aka, propofol infusion syndrome (PIF)
severe metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, lipidemia, rhabdomyolysis, hepatomegaly, and cardiac failure.
Inhaled
Therapeutic Gasses
Nitrous Oxide
Primary Actions
analgesia caused by suppression of pain mechanisms in the CNS
low potency and does not produce complete loss of consciousness or profound relaxation of skeletal muscle
commonly combined with other surgical anesthetic agents.
Ideal for short surgical or dental procedures because the patient remains conscious and can follow instructions while experiencing full analgesia.
always combined with oxygen (25 to 30%) and is administered in a semi closed method through a tube or by mask.
Alerts
Does NOT cause fetal harm
Adverse
Few adverse in low dose
At higher doses, stage 2 anesthesia such as anxiety, excitement, and combativeness
Lower dose will reverse
difficulty breathing or experience nausea and vomiting following the procedure
Contra
impaired consciousness, head injury, non-compliance, decompression sickness, nitrogen narcosis, air embolism, undiagnosed abdominal pain, bowel obstruction, hypotension, shock, COPD, cyanosis, pneumothorax, or air transport.
Use nitrous oxide cautiously in myasthenia gravis due to respiratory depression and prolonged effects. Monitor cardiovascular patients, especially with elevated ICP, for prolonged or potentiated hypnotic effects
Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a chronic autoimmune disorder in which antibodies destroy the communication between nerves and muscle, resulting in weakness of the skeletal muscles. Myasthenia gravis affects the voluntary muscles of the body, especially those that control the eyes, mouth, throat and limbs.
Volatile Liquids
Isoflurane (Forane)
MOA - produces a potent level of surgical anesthesia that is rapid in onset
Primary Actions
Provides smooth induction with a low degree of metabolism by the body
excellent muscle relaxation and may be used off-label as adjuvant therapy in the treatment of status asthmaticus
Isoflurane with oxygen or with an oxygen and nitrous oxide mixture may be used
does not sensitize the myocardium for dysrhythmias, and it produces fewer cardiovascular effects than other general anesthetics.
Alerts
Do not use in pregnant
Adverse
Mild nausea, vomiting, and tremor
dose-dependent respiratory depression and a reduction in blood pressure.
Malignant hyperthermia with elevated temperature has been reported.
Contraindications
Do not use for patients with genetic predisposition to malignant hyperthermia
Caution: patients with head trauma or brain neoplasms due to possible increases in intracranial pressure
Adjuncts to Anesthesia
Neuromuscular Blockers
Succinylcholine (Anectine, Quelicine)
Class
Skeletal muscle paralytic drug; neuromuscular blocker
Depolarizing blocker; acetylcholine receptor blocking drug
Actions
Like acetylcholine, succinylcholine acts on cholinergic receptor sites at neuromuscular junctions
Effects are first noted as muscle weakness and muscle spasms, eventually, paralysis
rapidly broken down by the enzyme cholinesterase;
when the IV infusion is stopped, the duration of action is only a few minutes
reduces the amount of general anesthetic needed for procedures.
Alerts
Do not administer in pregnant
Adverse
can cause complete paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles
Bradycardia and respiratory depression
High doses: tachycardia, hypotension, and urinary retention.
Contra
Do not use if u have malignant hyperthermia, pulmonary, kidney, cardiovascular, metabolic, or liver dysfunction.
Extreme Caution to - patients with severe burns or trauma, neuromuscular diseases, or glaucoma
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: ICU Meds
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Migraines
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing
Ch. 18.11 Drug Therapy for Migraines
Two major classes (both serotonin (5-HT) agonists:

Triptans - work by constricting intracranial vessels
Ergot Alkaloids
Algorithm for treating migraine:

Mild migraine - acetaminophen or NSAID. If ineffective, move to:
Triptans
Usually in oral form (may cause N/V), alternative forms are available
Intranasal or prefilled syringes also available
All triptans have similar effectiveness and side effects
If ineffective, move to:
Ergot Alkaloids
Ergotamine - inexpensive, available in oral, SL, suppository
Dihydroergotamine - nasal spray
Interact with adrenergic and dopaminergic receptors and serotonergic receptors => many side effects.
Some E.A can cause fetal harm and should not be used by women who may become pregnant!
Migraine Prophylaxis

Antiseizures - gabapentin, topiramate, valproic acid
Beta-adrenergic blockers - atenolol, metoprolol, propranolol, timolol
Calcium channel blockers - nifedipine, nimodipine, verapamil
Tricyclic antidepressants - amitriptyline, imipramine, protriptyline
Misc - riboflavin
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Respiratory Meds
item.description:
#pharmacology #nursing
#pharmacology #nursing
BAM-SLM


Prototype: Albuterol
Actions: activate the sympathetic nervous system, which relaxes bronchial smooth muscle
SABA that is used to relieve the bronchospasm of asthma
rapid onset and excellent safety profile = first-line drug for the termination of acute bronchospasm
facilitates mucus drainage and can inhibit the release of inflammatory chemicals from mast cells.
When inhaled 15 to 30 ­minutes prior to physical activity, it can prevent exercise-induced bronchospasm.
not recommended for asthma prophylaxis.
Administration Alerts: use only the actuator that comes with the canister. Observe and instruct the patient in proper use.
teratogenic in laboratory animals; however, human studies have not found increased birth defects or miscarriages. Effects on the breastfed neonate are not known.
Adverse Effects: palpitations, headaches, throat irritation, tremor, nervousness, restlessness, and tachycardia
Less common: dry mouth, insomnia, chest pain, allergic rxn
Contraindications: Hypersensitivity, Caution among patients with hx of cardiac disease, CAD, HTN

Prototype: Ipratropium
Actions:

block parasympathetic response
relieve and prevent the bronchospasm that is characteristic of COPD
Combined with albuterol as first-line drug for bronchospasm from COPD
it is prescribed off-label for the disorder for asthma
Alternative to SABA
Administration: MDI use, Wait 2-3 min between dosages
Adverse:

No evidence of fetal harm
Little absorbed by lungs = few systemic changes
Irritation of URI due to drying of nasal mucosa
Bitter taste
May cause epistaxis (nasal)
Contraindications: Hypersensitivity to soy or related to soy or peanut

Class of bronchodilators used to manage asthma and COPD, commonly includes theophylline and aminophylline
Relaxes smooth muscles of the bronchial airways, reduces airway responsiveness to irritants
Used in chronic asthma management, sometimes in COPD, less commonly used due to narrow therapeutic window and side effects
Nausea, vomiting, insomnia, nervousness, tachycardia, arrhythmias, seizures in toxicity cases
Nursing Considerations (GPT)
Monitor serum drug levels to prevent toxicity
Assess for signs of toxicity such as nausea, restlessness, and arrhythmias
Educate clients to avoid caffeine, as it can increase drug effects
Ensure consistent administration to maintain therapeutic levels
Monitor cardiac status, especially in clients with cardiovascular conditions
Inform clients about the importance of regular blood tests to monitor drug levels
Caution when using in older adults due to increased sensitivity to side effects


Prototype: Beclomethasone
Actions
aerosol inhalation (Qvar) for asthma or as a nasal spray (Beconase AQ, Qnasl) for allergic rhinitis.
first-line drugs for the long-term management of persistent asthma in both children and adults.
3-4 weeks before optimal benefits are obtained.
reduce inflammation, thus decreasing the frequency of asthma attacks.
not used as a rescue inhaler
Adverse
if swallowed, observe for signs of corticosteroid toxicity.
Local effects may include hoarseness, dry mouth, and changes in taste.
Inhaled corticosteroid use has been associated with the development of cataracts in adults.
Long-term intranasal or inhaled corticosteroids may cause growth inhibition in children.
can mask signs of infection: do not use if infected
Oral thrush
Contraindications
Hypersensitivity
The growth of pediatric patients should be monitored carefully because inhaled corticosteroids may reduce growth velocity in some children.

second-line drugs, considered when other meds failed to manage chronic asthma
mediators of the immune response that are involved in allergic and asthmatic reactions
montelukast (Singulair)
Actions and Uses
prophylaxis of persistent, chronic asthma; exercise-induced bronchospasm; and allergic rhinitis.
prevents airway edema and inflammation by blocking leukotriene receptors in the airways.
Given PO and acts rapidly, although it is not recommended for termination of acute bronchospasm.
Only drug in this class that is approved for pediatric use.
Available in chewable tablets and as granules that are recommended by the manufacturer to be mixed with applesauce, mashed carrots, or ice cream.
Administration Alerts
Do not use it to terminate acute asthma attacks.
If preventing exercise-induced bronchospasm, take drug at least 2 hours before the activity.
This drug did not show fetal harm in laboratory animals. Effects on the breastfed neonate are not known.
Adverse Effects
few serious adverse effects
headache, N/D
neuropsychiatric events, SA, hallucinations, depression
Contraindications:
The only contraindication is hypersensitivity to the drug.
Patients with known aspirin sensitivity should avoid taking montelukast.
Caution: patients with liver/hepatic failure

second-line drugs, considered when other meds failed to manage chronic asthma
item.dc:creator: RPB

item.title: Triptans
item.description:
Class of drugs used to treat acute migraine attacks and cluster headaches
Not for preventive use; taken at migraine onset


Sumatriptan (Imitrex) – first and most common triptan
Others: Rizatriptan, Zolmitriptan, Eletriptan, Naratriptan, Almotriptan, Frovatriptan


Selective serotonin (5-HT1B/1D) receptor agonists
Causes vasoconstriction of cranial blood vessels
Reduces inflamation and inhibits pain pathways in the brain


Acute migraine attacks (with or without aura)
Cluster headaches


History of cardiovascular disease (MI, stroke, uncontrolled HTN)
Peripheral vascular disease
Hemiplegic or basilar migraines
Use of MAO inhibitors within the past 2 weeks
Severe hepatic or renal impairment


Chest tightness/pressure, palpitations
Hypertension
Dizziness, drowsiness
Paresthesia (tingling, numbness)
Serotonin syndrome (if combined with SSRIs, SNRIs)
Rebound headaches with overuse


Assess for cardiovascular history before administration
Monitor BP due to risk of hypertension
Educate on proper use: Take at migraine onset, not for daily use
Warn about chest tightness—common but usually not serious
Advise against combining with SSRIs, SNRIs, or other triptans within 24 hours
Limit use to 2 days per week to avoid medication-overuse headaches
